Authors: Sekar K., Lahiri K., Dey S.
Title: Dynamic Platform Management for Configurable Platform-Based System-on-Chips
Source title: IEEE/ACM International Conference on Computer-Aided Design, Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, UC San Diego, San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sekar, K., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, UC San Diego, San Diego, CA, United States; Lahiri, K., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, UC San Diego, San Diego, CA, United States; Dey, S., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, UC San Diego, San Diego, CA, United States
Abstract: General-purpose System-on-Chip platforms consisting of configurable components are emerging as an attractive alternative to traditional, customized solutions (e.g., ASICs, custom SoCs), owing to their flexibility, time-to-market advantage, and low engineering costs. However, the adoption of such platforms in many high-volume markets (e.g, wireless handhelds) is limited by concerns about their performance and energy-efficiency. This paper addresses the problem of enabling the use of configurable platforms in domains where custom approaches have traditionally been used. We introduce Dynamic Platform Management, a methodology for customizing a configurable general-purpose platform at run-time, to help bridge the performance and energy efficiency gap with custom approaches. The proposed technique uses a software layer that detects time-varying processing requirements imposed by a set of applications, and dynamically optimizes architectural parameters and platform components. Dynamic platform management enables superior application performance, more efficient utilization of platform resources, and improved energy efficiency, as compared to a statically optimized platform, without requiring any modifications to the underlying hardware. We illustrate dynamic platform management by applying it to the design of a dual-access UMTS/WLAN security processing system, implemented on a general-purpose configurable platform. Experiments demonstrate that, compared to a statically optimized design (on the same platform), the proposed techniques enable upto 33% improvements in security processing throughput, while achieving 59% savings in energy consumption (on average).
Index Keywords: Dynamic voltage scaling (DVC); System on a chip (SOc); Algorithms; Buffer storage; Computer software; Data storage equipment; Energy efficiency; Hand held computers; Marketing; Microprocessor chips; Optimization; Throughput; Application specific integrated circuits

Authors: Kim N.S., Blaauw D., Mudge T.
Title: Leakage Power Optimization Techniques for Ultra Deep Sub-Micron Multi-Level Caches
Source title: IEEE/ACM International Conference on Computer-Aided Design, Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Advanced Computer Architecture Lab, Department of Electrical Eng., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, N.S., Advanced Computer Architecture Lab, Department of Electrical Eng., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Blaauw, D., Advanced Computer Architecture Lab, Department of Electrical Eng., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Mudge, T., Advanced Computer Architecture Lab, Department of Electrical Eng., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Abstract: On-chip L1 and L2 caches represent a sizeable fraction of the total power consumption of microprocessors. In deep sub-micron technology, the subthreshold leakage power is becoming the dominant fraction of the total power consumption of those caches. In this paper, we present optimization techniques to reduce the leakage power of on-chip caches assuming that there are multiple threshold voltages, VTH's, available. First, we show a cache leakage optimization technique that examines the trade-off between access time and leakage power by assigning distinct VTH's to each of the four main cache components - address bus drivers, data bus drivers, decoders, and SRAM cell arrays with sense-amps. Second, we show optimization techniques to reduce the leakage power of L1 and L2 on-chip caches without affecting the average memory access time. The key results are: 1) 2 VTH's are enough to minimize leakage in a single cache; 2) if L1 size is fixed, increasing the L2 size can result in much lower leakage without reducing average memory access time; 3) if L2 size is fixed, reducing L1 size can result in lower leakage without loss of the average memory access time; and 4) smaller L1 and larger L2 caches than are typical in today's processors result in significant leakage and dynamic power reduction without affecting the average memory access time.
Index Keywords: Average memory access time (AMAT); Microarchitectural simulation; Benchmarking; CMOS integrated circuits; Computer simulation; Energy dissipation; Leakage currents; Microprocessor chips; Optimization; Performance; Process control; Static random access storage; Transistors; Cache memory

Authors: Pohm A.V.
Title: Nanotechnology and Magnetic Memories
Source title: Advanced Semiconductor and Organic Nano-Techniques
Affiliations: Iowa State University, Ames, IA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pohm, A.V., Iowa State University, Ames, IA, United States
Abstract: As dimensions of magnetic memory cells are reduced in size, fundamental limits come into play which must be considered. The first is that the energy well depth of the storage states needs to be large enough so that thermal agitation will not disturb the stored information in the memory's lifetime. Secondly, the signal level from the memory cell must be large enough so that thermal noise and other disturbances do not corrupt the output signal. This chapter focuses the limits in regard to magnetic memories; they apply to all other memories. Ferromagnetic materials such as iron, cobalt, and nickel are ferromagnetic because the lattice spacing is just right so that a quantum effect termed ''exchange" makes it favorable for the spins of the outer shell electrons from one atom to align with the outer electrons spins from neighboring atoms giving rise to a region called a domain in which all of the net magnetization points in one direction. In a typical bulk material, there are many random domains and the magnetization in all of the domains only gets aligned when a large field is applied. The magnetic moment per unit volume when all of the domains are aligned is labeled as the saturated magnetic moment per unit volume (Ms). © 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Ferromagnetic materials; Ferromagnetism; Magnetic devices; Magnetic moments; Magnetic storage; Magnetism; Magnetization; Nanomagnetics; Quantum electronics; Quantum theory; Semiconductor storage; Lattice spacing; Magnetic memory; Magnetic memory cells; Outer shell electrons; Per unit volume; Quantum effects; Random domains; Thermal agitation; Magnetic domains

Title: Progress of COSMOS (CO2 sending method for ocean storage) and OACE (ocean abyssal carbon experiment)
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Offshore Mechanics and Arctic Engineering - OMAE

Institute, 7700 Sandholdt Road, Moss Landing, CA 9503, United States; Peltzer III, E.T., Monterey Bay Aquarium Res. Institute, 7700 Sandholdt Road, Moss Landing, CA 9503, United States; Haugan, P.M., University of Bergen, Allegaten 70, N-5007 Bergen, Norway; Johannessen, T., University of Bergen, Allegaten 70, N-5007 Bergen, Norway; Kvamme, B., University of Bergen, Allegaten 70, N-5007 Bergen, Norway; Bellerby, R.G.J., University of Bergen, Allegaten 70, N-5007 Bergen, Norway
Abstract: The storage of liquid CO2 at an ocean floor, one of promising measures to mitigate the global warming, requires 3500 m depth for the gravitationally stable storage, a breakthrough technology and a reasonable cost to realize, although it has large advantages such as the sequestration term longer than 2000 years. However CO2 can be sent to the ocean floor by shallow release, if we can use the nature that the cold CO2 to be shipped by a CO2 carrier is much denser than the ambient sea water even at shallow depths. The National Maritime Research Institute (NMRI) conducted several joint field CO2 release experiments with the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (MBARI. USA) since 1999 under the auspices of the NEDO. and proposed the improved COSMOS. CO2 Sending Method for Ocean Storage, in which CO2 is released into 200 m depth as slurry masses (mixture of dry ice and cold liquid CO2). Since 2002, under the NEDO Grant, the NMRI started a new international joint research. OACE, Ocean Abyssal Carbon Experiment with the MBARI and the University of Bergen (UoB, Norway), in order to accumulate the basic data on the long-term stability of stored CO2 and its environmental effects around storage site.
Index Keywords: Ocean sequestration; Ocean storage; Carbon dioxide; Computer simulation; Energy utilization; Environmental impact; Global warming; Gravitation; Light absorption; Nozzles; Raman spectroscopy; Seawater; Thermal insulation; Ocean engineering

Authors: Tronskar J.P.
Title: Accounting for constraint in probabilistic fracture mechanics analysis of welds in Floating Production, storage and Off-loading (FPSO) vessels
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Offshore Mechanics and Arctic Engineering - OMAE
Affiliations: Det Norske Verltas Pte Ltd, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Tronskar, J.P., Det Norske Verltas Pte Ltd, Singapore
Abstract: Revision 4 of the British Energy R6 document: "Assessment of the integrity of structures containing defects" provides methods to allow for loss of crack tip constraint for shallow weld flaws. The document also provides methods to estimate upper-bound values of the through thickness residual stress distribution for a range of common weld joint configurations. The present paper presents results of analyses where approaches to modify the R6 Option 1 or 2 failure assessment diagrams (FADs) for loss of crack tip constraint pertaining to primary and non-uniform residual stress have been applied. The modified FAD were formulated for probabilistic fracture mechanics analyses of semi-elliptical surface cracks located at transverse deck welds of Floating Production, Storage and Off-loading (FPSO) vessels designed to operate in the North Sea. The objective was to study the influence on the failure probability of modifying the FAD for constraint and allowing for non-uniform residual stress. Another objective was to study the influence of constraint correction on the combined fatigue and fracture failure probability for the vessels subjected to wave loading.Material and weld tensile properties and fracture toughness distributions for input to the probabilistic fracture mechanics analyses were obtained from testing of welded panels prepared using welding procedures for actual FPSO fabrication. The loading conditions were derived based on North Sea wave data pertaining to the offshore field where the FPSO is operating. The stresses were obtained from global FE analysis and fitted Weibull long-term and extreme value distributions.The results of the analyses demonstrate clearly the importance of correcting for crack tip constraint pertaining to both primary and secondary stress and to allow for non-uniform residual stress for shallow surface flaws of known crack heights. However, in combination with fatigue crack growth the effects become less prominent as the failure probability is governed by the uncertainty in the parameters of the crack growth relationship and the long-term stress distribution.
Author Keywords: Crack Tip Constraint; Fatigue Crack Growth; Floating Production Off-loading and Storage vessels; Probabilistic Fracture Mechanics; Residual Stress; Unstable Fracture; Welded Joints
Index Keywords: Crack tip constraint; Crack propagation; Fatigue of materials; Finite element method; Fracture mechanics; Loading; Metallographic microstructure; Naval vessels; Probability; Residual stresses; Stress concentration; Structural analysis; Tensile testing; Weibull distribution; Welds; Production platforms

Authors: Grove M.D.A., Da Conceição C.A.L., Schachter R.D.
Title: A concept design and hydrodynamic behavior of a Spar platform
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Offshore Mechanics and Arctic Engineering - OMAE
Affiliations: Projemar S.A., Brazil; Prog. de Engenharia Oceânica, COPPE/UFRJ, Brazil; Dept. de Engenharia Naval, EE/UFRJ, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Grove, M.D.A., Projemar S.A., Brazil; Da Conceição, C.A.L., Prog. de Engenharia Oceânica, COPPE/UFRJ, Brazil; Schachter, R.D., Dept. de Engenharia Naval, EE/UFRJ, Brazil
Abstract: This paper presents a study of a Production and Storage Spar Platform concept design for operations in deep water, under the environmental conditions of the Campos Basin, Brazil. This study is the result of a research sponsored by Agênda Nacional do Petróleo - ANP. The theme was chosen due the good results obtained by this kind of platform in the North Sea and the Gulf of Mexico. Since the exploration of hydrocarbonets is moving to deeper waters, where the Spar concept seems to be one of the best options for the task, due to its simplicity in construction and operation. Although it looks simple, this work had required perceptive studies, and the best way chosen to carry it out, was dividing it in two directions: one dealing with the design method and naval architecture aspects and other with its hydrodynamic behavior. The first line took into consideration the hull generation, compartmentation, weight distribution and stability. A design methodology is presented and the interaction of these factors are showed, taking into account the hydrodynamic results. The second line has favored the evaluation and the control of the vertical motion, excited by dominant waves from the spectra of energy of the sea, and the horizontal motions due the low frequency excitations, and its interaction with the mooring system.
Index Keywords: Vortex induced vibrations (VIV); Hulls (ship); Mooring; Naval architecture; Offshore structures; Structural design; Underwater construction; Vortex shedding; Water wave effects; Production platforms

Authors: Xuan H., Streif J., Saquet A.A., Bangerth F.
Title: Boron application affects respiration and energy status of 'conference' pears during CA-storage
Source title: Acta Horticulturae
Affiliations: Institut für Obstbau Bavendorf, Universität Hohenheim, D-88213 Ravensburg, Germany; Institut für Obst-, Gemüse- und Weinbau, Universität Hohenheim, D-70593 Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Xuan, H., Institut für Obstbau Bavendorf, Universität Hohenheim, D-88213 Ravensburg, Germany; Streif, J., Institut für Obstbau Bavendorf, Universität Hohenheim, D-88213 Ravensburg, Germany; Saquet, A.A., Institut für Obstbau Bavendorf, Universität Hohenheim, D-88213 Ravensburg, Germany; Bangerth, F., Institut für Obst-, Gemüse- und Weinbau, Universität Hohenheim, D-70593 Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: Boron supply of fruit tissue seems to alleviate the incidence of CA-related browning disorders in 'Conference' pears, which occur mainly under high CO2 and/ or low O2 concentrations. In three subsequent years the effect of pre-harvest boron sprays on various physiological parameters of pear fruit stored under high CO2 CAconditions was tested. Up to six times before harvest, trees of 'Conference' pears were sprayed with boron, alone or in combination with calcium. Following harvest, fruit were stored at -0.5 °C, 5% CO2 + 2% O2 CA-conditions for 5 months. During this time, the pears were monitored for physiological disorders, fruit quality, respiration, and energy charge of fruit tissue. Results showed that control fruit were more affected by internal browning than those treated with boron. The lowest incidence of browning disorders, however, was obtained in fruit sprayed with boron in combination with calcium. Moreover, at harvest time, these fruit were greener, firmer and had less titratable acidity than control fruit. Boron-treated fruit respired at lower rates harvest and during the entire storage period. However, the energy status, expressed as ATP:ADP-ratio was higher in boron-treated fruit. This may be caused by a lower energy requirement resulting in a higher net amount of energy being available for maintenance of cell integrity and function.
Author Keywords: ADP; ATP; Boron; CA-storage; Ethylene; Pear; Physiological disorder; Quality; Respiration

Authors: Mitra S.K., Kabir J., Dhua R.S., Dutta Ray S.K.
Title: Low cost cool chamber for storage of tropical fruits
Source title: Acta Horticulturae
Affiliations: Faculty of Horticulture, Bidhan Chandra Krishi Viswavidyalaya, Mohanpur 741 252, Nadia, West Bengal, India
Authors with affiliations: Mitra, S.K., Faculty of Horticulture, Bidhan Chandra Krishi Viswavidyalaya, Mohanpur 741 252, Nadia, West Bengal, India; Kabir, J., Faculty of Horticulture, Bidhan Chandra Krishi Viswavidyalaya, Mohanpur 741 252, Nadia, West Bengal, India; Dhua, R.S., Faculty of Horticulture, Bidhan Chandra Krishi Viswavidyalaya, Mohanpur 741 252, Nadia, West Bengal, India; Dutta Ray, S.K., Faculty of Horticulture, Bidhan Chandra Krishi Viswavidyalaya, Mohanpur 741 252, Nadia, West Bengal, India
Abstract: A large quantity of fresh fruits in India is wasted after harvest due to lack of enough storage facilities. The high cost involved in developing cold storage or controlled atmosphere storage is a pressing problem in several developing countries. In view of the current energy crisis, the low cost environment friendly cool chamber, working on the principle of evaporative cooling, developed at the Indian Agricultural Research Institute, was found very effective in extending storage life of tropical fruits like mango, litchi, guava, banana, sapota and mandarin. The storage life of fruits increased by 4-16 days and the fruits stored in the cool chamber were more acceptable as they had better appearance, texture, taste and flavour than those maintained in ambient conditions.
Author Keywords: Banana; Evaporative cool chamber; Guava; Litchi; Mandarin; Mango; Physiological loss in weight; Sapota; TSS/acid ratio

Authors: Saquet A.A., Streif J., Bangerth F.
Title: Reducing internal browning disorders in 'braeburn' apples by delayed controlled atmosphere storage and some related physiological and biochemical changes
Source title: Acta Horticulturae
Affiliations: Institut für Obstbau Bavendorf, Universität Hohenheim, D-88213 Ravensburg, Germany; Institut für Obst-, Gemüse- und Weinbau, Universität Hohenheim, D-70593 Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Saquet, A.A., Institut für Obstbau Bavendorf, Universität Hohenheim, D-88213 Ravensburg, Germany; Streif, J., Institut für Obstbau Bavendorf, Universität Hohenheim, D-88213 Ravensburg, Germany; Bangerth, F., Institut für Obst-, Gemüse- und Weinbau, Universität Hohenheim, D-70593 Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: This work was carried out to test the effectiveness of a delayed controlled atmosphere (CA) storage (21 days at 1 °C in air before CA storage) on the occurrence of browning disorders and related physiological changes like energy status and fatty acid metabolism in 'Braeburn' apples. After delayed CA, fruit were stored for up to 5 months in 4% CO2 + 1% O2 at 1 °C. Fruit subjected to rapid CA showed a high incidence of internal browning and cavities, whereas in delayed CA-fruit a very low incidence of these disorders was found. No significant losses of flesh firmness, acidity, skin colour and soluble solids content between treatments could be observed. Delayed CA-fruit showed clearly higher ethylene production and respiration rate during the first 2 months of storage which was associated with higher ATP concentrations in the fruit tissue. Therefore, significant higher energy charge of delayed CA-fruit was found and remained high until the end of storage period. Delayed CA-fruit showed higher contents of total fatty acids and polar fatty acids esterified with lipids than rapid CA-stored fruit. These results suggest that 'Braeburn' apples can become adapted to CA during the early stages of the storage period by delaying CA storage conditions making them more tolerant against browning disorders.
Author Keywords: ADP; ATP; Fatty acids; Malus domestica; Physiological disorders

Authors: Kim K., Lee S., Delfyett Jr. P.J.
Title: eXtreme chirped pulse amplification (X-CPA) using semiconductor gain media
Source title: Conference Proceedings - Lasers and Electro-Optics Society Annual Meeting-LEOS
Affiliations: University of Central Florida, School of Optics/CREOL, 4000 Central Florida Blvd, Orlando, FL 32816-2700, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, K., University of Central Florida, School of Optics/CREOL, 4000 Central Florida Blvd, Orlando, FL 32816-2700, United States; Lee, S., University of Central Florida, School of Optics/CREOL, 4000 Central Florida Blvd, Orlando, FL 32816-2700, United States; Delfyett Jr., P.J., University of Central Florida, School of Optics/CREOL, 4000 Central Florida Blvd, Orlando, FL 32816-2700, United States
Abstract: The concept of X-CPA using a semiconductor gain media with <1ns energy storage lifetime and CFBG with large dispersion is introduced. The pulse stretching and recompression is demonstrated with a pair of CFBGs (2000ps/nm). In addition, the gain saturation behavior without and with pulse stretching is demonstrated experimentally and numerically. The results showed that future high pulse energy, ultrafast mode-locked laser systems will be achievable from an all-semiconductor gain media platform.

Authors: Sano A., Ikemata Y., Fujimoto H.
Title: Analysis of dynamics of passive walking from storage energy and supply rate
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Gokiso-cho, Showa-ku, Nagoya 466-8555, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sano, A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Gokiso-cho, Showa-ku, Nagoya 466-8555, Japan; Ikemata, Y., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Gokiso-cho, Showa-ku, Nagoya 466-8555, Japan; Fujimoto, H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Gokiso-cho, Showa-ku, Nagoya 466-8555, Japan
Abstract: Passive walking robot can dynamically walk down with natural gait by the interaction between walker's dynamics and environment (slope). This robot exhibits a stable limit cycle and its gait bifurcates for larger slope. Analysis of dynamics of passive walking may be useful for understanding human locomotion and development of walking machine. In this paper, we analyze dynamics of passive walking from the aspect of "storage energy" and "supply rate". We also demonstrate that a stable fixed point becomes unstable when 1-periodic gait turns 2-periodic.
Index Keywords: Dynamics; Gait analysis; Kinematics; Kinetic energy; Mathematical models; Motion control; Potential energy; Human locomotion; One periodic gait turns two periodic; Passive walking; Robot movement; Storage energy; Supply rate; Mobile robots

Authors: Abella J., González A.
Title: On reducing register pressure and energy in multiple-banked register files
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: Computer Architecture Department, Universitat Politecnica de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain; Intel Barcelona Research Center, Intel Labs, Universitat Politecnica de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Abella, J., Computer Architecture Department, Universitat Politecnica de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain; González, A., Computer Architecture Department, Universitat Politecnica de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain, Intel Barcelona Research Center, Intel Labs, Universitat Politecnica de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain
Abstract: The storage for speculative values in superscalar processors is one of the main sources of complexity and power dissipation. In this paper, we present a novel technique to reduce register requirements as well as their dynamic and static power dissipation that is based on delaying the dispatch of instructions while minimizing its impact on performance. The proposed technique outperforms previous schemes in both performance and power savings. With only 1.77% IPC loss, the mechanism achieves more than 13% dynamic and 15% static extra power savings in the integer rename buffers and more than 9% dynamic and 10% static extra power savings in the FP rename buffers. Significant power savings are also achieved if the processor uses a physical register file for both committed and non-committed values instead of rename buffers. Additionally the register requirements are reduced by more than 18% and 13% for integer and FP programs respectively.
Index Keywords: Computational complexity; Design for testability; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Microelectronic processing; Dynamic power dissipation; Multiple banked register files; Static power dissipation; Microprocessor chips

Authors: Delaluz V., Kandemir M., Sivasubramaniam A., Irwin M.J., Vijaykrishnan N.
Title: Reducing dTLB energy through dynamic resizing
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Delaluz, V., The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Kandemir, M., The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Sivasubramaniam, A., The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Irwin, M.J., The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Vijaykrishnan, N., The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Abstract: Translation Look-aside Buffer (TLB), which is small Content Addressable Memory (CAM) structure used to translate virtual addresses to physical addresses, can consume significant energy in some architectures. In addition, its power density is high, due to its small area. Consequently, reducing power consumption of TLB is important for both high-end and low-end systems. While a large TLB might be preferable from the performance angle, it can also lead to excessive dynamic energy consumption. This paper focuses on data TLB (dTLB), and proposes an architectural solution to this problem which is based on dynamically resizing the dTLB considering application execution behavior. Our objective is to give the application the minimum dTLB size (at any point) without significantly degrading its performance. We present two different implementations of this idea, and give experimental data demonstrating that it is very effective in practice.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Cache memory; Calculations; Computer simulation; Dynamic random access storage; Sensitivity analysis; Data translation look-aside buffer; Dynamic energy consumption; Power density; Associative storage

Authors: O'Sullivan B.J., O'Connor E., Hurley P.K., Modreanu M., Roussel F., Roussel H., Audier M.A., Sénateur J.P., Fang Q., Boyd I.W., Jimenez C., Leedham T.
Title: Analysis of electrically active defects at Si(100) - HfO2 interface
Source title: Proceedings - Electrochemical Society
Affiliations: NMRC, University College, Cork, Ireland; INPG, Grenoble, France; Dept. of E, UCL, London, United Kingdom; JIPElec, Meylan, France; Inorgtech, Mildenhall, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: O'Sullivan, B.J., NMRC, University College, Cork, Ireland; O'Connor, E., NMRC, University College, Cork, Ireland; Hurley, P.K., NMRC, University College, Cork, Ireland; Modreanu, M., NMRC, University College, Cork, Ireland; Roussel, F., INPG, Grenoble, France; Roussel, H., INPG, Grenoble, France; Audier, M.A., INPG, Grenoble, France; Sénateur, J.P., INPG, Grenoble, France; Fang, Q., Dept. of E, UCL, London, United Kingdom; Boyd, I.W., Dept. of E, UCL, London, United Kingdom; Jimenez, C., JIPElec, Meylan, France; Leedham, T., Inorgtech, Mildenhall, United Kingdom
Abstract: Results are presented from an analysis of the electrically activity of defects at the Si(100)/HfO2 interface. Two clear peaks emerge in the interface state density profiles, at specific energies in the upper and lower energy gap, when the high K samples were deposited at sufficiently low temperatures to prevent hydrogen passivation of interface defects. The location of these peaks correspond to the location of Pb0 (/Pb1) defects in the Si(100)/SiO2 system. Defect densities are estimated to be of order mid 1012 cm-2 for HfO2 samples. This density is significantly higher than is the case in the Si(100)/SiO 2 system, and seems relatively independent of surface preparation steps performed. Performing a forming gas anneal at 450°C for 30 mins is not sufficient to fully passivate these interface defects, as is the case in the Si/SiO2 system.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Defects; Density (specific gravity); Dielectric materials; Dynamic random access storage; Electric insulators; Hafnium compounds; Heat conduction; Microelectronics; Silica; Thermodynamic stability; Active defects; Dielectric layers; State density; Valence bands; Interfaces (materials)

Authors: Fauske H.K.
Title: A quick thermal activity monitor (QTAM) for controlling chemical reaction hazard
Source title: Center for Chemical Process Safety 18th Annual International Conference - Managing Chemical Reactivity Hazards and High Energy Release Events
Affiliations: Fauske and Associates, Inc., Burr Ridge, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fauske, H.K., Fauske and Associates, Inc., Burr Ridge, IL, United States
Abstract: A quick and inexpensive method is introduced to facilitate product control in assuring safe chemicals management in transportation and storage. Product safety measures related to large quantities of reactive chemicals require frequent measurements of thermal activity at low temperature in order to control the potential for contamination, etc., that can accelerate the reaction rate. The QTAM* is an especially designed instrument to monitor chemical systems undergoing gaseous decomposition reactions with the capability of interpreting heating rates of the order of 1 μW/g or a self heat rate of the order of 10 -5 °C min -1. Recognizing the need for frequent sampling, the QTAM takes about 1 hour to run an analysis.
Index Keywords: Heat flow; Process safety management (PSM); Product control; Quick thermal activity monitor (QTAM); Accident prevention; Activation energy; Calorimetry; Decomposition; Heating; Impurities; Monitoring; Specific heat; Thermal effects; Transportation; Hazards

Authors: Weissbach R.S., Meyers T.S.
Title: Honors thesis work in renewable energy for an undergraduate student
Source title: ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Penn. State Erie, Behrend College, United States; Elec. Eng. Technology Department, Penn. State Erie, Behrend College, United States; Electrical Engineering Technology, Penn. State Erie, Behrend College, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weissbach, R.S., Penn. State Erie, Behrend College, United States, Elec. Eng. Technology Department, Penn. State Erie, Behrend College, United States; Meyers, T.S., Penn. State Erie, Behrend College, United States, Electrical Engineering Technology, Penn. State Erie, Behrend College, United States
Abstract: Renewable energy has become an important area of research and development for both environmental as well as economic reasons. At the academic level, it is possible to introduce students to issues related to renewable energy. This paper discusses the effort one student has put in, as part of a thesis, to develop an economically feasible, self-sufficient, renewable energy system for a residential home in the Great Lakes region. The design of the system sought to use both wind and solar energy to supply energy to the home. The student was able to consider effects such as the design and capability of the wind turbine and solar panels to determine whether the design would be viable economically. After deciding that the initial system design would be too expensive, the student then considered other options to reduce the cost of the renewable energy system while still providing the necessary electrical systems that are used in a modern home. This included the development of a survey that was distributed to faculty and staff. The survey was used to determine the critical electrical loads that families in the Great Lakes region would require throughout the year. Successes and challenges of using thesis work as a teaching methodology for education in renewable energy will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Complex problems; Electrical energy technology; Teaching technology; Curricula; Electrical engineering; Energy storage; Engineering education; Mathematical models; Solar energy; Students; Renewable energy resources

Authors: Amatucci G.G., Badway F., Dupasquier A., Cosandey F., Plitz I.
Title: Next generation positive electrode Materials Enabled by Nanocomposites: -Metal Fluorides-

Abstract: Nanotechnology has been receiving significant exposure regarding its potential to offer non evolutionary advancements in a wide breadth of technologies. Within the confines of this paper we explore specific avenues which our group has identified promise for non-evolutionary advancement in energy storage technology, specifically such technologies utilizing ion insertion processes such as Li battery technology. We show that within certain defined foci, nano and nanocomposite materials can open the door to next generation devices exhibiting, exceptionally high power and energy. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Laystrom J.K., Burton R.L., Benavides G.F.
Title: Geometric optimization of a coaxial pulsed plasma thruster
Source title: 39th AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference and Exhibit
Affiliations: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Aerospace Engineering, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; CU Aerospace L.L.C., Champaign, IL 61820, United States
Authors with affiliations: Laystrom, J.K., University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Aerospace Engineering, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Burton, R.L., University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Aerospace Engineering, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Benavides, G.F., CU Aerospace L.L.C., Champaign, IL 61820, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses a TeflonTM pulsed plasma thruster (PPT) that was designed, built, and tested with efficiency, size, simplicity, and scalability at the forefront of the design process. Thruster model PPT-11 was designed after a successful series of tests with thruster PPT-10.3 and incorporates a high geometry. The preferred design is a large-radius-ratio coaxial geometry with a central anode and four side-fed propellant bars, utilizing high-capacitance (82 μF) energy storage units. This paper discusses geometric modifications, including propellant and anode sizing and materials selection, which are integrated into the PPT-11 design. An Isp of 1200 s, thrust of 1.7 mN, and a thrust efficiency of 12% are achieved with an electromagnetic thrust fraction of 65%. © 2003 by Julia K. Laystrom.
Index Keywords: Coaxial geometry; Coaxial pulsed plasma thrusters; Electromagnetic thrust; Energy storage unit; Geometric optimization; Materials selection; Thrust efficiency; Thruster models; Propellants; Propulsion; Pulsed plasma thrusters; Geometry

Authors: Grantham K.
Title: Sub-optimal analytic guidance laws for reusable launch vehicles
Source title: AIAA Guidance, Navigation, and Control Conference and Exhibit
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics, University of Missouri - Rolla, Rolla, MO 65401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grantham, K., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics, University of Missouri - Rolla, Rolla, MO 65401, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a guidance scheme for the Terminal Area Energy Management (TAEM) and Approach and Landing phases of flight for the next generation of reusable launch vehicles (RLVs). The guidance scheme presented is developed in two parts, the kappa guidance section and the touchdown trajectory section. The kappa guidance section begins at the TAEM interface and continues until 475m slant range before the desired touchdown point. The touchdown trajectory section begins at the 475m slant range interface and continues until the RLV reaches the desired touchdown point. The guidance algorithm for the kappa guidance section is an approximate analytic solution to the nonlinear optimization of minimizing the final velocity of the trajectory while meeting a constraint on the final flight path angle. The assumptions used to develop the approximate analytic solution begin to degrade this guidance algorithm's performance near the touchdown point; therefore, the touchdown trajectory section was incorporated into the guidance scheme. This guidance algorithm uses linear quadratic regulator control theory to find the change in angle of attack from the nominal that produces a desired touchdown rate at the touchdown point. Both guidance algorithms have "trajectory shaping parameters" which help meet the final constraints for each section. These parameters have a relationship with both velocity and flight path angle which is approximated by neural networks. The combination of these two guidance algorithms yield a wide range of allowable initial conditions that an RLV can have and still be able to land with a desirable touchdown rate at the touchdown point. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Approach and landings; Approximate analytic solutions; Initial conditions; Linear quadratic regulator control; Non-linear optimization; Reusable launch vehicles; Terminal area energy management; Trajectory shaping; Algorithms; Launching; Optimization; Reusable rockets; Trajectories; Magnetic disk storage

Authors: Kozlowski M.V., Cole D.G., Clark R.L.
Title: Performance and sensitivity study on sensoriactuator circuits for positive-real damping schemes
Source title: 44th AIAA/ASME/ASCE/AHS/ASC Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference
Affiliations: Pratt School of Engineering, Mechanical Engineering and Material Science Department, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kozlowski, M.V., Pratt School of Engineering, Mechanical Engineering and Material Science Department, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Cole, D.G., Pratt School of Engineering, Mechanical Engineering and Material Science Department, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Clark, R.L., Pratt School of Engineering, Mechanical Engineering and Material Science Department, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Abstract: Current piezoelectric based control schemes which are totally passive, such as various resonant and resistive shunts, suffer performance limitations because of the energy storage of the capacitance of the piezoelectric. Active schemes which offer the prospect of greater performance can be complicated in implementation and knowledge required as well as being prone to stability issues. Use of sensoriactuators, single piezoelectrics operating simultaneously as sensors and actuators, for collocated feedback control eliminates the performance limiting effects of the patch capacitance and guarantees a minimum phase system. Such plants with an appropriate choice of a positive-real compensation filter guarantee a closed-loop feedback system to be stable. This research investigates two such compensation filters for use on a single structural mode, develops the associated tuning laws, and examines the performance and performance robustness gains over the comparison benchmark of the resonant shunt. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Closed-loop feedback system; Compensation filters; Limiting effects; Minimum-phase systems; Performance limitations; Performance robustness; Sensitivity studies; Sensors and actuators; Capacitance; Feedback control; Piezoelectricity; Structural dynamics; Benchmarking

Authors: Chigier N., Gemci T.
Title: A review of micro propulsion technology
Source title: 41st Aerospace Sciences Meeting and Exhibit
Affiliations: Spray Systems Technology Center, Mechanical Engineering Department, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chigier, N., Spray Systems Technology Center, Mechanical Engineering Department, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States; Gemci, T., Spray Systems Technology Center, Mechanical Engineering Department, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Abstract: Micro ElectroMechanical Systems (MEMS) based propulsion devices have a great potential for providing high specific power. The inherent difficulty of placing a spacecraft into orbit requires a payload mass as small as possible. The application of Micro Power Generation technology to space propulsion systems will provide increased orbit and stationkeeping capabilities at possible lower cost. Replacing a single large mass, high power satellite with a series of smaller platforms can lower the system cost. New generation spacecraft and satellites are getting smaller and require micro-propulsion systems for all aspects of their operations. A growing trend of miniaturization in electro and mechanical engineering devices (micro transmitters, embedded micro sensors/actuators, small robots, wrist communicators, indestructible jet engines, micro airborne sensor/communicators, micro thermal-chemical power systems etc.) has stimulated new prospects for thermal-fluid scientists in the field of micro-power generation in the watts range. The interest in chemical energy sources as alternatives to electrochemical batteries for MEMS applications lies in the potential to significantly increase energy storage densities. The development of micropropuls ion systems with associated combustors for micro electricity-generation that utilize liquid fuel, poses major challenges for fuel injection, mixing, combustion, and chemical reactor systems. A microspacecraft with high-accuracy station-keeping and attitude control capabilities needs to have a low mass and a small impulse. Liquid propellants with high energy density are capable of meeting these goals. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: VanOverbeke T.J.
Title: Modeling of pressure reduction due to axial-jet mixers in cryogenic tanks
Source title: 41st Aerospace Sciences Meeting and Exhibit
Affiliations: NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: VanOverbeke, T.J., NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: Computational modeling of inter-phase condensation and pressure reduction is compared to experimental data for jet induced mixing in liquid Hydrogen tanks. Heat leak or heat transfer in cryogenic storage tanks causes temperature stratification and a pressure build up in the vapor or ullage space. An axial-jet pump is used to mix sub-cooled fluid from the bottom of the tank with thermally stratified fluid, cooling the liquidvapor interface causing condensation. This has been successfully modeled using a commercial code with modification to user subroutines. The liquid phase is modeled using CFX-4 code with modified user routines to calculate transient boundary conditions and heat transfer. The vapor ullage space is modeled using a two-point model. This allows for heat transfer calculations across the ullage rather than using a single lumped model. At each time step the liquid solution is iterated until convergence. Then inter-phase mass transport is equated to the difference in heat transfer occurring at the liquid and vapor interface divided by the energy needed for phase change. Two geometries have been used. Both geometries used body fitted 2-D cylindrical grids. The first is a small cylindrical tank with hemispherical ends. Experimental data was used to initialize the temperature field and modeled ullage. At computational zero time flow from the mixer was initiated. The flow rises then impinges on the liquid-vapor interface and spreads outward. The mixer-jet flow entrains surrounding flow forming an upper vortex. With time this flow grows in size to take up the whole tank. Experimental temperature data at the bottom of the tank also showed low temperature until significant mixing had occurred. The second tank is a larger ellipsoidal tank tested at NASA Plumbrook. Predictions of pressure reduction were done using selfpressurized data and externally pressurized tanks. A run done using self-pressurized data produced the best predictions.

Authors: Kawanaka J., Yamakawa K., Nishioka H., Ueda K.-I.

Photon Research Center, Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, 8-1 Umemidia, Kizu-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto 619-0215, Japan; Nishioka, H., Institute for Laser Science, University of Electro-Communcations (ILS/UEC), 1-5-1 Chofugaoka, Chofu-shi, Tokyo 182-8585, Japan; Ueda, K.-I., Institute for Laser Science, University of Electro-Communcations (ILS/UEC), 1-5-1 Chofugaoka, Chofu-shi, Tokyo 182-8585, Japan
Abstract: Yb:LiYF4 (Yb:YLF) crystal is focused on as one of the promised laser materials in the diode-pumped ultrahigh-peak-power lasers due to its high energy storage, wide spectral emission range, low nonlinear refractive index and high thermal conductivity. In this paper, spectral control with a pellicle was demonstrated for broadening a spectral width of the regenerative amplified pulse. Sub-100 fs pulse duration with over-ten-milli-joule pulse energy after compression could be obtained with pellicle spectral shaping and additional pump diode by replacing the fiber stretcher to an antiparallel grating pair pulse stretcher. © 2003 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Amplified pulse; High thermal conductivity; Nonlinear refractive index; Regenerative amplifier; Spectral control; Spectral emission; Spectral shaping; Spectral widths; Optical pumping; Refractive index; Stretchers; YLF lasers; Ytterbium; Pulse shaping

Authors: Park S.-M., Kim J.-H.
Title: Chameleon: A resource scheduler in a data grid environment
Source title: Proceedings - CCGrid 2003: 3rd IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Cluster Computing and the Grid
Affiliations: Graduate School of Information and Communication, Ajou University, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Park, S.-M., Graduate School of Information and Communication, Ajou University, South Korea; Kim, J.-H., Graduate School of Information and Communication, Ajou University, South Korea
Abstract: Grid computing is moving into two ways. The Computational Grid focuses on reducing execution time of applications that require a great number of computer processing cycles. The Data Grid provides the way to solve large scale data management problems. Data intensive applications such as High Energy Physics and Bioinformatics require both Computational and Data Grid features. Job scheduling in Grid has been mostly discussed from the perspective of computational Grid. However, scheduling on Data Grid is just a recent focus of Grid computing activities. In Data Grid environment, effective scheduling mechanism considering both computational and data storage resources must be provided for large scale data intensive applications. In this paper, we describe new scheduling model that considers both amount of computational resources and data availability in Data Grid environment. We implemented a scheduler, called Chameleon, based on the proposed application scheduling model. Chameleon shows performance improvements in data intensive applications that require both large number of processors and data replication mechanisms. The results achieved from Chameleon are presented. © 2003 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Application scheduling; Computational grids; Computational resources; Computer processing; Data Grid environment; Data-intensive application; Large-scale data management; Scheduling mechanism; Bioinformatics; Cluster computing; High energy physics; Information management; Scheduling; Grid computing

Authors: Wirtz R., Fuchs A., Narla V., Shen Y., Zhao T., Jiang Y.
Title: A multi-functional graphite/epoxy-based thermal energy storage composite for temperature control of sensors and electronics
Source title: 41st Aerospace Sciences Meeting and Exhibit
Affiliations: University of Nevada, Reno, NV, 89557, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wirtz, R., University of Nevada, Reno, NV, 89557, United States; Fuchs, A., University of Nevada, Reno, NV, 89557, United States; Narla, V., University of Nevada, Reno, NV, 89557, United States; Shen, Y., University of Nevada, Reno, NV, 89557, United States; Zhao, T., University of Nevada, Reno, NV, 89557, United States; Jiang, Y., University of Nevada, Reno, NV, 89557, United States
Abstract: A novel multi-functional plate-like lamination that combines a thermal energy storage capability with a structural capability is described. The lamination consists of a paraffin impregnated porous graphitic core (the energy storage volume) encapsulated between rigid graphite/epoxy composite skins. Heat storage is via solid-liquid phase transition of the paraffin. Stacked laminations form a sandwich structure. A thermal response model shows that the graphite foam is an effective thermal conductivity enhancer to the imbedded paraffin. It will effectively immobilize liquid paraffin so that the thermal storage process will be unaffected by up to a 10g load. Furthermore, the foam can accommodate the relatively large specific volume change that accompanies paraffin phase transition. However, it does so at the expense of reduced thermal performance. Structural analysis shows that graphitic foam has a low strength and elasticity modulus, and the material displays tension-compression asymmetry. The paraffin fill is shown to increase the compressive ultimate strength and elasticity modulus. The use of carbon fiber/epoxy skin greatly enhances the overall strength of the structure. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Abusleme A., Dixon J., Soto D.
Title: Improved performance of a battery powered electric car, using photovoltaic cells
Source title: 2003 IEEE Bologna PowerTech - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile, Casilla 306, Correo 22, Santiago, Chile
Authors with affiliations: Abusleme, A., Electrical Engineering Department, Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile, Casilla 306, Correo 22, Santiago, Chile; Dixon, J., Electrical Engineering Department, Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile, Casilla 306, Correo 22, Santiago, Chile; Soto, D., Electrical Engineering Department, Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile, Casilla 306, Correo 22, Santiago, Chile
Abstract: One of the major problems for the massive applicability of Electric Vehicles (EVs) is the scarce capacity of conventional electrical energy storage systems. Although this constraint has been overcome in many cases using advanced technologies such as fuel cells and high-capacity batteries, it is still difficult to develop an economically viable and socially acceptable EV for massive use. In this context, solar energy is not a practical solution for satisfying this lack of energy. However, if a particular situation is considered, in which a small-sized, high-efficiency EV operates at low duty cycles in a sunny, predictable environment, solar power can become a solution for reducing transport costs. This paper deals with the reach of this approach. © 2003 IEEE.

Authors: Steurer M., Woodruff S., Brooks N., Giesbrecht J., Li H., Baldwin T.
Title: Optimizing the transient response of voltage source converters used for mitigating voltage collapse problems by means of real time digital simulation
Source title: 2003 IEEE Bologna PowerTech - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Center for Advanced Power Systems, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL 32310, United States; RTDS Technologies, Inc., 200-1619 Pembina Highway, Winnipeg, MB, R3T 3Y6, Canada

Abstract: Shunt-connected voltage controllers such as STATCOMs have the potential to mitigate voltage collapse problems in distribution systems with heavy induction motor loadings by injecting reactive current into the AC system. In networks with very low X/R ratios, the addition of active (real) power by the STATCOM is required and may be provided by superconducting energy storage systems (SMES). This paper presents a real time network simulation model of a STATCOM-SMES system and shows how control parameters can be optimized for fast transient response by combining simulations with sophisticated optimization strategies. It is concluded that real-time simulation, possibly also in conjunction with hardware-in-the-loop experiments, can aid optimal use of future static compensators in advanced electric power systems. © 2003 IEEE.

Title: Electrical Thermal Storage modeling: A tool to evaluate new opportunities and bids for residential users in a deregulated market
Source title: 2003 IEEE Bologna PowerTech - Conference Proceedings

Politécnica de Valencia, 46020 Valencia, Spain; Fuentes, J.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Universidad Politécnica de Cartagena, 30202 Cartagena, Spain; Gómez, E., Department of Electrical Engineering, Universidad Politécnica de Cartagena, 30202 Cartagena, Spain
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to describe a useful tool for the initial analysis to assess the possibilities of residential Electric Thermal Storage (ETS), taking into account heat storage and cool storage devices. These load models are based on an energy balance between the indoor environment, the dwelling constructive parameters, the ETS device and the internal mass through a discrete state-space equation system. The main application of this load model has been oriented towards the simulation of ETS performance in order to evaluate the possibilities of Load Management in the new deregulated structures of Electrical Power Systems. The proposed model has been implemented and validated for heat storage, using real data collected during the last years in residential areas to evaluate its accuracy and flexibility. Finally, a simulation case study is presented to show the possibilities of modifying the actual residential demand profile through a storage period re-scheduling proposed by the authors, taking into account the customer minimum comfort levels and avoiding program rejection. © 2003 IEEE.

Authors: Awad H., Svensson J., Bollen M.H.J.
Title: Testing Static Series Compensator against capacitor-bank energizing
Source title: 2003 IEEE Bologna PowerTech - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Dept. of Electric Power Engineering, Chalmers University of Technology, SE-41296 Gothenburg, Sweden; ABB Utilities, HVDC Light Competence Center, Gothenburg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Awad, H., Dept. of Electric Power Engineering, Chalmers University of Technology, SE-41296 Gothenburg, Sweden; Svensson, J., ABB Utilities, HVDC Light Competence Center, Gothenburg, Sweden; Bollen, M.H.J., Dept. of Electric Power Engineering, Chalmers University of Technology, SE-41296 Gothenburg, Sweden
Abstract: The Static Series Compensator (SSC) has shown to be an effective power electronics apparatus for mitigation of voltage dips. However, the power system operation is not only affected by voltage dips but also other power system events may cause disturbances. In this paper, the behavior of the SSC is investigated in case of upstream capacitor-bank energizing. Upstream capacitor-bank energizing leads to a transient at the terminals of the SSC followed y a sustained overvoltage. This overvoltage is exploited to charge the energy-storage capacitor of the SSC to the maximum allowable dc voltage. Simulations with PSCAD/EMTDC show that the capacitor-energizing transient does negatively affect the performance of the SSC. © 2003 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Capacitor-bank energizing; Power quality; Static series compensator; Vector control

Authors: Pay S., Baghzouz Y.
Title: Effectiveness of battery-supercapacitor combination in electric vehicles
Source title: 2003 IEEE Bologna PowerTech - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Harris Engineering Consultants, Las Vegas, NV 89119, United States; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Nevada, Las Vegas, NV 89154, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pay, S., Harris Engineering Consultants, Las Vegas, NV 89119, United States; Baghzouz, Y., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Nevada, Las Vegas, NV 89154, United States
Abstract: This paper investigates the application of a supercapacitor bank when used as a power buffer to smooth rapid power fluctuations in and out of the battery of an electric or hybrid vehicle. The study considers the simple case where the supercapacitor bank is connected directly in shunt with the battery as well as the case where it is connected through a DC/DC converter that is necessary to achieve optimal performance. The work is illustrated through computer simulations during vehicle acceleration and deceleration. Partial experimental data on a prototype circuit is also shown. Proper design of such a hybrid electrical energy storage system is expected to result in substantial benefits to the well being of the battery bank. © 2003 IEEE.

Authors: Rufer A., Hotellier D., Barrade P.
Title: A supercapacitor-based energy-storage substation for voltage-compensation in weak transportation networks
Source title: 2003 IEEE Bologna PowerTech - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Industrial Electronics Laboratory, EPFL, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Lausanne, Switzerland; SEMER, Passy, France
Authors with affiliations: Rufer, A., Industrial Electronics Laboratory, EPFL, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Lausanne, Switzerland; Hotellier, D., SEMER, Passy, France; Barrade, P., Industrial Electronics Laboratory, EPFL, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: A supercapacitive-storage based substation for the compensation of resistive voltage-drops in transportation networks is proposed. It allows to feed as a current-source in any voltage conditions of the line. The system has been designed as a compensation-substation to be placed at weak points like end-of-line stations, instead of additional feeding substations. A dedicated power-electronic converter with an associated control system for the stabilization of the voltage level at the point of coupling in case of strong perturbations is proposed. Practical results are also presented, which have been recorded from a reduced-size prototype. © 2003 IEEE.

Authors: Korpaas M., Hildrum R., Holen A.T.
Title: Optimal operation of hydrogen storage for energy sources with stochastic input
Source title: 2003 IEEE Bologna PowerTech - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, 7491 Trondheim, Norway; Statkraft SF, 0216 Oslo, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Korpaas, M., Department of Electrical Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, 7491 Trondheim, Norway; Hildrum, R., Statkraft SF, 0216 Oslo, Norway; Holen, A.T., Department of Electrical Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, 7491 Trondheim, Norway
Abstract: An operation strategy for hydrogen storage in combination with stochastic energy sources is presented. The hydrogen storage can simultaneously be used for power smoothing and provide clean fuel for vehicles. The method is based on optimization of an objective function that takes into account electricity market conditions and penalties for not providing hydrogen and oxygen to the loads. Three case studies where wind is the primary energy source have been analyzed. Simulation results show that the hydrogen storage makes it possible to reduce wind power fluctuations, and at the same time take advantage of hourly variations in the electricity price. In isolated operation mode, utilization of excess heat from the fuel cell leads to a significant reduction of the usage of back-up generator. The results indicate that it is valuable to use optimization techniques for operation of hydrogen storage in connection with stochastic energy sources. © 2003 IEEE.

Authors: Zhihong L., Hua B.
Title: Study of heat storage setting & its release time for batch processes
Source title: Computer Aided Chemical Engineering
Affiliations: Institute of Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510641, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhihong, L., Institute of Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510641, China; Hua, B., Institute of Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510641, China
Abstract: This paper approaches the problem about the heat storage setting and its release time during the energy synthesis for batch processes, points out that the economy analysis must be considered according to production scale. The paper also proposes the economy criterion to decide heat storage to be set or not. Moreover, the paper presents the optimization strategy for confirming the heat storage setting and its release time based on the method of artificial intelligence (AI). Compared with literatures, the above strategy can deal with not only the depreciation of energy quality, but also the effect of practical engineering factor of batch process, such as the distant match and its investment of pipeline and the flow exergy dissipation. This paper also proposes the steps of the heat exchanger networks synthesis for batch process. Further, the paper also proposes the conception of the period of investment reclamation, which can provide the economy criterion for investment decision-marker. A case study illustrates the method presented by this paper is practical. © 2003 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: artificial intelligence; batch process; heat storage

Authors: Masruroh N.A., Li B., Klemeš J.
Title: Life cycle analysis of a solar thermal system with thermochemical storage process
Source title: Computer Aided Chemical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Process Integration, University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST), PO Box 88, Manchester, M60 1QD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Masruroh, N.A., Department of Process Integration, University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST), PO Box 88, Manchester, M60 1QD, United Kingdom; Li, B., Department of Process Integration, University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST), PO Box 88, Manchester, M60 1QD, United Kingdom; Klemeš, J., Department of Process Integration, University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST), PO Box 88, Manchester, M60 1QD, United Kingdom
Abstract: A new more efficient solar heating/cooling system has been developed for houses and buildings by an EU co-financed SOLASTORE (5FW ENERGIE) project with a consortium of partners from France, Spain, Portugal and the UK. It is targeting a considerable reduction of CO2 emission by improvement of the solar energy system efficiency and the extended utilization of the solar energy using reversible chemical reactions as energy storage. Although solar energy is considered environmentally friendly, the whole life cycle of a solar energy production has to be evaluated. The production targets for the SOLARSTORE system are potentially thousands units. This makes it very important to explore the total environmental impacts caused during its whole life cycle. This work employs Life Cycle Analysis (LCA), an ISO 14040 based technique for evaluating the total environmental impacts associated with a product, to analyse the total environmental impacts of SOLARSTORE system during its whole life cycle. The standard LCA methodology has been extended and modified to cope successfully with this task. The LCA results show the total environmental impacts to achieve 1 GJ energy by using SOLARSTORE system: global warming potential ranging in 6.3-10 kg CO2, acidification potential in 46.6-70 g SO2, eutrophication in 2.1-3.1 g phosphate and photochemical oxidant in 0.99-1.5 g C2H4. The raw material acquisition processes contribute 99% to the total environmental impacts. A LCA based comparison has been made analysing the total environmental impacts of a traditional solar heating system, a traditional fossil fuel heating system and SOLARSTORE system. It shows that SOLARSTORE provides a better solution for reduction of negative environmental impacts by using solar energy. © 2003 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Dimitroulakos G., Milidonis A., Galanis M.D., Theodoridis G., Goutis C.E., Catthoor F.
Title: Power aware data type refinement on the HIPERLAN/2
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits, and Systems
Affiliations: VLSI Design Laboratory, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Patras, Patras, Greece; Physics Department, University of Salonica, Greece; Interuniversity Micro Electronics Center (IMEC), Kapeldreef 75, B3001, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Dimitroulakos, G., VLSI Design Laboratory, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Patras, Patras, Greece; Milidonis, A., VLSI Design Laboratory, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Patras, Patras, Greece; Galanis, M.D., VLSI Design Laboratory, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Patras, Patras, Greece; Theodoridis, G., Physics Department, University of Salonica, Greece; Goutis, C.E., VLSI Design Laboratory, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Patras, Patras, Greece; Catthoor, F., Interuniversity Micro Electronics Center (IMEC), Kapeldreef 75, B3001, Belgium
Abstract: A power aware data type refinement performed on the Data Link Control layer of the HIPERLAN 2 protocol is presented. Applying static and dynamic analysis on the initial specification code the crucial data types in terms of memory access and storage are identified. Then proper data structures are selected and an efficient memory architecture is derived meeting the time constraints and reducing the energy of the system's memories. Experimental results show a reduction of the memory energy consumption up to 37% compared with the energy consumption of the memory architecture imposed by the initial specification code. © 2003 IEEE.

Title: Using a change-management approach to promote customer-centered design
Source title: Proceedings of the 2003 Conference on Designing for User Experiences, DUX '03
Affiliations: Hewlett-Packard Company, 18110 SE 34th St., Vancouver, WA 98607, United States; Hewlett-Packard Ltd., Filton Road, Stoke-Gifford Bristol, BS348QZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sato, S., Hewlett-Packard Company, 18110 SE 34th St., Vancouver, WA 98607, United States; Panton, A., Hewlett-Packard Ltd., Filton Road, Stoke-Gifford Bristol, BS348QZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Future business success is strongly linked to establishing and sustaining a superior customer experience. Through an internal company wide initiative called Total Customer Experience, Hewlett-Packard (HP) has focused on the delivery of a superior customer experience as a differentiating advantage. Using a proven change-management framework, the authors promoted a customer-centered approach to product development in designing tape drive products. This paper discusses the approach taken within the HP Tape Storage Division in Bristol, UK to introduce and successfully institutionalize customer-centered design within the tape drive development function. Compared to designing the customer-centered approach, the change-management process accounted for a major part of the authorsí time and energy. Introducing the customer-centered design approach at the appropriate phase in the change-management process was crucial to its adoption. © 2003 ACM.

Abstract: The proceedings contains 95 papers from the conference on ISLPED'03 : Proceedings of the 2003 International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design. The topics discussed include: low power requirements for future digital life style; evolution of low power electronics and its future applications; a forward body-biased low-leakage SRAM cache: device and architecture considerations; reducing translation lookaside buffer active power; a power-aware SWDR cell for reducing cache write power and a noise tolerant cache design to reduce gate and sub-threshold leakage in the nanometer regime.

Authors: Schulze Chr., Hahn J., Munder F., Für Chr.
Title: Crushing of wet feed grain
Source title: VDI Berichte
Affiliations: Humboldt-Universität Berlin, Germany; Institue of Agricultural Engineering Potsdam-Bornim, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schulze, Chr., Humboldt-Universität Berlin, Germany; Hahn, J., Humboldt-Universität Berlin, Germany; Munder, F., Institue of Agricultural Engineering Potsdam-Bornim, Germany; Für, Chr., Institue of Agricultural Engineering Potsdam-Bornim, Germany
Abstract: The preservation of wet feed grain is an alternative to the normal preservation by drying. In the process of preservation of crushed wet feed grain, the mass throughput of harvest and crushing should be adjusted to each other to avoid an expensive intermediate storage. Up to now, the used mills reach this throughput only by an unacceptable use of technology. By using Korncracker higher throughputs are expected. During the first measurements, high throughput with low energy consumption by crushing wheat and rye was reached.

Authors: Suppes G.J., Goff M.J., Lopes S.
Title: Use of renewable phase change materials to reduce carbon dioxide emissions
Source title: ACS Division of Environmental Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, W2028 Engineering Bldg, East, Columbia, MO 65211, United States
Authors with affiliations: Suppes, G.J., Department of Chemical Engineering, W2028 Engineering Bldg, East, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Goff, M.J., Department of Chemical Engineering, W2028 Engineering Bldg, East, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Lopes, S., Department of Chemical Engineering, W2028 Engineering Bldg, East, Columbia, MO 65211, United States
Abstract: Phase change materials (PCM) can reduce heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) costs by a number of different mechanisms, including eliminating air conditioning costs by storing nighttime coolness for use during the day, eliminating heating costs by storing daytime warmness for use during the night, and by load-shifting of electricity through thermal storage. A discussion covers the synthesis of PCM from beef tallow and the cost and greenhouse gas savings from their use; CO2 emissions by source in the US; two important performance advantages of thermal over battery, water, or other storage options when evaluating chemicals for energy storage; peak load shifting, the easiest application of phase change materials and is also the application capable of producing the greatest reductions in CO2 emissions; and eliminating HVAC electrical power or fossil fuel loads in some instances, e.g., to store solar energy accumulated during the day and used during the night. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 6th Annual Green Chemistry and Engineering Conference (Washington, D.C. 6/24-27/2003).

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Offshore LNG terminals meet environmental, security goals
Source title: ENR (Engineering News-Record)
Abstract: El Paso Corp.'s Energy Bridge and ChevronTexaco have announced plans to establish offshore regasification terminals for LNG in the Gulf of Mexico. El Paso Corp.'s Energy Bridge would regasify LNG aboard ship on the open sea, while ChevronTexaco's Port Pelican project uses a concrete island for its regasiflcation equipment and storage. EP plans to build the Energy Bridge 116 miles off the coast of Louisiana at an estimated cost of $50 million. ChevronTexaco's Port Pelican is made up of two concrete gravity-based structures, embedded in the sea floor, that extend above water level and the wave-impact zone. The company plans to use 42-in.-dia offshore pipeline to transport the gas from the terminal, connecting to the Henry Flood Gas Gathering System. Offshore regasification plans have spread beyond the Gulf of Mexico as well, as Italian gas pipeline company OLT Offshore's plans for an offshore terminal near Livorno, Italy.

Authors: Gupta T.K.S.P., Verma S.S.
Title: Nanomagnetic materials: A review
Source title: 2003 Nanotechnology Conference and Trade Show - Nanotech 2003
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Sant Longowal Inst. Eng./Technol., Longowal-148 106 (Sangrur), India
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, T.K.S.P., Department of Physics, Sant Longowal Inst. Eng./Technol., Longowal-148 106 (Sangrur), India; Verma, S.S., Department of Physics, Sant Longowal Inst. Eng./Technol., Longowal-148 106 (Sangrur), India
Abstract: Nanotechnology and nanostructured materials have the potential to significantly impact energy efficiency, storage, and production. Such applications can be used to monitor and remediate environmental problems; curb emissions from a wide range of sources; and develop new, "green" processing technologies that minimize the generation of undesirable by-product effluents. As well as being an excellent experimental means of studying fundamental magnetic phenomena, these low dimensionality magnets may in the future form the basis of technologies (information storage, permanent magnets, color printers, etc.). Highlighted areas include the quest for magneto-electronics and the importance of novel interfacial magnetic coupling phenomena. Nanomagnetism includes the artificial structuring of magnetic materials on a sub micron level and natural occurring magnetic entities such as molecules and clusters. Here the emphasis will be on the macroscopic behaviors found in single domains of quantum spins, quantum coherence, dissipation and tunneling of magnetization, and disorder and frustration effects. Nanometer-sized magnetic particles are situated at the frontier between classical and quantum magnetism.
Author Keywords: Nanomagnets; Nanostructures; Nanotechnology

Abstract: Renewable energy systems (RES) have to be designed specifically for both site and application. A comparison between different RES with the aim of evaluating the performance and the relative merits of the systems as a whole and/or their components is therefore difficult. As part of the BENCHMARKING project which is an international project carried out by 10 European research organisations, NREL (US) and the Australian Cooperative Research Centre, a proposal is here presented on how to measure performance, compress data and evaluate them in a standardised form, i.e. a standard evaluation report (SER). It covers all types of renewable energy systems at any location and for any application. Its primary aim is to allow a comparison of RES and their key components.

Abstract: There is an increasing acceptance for the use of renewable energy sources to achieve a sustainable power supply. In our contribution we present a vision of new energy supply structures and a cluster of projects supported by the European Commission which address the integration of renewable energy sources (RES) and distributed generation (DG) into the electricity grid.
