Authors: Conley W.G., Raman A., Krousgrill C.M.
Title: Nonlinear dynamical aspects of atomic scale friction
Source title: 2003 Nanotechnology Conference and Trade Show - Nanotech 2003
Affiliations: Purdue Univ. Sch. of Mech. Eng., 585 Purdue Mall, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Authors with affiliations: Conley, W.G., Purdue Univ. Sch. of Mech. Eng., 585 Purdue Mall, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States; Raman, A., Purdue Univ. Sch. of Mech. Eng., 585 Purdue Mall, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States; Krousgrill, C.M., Purdue Univ. Sch. of Mech. Eng., 585 Purdue Mall, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Abstract: This work presents a detailed computational and an-alytical investigation of Tomlinson's model for atomic scale dry friction. The model describes a prototypical mechanism of energy dissipation from an atom dragged across a periodic atomic lattice and is often used to model the dynamics of friction force microscope tips and for the atomistic sliding of adsorbate layers on surfaces. While a number of articles in the literature utilize this model, there is little work in the literature that utilizes the computational and theoretical tools of modern nonlinear dynamics in analyzing this model. This research demonstrates that the use of computational nonlinear dynamics techniques provides a deep insight into the mechanisms of chaotic stick-slip phenomena and the speed dependence of frictional forces of atomic scale friction.
Author Keywords: Atomic-Scale; Dynamics; Friction; Nanoscale; Nonlinear
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Computer simulation; Data storage equipment; Friction; Lubrication; Microelectromechanical devices; Surface treatment; Atomic-scale; Elastic asperity; Friction force microcantilever (FFM); Tomlinson's model; Nonlinear systems

Authors: Woyte A., Belmans R., Nijs J.
Title: Analysing short-time irradiance fluctuations by their characteristic time scales
Source title: Proceedings of the 3rd World Conference on Photovoltaic Energy Conversion
Affiliations: Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, ESAT-ELECTA, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Photovoltech SA, C/o IMEC Vzw, K.U.Leuven, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Woyte, A., Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, ESAT-ELECTA, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Belmans, R., Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, ESAT-ELECTA, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Nijs, J., Photovoltech SA, C/o IMEC Vzw, K.U.Leuven, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: In moderate climates short time fluctuations in solar irradiance and their impact on the distribution grids will become an important issue with regard to future large scale application of embedded photovoltaic systems. The approach that is presented here uses the method of time-scale decomposition of the solar irradiance in order to determine the power content of fluctuations according to their amplitude, characteristic time of persistence, and frequency of occurrence. The 'fluctuation power index' and 'fluctuation energy index' are defined as a measure for the occurrence of fluctuations of a particular persistence on an annual basis. Based on values for the squared fluctuation index for Belgium, it is indicated how a suitable strategy for storage and voltage control can be determined.
Index Keywords: Distribution grids; Low-voltage grids; Root mean square (RMS); Solar irradiance; Electric potential; Electric power distribution; Fourier transforms; Installation; Natural frequencies; Solar radiation; Wavelet transforms; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Loechelt G.H., Sellers J., Morgan J., Azam M.
Title: Carrier transit time optimization of a high speed bipolar transistor using numerical device simulation
Source title: 2003 Nanotechnology Conference and Trade Show - Nanotech 2003
Affiliations: ON Semiconductor, Mail Drop AE100, 5005 East McDowell Road, Phoenix, AZ 85008, United States
Authors with affiliations: Loechelt, G.H., ON Semiconductor, Mail Drop AE100, 5005 East McDowell Road, Phoenix, AZ 85008, United States; Sellers, J., ON Semiconductor, Mail Drop AE100, 5005 East McDowell Road, Phoenix, AZ 85008, United States; Morgan, J., ON Semiconductor, Mail Drop AE100, 5005 East McDowell Road, Phoenix, AZ 85008, United States; Azam, M., ON Semiconductor, Mail Drop AE100, 5005 East McDowell Road, Phoenix, AZ 85008, United States
Abstract: The doping profile of a high speed silicon NPN bipolar junction transistor (BJT) was optimized using numerical device simulation (TCAD). A technique was employed in which the transient charge storage in the device was related to its carrier transit time, thereby providing a graphic demonstration of the impact of high carrier injection effects on the speed performance of the device. This knowledge enabled the engineering of a selectively implanted collector (SIC), which dramatically improved the switching frequency of the transistor over an identical device with a low-doped epi collector. The debiasing effect of the intrinsic collector resistance was also investigated for both devices. A comparison to preliminary measured electrical data is made for the transistor with the SIC.
Author Keywords: Bipolar transistor; Carrier transit time; Charge storage; Device simulation; Profile optimization
Index Keywords: Carrier temperature; Carrier transit time; Device simulation; Profile optimization; Carrier concentration; Computer simulation; Electric charge; Energy gap; Hydrodynamics; Secondary ion mass spectrometry; Semiconductor doping; Semiconductor junctions; Bipolar transistors

Affiliations: CEA-GENEC, 13108 St. Paul Lez Durance, France
Authors with affiliations: Perrin, M., CEA-GENEC, 13108 St. Paul Lez Durance, France; Malbranche, P., CEA-GENEC, 13108 St. Paul Lez Durance, France; Mattera, F., CEA-GENEC, 13108 St. Paul Lez Durance, France; Simonin, L., CEA-GENEC, 13108 St. Paul Lez Durance, France; Sauer, D.U.; Lailler, P.; Joessen, A.; Willer, B.; Dahlen, M.; Ruddell, A.; Cyphelly, I.; Tassin, N.; Bruesewitz, M.
Abstract: In order to increase the use of renewable energies, the topic of RE storage is a critical issue. Within the European thematic network INVESTIRE, nine different technologies are evaluated for the storage of renewable energy, either in stand-alone or in grid-connected applications. In this paper, the strains put by a PV application on a storage function are defined with reference to existing systems. Furthermore, the way different storage technologies can answer these needs is evaluated. The technologies assessed are lead/acid, lithium systems, double-layer capacitors, nickel systems, electrolyser/ hydrogen storage/ fuel-cell associations, flywheels, redox flow batteries, compressed air and metal-air systems. The analysis will allow the assessment of hybridising possibilities and of future RTD goals.
Index Keywords: Double layer capacitors; Electrolyzers; Redox flow batteries; Capacitors; Energy storage; Fuel cells; Renewable energy resources; Scattering; Solar power generation; Wind power; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: King R.J., Warner C.
Title: Solar Decathlon: Energy we can live with
Source title: Proceedings of the 3rd World Conference on Photovoltaic Energy Conversion
Affiliations: Photovoltaic R and D Program, U.S. Department of Energy, 1000 Independence Avenue, SW, Washington, DC 20585, United States; National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO 80401, United States
Authors with affiliations: King, R.J., Photovoltaic R and D Program, U.S. Department of Energy, 1000 Independence Avenue, SW, Washington, DC 20585, United States; Warner, C., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO 80401, United States
Abstract: The Solar Decathlon is a competition to design, build and operate the most effective and attractive house powered solely by the sun. The U.S. Department of Energy proudly sponsors the international competition for college level students. The competition is designed to showcase "energy we can live with", meaning solar and energy efficiency technologies that are not only viable today, but are also unobtrusive features of homes that fit gracefully into our modern lifestyles. Fourteen university teams from the U.S., including Puerto Rico, competed in the 2002 Solar Decathlon at the National Mall in Washington, D.C. Construction of the solar village began on September 19 th, 2002. Seven days later on September 26 th, the Solar Decathlon began and ten days of intense competition followed. On Saturday, October 5 th, the University of Colorado at Boulder won the first ever competition.
Index Keywords: Energy balances; Energy demands; Energy performance; Solar decathlon; Computer simulation; Cooling; Energy storage; Fossil fuels; Graphic methods; Space heating; Water; Websites; Solar energy

Title: An optimal design and use of solar home system in Mongolia
Source title: Proceedings of the 3rd World Conference on Photovoltaic Energy Conversion

Abstract: This paper presents the results of study related into optimal design and use of Solar Home System (SHS) in Mongolia. Over recent years, SHS becomes widely used by nomadic households in Mongolia. In the other hand, there exists an increasing problem of system component failure, low battery lifetime and users' dissatisfaction. To overcome the present problem, a user training manual and demand-side load management seems to be necessary for enhance lifetime and minimize failures of SHS. The time-serial simulation results shows possibilities to gain more performance ratio of SHS, which sized design parameter method. The optimal load table to support DSM for user proposed in the case of Mongolian central area.

Authors: Strauss Ph., Engler A.
Title: AC coupled PV hybrid systems and micro grids - State of the art and future trends
Source title: Proceedings of the 3rd World Conference on Photovoltaic Energy Conversion
Affiliations: Division of Engineering Electronics, Inst. Solare E.E.V., Königstor 59, 34119 Kassel, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Strauss, Ph., Division of Engineering Electronics, Inst. Solare E.E.V., Königstor 59, 34119 Kassel, Germany; Engler, A., Division of Engineering Electronics, Inst. Solare E.E.V., Königstor 59, 34119 Kassel, Germany
Abstract: The consequent AC-coupling of generators, storage units and loads for setting up hybrid systems or hybrid micro grids is under investigation at ISET since more than ten years. After the development of suitable components like the PV-inverter Sunny Boy® and the battery inverter Sunny Island ®1 and after the implementation of new control concepts for parallel operation, these systems can be easily set up with series produced components. This paper describes the principals of the Modular Systems Technology and shows some examples of operating hybrid micro grids containing AC-PV, AC-battery power units, wind turbines and diesel gensets. Further developments and aims are described including the distributed generation and energy storage in micro grids as well as the stepwise interconnection of micro grids. A first approach for the control and management of disconnecting houses or grid parts which make use of their distributed energy generators or storage units for emergency power will be outlined.
Index Keywords: Battery inverters; Diesel generators; Energy converters; Hybrid systems; Distributed parameter control systems; Electric generators; Electric inverters; Energy conversion; Energy resources; Energy storage; Hybrid computers; Solar radiation; Photovoltaic effects

Authors: Yang C.-Z., Dai X.-L., Deng Q.-L., Ryozo O., Shinsuke K., Dai X.-Z., Yao S.-C.
Title: Experimental study on ground source heat pump system utilizing groundwater in the heating mode
Source title: Proceeding of the 2003 Energy and Environment
Affiliations: Coll. of Civil Eng., Hunan Univ., Changsha 410082, China; Production Technol. Inst., Tokyo Univ., Tokyo, Japan; Hunan Arch. Design Inst., Changsha 410000, China
Authors with affiliations: Yang, C.-Z., Coll. of Civil Eng., Hunan Univ., Changsha 410082, China; Dai, X.-L., Coll. of Civil Eng., Hunan Univ., Changsha 410082, China; Deng, Q.-L., Coll. of Civil Eng., Hunan Univ., Changsha 410082, China; Ryozo, O., Production Technol. Inst., Tokyo Univ., Tokyo, Japan; Shinsuke, K., Production Technol. Inst., Tokyo Univ., Tokyo, Japan; Dai, X.-Z., Hunan Arch. Design Inst., Changsha 410000, China; Yao, S.-C., Hunan Arch. Design Inst., Changsha 410000, China
Abstract: With the increasingly serious energy and environmental problems, more and more HVAC systems have been in service in World, which have significant influence upon energy and environment. The ground water heat pump (GWHP) system utilizes groundwater with constant temperature to work, so it is hardly influenced by the outside weather conditions, and it does not harm to the environment either. The paper surveys a GWHP system that is running in the heating mode in middle and lower reaches of the Changjiang River in China. This system is connected in parallel by two ground source heat pump (GSHP) units whose rated heating capacities are 40 kilowatt and 100 kilowatt respectively. In this experiment, the quantity, quality and temperature of the circulating water in every system, electric consumption and the outside weather conditions and so on are investigated. Based on the tested data, the operating characteristic of this system in the heating mode on the whole is understood, and how these parameters influence the coefficient of performance (COP) of the heat pump units are analyzed. At the same time the GSHP system is compared with the air-source heat pump (ASHP) system and the boiler heating system in energy saving. All the experimental results can also provide some reference values for the design, manufacture and operation of the GSHP systems further.
Author Keywords: Ground source heat pump; Groundwater; Operating characteristic
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Groundwater resources; Electric consumption; Ground source heat pump; Heating mode; Operating characteristic; Heat pump systems

Abstract: The importance of life sciences, water resources and biological systems, is discussed. Life science comprise an interdisciplinary science of nature, of mankind and its behavior. Water is used in most important storage, converter and transporter of energy in nature and technology. Biological systems are open system. They exchange permanently energy, matter and information with their environment.

Authors: Pagano E., Piegari L., Tricoli P.
Title: Ultracap-based new electrical drives for off-road vehicles and rovers
Source title: VDI Berichte
Authors with affiliations: Pagano, E.; Piegari, L.; Tricoli, P.
Abstract: By means of results of experimental tests and of theoretical considerations the paper analyses the benefits given by supercaps used as auxiliary supplying devices in road and off-road electrical vehicles. The authors show how small sets of supercaps increase electrochemical batteries life and fuel distance, because they are capable of supporting transient current peaks and of regenerating electrical energy with higher efficiency than traditional batteries. Due to the characteristics of supercaps and electrical batteries, i.e. mainly to their inner resistances, to their energy/weight and energy/volume ratios the compound use of both components must be properly balanced to obtain concrete improvements of system performances. A sample designing procedure is suggested in the paper, based on the duty-cycles of vehicles. It evaluates the battery and supercap ratings required to obtain a compound set which covers the full power requested by the load without overloading the battery.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric resistance; Electric vehicles; Electrochemistry; Fuels; Electrochemical batteries; Rovers; Supercaps; Supplying devices; Off road vehicles

Authors: Schneider D., Siemroth P.
Title: Characterizing ultra-thin films by laser-acoustics
Source title: VDI Berichte
Affiliations: Fraunhofer Inst. F. Werkstoff-/S., Dresden, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schneider, D., Fraunhofer Inst. F. Werkstoff-/S., Dresden, Germany; Siemroth, P., Fraunhofer Inst. F. Werkstoff-/S., Dresden, Germany
Abstract: For protecting against damage, computer hard disks have to be coated by hard films. The increasing data density requires reducing the film thickness down to few nano-meters due to the decreasing distance between the write-read head and the disk. This can only be realized using ultra-thin films of enhanced performance for wear and corrosion protecting. The excellent properties of amorphous carbon films termed diamond-like carbon (DLC) have turned to be suitable for this application. The mechanical testing of these ultra-thin and super-hard films is a challenge for the available test methods. Efforts have been done to adapt the laser-acoustic method to the requirements of testing ultra-thin films. The laser-acoustic method yields the Young's modulus, revealing the effect of varying bonding structure of the material, porosity and other micro-defects, including insufficient adhesion. For diamond-like carbon material, Young's modulus correlates with the fraction of tetrahedral sp 3-bonds causing its high hardness and excellent wear behavior. The films were deposited by high current pulsed vacuum arc discharges. The effects of the substrate temperature during the deposition and the film thickness were studied. The minimum film thickness was less than 3 nm.
Index Keywords: Cathode ray oscilloscopes; Computer hardware; Diamond like carbon films; Elastic moduli; Hard disk storage; Hardness; Laser pulses; Spectrum analysis; Stiffness; Surface waves; Thermal effects; Thickness measurement; Transducers; Carbon films; Laser-acoustic method; Phase velocity; Pulse energy; Thin films

Authors: Choy F.K., Hamzah F.
Title: Rainfall enhancement for increasing power generation at the Temengor Hydroelectric Power Station, Malaysia - A preliminary assessment
Source title: Sustainable World
Affiliations: Tenaga Nasional Berhad, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Choy, F.K., Tenaga Nasional Berhad, Malaysia; Hamzah, F., Tenaga Nasional Berhad, Malaysia
Abstract: The Temengor Hydroelectric Project (348 MW) was constructed between 1974 and 1978, it is one of the four major hydro projects built on the upper Sungai Perak. The other three projects are namely Bersia (72 MW), Kenering (120 MW) and Chenderoh (40 MW). The electricity demand in Peninsular Malaysia experienced an average annual growth rate of about 13% to 14% in the early and mid-nineties prior to the outbreak of the financial crisis in 1997. Subsequent to the financial crisis, there was a substantial drop in the electricity demand for the years 1997/98 and 1998/99. The demand for electricity then rapidly increased by more than 11% in 1999/2000. However, a number of independent power producers (IPP) have already decided to defer the construction of their proposed power plants due to problems resulting from the financial crisis. This leads to the reduction in the reserve margin of generation capacity and constraint on the system operation. To ensure the system reliability, the decision was made to do cloud seeding to enhance rainfall over the Temengor's catchment as a short-term measure. The purpose is to fill up the Temengor reservoir with water and to raise its water level to as close to the full supply level as possible, so that there is readily available energy reserve from the incremental water storage. This paper presents a preliminary assessment of the cloud seeding operation carried out over the Temengor catchment for a total period of four months in two sessions in 2001.
Index Keywords: Catchments; Electric power generation; Electricity; Flood control; Problem solving; Project management; Rain; Financial crisis; Rainfall enhancement; Supply level; System reliability; Hydroelectric power plants

Authors: Wang L., Ren X.J., Shatil G.
Title: Assessment of fatigue and fracture strength of transportation energy storage flywheel using finite element simulation
Source title: Structures and Materials
Affiliations: Structural Integrity Group, CEMS, University of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wang, L., Structural Integrity Group, CEMS, University of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom; Ren, X.J., Structural Integrity Group, CEMS, University of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom; Shatil, G., Structural Integrity Group, CEMS, University of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: The safety of an energy storage flywheel for a light rail transportation system was assessed using structural and damage tolerance analyses. The flywheel's strength was estimated using a detailed 3-D finite element (FE) simulation incorporating contact surfaces and sub-modelling techniques. Critical areas were identified near the bolt's holes and, although the simulated strength was considered safe under normal operation (about 3000 RPM), it was conceived that failure due to fracture under extreme conditions such as over-speed may occur. Crack growth at these critical locations near the disk's bolt's holes was considered in an elastic fracture analysis. For three crack positions the maximum stress intensity factor (Kmax) was calculated by conducting separate simulations for different crack lengths. The material fracture resistance was compared to the FE results using an R-curve procedure and the critical crack lengths to cause fracture were obtained. The critical cracks were then used to predict the life of the flywheel in a fatigue crack growth rate analysis. Following the investigation a structural integrity analysis was introduced into the design process for further development.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Crack propagation; Elasticity; Finite element method; Flywheels; Fracture toughness; Light rail transit; Damage tolerance analysis; Light rail transportation systems; Transportation energy storage flywheels; Fatigue of materials

Authors: Wang W., Zhang S.Z., Zhou X.L., Chen G.M.
Title: Experimental study on osmotic properties of human cord blood stem cell exposed to dimethyl sulfoxide
Source title: Proceedings of the 2003 International Conference on Cryogenics and Refrigeration
Affiliations: Refrigeration Inst., Zhejiang Univ., Hangzhou 310027, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, W., Refrigeration Inst., Zhejiang Univ., Hangzhou 310027, China; Zhang, S.Z., Refrigeration Inst., Zhejiang Univ., Hangzhou 310027, China; Zhou, X.L., Refrigeration Inst., Zhejiang Univ., Hangzhou 310027, China; Chen, G.M., Refrigeration Inst., Zhejiang Univ., Hangzhou 310027, China
Abstract: Study on the osmotic properties of cells in the presence of cryoprotectant facilitates the design of cryopreservation protocols. The osmotic properties of human cord blood stem cell (HCBSC) are experimentally studied with a diffusion chamber. The inactive volume of HCBSC is determined to be 52±7%. With an Arrhemius assumption, the permeability to water at reference temperature 0°C is determined to be 5.05×10-14 m3/N·s, and the activation energy is 58.6 kJ/mol. The permeability to dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) at room temperature 25°C is 4.22×10-8m/s and the corresponding activation energy is 12.9 kJ/mol. The presence of DMSO is found to decrease the permeability of the cell membrane to water.
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Cell membranes; Low temperature operations; Transplants; Water; Cryobiophysical properties; Cryoprotectant facilitates; Cryopteservation protocols; Dimethyl sulfoxide; Human cord blood stem cell; Long term storage; Osmotic properties; Biological materials preservation

Authors: Kazuhiko M.
Title: Energy storage system by using lithium-bromide solution
Source title: Proceedings of the 2003 International Conference on Cryogenics and Refrigeration
Affiliations: Dept. of Mech. Eng., Faulty of Eng., Tokyo Metropolitan Univ., 1-1, Minami-osawa, Hachioji, Tokyo, 192-0397, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kazuhiko, M., Dept. of Mech. Eng., Faulty of Eng., Tokyo Metropolitan Univ., 1-1, Minami-osawa, Hachioji, Tokyo, 192-0397, Japan
Abstract: It is suggested effective energy utilization by concentrating and storage of working fluid for absorption refrigeration systems using surplus heat or cheap electricity in midnight. Concentrating of lithium-bromide aqueous solution of one of the working fluid for absorption refrigeration systems has effect as storage of evaporative latent heat of water. 75 wt% lithium-bromide aqueous solution can absorb water becoming thin to 58 wt%, and mean storage of water latent heat of 730 kJ/kg. This fact effects over twice of an ice thermal storage system because that is about 323 kJ/kg (IPF=0.9). Stocked high concentrate lithium-bromide aqueous solution can be used on absorption refrigeration systems in daytime and cut peak of electricity. An energy storage system by using lithium-bromide aqueous solution is estimated the possibility of progress comparing with an ice thermal storage system. The latent heat, volume of a system, merits or demerits and others are discussed.
Index Keywords: Absorption; Bromine compounds; Cooling systems; Crystallization; Energy utilization; Lithium; Solutions; Absorption refrigeration systems; Ice thermal storage systems; Lithium bromide aqueous solution; Water latent heat; Working fluids; Energy storage

Authors: Fu Z., Li N., Tang G., Gong G.
Title: Exergy analysis of underground aquifer thermal energy storage systems
Source title: Proceedings of the 2003 4th International Symposium on Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning
Affiliations: College of Civil Eng., Hu'nan Univ., Changsha 410082, China
Authors with affiliations: Fu, Z., College of Civil Eng., Hu'nan Univ., Changsha 410082, China; Li, N., College of Civil Eng., Hu'nan Univ., Changsha 410082, China; Tang, G., College of Civil Eng., Hu'nan Univ., Changsha 410082, China; Gong, G., College of Civil Eng., Hu'nan Univ., Changsha 410082, China
Abstract: While researching on energy balance of underground aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) systems, energy efficiency or energy recovery factor, defined by the first-law in thermodynamics and based on energy quantities, are found to be misleading. After introducing the principles and benefits of exergy analysis, exergy equations of ATES systems are derived in the paper. Then calculation algorithms incorporating energy and exergy efficiencies into computer programs are discussed. Three operation strategies are thus simulated utilizing the computer code. Finally, simulation results are analyzed and a more appropriate exergy efficiency, taking electricity consumption of pumps into account, is put forward.

Abstract: The heat transfer process is analyzed based on the character of phase-change heat transfer. The bundle model is established on the basis of hypothesis. Through solving the model with the method of thermal resistance net, the effect of structure parameters such as material of coils, diameter of coils and pitch between tubes are analyzed. Abstract: Chaira Underground Pumped Storage Power Station is located in the area of the Chaira Resort, approximately 100 km south-east of Sofia, Bulgaria. Waste heat is released by the water cooling system for transformer oil. Cooling water for transformers oil coolers enters the heat pump evaporator through the heat exchanger and buffer tanks. Hot water from the condenser will be delivered by circulation pumps to the accumulator and the district heating system. In order to save electric energy, the heat pump was operated predominantly during the night hours and heat can be accumulated in an accumulator with a storage capacity of 1500 m3. This feasibility study presents technical and economical evaluations of the alternative heat sources energy efficiency.

Authors: Zhou W., Zhou J., Chen G.
Title: Experimental study on heat transfer characteristics of conductive plastic ice-on-coil
Source title: Proceedings of the 2003 International Conference on Cryogenics and Refrigeration
Affiliations: Cryogenics Lab., Zhejiang Univ., Hangzhou 310027, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, W., Cryogenics Lab., Zhejiang Univ., Hangzhou 310027, China; Zhou, J., Cryogenics Lab., Zhejiang Univ., Hangzhou 310027, China; Chen, G., Cryogenics Lab., Zhejiang Univ., Hangzhou 310027, China
Abstract: Ice-on-coil thermal storage tank is widely used in ice thermal storage air conditioning system, in which glycol water is usually used as the cooling medium. However, glycol water has negative effect on the long-term stability of the traditional metal ice-on-coil due to its corrosiveness. This paper proposes to use a kind of novel conductive plastics instead of traditional metals as tube material. In order to testify the feasibility of conductive plastic ice-on-coil, an experimental apparatus is built to study its heat transfer characteristics during both the charging and discharging periods. Experimental results show that the heat transfer characteristics are similar to those of metal one. So conductive plastic ice-on-coil can not only fulfill the demands of engineering applications, but also extend the service life because of its good anti-corrosiveness.

Authors: Iwata T., Kitano H., Sagara K.
Title: Mixing model for parallel type of temperature-stratified water thermal storage tank
Source title: Proceedings of the 2003 4th International Symposium on Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning
Affiliations: Dept. of Arch., Faculty of Eng., Mie Univ., 1515 Kamihama-cho, Tsu, Mie 514-8507, Japan; Dept. of Arch. Eng., Graduate Sch. of Eng., Osaka Univ., 2-1 Yamadaoka, Suita, Osaka 565-0871, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Iwata, T., Dept. of Arch., Faculty of Eng., Mie Univ., 1515 Kamihama-cho, Tsu, Mie 514-8507, Japan; Kitano, H., Dept. of Arch., Faculty of Eng., Mie Univ., 1515 Kamihama-cho, Tsu, Mie 514-8507, Japan; Sagara, K., Dept. of Arch. Eng., Graduate Sch. of Eng., Osaka Univ., 2-1 Yamadaoka, Suita, Osaka 565-0871, Japan
Abstract: In order to improve the water thermal storage performance, it is trying to replace the conventional type in which tanks are connected in series into the parallel type of temperature-stratified thermal storage tank having its own inlet and outlet. Though it is difficult to keep the balance of input/output water flow rate and stored heat in each tank, the connecting holes through partition between tanks are useful to keep the balance of stored heat. A mixing model which allows to study the effect of connecting holes through tank partition in the parallel type of temperature-stratified water thermal storage tank is presented. The mixing model consists of several sub-models; a complete mixing model, a one-dimensional diffusion model, a plume model and a connecting hole model. The accuracy of the mixing model was verified by comparing with experimental data, and the size and position of connecting holes were studied with simulation using this mixing model.
Author Keywords: Model; Parallel; Stratification; Thermal energy storage; Water
Index Keywords: One dimensional; Thermal stratification; Thermal energy storage; Water flow rate; Heat storage

Authors: Lin K., Zhang Y., Xu X., Di H., Qin P., Yang R.
Title: Experimental study of under-floor electric heating system with shape-stabilized PCM plates
Source title: Proceedings of the 2003 4th International Symposium on Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning
Affiliations: Dept. of Building Sci., Tsinghua Univ., Beijing 100084, China; Dept. of Chem. Eng., Tsinghua Univ., Beijing 100084, China

Eng., Tsinghua Univ., Beijing 100084, China; Yang, R., Dept. of Building Sci., Tsinghua Univ., Beijing 100084, China, Dept. of Chem. Eng., Tsinghua Univ., Beijing 100084, China
Abstract: This paper put forward a kind of under-floor electric heating system with shape-stabilized PCM plates. Different from conventional PCM, shape-stabilized PCM can keep the shape unchanged during phase change process. Therefore, the PCM leakage danger can be avoided. This system can charge heat by using cheap nighttime electricity and discharge the heat stored at daytime. The thermal physical properties of shape-stabilized PCM developed by us were measured. A prototype room with this system was set up in Beijing to testify its thermal performance and feasibility of this heating mode. The results show that temperature of the PCM plates upper surface can be kept near the phase transition temperature in whole day and a lot of off-peak period electricity can be used for space heating in stead of using peak period electricity, which lowers the electricity tariff.
Author Keywords: Shape-stabilized PCM; Thermal energy heat storage; Under-floor electric heating
Index Keywords: Electric power utilization; Heat storage; Phase transitions; Electricity tariff; Phase change; Thermal physical properties; Electric space heating

Authors: Zheng M., Zhi Y.S., Lin Y.
Title: Study of heating and cooling system with solar heat soil storage in sever cold area
Source title: Proceedings of the 2003 4th International Symposium on Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning
Affiliations: Harbin Inst. of Technol., The No. 202 Haihe Road, Harbin 150090, China
Authors with affiliations: Zheng, M., Harbin Inst. of Technol., The No. 202 Haihe Road, Harbin 150090, China; Zhi, Y.S., Harbin Inst. of Technol., The No. 202 Haihe Road, Harbin 150090, China; Lin, Y., Harbin Inst. of Technol., The No. 202 Haihe Road, Harbin 150090, China
Abstract: The article presents study about the system of the solar heat, the soil thermal storage and the ground-source heat pumps which were made two years ago in HIT. This system is divided into two parts. One is heating system, which directly carries solar energy to soil for thermal storage after heating in winter until the next winter. The other part is heating and cooling system. It doesn't immediately store the heat after heating, but the cool is directly taken out of soil for cooling in summer by the exchangers. The process of the extracted cool is also that of the thermal storage. When cooling finished, the part also stores the solar heat into soil for heating. The two parts are used together for heating in winter by GSHP and the solar hot water system. Because a lot of heat is taken out of the underground soil for heating and the lost heat is complemented by the solar heat collected in three seasons of the year and by the stored heat for cooling in summer, the temperature of the underground soil is periodically changing in one year. So it can keep thermal balance and this system can operate for the long period (many years). It was proved in the experiment that the above-mentioned system has good heating and cooling effect.
Author Keywords: Ground-source heat pump; Heating and cooling system; Solar energy
Index Keywords: Cooling; Heat losses; Heat pump systems; Heat storage; Soils; Solar energy; Soil thermal storage; Thermal balance; Space heating

Authors: Dai Y., Wang R.
Title: Simulation study of a solar liquid desiccant cooling system with energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the 2003 International Conference on Cryogenics and Refrigeration
Affiliations: Inst. of Refrigeration, Shanghai Jiaotong Univ., Shanghai 200030, China
Authors with affiliations: Dai, Y., Inst. of Refrigeration, Shanghai Jiaotong Univ., Shanghai 200030, China; Wang, R., Inst. of Refrigeration, Shanghai Jiaotong Univ., Shanghai 200030, China
Abstract: A simulation study was carried out to investigate the performance of a solar assisted liquid desiccant cooling system with energy storage. The proposed system, which runs in open cycle mode, consists of a liquid desiccant dehumidifier, a solar assisted regenerator, a liquid desiccant solution storage tank, an indirect evaporative cooler, and some necessary heat recovery devices. The simulation model to estimate the performance of the proposed system was described. The dominating effects on the operation process were discussed. Also conducted is the analysis of energy storage capacity regarding calcium chloride, a cost economic liquid desiccant material.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Crystallization; Energy storage; Solar refrigeration; Calcium chloride; Open cycle modes; Simulation study; Solar liquid desiccant cooling systems; Storage capacity; Cooling systems

Authors: Sutanto D., Aware M.
Title: A novel High Temperature Super Conducting Magnetic Energy Storage (HT-SMES) using hysterisis control
Source title: Sixth International Conference on Advances in Power System Control, Operation and Management - Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Sutanto, D., Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Hong Kong; Aware, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Hong Kong
Abstract: This paper describes the design and implementation of a new High Temperature Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage System (HTS-SMES) unit consisting of a high temperature superconducting coil as the energy storage device and two power converters to provide the power conditioning system capability (PCS). Two hysterisis controllers are used, one to control the ac supply current for active filtering and maximum demand control and the other to regulate the dc capacitor voltage to control the energy in and out of the superconducting coil. A strategy to provide fast charging to the superconducting coil after discharge is proposed. The operating principles of the proposed controllers are analyzed and the feasibility and performance of the proposed HTS-SMES under different operating modes are demonstrated through simulation and experimental results.
Index Keywords: Energy storage devices; Magnetic energy storage systems; Power conditioning systems (PCS); Superconducting coils; Capacitors; Computer simulation; Electric coils; Electric inductors; Electric inverters; Electric loads; Electric potential; Energy storage; Hysteresis; Natural frequencies; Parameter estimation; Power converters; Waveform analysis; High temperature superconductors

Authors: Sutanto D., Leung K.K.
Title: Alternative unified power flow controller using energy storage
Source title: Sixth International Conference on Advances in Power System Control, Operation and Management - Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Sutanto, D., Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Hong Kong; Leung, K.K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Hong Kong
Abstract: This paper describes a new topology of an intelligent power compensation system utilizing energy storage to enhance power system performance and reliability. The system can also provide all the benefits associated with a Unified Power Flow Controller (UPFC). In one single device, the alternative Unified Power Flow Controller (AUPFC) can provide (i) fast control of real and reactive power along a transmission corridor, (ii) phase angle control, (iii) series compensation, (iv) shunt reactive power compensation, (v) harmonic compensation, (vi) load leveling, (vii) voltage stability improvement and (viii) back-up supply. These UPFC's can provide improved power system operation and control, added system security and reduced power system losses.
Index Keywords: Flexible AC transmission systems (FACTS); Intelligent systems; Thyristor series compensation systems (TSCS); Unified power flow controllers (UPFC); Computational methods; Electric lines; Energy management; Energy storage; Large scale systems; Loading; Mathematical models; Reliability; Thyristors; Topology; Vectors; Voltage control; Control equipment

Authors: Marques S.R., Onisto H.J., Tavares P.F.
Title: Filling pattern measurement in the LNLS storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: LNLS, Campinas, SP 13083-100, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Marques, S.R., LNLS, Campinas, SP 13083-100, Brazil; Onisto, H.J., LNLS, Campinas, SP 13083-100, Brazil; Tavares, P.F., LNLS, Campinas, SP 13083-100, Brazil
Abstract: The storage ring filling pattern affects the performance of the machine in several ways. A bunch charge meter has been developed in order to perform bunch-by-bunch charge measurement and to record the storage ring filling pattern. This instrument separates the electric pulse produced by the selected bunch from the RF signal obtained from a button pick-up. A fast switch based on a double balanced mixer (DBM) was developed to strip off all but one bunch pulse at each revolution period. A 12-bit ADC with a FIFO buffer card acquires the bunch signals. A PECL timing card performs the bunch selection. The bunch charge meter is connected to the LNLS control system through a DSP processor board, which controls the instrument through an FPGA interfacing board. The DSP software provides digital filtering. Some implementation details, performance data and operational results are presented.
Index Keywords: Attenuation; Control systems; Database systems; Digital signal processing; Electric connectors; Electric exciters; Field programmable gate arrays; Mixers (machinery); Particle beam bunching; Program processors; Switching circuits; Synchrotrons; Attenuators; Beam energy; Double balanced mixers (DBM); Filling patterns; Storage rings

Authors: Bogacz A., Beard K., Bengtsson J., Butler C., Chao Y., Chattopadhyay S., Dong H., Douglas D., Freyberger A., Guerra A., Hicks R., Hofler A., Hovater C., Hutton A., Kazimi R., Lauze R., Merminga L., Plawski T., Roblin Y., Spata M., Tennant C., Tiefenback M., Bernhard A., Magerl A., Toyokawa H.
Title: CEBAF energy recovery experiment
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Friedrich-Alexander Univ. Erlangen, Nürnberg, Germany; Natl. Inst. Adv. Indust. Sci./T., Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Bogacz, A., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Beard, K., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Bengtsson, J., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Butler, C., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Chao, Y., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Chattopadhyay, S., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Dong, H., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Douglas, D., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Freyberger, A., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Guerra, A., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Hicks, R., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Hofler, A., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Hovater, C., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Hutton, A., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Kazimi, R., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Lauze, R., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Merminga, L., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Plawski, T., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Roblin, Y., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Spata, M., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Tennant, C., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Tiefenback, M., Jefferson Lab., Newport News, VA 23606, United States; Bernhard, A., Friedrich-Alexander Univ. Erlangen, Nürnberg, Germany; Magerl, A., Friedrich-Alexander Univ. Erlangen, Nürnberg, Germany; Toyokawa, H., Natl. Inst. Adv. Indust. Sci./T., Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: A successful GeV scale energy recovery demonstration with high ratio of accelerated-to-recovered energies (50:1) was recently carried out on the CEBAF recirculating linear accelerator. Future high energy (multi-GeV), high current (hundreds of milli-Amperes) beams would require gigaWatt-class RF systems in conventional linacs - a prohibitively expensive proposition. However, invoking energy recovery [1] alleviates extreme RF power demands; required RF power becomes nearly independent of beam current, which improves linac efficiency and increases cost effectiveness. Furthermore, energy recovering linacs promise efficiencies of storage rings, while maintaining beam quality of linacs: superior emittance and energy spread and short bunches (sub-pico sec.). Finally, energy recovery alleviates shielding, if the beam is dumped below the neutron production threshold. Jefferson Lab has demonstrated its expertise in the field of Energy Recovery Linacs (ERLs) with the successful operation of the Infrared FEL, where 5 mA of average beam current have been accelerated up to 50 MeV and the energy stored in the beam was recovered via deceleration and given back to the RF power source. To date this has been the largest scale demonstration of energy recovery.
Index Keywords: Acceleration; Cost effectiveness; Electron beams; Electron energy levels; Measurement theory; Synchrotrons; Beam energy; Beam quality; Dump; Energy recovery linacs (ERL); Light sources

Authors: Aleksandrov A., Assadi S., Blokland W., Deibele C., Grice W., Pogge J.
Title: Beam in Gap measurements at the SNS Front-End
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: ORNL, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States
Authors with affiliations: Aleksandrov, A., ORNL, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States; Assadi, S., ORNL, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States; Blokland, W., ORNL, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States; Deibele, C., ORNL, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States; Grice, W., ORNL, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States; Pogge, J., ORNL, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States
Abstract: The pulsed beam in the SNS accelerator has a fine time structure which consists of 695ns long mini-pulses separated by 250ns gaps in order to minimize transient beam losses in the accumulator ring which could arise during the ring extraction kicker rise time. This time structure is provided by a two stage Front End chopping system which must reduce the beam current in the gap to a level of 10-4 of the nominal current in order to satisfy requirements on the ring extraction losses. A Beam-in-Gap measuring system based on H - stripping using NdYAG laser was developed and tested during the SNS Front-End commissioning period. This paper describes the Beam-in-Gap measurement system design and measured performance.
Index Keywords: Calibration; Computer simulation; Electron beams; Ion beams; Laser diagnostics; Laser pulses; Neodymium lasers; Photodiodes; Storage rings; Beam losses; Low energy beam transport (LEBT); Medium energy beam transport (MEBT); Signal strength; Particle accelerators

Title: Formation and dissipation of the electron cloud
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: LBNL, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Furman, M.A., LBNL, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: We present an understanding of the effect of various features of the secondary emission yield (SEY) and secondary emission spectrum on the formation and dissipation of the electron cloud (EC). This understanding is based on dedicated experimental studies at several storage rings and systematic benchmarks of simulations against these measurements.

Abstract: The upgrade project of the pulse X-ray source PF-AR was successfully completed by the end of 2001. The initial beam current and the lifetime were largely improved. The injection energy was raised from 2.5GeV to 3.0GeV, the maximum beam current of 65mA was achieved. With a new global orbit feedback system, orbit drifts were largely improved.
Index Keywords: Electrons; Feedback; Magnets; Particle beam injection; Photons; Vacuum; X rays; Beam current; Feedback systems; Injection energy; Photon factory (PF); Storage rings

Authors: Liepe M., Belomestnykh S.
Title: Microphonics detuning in the 500 MHz superconducting CESR cavities
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liepe, M., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Belomestnykh, S., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Abstract: The RF system of the Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR) consists of four superconducting (s.c.) 500 MHz cavities. For a charm-tau upgrade (CESR-c, see [1]) we plan to drive two cavities by one klystron and to operate some cavities in passive mode. During the previous high energy run the RF system performance was not significantly affected by microphonic cavity detuning, since the cavities were operated under strong beam loading with a low loaded quality factor of 2 · 105. However, in low energy CESR-c operation With increased loaded Q-factor the RF system becomes less tolerant to microphonics, especially when two cavities are driven by one klystron. In order to address this potential problem we have studied microphonics in the CESR cavities in detail. Significant improvements have been achieved by reducing major contributions to the detuning. For further improvements we plan to study the performance of an active microphonics compensation scheme, which is based on a fast piezoelectric-driven frequency tuner.
Index Keywords: Bandwidth; Cavity resonators; Electric potential; Feedback; Klystrons; Phase modulation; Piezoelectric devices; Storage rings; Superconducting devices; Vibrations (mechanical); Beam loading; Cavity field stability; Detuning; Microphonic noise; Microphonism

Authors: Schramm U., Schätz T., Bussmann M., Habs D.
Title: Storage of crystalline ion beams
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Sektion Physik, LMU Munich, D-85748 Garching, Germany; NIST Boulder, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schramm, U., Sektion Physik, LMU Munich, D-85748 Garching, Germany; Schätz, T., Sektion Physik, LMU Munich, D-85748 Garching, Germany, NIST Boulder, United States; Bussmann, M., Sektion Physik, LMU Munich, D-85748 Garching, Germany; Habs, D., Sektion Physik, LMU Munich, D-85748 Garching, Germany
Abstract: Recently, the phase transition of a low-energy 24Mg+ ion beam into the Coulomb-ordered 'crystalline' state could be realized in the rf quadrupole storage ring PALLAS at the LMU Munich. Thereby, an increase of the phase space density of the beam, subjected to longitudinal laser cooling, by about six orders of magnitude was observed. In this paper, we focus on the systematic experimental investigation of the role of the focusing conditions and of bending shear in the storage ring on the attainment of crystalline beams of different crystal structure.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Crystals; Ions; Phase transitions; Shear stress; Storage rings; Thermal effects; Coulomb collisions; Focusing period; Phase advance; Phase space density; Ion beams

Authors: Bazarov I.V., Hoffstaetter G.H.
Title: Lattice options for a 5 GeV light source at cornell
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14850, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bazarov, I.V., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14850, United States; Hoffstaetter, G.H., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14850, United States
Abstract: Cornell University has proposed an Energy Recovery Linac (ERL) based synchrotron-light facility which can provide improved X-ray radiation due to the high beam quality which is available from a linac. To additionally utilize beam currents that are competitive with ring-based light sources, the linac has to operate with the novel technique of energy recovery. Cornell plans to address the outstanding issues of high-current injector, higher-order mode damping and extraction from superconducting RF environment, etc. in a downscaled prototype ERL prior to submitting a proposal for a full-scale machine. The flexibility of linacs allows for different modes of operating the ERL X-ray source, each of which requires specific manipulations of longitudinal phase-space that restrict the choice of the lattice. Here we discuss the different proposed modes of operating the ERL X-ray source and present options for corresponding lattices.
Index Keywords: Beam injectors; Energy Recovery Linac (ERL) accelerators; Gaussian beams; Magnetic lattices; Electron beams; Electron sources; Light sources; Magnetic materials; Particle beam extraction; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Superconductivity; Waveform analysis; X rays; Synchrotrons

Authors: Were J.O.
Title: An overview of waste management aspects of geothermal development
Source title: Transactions - Geothermal Resources Council
Affiliations: Kenya Elec. Generating Company Ltd., Olkaria Geothermal Project, P. O. Box 785, Naivasha, Kenya
Authors with affiliations: Were, J.O., Kenya Elec. Generating Company Ltd., Olkaria Geothermal Project, P. O. Box 785, Naivasha, Kenya
Abstract: In the geothermal energy sector, one of the environmental challenges has been the management of the large volume of waste geothermal fluids and effluents and other minor quantities of solid waste materials generated during exploration and utilization. In this paper the results of an attempt to characterize geothermal and associated waste materials in terms of their origin, quantity, chemical content, and environmental behaviour, are presented. The basic waste management principles for the categories identified are reviewed. The review reveals that employment of an integrated sound management system for geothermal waste fluids and effluents makes the potential negative environmental effects of geothermal waste negligible. This management system includes re-injection and constructed "wetland" systems, periodical monitoring of levels of toxic chemical elements in waste products and studies of impact indicators, disposal of drilling mud, sludge, scales and other construction and maintenance debris in properly designed and managed landfills, and careful storage and handling of toxic and hazardous dosing chemicals and petroleum products.
Author Keywords: Characterization; Geothermal; Management; Waste
Index Keywords: Environmental impact; Petroleum products; Solid wastes; Thermal effluents; Toxic materials; Waste management; Chemical components; Energy development; Geothermal; Waste fluids; Geothermal energy

Ener. Research Institute, Sayo-gun, Hyogo 679-5148, Japan
Abstract: In August 2002, a 10-T superconducting wiggler was installed in the 8-GeV electron storage ring at SPring-8. High-energy (∼3MeV) and intense synchrotron radiation was produced from the wiggler, and scattered photons were generated by the interaction of synchrotron radiation with photon absorber materials. The intense radiation environment in the storage ring tunnel damages accelerator components, such as cable insulators and coils for electromagnets. To suppress such damage, it is necessary to understand the dose distribution and the spectrum of scattered photons near the wiggler. The dose distribution and the spectrum of scattered photons from the photon absorber was measured by thermoluminescent dosimeters (LiF TLD) with lead filters (0, 0.5, 1, 3, 6 mm in thickness). At the same time, alanine dosimeters and GafChromic film (made of polyethylene) were used to measure the dose of photons which exceeded the dynamic range of TLD dosimeters. The results of an experimental data analysis showed that, as expected, photons of energies of several hundred keV were scattered over a wide range.
Index Keywords: Data reduction; Dosimetry; Electromagnets; Light scattering; Photons; Polyethylenes; Synchrotron radiation; Thermoluminescence; Power density; Radiation angle; Radiation measurement; Superconducting wiggler; Electron ring accelerators

Authors: Tecker F., Corsini R., Rinolfi L., Biscari C., Ghigo A., Preger M., Royer P., Ferrari A.
Title: Bunch frequency multiplication in the CLIC test facility CTF3
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; LNF-INFN, Frascati, Italy; Inst. de Phys. des Hautes Energies, Université de Lausanne, Switzerland; Department of Radiation Sciences, Uppsala University, Sweden

Abstract: The aim of the CLIC Test Facility CTF3 at CERN is to prove the feasibility of key issues of the two-beam based Compact Linear Collider (CLIC) study. In particular, it addresses the generation of a drive beam with the appropriate time structure to produce high power RF pulses at a frequency of 30 GHz. The first major goal of CTF3 was to demonstrate, at low charge, the combination of successive bunch trains by RF deflectors in an isochronous ring. This bunch frequency multiplication has been successfully performed for various combination factors up to five and will be presented.
Index Keywords: High energy physics; Luminescence; Parameter estimation; Particle beam injection; Particle beams; Storage rings; Betatron phase; Compact linear colliders (CLIC); RF deflectors; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Liepe M., Barstow B., Padamsee H.
Title: First studies for a low temperature higher-order-mode absorber for the cornell ERL prototype
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liepe, M., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Barstow, B., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Padamsee, H., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Abstract: Cornell University, in collaboration with Jefferson Laboratory, has proposed the construction of a prototype energy-recovery linac (ERL) to study the energy recovery concept with high current, low emittance beams. The beam with a current of up to 100 mA will excite significant higher-order-mode (HOM) power in the superconducting (s.c.) RF cavities with frequencies up to 100 GHz. Strong damping of the HOMs is essential for beam stability and to reduce the HOM losses to a few hundred Watts per meter. To achieve this demanding goal we plan to place RF absorbing material in the beam tubes between the cavities in the linac. However, this will require operating the HOM absorbers at temperatures below 80 K to simplify the thermal transition to the cavities at 2 K with low static losses to 2 K. One possible material candidate is ferrite, as it is used at room temperature in the HOM absorbers in the s.c. CESR cavities. In this paper we present experiments performed to study the RF absorption properties of ferrite at cryogenic temperatures in the frequency range from 1 GHz to 15 GHz. First results are shown and the resulting HOM damping is evaluated and discussed.
Index Keywords: Absorption; Amplitude modulation; Computer simulation; Cryogenics; Damping; Electric conductors; Electric currents; Ferrite applications; Frequency agility; Storage rings; Systematic errors; CESR cavities; Energy recovery linac (ERL); HOM absorbers; Low emittance beams; Superconducting devices

Authors: Sekutowicz J., Ciovati G., Kneisel P., Wu G., Brinkmann A., Hartung W., Parodi R., Zheng S.
Title: Cavities for jlab's 12 GeV upgrade
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: TJNAF, Newport News, VA 23606, United States; DESY, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; MSU, East Lansing, MI, United States; INFN Genoa, 16146 Genoa, Italy; Tsinghua University, 100084 Beijing, China

Abstract: The future 12 GeV upgrade of CEBAF requires new cryomodules in both linacs to increase the energy gain per pass to 1090 MeV. Until recently, the design of new cryomodules, which should deliver on average operational voltage of 70 MV each, was based on 7-cell superconducting cavities that are an extended version of the 5-cell structures currently used in the machine. The 5-cell cavities were constructed 20 years ago at Cornell University (Original Cornell-shape) for the Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR). The geometry of these structures met specifications at the time CESR was constructed but is not optimized for the future operation of CEBAF. Two improved cavity shapes have been proposed. This contribution presents the RF features of both new shapes and discusses advantages for the machine operation resulting from the improvement. In addition, we comment on the measurements on copper models of both new cavities and present results of the multipacting calculations.
Index Keywords: Copper; Coupled circuits; Electric potential; Electron emission; Electron energy levels; Geometry; Optimization; Polarization; Radiation; Sensitivity analysis; Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR); Electron showers; Low loss (LL) shape; Superconducting cavities; Particle accelerators

Abstract: The cooler synchrotron COSY delivers unpolarized and polarized protons and deuterons in the momentum range 300 MeV/c up to 3.65 GeV/c. Electron cooling at injection level and stochastic cooling covering the range from 1.5 GeV/c up to maximum momentum are available to prepare high precision beams for internal as well as external experiments in hadron physics. The beam is fed to external experiments by a fast kicker extraction or by stochastic extraction. Results of extracted electron cooled beams and developments to increase the number of stored particles and to increase the degree of polarization during acceleration are reported.

Abstract: Deuteron and gold beams have been accelerated to a collision energy of √s = 200 GeV/u in the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC), providing the first asymmetric-species collisions of this complex. Necessary changes for this mode of operation include new ramping software and asymmetric crossing angle geometries. This paper reviews machine performance, problems encountered and their solutions, and accomplishments during the 16 weeks of ramp-up and operations.

Authors: Mikhailov S.F.
Title: Challenges for magnetic design of a compact booster fed by single power supply
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: FEL Laboratory, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mikhailov, S.F., FEL Laboratory, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Abstract: In design of full energy Booster injectors, commonly used in the modern accelerator facilities, there is a tendency of avoiding saturation of the magnetic elements in order to avoid losses associated with tune change during the energy ramp. Typical maximum field in the bending magnets of the modern Booster projects of 1.0-1.4 T results in the large circumference. For 0.27-1.2 GeV full energy Booster injector for the Duke FEL storage ring, recently under design and fabrication, there was an ultimate goal to fit it into existing storage ring room to avoid cost extensive building construction. Therefore, the Booster ring has to be compact, therefore the maximum field in the bending magnets was accepted 1.76 T. With a different level of saturation in the bending magnets, focusing and defocusing quadruples it was not possible to avoid a tune change with the energy rise. However, the ratio of saturation levels for the elements was optimized to avoid crossing of any significant resonance while ramping through the entire energy range. The lattice was simulated for different energies based on the results of 3D calculations of the magnetic elements with the use of MERMAID 3D code. Another challenging part of the design was supplying all the dipoles and quadrupoles by single power supply.
Index Keywords: Bending strength; Compaction; Cost effectiveness; Design; Electric exciters; Electric power systems; Energy absorption; Energy dissipation; Magnetic permeability; Particle accelerators; Particle beam injection; Particle beams; Resonance; Saturation (materials composition); Bending magnets; Energy range; Magnetic designs; Ramping; Magnetic materials

Authors: Lewellen J.W., Pasky S.
Title: An operator training facility at the advanced photon source
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: ANL, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lewellen, J.W., ANL, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Pasky, S., ANL, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Abstract: The Advanced Photon Source (APS), a premier third-generation synchrotron radiation source, presently operates in top-up mode during most user run time. During top-up mode, charge is injected into the storage ring at approximately 2-minute intervals to stabilize the stored beam current to within 0.1%. Top-up mode requires the dedicated use of the entire APS injector system, severely limiting time available for operator training. The APS injector test stand (ITS) is presently configured to operate a ballistic bunch compression (BBC) rf gun, which uses three independently powered and phased rf cavities, and either a thermionic cathode or a photocathode. Operation of the BBC gun requires cavity phasing and input rf power selection analogous to the operation of a high-energy linac. In conjunction with the ITS beamline components (quadrupoles, dipoles, diagnostics, correctors), this provides an effective analog to the APS linac. Operators can therefore practice accelerator tuning and control methods with a live beam and real components, rather than simulations, while top-up operation is ongoing.
Index Keywords: Free electron lasers; Mirrors; Particle accelerators; Particle beam bunching; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Advanced photon source (APS); Ballistic bunch compression (BBC); Injector test stand; Photons

Authors: Hoffstaetter G.H., Barstow B., Bazarov I.V., Belomestnykh S., Bilderback D., Gruner S., Liepe M., Padamsee H., Sagan D., Shemelin V., Sinclair C., Talman R., Tigner M., Veshcherevich V., Krafft G.A., Merminga L.
Title: The Cornell ERL prototype project
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; TJNAF, Newport News, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoffstaetter, G.H., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Barstow, B., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Bazarov, I.V., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Belomestnykh, S., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Bilderback, D., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Gruner, S., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Liepe, M., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Padamsee, H., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Sagan, D., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Shemelin, V., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Sinclair, C., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Talman, R., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Tigner, M., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Veshcherevich, V., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Krafft, G.A., TJNAF, Newport News, VA, United States; Merminga, L., TJNAF, Newport News, VA, United States
Abstract: Synchrotron light sources based on Energy Recovery Linacs (ERLs) show promise to deliver X-ray beams with both brilliance and X-ray pulse duration far superior to the values that can be achieved with storage ring technology. Cornell University, in collaboration with Jefferson Laboratory, has proposed the construction of a prototype ERL. This 100MeV, 100mA CW superconducting electron accelerator will be used to study and resolve the many accelerator physics and technology issues of this type of machine. These studies are essential before ERLs can be confidently proposed for large-scale applications such as synchrotron light sources. Key issues include the generation of high average current, high brightness electron beams; acceleration and transport of these beams while preserving their brightness; adequate damping of higher order modes (HOMs) to assure beam stability; removal of large amounts of HOM power from the cryogenic environment; stable RF control of cavities operating at very high external Q; reduction of beam losses to very low levels; and the development of precision non-intercepting diagnostics to allow beam setup, control and characterization. Our prototype design allows us to address these and other issues over a broad range of parameter space. This design, along with recent progress on understanding these issues, will be presented.
Index Keywords: Cornell electron storage rings (CESR); Electron-ion collider (EIC); Energy recovery linacs (ERL); High order modes (HOM); Acceleration; Cavity resonators; Electric potential; Electron beams; Particle accelerators; Software prototyping; Wave propagation; X ray analysis; Light sources

Sci./T., 1-1-1 Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-8568, Japan
Abstract: The temporal performance of the free electron lasers and the electron-beam qualities have been measured with the compact storage ring NIJI-IV at the electron-beam energy of 310 MeV. It was found that the pulse width and spectral width kept decreasing after the peak of the FEL macropulse intensity. It was confirmed that the bunch length and the energy spread increased due to the FEL oscillations. The ratio of the FEL gain to the cavity loss estimated from the beam qualities on and off FEL oscillations was almost in accord with the ratio evaluated directly with the measured data of the FEL gain and the cavity loss.

Authors: Wu Y.K., Hartman S., Mikhailov S.F.
Title: A physics based control system for the Duke storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: FEL Lab., Duke University, NC 27708-0319, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, Y.K., FEL Lab., Duke University, NC 27708-0319, United States; Hartman, S., FEL Lab., Duke University, NC 27708-0319, United States; Mikhailov, S.F., FEL Lab., Duke University, NC 27708-0319, United States
Abstract: At the Duke FEL Lab, we have developed a new storage ring control system in terms of the physics quantities of the accelerator. Instead of controlling power supply currents in Amperes, this system controls the effective focusing of magnets. By directly controlling the physics quantities, this control system allows tighter integration of the physics model based high level controls with the EPICS based low-level controls. EPICS events have been extensively used to provide time synchronization during the energy and lattice ramping. This new control system also facilitates the implementation of multiple functions on shared control channels. As a result, the physics based control system simplifies many complex control tasks, improves the beam stability during ramping, and facilitates machine studies. With better understanding of the accelerator, it is possible to fine tune this control system to present users with a virtual accelerator whose operation is independent of the ring energy.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Free electron lasers; Magnetic field effects; Particle accelerators; Real time systems; Synchronization; User interfaces; Beam energy; Duke storage rings; Input output controller (IOC); Ring energy; Storage rings

Authors: Kim E.-S., Han Y.-J., Jeong S.-H., Kim M.-G., Kim S.-C., Park S.-S., Seo J.-H.
Title: Operational performance in 2.5 GeV full enenrgy injection at PLS
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, POSTECH, Pohang, 790-784, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, E.-S., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, POSTECH, Pohang, 790-784, South Korea; Han, Y.-J., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, POSTECH, Pohang, 790-784, South Korea; Jeong, S.-H., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, POSTECH, Pohang, 790-784, South Korea; Kim, M.-G., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, POSTECH, Pohang, 790-784, South Korea; Kim, S.-C., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, POSTECH, Pohang, 790-784, South Korea; Park, S.-S., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, POSTECH, Pohang, 790-784, South Korea; Seo, J.-H., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, POSTECH, Pohang, 790-784, South Korea
Abstract: The PLS has provided 2.5 GeV electron beam to users of beam lines since Jan. 2000. During Jan. 2000 to Oct. 2002, 2 GeV electron beam was injected from the linac to the storage ring and the storage ring had used energy ramping process to increase the beam energy to 2.5 GeV. Instead of energy ramping process, we have used the 2.5 GeV full energy injection from the linac to the storage ring since Oct. 2002. We present the activities on the stability and reliability of the linac for 2.5 GeV operation, stabilities of injection kicker and septum magnets in the storage ring, orbit correction of COD due to leakage field of the septum magnet, and a DC bump for beam injection. Orbit stabilities and global orbit correction on the operation of 2.5 GeV full energy injection are also presented.
Index Keywords: Electric power systems; Electron beams; Electron energy levels; Klystrons; Leakage currents; Magnets; Storage rings; Beam parameters; Energy injection; Energy-ramping; Machine stability; Particle beam injection

Abstract: In this paper, we summarize the R&D status of the X-band power source development for the GLC (Global Linear Collider, previously called JLC) project. Main emphases are on the latest achievements of the PPM klystrons and the development of the IGBT induction modulator. The pulse compression schemes and the optimisation of the tunnel layout for different configuration of the main linac are also discussed.
