Authors: Pandian S.S.
Title: A physical analogy for ac electrical power
Source title: Plant Engineering (Barrington, Illinois)
Affiliations: Design Services Division, PD and CD, Saudi Aramco, Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Pandian, S.S., Design Services Division, PD and CD, Saudi Aramco, Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: A physical analogy for ac electrical power is presented. The analogy applies to linear electrical loads as well as nonlinear loads that draw a nonsinusoidal current, except that the harmonic currents generated by nonlinear loads have some effect on pf. For an inductive load with a resistive component due to the phase lag of the current with reference to the ac voltage, the electrical power drawn from the supply system has three components which include active power, reactive power and apparent power. These three component of power can be visualized by the power triangle.

Authors: Gómez-Romero P., Cuentas-Gallegos K., Lira-Cantú M., Casañ-Pastor N.
Title: Energy storage in hybrid organic-inorganic materials
Source title: Proceedings - Electrochemical Society
Affiliations: Materials Science Institute, Barcelona (ICMAB, CSIC), Campus UAB, E08193 Bellaterra (Barcelona), Spain
Authors with affiliations: Gómez-Romero, P., Materials Science Institute, Barcelona (ICMAB, CSIC), Campus UAB, E08193 Bellaterra (Barcelona), Spain; Cuentas-Gallegos, K., Materials Science Institute, Barcelona (ICMAB, CSIC), Campus UAB, E08193 Bellaterra (Barcelona), Spain; Lira-Cantú, M., Materials Science Institute, Barcelona (ICMAB, CSIC), Campus UAB, E08193 Bellaterra (Barcelona), Spain; Casañ-Pastor, N., Materials Science Institute, Barcelona (ICMAB, CSIC), Campus UAB, E08193 Bellaterra (Barcelona), Spain
Abstract: Conducting organic polymers (COPs) provide an excellent basis for the development of electroactive hybrid organic-inorganic materials for energy storage applications. There are two main types of hybrids, those made by insertion of inorganic molecular or cluster species into COPs (O-I Hybrids) and those in which COPs are in turn inserted in extended inorganic or mineral phases (IO Hybrids). I-O hybrids such as Polyaniline-V2O5 have been prepared and studied and their application as cathodes in rechargeable Li cells has been evaluated. O-I Hybrids integrate molecular (ex. [Fe(CN)6 ] 3/4-) or cluster inorganic species(ex. [PMo12O 40]3-) into COPs matrices and provide an opportunity to control the redox insertion mechanism of the polymers. These O-I materials provide a unique opportunity to harness the electroactivity of molecular (and soluble) inorganic species and put them to work (among others) in energy storage devices and applications. This chapter will present the electrochemistry of these materials, and their application in rechargeable lithium batteries and electrochemical supercapacitors.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Doping (additives); Electrochemistry; Electrolytes; Energy storage; Hydrogen bonds; Lithium batteries; Molecular dynamics; Organic polymers; Secondary batteries; Mineral phases; Redox insertion mechanism; Supercapacitors; Materials science

Authors: Jørgensen S.E.
Title: The recent development toward a consistent ecosystem theory
Source title: Advances in Ecological Sciences
Affiliations: Univ. of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Copenhagen, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Jørgensen, S.E., Univ. of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Copenhagen, Denmark
Abstract: Several ecosystem theories have been presented during the last 2-3 decades. Lately, it has been possible to unite these theories into a consistent pattern. Intensive discussions at meetings have been the key to the formation of this pattern of ecosystem theories. Another driving factor has been the reformulation of Odum's attributes [1] into three growth or development forms: growth of the biological structure (the biomass), growth of the network (more cycling, more linkages) and the growth of information. An analysis of the growth forms (Jørgensen et al. [2]) shows that through-flow (power), ascendency and exergy storage are all increasing as a consequence of all three types of growth. However, exergy dissipation, entropy production, specific exergy (exergy/biomass), retention time and the ratio indirect/direct effect only increases or decreases with one or two of the growth forms. Emergy expresses the formation cost in equivalent solar energy. Nature has the ability to obtain a high exergy storage for a given input of emergy, and there is therefore a correlation between exergy and emergy. We show with one example, out of the many recently published in various scientific journals, how to use the ecosystem theory to explain ecological observations. The example given in this paper is simply to illustrate how the ecosystem theory is applied to explain ecological observations by the use of models.
Index Keywords: Biomass; Degradation; Ecology; Energy dissipation; Entropy; Mathematical models; Numerical methods; Solar energy; Ecosystem theory; Retention time; Specific exergy; Ecosystems

Authors: Terra G.S., Lopes M.C.S., Ebecken N.F.F.
Title: A data mining approach for medium-term demand forecasting
Source title: Management Information Systems
Affiliations: NIT, COPPE, Univ. Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; CEFET-Campos, UNED-Macaé, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Terra, G.S., NIT, COPPE, Univ. Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, CEFET-Campos, UNED-Macaé, Brazil; Lopes, M.C.S., NIT, COPPE, Univ. Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Ebecken, N.F.F., NIT, COPPE, Univ. Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Abstract: The Brazilian government, in the past, monopolized the generation, transmission and distribution of electric energy. Following world-wide tendencies, nowadays the government assumes the regulation function in a competitive and horizontal market. The variable load, fundamental in the planning of the electrical and energy operation, in the studies of magnifying and reinforcement of the basic network, assumes strategic importance in the commercial area, improving the data storage and knowledge extraction process using computational techniques. In the present work, data mining techniques are used to produce monthly load forecasts in intervals of high, medium and low consumption, according to the needs of electrical energy distribution companies. The results of neural network models, when compared to statistical results, show improved performance, presenting an Average Relative Error about 0.5% lower.
Index Keywords: Demand forecasting; Electric energy; Hourly consumption of electric energy (HCEE); Knowledge extraction; Digital storage; Electric power systems; Errors; Forecasting; Genetic algorithms; Knowledge acquisition; Laws and legislation; Neural networks; Public policy; Statistical methods; Strategic planning; Data mining

Authors: Frantzis I.
Title: Recycling and processing of waste: Possibilities and perspectives
Source title: Sustainable World
Affiliations: I. Frantzis and Associates Ltd., Greece
Authors with affiliations: Frantzis, I., I. Frantzis and Associates Ltd., Greece
Abstract: Recycling has become a fundamental element of any Solid Waste Management (SWM) system and legitimate obligation of the relevant Agencies. According to the legislation, alternative management (reuse, recycling, energy evaluation) of municipal waste is obligatory, while qualitative and quantitative targets have been set. The huge increase of packaging materials is playing a great role in this. Up to now, in Greece, recycling is implemented almost exclusively through Separation at Source. A number of SWM Agencies are running such programs showing useful results, such as high operating cost (due to collection), very low waste reduction, i.e., not exceeding 3-4% of Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) and necessary post processing (due to contaminants or necessity for materials separation into different categories). Based on this it is quite clear that Separation at Source cannot be the only recycling method, its low contribution to a significant waste reduction is not to be omitted, but mixed municipal waste processing becomes unavoidable aiming towards τmaterials and energy recovery.
Index Keywords: Energy utilization; Impurities; Land fill; Laws and legislation; Optimization; Packaging materials; Recycling; Solid wastes; Storage (materials); Energy recovery; Refuse derived fuels (RDF); Waste processing; Waste reduction; Waste management

Authors: Zimmels Y., Kirzhner F., Krasovitski B.
Title: Energy loss of compressed air storage in hard rock
Source title: Advances in Ecological Sciences
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Technion - Israel Inst. of Technol., Israel
Authors with affiliations: Zimmels, Y., Department of Civil Engineering, Technion - Israel Inst. of Technol., Israel; Kirzhner, F., Department of Civil Engineering, Technion - Israel Inst. of Technol., Israel; Krasovitski, B., Department of Civil Engineering, Technion - Israel Inst. of Technol., Israel
Abstract: Underground space provides opportunities for environmentally safe storage and retrieval of energy. Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) in underground caverns can be used to generate electrical power during peak demand periods. The excess power generation capacity, which is available when demand is low, is used to store energy in the form of compressed air. This energy is then retrieved during peak demand periods. The structural stabilities and leakage features of the air storage site determines the expected energy losses, efficiencies of energy conversions and the corresponding economics. Design examples of CAES systems are presented, their geomechanical and thermal responses to compression and air release cycles are considered, and the corresponding energy losses are estimated.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric power generation; Electric power systems; Energy dissipation; Energy efficiency; Gas turbines; Hydraulics; Rock mechanics; Compressed air energy storage (CAES); Geomechanical responses; Structural stabilities; Thermal responses; Energy storage

Authors: Sciubba E., Susani L., Tiezzi E.B.P.
Title: Exergy and extended exergy accounting of the Province of Siena
Source title: Advances in Ecological Sciences
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Roma 1, Italy; Department of Chemical Science, University of Siena, Italy; Department of Mathematic, University of Siena, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Sciubba, E., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Roma 1, Italy; Susani, L., Department of Chemical Science, University of Siena, Italy; Tiezzi, E.B.P., Department of Mathematic, University of Siena, Italy
Abstract: This paper describes an application of the classical Exergy and Extended Exergy Accounting (EEA) of a complex system. The system studied, supposed to be in a steady state, is the province of Siena (on a year 2000 database). It is represented by structural connectivity which describes in a synthetic way the interactions of each mass or energy flow with each sector of the society. The exergy accounting converts the total amount of resources entering in a system in exergetic form with the help of a table of "raw exergy data" available in the literature. After the conversion of each flow into a common exergetic basis it's possible to evaluate the efficiencies of each energy and mass transfer between the seven sectors and to find out where the main irreversible exergy losses are. The advantage of the EEA, compared to a classical exergy accounting, consists in the inclusion in the system balance of the exergetic equivalent of human Labour and of Capital. EEA also allows one to calculate the efficiency of the domestic sector which is otherwise impossible to evaluate, accounting the working hours as a product of this sector of the society. The results show that the Province of Siena has values of efficiency for the different sectors close to Italian average except for two sectors, tertiary and energy conversion, that are more efficient, in agreement with system's features. The largest inefficiency is due to the transportation sector which is lower then 30% in EEA and lower than 10% in classical accounting.
Index Keywords: Economic and social effects; Energy absorption; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Heat losses; Mass transfer; Natural resources; Personnel; Public policy; Remediation; Thermodynamics; Energy flow; Global policy planning; Raw exergy data; Structural connectivity; Exergy

Abstract: Coupling theory is employed to analyze the coupling gain and a novel optical system is presented for image edge-enhancement by employing photorefractive two-wave coupling in BaTiO3 crystal, in which the ordinarily discarded background light is recycled as the pump source to amplify the signal light. Further, we demonstrate the principle of optical correlation and compare the discrimination capability of two kinds of correlators by computer simulation, in one of which input images are edge-enhanced and in the other the ones do not experience edge-enhancement. At last, we draw a conclusion that edge-enhancement preprocessing can improve discrimination capability effectively.

Authors: Higuchi S., Matsuda T.
Title: A high earthquake-proof spread foundation system for energy storage tanks
Source title: Advances in Earthquake Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Tech. Res. Institute, Obayashi Co., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Higuchi, S., Department of Civil Engineering, Tech. Res. Institute, Obayashi Co., Japan; Matsuda, T., Department of Civil Engineering, Tech. Res. Institute, Obayashi Co., Japan
Abstract: A high earthquake proof spread foundation for the tank structures named "Seismic action control foundation" was developed. "Seismic action control foundation" consists of a concrete slab and the improved ground under the slab utilizing the deep mixing method. "Seismic action control" effect is theoretically basing on the dynamic soil-structure interaction. In this study, performances of the "Seismic action control foundation" were investigated with numerical analyses. Followings were found from the results. (1) Up to 30 % reduction of the base shear of the tank structure is turned out on the "Seismic action control foundation" compared with those of the piled foundation by numerical analyses. (2) It is able to reduce the area of "Seismic action control foundation" up to 50% without decreasing the effect of the seismic input reduction.
Index Keywords: Concrete mixing; Concrete slabs; Construction; Foundations; Seismology; Soils; Tanks (containers); Base slabs; Energy storage tanks; Seismic regions; Earthquakes

Authors: Wei J.
Title: Spallation neutron source ring - Status, challenges, issues, and perspectives
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Spallation Neutron Src. C., United States
Authors with affiliations: Wei, J., Spallation Neutron Src. C., United States
Abstract: The Spollation Neutron Source (SNS) ring is designed to accumulate beam pulses of 1.5×1014 protons of 1 GeV kinetic energy at a repetition rate of 60 Hz [1]. At such beam intensity and power, key design challenges include control of beam loss and radio-activation, construction of high-quality large-aperture magnets and power supplies, design of robust injection and extraction systems, minimization of beam-coupling impedances, and mitigation of electron-cloud effects. This paper discusses the status of the ring systems with emphasis on technical challenges and issues, and presents future perspectives towards a next-generation high-intensity facility.
Index Keywords: Mathematical models; Neutron sources; Phase modulation; Radioactivity; Synchrotrons; Transfer functions; Beam collimation; Electron clouds; Fractional beam losses; High-energy beam transport (HEBT); Magnetic rigidity; Storage rings

Authors: Lopez P.M., Baker A., Stammnitz V., Grizzard J.A.
Title: Applying technology forecasting and selection to the all electric ship
Source title: Institute of Marine Engineering, Science and Technology, IMarEST - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Syntek Technologies Incorporated, BMT Group of Companies, United States; Power Systems Technology, Syntek Technologies, Inc.; American Society of Naval Engineering (ASNE), United States; Power Systems Division, Syntek Technologies Inc.; AIAA, United States; AHS; INCOSE
Authors with affiliations: Lopez, P.M., Syntek Technologies Incorporated, BMT Group of Companies, United States, Power Systems Technology, Syntek Technologies, Inc., American Society of Naval Engineering (ASNE), United States; Baker, A., Syntek Technologies Incorporated, BMT Group of Companies, United States, Power Systems Division, Syntek Technologies Inc., AIAA, United States, AHS, INCOSE; Stammnitz, V., Syntek Technologies Incorporated, BMT Group of Companies, United States; Grizzard, J.A., Syntek Technologies Incorporated, BMT Group of Companies, United States
Abstract: In the year 2000, the United States Navy made a commitment to implement integrated electric propulsion in future surface combatants and also strove to replace auxiliary steam and hydraulic systems with electrical systems in other ship classes. The Office of Naval Research, a significant contributor to the technology developments necessary to achieve all-electric ship architectures, looked for ways to prioritize their investments in technologies that provide the best improvements in overall ship performance and affordability. To facilitate the associated decision-making process, a decision analysis methodology was developed that provides both the structure and guidance for thinking systematically about these difficult decisions. By employing both deterministic and probabilistic analysis techniques the methodology compares the net worth of a variety of electric ship technologies as they relate to ship performance and cost. It addresses technologies in the areas of propulsion, power generation, power conversion, distribution and control, and energy storage. For each assessed technology, input parameters are defined and translated into impacts on war-fighting capability metrics, efficiency, weight, volume, availability and life cycle cost. The impacts are assessed at the ship level and not merely at the component or subsystem level. This paper describes the application of a method, known as Technology Identification, Evaluation and Selection (TIES) 1, to the net value assessment of electric ship technologies. In this research, technology parameters are related to ship performance and technology comparison metrics over a full range of hullform types. From the example assessments performed for technologies ranging from super-conducting propulsion motors, high-speed generators, to fuel cells and motor drives, the reader will gain an appreciation for why this methodology is becoming an integral part in developing the US Navy's investment strategy for future electric ship technologies. Copyright © IMarEST 2005 - all rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Electric ships; Life cycle costs; Motor drives; Surface combatmants; Decision making; Decision theory; Electric energy storage; Electric power generation; Electric propulsion; Life cycle; Probability; Ships; Electric vehicles

Abstract: The temperatures of components of DIII-D ECH launchers were observed during 2003 tokamak operation. The injected power was typically 500-700 kW and the pulse length was typically 2 s. Plasma shots were performed at intervals of about 17 min from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. The temperatures of a movable mirror, a fixed mirror and a launcher reached an equilibrium after about six hours of repetitive pulsing. The saturation temperature depends to some extent on the plasma stored energy. However, even in high β plasma, the temperatures plateaued at acceptable values. ©2003 IEEE.

Authors: Nordqvist U., Liu D.
Title: Power optimized packet buffering in a protocol processor
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits, and Systems

Authors with affiliations: Nordqvist, U., Department of Electrical Engineering, Linköping University, SE-581 83 Linköping, Sweden; Liu, D., Department of Electrical Engineering, Linköping University, SE-581 83 Linköping, Sweden
Abstract: In the emerging research area of protocol processors (PP) there exist many hardware platform proposals. One example of suck a platform solution has been proposed by the author in a series of papers, mainly focusing on datapath organization and optimization. The proposed platform is unique since the fast path process incoming packets before storage in the input buffer. This paper proposes that a FIFO buffer should be added to the input buffer to lower the power consumption. The optimization process and the optimal input buffer architecture are dependent on a large number of parameters, e.g. network type and traffic, host system and physical implementation process. Simulating energy consumption characteristics, a number of architectural conclusions have been made. Especially an input packet buffer configuration is proposed which can be used in a wide variety of network applications and host systems. © 2003 IEEE.

Abstract: It is increasingly popular to use the ice storage technique for shifting the electricity demand in the peak periods. In this paper, the form of direct evaporation ice-on-coil storage technology is studied. A quasi-steady state energy balance model of the ice-storage evaporator has been built for simulating the freezing process on the coil. Good agreement is obtained between simulated results and experimental data. The results show that with the increasing ice layer thickness, the evaporating temperature will decrease. This could result in the reduction of the Coefficient of Performance (COP) of system.

Abstract: Following previous bilateral cooperative activities, the Russian/French/German studies conducted from June 2, 1998 to June 1, 2002 under a Trilateral Intergovernmental Agreement (AÏ DA/MOX 2 program) have produced a detailed description of the facilities to be built in the Russian Federation to transform W-Pu into MOX fuel and of the modifications to implement in Russian reactors so they can be loaded with MOX fuel in compliance with safety requirements. Authors: Zheng M., Wang D., Zhi Y.
Title: The study of heating and cooling technique with solar energy in severe cold area
Source title: Energy and the Environment - Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy and the Environment
Affiliations: Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, Heilongjiang, China
Authors with affiliations: Zheng, M., Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, Heilongjiang, China; Wang, D., Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, Heilongjiang, China; Zhi, Y., Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, Heilongjiang, China
Abstract: The heat demand for heating in winter is huge in severe cold area. It is difficult to realize or very uneconomical to heating only by solar energy that is collected in winter. The article in detail presents the solar energy heating and cooling new technical experimental system that has been founded in the Energy Conservation Laboratory of HIT (Harbin Institute of Technology). It is experimented and studied by this system that the collected solar energy is stored up into the deep underground soil by the exchangers in three seasons of the year. The ground-source heat pump (GSHP) system and the solar hot water system are used together to heating in winter. The system is divided into two parts after the heating. One part directly stores solar energy up into soil. The other directly takes the cold out of soil for cooling in the summer. Because a lot of heat is taken out from the under ground soil in winter, the cold can be directly taken in summer by the circulating pump and not using the refrigerator. When cooling finished, this part also stores the solar energy in soil in order to heating in winter. And good results have been achieved that the heating coefficient of performance (COP) is above 3.0, and the cooling is above 15.0 through two years experiment. Not only the petrochemical energy is saved, but also the environment is protected. The technique can be used in the severe cold area, in addition, it can be used in the other region and it can be achieved the better effect.
Author Keywords: Cooling; Ground-source heat pump; Heating; Soil thermal storage; Solar energy
Index Keywords: Cooling; Environmental protection; Heat pump systems; Heating; Petrochemical plants; Soils; Circulating pumps; Ground soils; Ground-source heat pump; Soil thermal storage; Solar energy

Abstract: The Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE) provides neutrons and protons for research at three user facility areas. The 800MeV linear accelerator, proton storage ring (PSR), beam transport systems and target areas have operated routinely at beam power levels of 1kW to 800kW and up to 1MW. The facility has been operational for 30 years and has served a diverse user community. Substantial experience has been gained in the operation, maintenance, and improvement of the linear accelerator, PSR, and beam transport systems. We will review our experience in the operation and maintenance of this facility and provide summary lessons learned for similar facilities now under design or construction.

Abstract: To solve the present problem of breather valve used in winter or frigid area, the essential causes of breather valve freeze is analyzed in this paper and the new style solar energy heat pipe breather valve is developed. Abstract: The results of studies performed to examine the viability of reprocessing were discussed. the total system costs of direct disposal in two respositories were compare with system costs associated with the disposal of vitrified and compacted wastes in a single repository. While direct disposal of SNF does not require investment in reprocessing and interim glass storage installations, it requires numerous repositories sooner than the reprocessing-based option. The cost of the additional installations required for reprocessing are therefore offset by the ability to push the need for a first repository in the future, and to push the need for a second repository even further away in time.

Authors: Lin K., Zhang Y., Jiang Y.
Title: Simulation and designing of PCM wallboard rooms combined with night ventilation
Source title: Energy and the Environment - Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy and the Environment
Affiliations: Department of Building Science, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Lin, K., Department of Building Science, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Zhang, Y., Department of Building Science, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Jiang, Y., Department of Building Science, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Abstract: This paper illustrates the mechanisms of applying phase change material (PCM) wallboard combined with controlled night ventilation to improve the indoor thermal performance of offices in summer. The aim of the study is to investigate the effects of PCM wallboard on thermal performance of a room with night ventilation numerically, and to provide a method of designing the PCM wallboard and night ventilation. The paper develops a theoretical model for analyzing the thermal performance of PCM wallboard rooms combined with controlled night ventilation in summer, and defines two new parameters (I DC and IDCT) for describing the overheating degree, with which to evaluate the potential of controlled night ventilation in PCM wallboard rooms. The method of optimizing the design of PCM wallboard and night ventilation is discussed by the example of a 5m×5m office in Yining in China. The result shows that PCM wallboard can improve the indoor thermal comfort degree in non-air-conditioned buildings in some regions. The study is useful for designing more effective PCM wall for passive energy storage.
Author Keywords: Night ventilation; Phase change material; Thermal comfort
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Buildings; Computer simulation; Differential scanning calorimetry; Energy storage; Freezing; Optimization; Night ventilation; Phase change materials (PCM); Thermal comfort; Thermal energy; Ventilation

Authors: Lin K., Zhang Y.
Title: Modeling and simulation of thermal performance of under-floor electric heating system with shape-stabilized PCM thermal energy storage plate
Source title: Energy and the Environment - Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy and the Environment
Affiliations: Department of Building Science, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Lin, K., Department of Building Science, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Zhang, Y., Department of Building Science, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Abstract: The paper illustrates a structure of electric floor heating system with shape-stabilized phase change material (PCM) thermal storage plate as a new space-heating mode. Such system is of two salient features: being capable of applying the electricity at night which may be much cheaper than that at daytime to heat the occupied space so that the electric tariff may be saved a lot, and the thermal comfort degree can be improved compared with applying sensible heat thermal energy storage plate. The main purpose of the paper is to clarify the thermal performance of the system and its feasibility in winter. For this reason a theoretical model of analyzing the thermal performance of a room applying under-floor electric heating system with shape-stabilized PCM thermal energy storage in winter is developed. The model refers to the overall building envelopes, electric floor system and indoor air. By modeling and simulation, the main factors of influencing the thermal performance of the system are clarified. To improve the indoor thermal comfort degree and reduce the energy waste, the paper presents a control method of varying the heating area in responds to the mean indoor temperature of the previous day and calculates its effect.
Author Keywords: Electric floor heating; Shape-stabilized PCM; Thermal energy storage

Authors: Isaacs T.H., Choi J.-S.
Title: Management of global nuclear materials for international security
Source title: Global 2003: Atoms for Prosperity: Updating Eisenhowers Global Vision for Nuclear Energy
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA 94551-0808, United States
Authors with affiliations: Isaacs, T.H., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA 94551-0808, United States; Choi, J.-S., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA 94551-0808, United States
Abstract: Nuclear materials were first used to end the World War II. They were produced and maintained during the cold war for global security reasons. In the succeeding50 years since the Atoms for Peace Initiative, nuclear materials were produced and used in global civilian reactors and fuel cycles intended for peaceful purposes. The Nonproliferation Treaty (NPT) of 1970 established a framework for appropriate applications of both defense and civilian nuclear activities by nuclear weapons states and non-nuclear weapons states. As global inventories of nuclear materials continue to grow, in a diverse and dynamically changing manner, it is time to evaluate current and future trends and needed actions: what are the current circumstances, what has been done to date, what has worked and what hasn't? The aim is to identify mutually reinforcing programmatic directions, leading to global partnerships that measurably enhance international security. Essential elements are material protection, control and accountability (MPC&A) of separated nuclear materials, interim storage, and geologic repositories for all nuclear materials destined for final disposal. Cooperation among key partners, such as the MPC&A program between the U.S. and Russia for nuclear materials from dismantled weapons, is necessary for interim storage and final disposal of nuclear materials. Such cooperative partnerships can lead to a new nuclear regime where a complete fuel cycle service with fuel leasing and spent fuel take-back can be offered to reactor users. The service can effectively minimize or even eliminate the incentive or rationale for the user-countries to develop their indigenous enrichment and reprocessing technologies. International cooperation, supported by governments of key countries can be best to facilitate the forum for formation of such cooperative partnerships.
Index Keywords: Cooperative partnerships; Global nuclear materials; International security; Accident prevention; Civil defense; Disaster prevention; Information dissemination; International cooperation; Nuclear fuels; Nuclear reactors; Ordnance; Nuclear energy

Authors: Smith R.M., Tulenko J.S.
Title: The feasibility of greater than 5-wt% U 235 commercial fuel
Source title: Global 2003: Atoms for Prosperity: Updating Eisenhowers Global Vision for Nuclear Energy
Affiliations: University of Florida, 202 Nuclear Sciences Center, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, R.M., University of Florida, 202 Nuclear Sciences Center, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Tulenko, J.S., University of Florida, 202 Nuclear Sciences Center, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Abstract: The nuclear power industry is currently limited to 5-wt% U 235 fuel. Increasing this limit would enable utilities to decrease the number of spent fuel assemblies, allow upgrades in reactor power, more flexibility in fuel cycle lengths, and make way for the development of advanced fuel designs. Any increase in fuel enrichments will require an extensive analysis of the current manufacturing, shipping, and storage of enriched fuel. The cost of this analysis, the licensing, and the upgrades to existing facilities may not justify the use of higher enriched fuel. The purpose of this study is to develop an economic model to determine the feasibility of using greater than 5-wt% U 235 commercial fuel. The study is currently focusing on evaluating typical fuel-processing operations to establish limits on current facilities and cost penalties for fabricating, shipping, and storage of higher enriched fuel. Our studies show that there appears to be an economic incentive for reactors on a 24-month cycle to increase enrichments up to 6.5-wt% U 235.
Index Keywords: Composite fuels; Economic models; Fuel enrichments; Accident prevention; Nuclear energy; Nuclear industry; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste transportation; Uranium; Spent fuels

Authors: Liu D., Xu Y., Song M., Huang W.

Abstract: In order to study the application of PCMs (phase change material system) in solar water heater, an experimental apparatus of solar water heater using paraffin wax as PCM (phase change material) to store heat is designed and set up. The experimental results for thermal storage process and insulating process show that the efficiency of thermal storage can be increased at least by 12% and the capability of heat preservation can be greatly improved (the coefficient of average heat loss decrease at least by 35%) compared with the common solar water heater with the same absorber area and storage volume when the PCM capsules (Φ40mm) is put into the water tank (Φ300mm×420mm). The experimental investigations about the effect of porosities on thermal performances of the solar water heater are also carried out.

Authors: Sproat III E.F., McNeill Jr. C.A., Nicholls D., Kadak A., Matzie R.
Title: Demonstrating the nuclear hydrogen roadmap with the pebble bed modular reactor
Source title: Global 2003: Atoms for Prosperity: Updating Eisenhowers Global Vision for Nuclear Energy
Affiliations: 18 Long Lane, Berwyn, PA, United States; ESKOM, P.O.Box 1091, Johannesburg 2000, South Africa; MIT, 77 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge, MA, United States; Westinghouse Electric Co., 2000 Day Hill Rd, Windsor, CT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sproat III, E.F., 18 Long Lane, Berwyn, PA, United States; McNeill Jr., C.A.; Nicholls, D., ESKOM, P.O.Box 1091, Johannesburg 2000, South Africa; Kadak, A., MIT, 77 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge, MA, United States; Matzie, R., Westinghouse Electric Co., 2000 Day Hill Rd, Windsor, CT, United States
Abstract: The US Department of Energy (DOE) has made the development of hydrogen production, transmission and utilization technologies leading to a hydrogen economy a national priority and has developed a National Hydrogen Roadmap which identifies needed research and development work in these areas. As part of that roadmap, the use of nuclear energy for the carbon emission-free production of hydrogen was identified as an objective. Planning being done within the DOE and national laboratories indicates that the demonstration of the large scale generation of hydrogen from nuclear energy will not take place until the middle of the next decade. The authors propose that by utilizing the work performed in the Republic of South Africa over the last five years in the development of the Pebble Bed Modular Reactor (PBMR), the demonstration of this crucial piece of the national hydrogen roadmap can be accomplished, at least five years earlier than the indicated in the current plan.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Energy storage; Fueling; Hydrogen; Industrial emissions; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuels; Nuclear reactor licensing; Electricity production; Hydrogen production; Pebble bed modular reactors (PBMR); Nuclear reactors

Authors: Elsden A.
Title: Sustainability - The role of fuel cycle technologies for the future
Source title: Global 2003: Atoms for Prosperity: Updating Eisenhowers Global Vision for Nuclear Energy
Affiliations: BNFL, 1100 Daresbury Park Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4GB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Elsden, A., BNFL, 1100 Daresbury Park Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4GB, United Kingdom
Abstract: The role of fuel cycle technologies in meeting future energy demands is discussed. It is suggested that when considering a fuel cycle for future strategy, the aim should be to allow maximum utilization of fissile material, by recycling unused uranium and plutonium from irradiated fuel and other sources. It is also suggested that optimization across the whole of the fuel cycle is required and that the outcome of the optimization process will be the driving force behind changes to the back end of the fuel cycle. The four major options for the back end of the fuel cycle are reprocessing, conditioning, interim storage and direct disposal.
Index Keywords: Environmental impact; Fission products; Mixed oxide fuels; Nuclear fuel reprocessing; Plutonium; Public policy; Radioactive waste disposal; Regulatory compliance; Sustainable development; Uranium; Energy demand; Fuel cycle; Robotic handling; Spent fuels

Authors: Althaus R., Wiederhold K., Rickli J.-P.
Title: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) a means for optimizing energy systems
Source title: Energy and the Environment - Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy and the Environment
Affiliations: ALSTOM (Power), Baden, Switzerland; JPR Concepts and Innovation, Uster, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Althaus, R., ALSTOM (Power), Baden, Switzerland; Wiederhold, K., ALSTOM (Power), Baden, Switzerland; Rickli, J.-P., JPR Concepts and Innovation, Uster, Switzerland
Abstract: Traditionally, the transmission and distribution grids branched out from the power plant to the outer limits of the allocated distribution region. The power plants itself, were located close to the fuel, e.g. the coal mines, the transportation terminals for the coal or the oil, the water retaining basin, etc. The grid was, in a certain kind, innerving the country with electrical power from a broad, central line into ever thinning lines, when reaching the outer regions of the distribution authority. The grid owner was, at the same time, also the main generator for the grid. Therefore, he had a strong interest to have a generation mix allowing him to ensure a safe and reliable supply of electricity and follow the load variations at any time. The deregulation of the electricity market brought a paradigm change for the owner of the transmission and distribution grid. The price of electricity is not any more a bulk mix for all services, e.g. generation, transmission, power bridging, power reliability and quality. Much more, all these functions have to be paid separately. Additional players, like power producers out of renewable energy sources, add their toll on the existing grids as their location does not necessarily correspond to the grid structure. Furthermore, their stochastic character brings an increase in the volatility of this market and an additional uncertainty as well. Within this new environment, the value of ancillary services has to be defined appropriately to ensure an adequate mix of generation capacity and characteristics. Furthermore, energy storage becomes more and more an issue and the corresponding technologies are actually evaluated. One of these, based on decades of experience, is the "Compressed Air Energy Storage" (CAES). It is besides pumped hydropower, the other solution for large energy storage capacity. The present paper gives the actual status of that technology as applied for the actual option for projects in the United States. Various aspects of grid operation with CAES plants are discussed together with the related economical factors.

Abstract: Surface exchanging heat coefficient is one of the important parameters analyzed in building energy consumption. It has a great significant to load calculation and building energy consumption analysis that measuring and distinguishing surface exchanging heat coefficient of phase change and energy storage wallboard correctly. This paper utilizes the data collecting system to collect two important parameters: the heat flow of wall surface and the difference in temperature between the indoor air and the wall surface. Then the sample data are distinguished respectively with the genetic algorithm and least square method. The estimating data of surface exchanging heat coefficient are reached finally. The predictable data and experimental data are very identical while comparing the surveying data of heat flow and predictable data of genetic algorithm. It proved that the genetic algorithm is an effective method of obtaining surface exchanging heat coefficient of phase change and energy storage wallboard by a kind of dynamic experimental data of wall surface.

Title: Power system quality improvement using doubly-fed rotary frequency converter
Source title: Proceedings of the IASTED International Conference, PowerCon 2003 - Special Theme: Blackout
Affiliations: Shibaura Institute of Technology, 3-9-14 Shibaura, Minato-ku, Tokyo 108-8548, Japan; Tokyo Metropolitan Univiversity, 1-1 Minamiosawa, Hachioji-shi, Tokyo 197-0397, Japan; Tepco Systems Corporations, 6-19-15 Shinbashi, Manito-ku, Tokyo 105-0004, Japan; Meidensha Corporations, 36-2 Nihonbashihakozakicho, Cyuo-ku, Tokyo 103-8515, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kajihara, M., Shibaura Institute of Technology, 3-9-14 Shibaura, Minato-ku, Tokyo 108-8548, Japan; Ezaki, K., Shibaura Institute of Technology, 3-9-14 Shibaura, Minato-ku, Tokyo 108-8548, Japan; Okuda, M., Shibaura Institute of Technology, 3-9-14 Shibaura, Minato-ku, Tokyo 108-8548, Japan; Fujita, G., Shibaura Institute of Technology, 3-9-14 Shibaura, Minato-ku, Tokyo 108-8548, Japan; Yokoyama, R., Tokyo Metropolitan Univiversity, 1-1 Minamiosawa, Hachioji-shi, Tokyo 197-0397, Japan; Koyanagi, K., Tepco Systems Corporations, 6-19-15 Shinbashi, Manito-ku, Tokyo 105-0004, Japan; Funabashi, T., Meidensha Corporations, 36-2 Nihonbashihakozakicho, Cyuo-ku, Tokyo 103-8515, Japan
Abstract: An application of rotary frequency converter for a wind farm system is proposed in this paper. Wind power is getting attention for prospective renewal energy sources, and introduction of wind farm generation will solve environmental matters and energy exhaust problem. However, the quality of power system frequency will be degraded as the capacity of wind power generator increases. Attenuation of mismatch between the served power and load demand is most important problem in order to increase number of wind generators. A wind firm is connected to the proposed rotary frequency converter as a buffer to connect the wind farm and the power system. This provides energy storage function of the output power associated with irregular wind power. The converter has a synchronous generator and a doubly-fed machine. The synchronous motor is connected to the wind farm to supply AC voltage for induction generators of wind power generation units. The shaft of the doubly-fed machine is mechanically jointed to the synchronous motor, and rotates together. Tuning the current of the secondary winding supplied by cycloconverter or self-commutated inverter controls the output power. At present, doubly-fed machine is commonly used in pumped storage hydraulic power plants recently constructed. The proposed scheme is an expansion from the present application. In order to evaluate the proposed scheme, firstly, load reference simulation test is carried out for discussion of the power exchange response to a power grid. Secondly, experimental study is discussed in order to identify the required capacity for the rotary frequency converter to improve the frequency quality. These studies show preferable characteristic for the viewpoint of power system quality improvement.
Author Keywords: Flywheel; Rotary frequency converter; Wind generation
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric energy storage; Electric inverters; Electric power generation; Flywheels; Frequency converters; Synchronous generators; Wind power; Rotary frequency converters; Wind generation; Wind generators; Electric power systems

Authors: Buczek B., Klimowska E.
Title: Physico-chemical treatment of commercial active carbon for its utilize in adsorption cooling system
Source title: Energy and the Environment - Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy and the Environment
Affiliations: University of Mining and Metallurgy, Cracow, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Buczek, B., University of Mining and Metallurgy, Cracow, Poland; Klimowska, E., University of Mining and Metallurgy, Cracow, Poland
Abstract: Methanol adsorption of the active carbon seems to be very interesting for use in thermodynamic systems such as heat pumps and transformers as well as cooling systems. The porous structure of commercial active carbon modified by successive removal of external layers from a particle surface as produced by abrasion in a spouted bed and by demineralisation was evaluated on the basis of the nitrogen adsorption data and those for methanol. The modifications improve densimetric characteristics and heat effects of methanol adsorption. Porous structure parameters obtained for nitrogen and methanol agreed reasonably well and Dubinin-Radushkevich approach can be useful method for characterisation of these systems. The methods for calculation of heat effects of methanol adsorption in wide range of temperature and pressures are discussed.

Authors: Tinturier B., Debes M.
Title: EDF's views and commitments concerning energy sustainability and nuclear energy
Source title: Global 2003: Atoms for Prosperity: Updating Eisenhowers Global Vision for Nuclear Energy
Affiliations: EDF, 22/30 avenue Wagram, 75008 Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Tinturier, B., EDF, 22/30 avenue Wagram, 75008 Paris, France; Debes, M., EDF, 22/30 avenue Wagram, 75008 Paris, France
Abstract: Energy sustainability and nuclear energy nowadays are in fact far reaching issues with many implications: safety and public acceptance, long term development and energy choices, high level waste treatment, economy, political and democratic choices. Regarding spent fuel and the back-end of fuel cycle, the current reprocessing and recycling strategy enables to meet sustainable development requirements in the long run with existing facilities: Ensuring a fully safe and long lasting confinement of high level waste, with vitrification in glass canisters. Reducing the amount of nuclear spent fuel in interim storage. Maintaining the possibility for the far future to use the plutonium concentrated in the MOX spent fuel. Maintaining the flexibility of future choices concerning back-end and nuclear waste treatment. For the far future EDF considers Generation IV program to design fast reactors able to burn plutonium and to ensure a full use of uranium resource, while minimizing high level wastes or minor actinides.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Radioactive wastes; Spent fuels; Sustainable development; Vitrification; Waste treatment; EDF; Energy sustainability; Europe; Political aspects; Nuclear energy

Authors: Xu S., Li W., Zhang L., Guo Y., Quan S.
Title: A new thermal energy storage technology: Refrigerating/heating potential storage technology
Source title: Energy and the Environment - Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy and the Environment
Affiliations: Department of Power Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning, China
Authors with affiliations: Xu, S., Department of Power Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning, China; Li, W., Department of Power Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning, China; Zhang, L., Department of Power Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning, China; Guo, Y., Department of Power Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning, China; Quan, S., Department of Power Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning, China
Abstract: This paper proposes a new idea of thermal energy storage (TES) technology which is not to directly store cold or heat energy, but is to change a kind of energy, such as electric, heat and other formal energy, into the refrigerating/heating potential - chemical potential of working fluids, and then the potential is stored. When the consumers need cold or thermal energy, the stored potential can easily be transformed into cold or thermal energy by means of refrigeration or heat pump. So the TES technology is called as refrigerating/heating potential storage (R/HPS) technology.

Authors: Job P.K., Alderman J.
Title: A neutron detection system for electron accelerators
Source title: International Meeting on Nuclear Applications of Accelerator Technology: Accelerator Application in a Nuclear Renaissance
Affiliations: Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Job, P.K., Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Alderman, J., Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Abstract: In an electron accelerator, neutrons are generated as a result of the electron beam interaction with high-Z materials, such as scrapers and collimators. When the energy of the incident electron beam is sufficiently high, it can produce high-energy photons, which subsequently interact with a nucleus, resulting in the emission of neutrons. This interaction is known as a photonuclear interaction. The Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory consists of a 7 GeV electron storage ring, which is high enough energy to produce photonuclear interactions. Neutron fluence estimates inside the APS storage ring during operation revealed non-trivial neutron fluences for stored beam loss as well as injection loss on accelerator components. A 93% enriched 235U fission detector was chosen for the purpose of measuring the neutron fluence within the APS storage ring. When a neutron interacts with the thin (16 mg) 235U foil, fission occurs, producing two fission fragments of approximately 80 MeV each, and a few neutrons. Due to their higher energy (80 MeV), fission fragments produce ionization within the detector, resulting in a large pulse, which allows for the essential discrimination between neutrons and photons in a high photon background. The detector provides valuable information on the photoneutron fluence within the APS accelerator tunnel as well as useful information on the beam loss scenarios at various locations. These detection systems also make it possible to monitor neutron doses in terms of neutron-induced damage of radiation-sensitive equipment within accelerators.
Index Keywords: Beam loss; Electron storage ring; Photon sources; Photonuclear interaction; Copper; Dosimetry; Electron beams; Fission reactions; Ionization; Neutron detectors; Optical collimators; Particle accelerators

Authors: Cao J., Sheng K.
Title: Study of load forecasting and optimal operation of boiler plant with thermal storage
Source title: Energy and the Environment - Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy and the Environment

Abstract: Load forecasting is a precondition of optimal operation of boiler plant. In the paper the method of least square trend rejection is adopted to make a feasible domain of load forecasting, of which can be found out the optimal forecasting including the optimal segmentation and the load levels for various intervals. These load levels allow optimal assignment of load to the boilers, thus guarantee the overall cost of unit heat produced by the plant being the minimum. A computer program was completed according to the model blocks of load forecasting and optimization of load assignment together with optimal segmentation of a workday. Computation examples are given.

Abstract: Based on illuminating the benefits from utilization of natural cooling/heating sources and the characteristics of them, a new type of residential air-conditioning system utilizing aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES), groundwater and solar energy is put forward in the paper. Then basic concepts of ATES are illustrated and the numerical models of ATES systems are presented. Adapting a special model (Steady Flow Model), a computer program is built up to simulate ATES systems. Making use of the computer program, the results of ATES under different conditions are thus simulated respectively. Eventually, the simulation results are discussed in the eyes of application in engineering.

Authors: Gallego N.C., Burchell T.D.
Title: Carbon materials for hydrogen storage
Source title: Global 2003: Atoms for Prosperity: Updating Eisenhowers Global Vision for Nuclear Energy
Affiliations: Carbon Materials Technology Group, Metals and Ceramics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gallego, N.C., Carbon Materials Technology Group, Metals and Ceramics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, United States; Burchell, T.D., Carbon Materials Technology Group, Metals and Ceramics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, United States
Abstract: The issue of hydrogen storage on carbon materials has opened up a big discussion and controversy. The Carbon Materials Technology Group at ORNL is currently undergoing a comprehensive study of several forms of carbon, from the very amorphous activated carbons to the very ordered forms such as graphite and nanostructured carbons. Hydrogen uptake measurements were performed in a gravimetric system at both room and cryogenic temperatures, and at pressures of up to 20 bar (∼300psi). It was found that carbon materials store very little hydrogen (<0.3 wt. %) at room temperature but considerable amounts of hydrogen at cryogenic temperatures. The ongoing effort is being focused on understanding the variables (carbon source, surface area, pore size, dopants, degree of crystallinity, etc) that affect hydrogen adsorption, and to tailor these properties to optimize the storage to achieve the current storage target established by the US Department of Energy.

Abstract: The research on waste conducted in the framework of the law of December 30, 1991 in France is discussed. The research is conducted for minimizing the quantity and the hazardousness of waste, disposing the waste in deep geological formations, waste conditioning and long-term interim storage. The research has been conducted in a sustained way since 1992 and benefits from major co-operations in France, Europe and internationally. It was concluded that plutonium control, recycling and management are the first priority in any strategy to minimize radiotoxicity.

Abstract: The economics of nuclear hydrogen production for chemical plants and petroleum refineries was discussed. It integrates the nuclear and thermochemical processes with infrastructure. The baseline cost of natural gas used in nuclear hydrogen production was $ 5 per million BTU. The delivered cost of hydrogen was estimated to be $ 1.39 per kilogram. The major economic variables, in addition to plant type, includes the levelized price of the natural gas and the value of credits related to the carbon free nature of nuclear hydrogen.

Authors: Zheng M., Wang L., Gong L.
Title: Experimental research on ice-making and ice-dropping of longitudinal ribbed pipe dynamic ice thermal storage
Source title: Energy and the Environment - Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy and the Environment
Affiliations: Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, Heilongjiang, China; Jilin Arch./Civ. Eng. Institute, Jilin, China; 4th Eng. Des./Res. Acad. Gen. Staff, PLA, China
Authors with affiliations: Zheng, M., Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, Heilongjiang, China; Wang, L., Jilin Arch./Civ. Eng. Institute, Jilin, China; Gong, L., 4th Eng. Des./Res. Acad. Gen. Staff, PLA, China
Abstract: Thermal storage is a practical energy saving technique that promotes energy, economy and environment to correspondingly develop. This air-conditioning system using ice storage technique aims for peak load shifting and energy conservation. Dynamic ice storage is the most advantageous method of ice storage. In this article, in detail present that using longitudinal ribbed pipe as evaporator studies the dynamic ice storage of the direct evaporating ice making and compressor-exhausting ice dropping. It also indicates a small-scale ice storage air-condition system which is equipped with air-conditioner and involves ice making, ice dropping, ice storage and ice melting. The foundation of this system mainly purposes to study the process and characteristic of ice making and ice dropping of longitudinal ribbed pipe. And the efficiency of ice making is also mainly studied. Many experiments are made about the effect of the length of longitudinal rib, the different angle between the longitudinal ribs around the pipe and the time of compressor-exhausting recoil on ice dropping. The reasonable angle between the ribs is optimized. The function of this device involves ice-making, ice-dropping and ice-storage. Its initial cost is small and the technology is simple. It is very suitable for the moderate, small scale ice storage air-conditioning system.
Author Keywords: Ice thermal storage; Ice-dropping; Ice-making; Longitudinal ribbed pipe

It has many merits: high phase change latent heat; no pollution; convenient regulation; no conventional charge difficulty. It can make full use of evening electricity, alleviate much difference between the peak value and the vale value in the power network and save operation cost of electrical heating. Abstract: Various properties of metal hydrides and their use in energy storage and conversion systems are discussed. Metal hydrides can be classified in terms of the hydrogen bonding to the metal. For the alloy side of the hydride family, hydrogen is usually bound in the interstitial sites in a metallic state with usually minor distortions of generally stable H-free alloy structure. Metal hydrides are being considered for applications involving the absorption and desorption of hydrogen gas, as many of them can readily absorb and desorb hydrogen gas around room temperature and near atmospheric H 2 pressure.

Title: A modified nitride-based fuel for long core life and proliferation resistance
Source title: Global 2003: Atoms for Prosperity: Updating Eisenhowers Global Vision for Nuclear Energy
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94551, United States

Abstract: A modified nitride-based uranium fuel to support the small, secured, transportable, and autonomous reactor (SSTAR) 1 concept is initiated at Lawrence Livermore National laboratory (LLNL). This project centers on the evaluation of modified uranium nitride fuels imbedded with other inert (e.g. ZrN), neutron-absorbing (e.g. HfN), or breeding (e.g. ThN) nitrides to enhance the fuel properties to achieve long core life. A long-life fuel could minimize the need for on-site refueling and spent-fuel storage. As a result, it could significantly improve the proliferation resistance of the reactor/fuel systems. This paper discusses the potential benefits and detriments of modified nitride-based fuels using the criteria of compactness, long-life, proliferation resistance, fuel safety, and waste management. Benefits and detriments are then considered in recommending a select set of compositions for further study.

Inst., Justus-Liebig-University, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, D-35392 Giessen, Germany; Münzenberg, G., Gesell. für Schwerionenforsch., Planckstr. 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Shiskine, V., Gesell. für Schwerionenforsch., Planckstr. 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Weick, H., Gesell. für Schwerionenforsch., Planckstr. 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Wollnik, H., II. Phys. Inst., Justus-Liebig-University, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, D-35392 Giessen, Germany; Yavor, M., Inst. of Analytic Instrumentation, Russian Academy of Science, Rizhskij pr. 26, 198103 St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: For more than a decade the projectile FRagment Separator FRS at GSI (Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, Darmstadt, Germany) has successfully demonstrated the research potential of in-flight separators at relativistic energies. Many pioneering experiments have been performed specially also in combination with the storage-cooler ring ESR. To move closer to the extreme limit of stability the next generation of a large-scale European in-flight facility is presently planned at GSI. It will provide primary beam intensities of up to 1012 ions/s of 238U at an energy of 1500 MeV/u. The new fragment separator, the Super-FRS, is a super conducting large acceptance device with multiple degrader stages. It is especially well suited for the separation of projectile fission fragments with large phase space. Different experimental branches including a combination with a new storage-cooler ring system follow the Super-FRS. The layout and the characteristics of the facility will be presented.

Authors: Fukuda K., Bonne A.
Title: Highlights of IAEA's recent and current activities on nuclear fuel cycle technologies for sustainable development of nuclear energy
Source title: Global 2003: Atoms for Prosperity: Updating Eisenhowers Global Vision for Nuclear Energy

Abstract: The IAEA has implemented the Nuclear Fuel Cycle and Materials Programme for assisting the Member States in policy making, strategic planning, developing technology and addressing issues regarding the nuclear fuel cycle. This programme consists of four sub-programmes, designed to cover the entire nuclear fuel cycle. This paper highlights the prominent outputs from the programme. For the sub-programme on uranium production, a brief summary of the Red-Book is given, focusing on uranium supply and demand. From the sub-programme on fuel technology, three highlights are described; the MOX symposium, a technical document on fuel behaviour modelling and a MOX fuel technical document. From the sub-programme on spent fuel management, the international conference on spent fuel storage is highlighted, as well as several documents in this area. The international conference on innovative technologies for nuclear fuel cycle and nuclear power is highlighted from the fourth sub-programme, covering nuclear fuel cycle issue.
Index Keywords: Energy utilization; Nuclear energy; Nuclear reactors; Strategic planning; Sustainable development; Technical presentations; Uranium; Fuel behavior modeling; MOX; Nuclear fuel cycles; Spent fuel management; Spent fuels

Authors: Zander D., Kofmann B., Eliezer D., Gutmanas E.Y., Abramov E., Olson D.
Title: Influence of hydrogen on phase stability and microhardness in Ti-Nb
Source title: Hydrogen Effects on Material Behaviour and Corrosion Deformation Interactions - Proc. of the International Conference on Hydrogen Effects on Material Behaviour and Corrosion Deformation Interactions
Affiliations: Dept. of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO 80401-1887, United States; Dept. of Materials Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel; Dept. of Materials Engineering, Technion, Haifa 32000, Israel; Nuclear Research Center, Negev, P.O.Box 9001, Beer-Sheva, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Zander, D., Dept. of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO 80401-1887, United States, Dept. of Materials Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel; Kofmann, B., Dept. of Materials Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel; Eliezer, D., Dept. of Materials Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel; Gutmanas, E.Y., Dept. of Materials Engineering, Technion, Haifa 32000, Israel; Abramov, E., Nuclear Research Center, Negev, P.O.Box 9001, Beer-Sheva, Israel; Olson, D., Dept. of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO 80401-1887, United States
Abstract: Alloying of Ti-based alloys with hydrogen is used to modify microstructure and hence microhardness. Titanium and titanium alloys have a high affinity to hydrogen and a large storage capacity. In this study, hydrogen charging was performed electrochemically in a 2:1 glycerin-phosphoric acid electrolyte at high fugacities. The objective of our present research is to investigate in detail by means of X-ray diffraction, SEM as well as TEM and microhardness the influence of hydrogen at high fugacities on phase stability as well as on microhardness in Ti-Nb (20-45 wt.% Nb) alloys. Hydrogenation of Ti-Nb was found to exhibit a significant effect on the phase stability as well as the microhardness of Ti-Nb (20-45 wt.% Nb). Hydrogenation of the near α Ti-20wt.%Nb alloy at high fugacities led to precipitation of (Ti,Nb)H x in the metastable α″ matrix and to an increase of the lattice parameter of the β-phase. The microhardness of Ti-20wt.%Nb decreased with increasing hydrogen content up to 3000 ppm. For the investigated β Ti-Nb alloys, it was found that hydrogen stabilized the investigated bcc β-phase, but destabilized the hep ω-phase. With increasing hydrogen content an expansion of the lattice constant of the β-phase occurred, followed by the formation of (Ti,Nb)Hx. The microhardness measurements for Ti-40wt.%Nb nor for Ti-45wt.%Nb showed no significant change after hydrogenation. It is known that hydrogen strongly influences the slip mechanism in the bcc-phase and assists in lowering the deformation energy, so the influence of hydrogen on the mechanism of plastic deformation of Ti-Nb is of considerable interest. The observed microstructural investigations should provide significant insight as to the microstructural mechanism through which hydrogen enhances the plasticity of Ti-Nb alloys.
Index Keywords: Alloying; Chemical modification; Electrolytes; Hydrogen; Lattice constants; Microhardness; Microstructure; Niobium alloys; Scanning electron microscopy; Transmission electron microscopy; X ray diffraction analysis; Fugacities; Hydrogen charging; Phase stability; Storage capacity; Titanium alloys

Authors: Shields E.A., Liu W., Talghader J.J., Leger J.R.
Title: Imaging micro-spectrometer with space-variant adaptive dispersion incorporating a MEMS mirror array
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, 200 Union St. SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shields, E.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, 200 Union St. SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Liu, W., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, 200 Union St. SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Talghader, J.J., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, 200 Union St. SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Leger, J.R., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, 200 Union St. SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Abstract: We report the design, fabrication, and testing of a novel imaging micro-spectrometer system for the 500-1000 nm wavelength range. The space-variant design incorporates a linear array of MEMS mirrors in order to vary the dispersion spatially on a pixel-by-pixel basis. A planar-optics geometry is used so that the spectrometer optics are contained on a single piece of bulk fused silica. The object to be investigated is imaged onto a linear array of tilting MEMS mirrors that define the spectrometer slit. Each individual MEMS mirror tilts to send the light to one of three blazed gratings of differing dispersive powers. Depending on the wavelength and selected grating the spectral resolution is between 5 and 20 nm. The collimating and focusing mirrors of the spectrometer are fabricated in standard photoresist via grayscale photolithography with a custom high-energy beam-sensitive (HEBS) photomask. A reflow at 70 degrees Celsius for 40 hours is necessary to achieve near diffraction-limited performance. The blazed gratings are fabricated in SU-8 via direct-write electron-beam lithography. Spectrometer results with a variety of lasers and gaseous discharge tubes are presented and indicate that system performs as expected.
Author Keywords: MEMS; Micro-optics; MOEMS; Optical spectrometer; Space-variant systems
