Authors: Fillion R., Wojnarowski R., Kapusta C., Saia R., Kwiatkowski K., Lyke J.
Title: Three-D Vertically Stacked Electronic Structures for Array Sensors
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: GE Global Research, Niskayuna, NY 12309, United States; Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States; Air Force Research Laboratory, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fillion, R., GE Global Research, Niskayuna, NY 12309, United States; Wojnarowski, R., GE Global Research, Niskayuna, NY 12309, United States; Kapusta, C., GE Global Research, Niskayuna, NY 12309, United States; Saia, R., GE Global Research, Niskayuna, NY 12309, United States; Kwiatkowski, K., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States; Lyke, J., Air Force Research Laboratory, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Abstract: Array sensors such as Focal Plane Array Detectors, IR Imagers, X-Ray detectors and the like, have dense arrays of detector cells that capture ultra-low levels of energy. The energy received in each array pixel is in the form of low levels of UV, IR, or visible light, X-Rays, microwaves or other electromagnetic energy and is converted in each array pixel into electrical signals. These sensor arrays are used in military imaging or detection or in medical or industrial diagnostic imagining. In all of these areas, the pixel density is being continually increased as fabrication photolithography attains finer resolution and the device performance is improved. This leads to arrays with ever decreasing levels of stored energy per pixel and ever-increasing number of pixels per device. These trends lead to lower pixel output signals that are more susceptible to interconnect signal losses, cross-talk and external noise, all of which are made worse by the increase in the number of pixels and in the pixel density. One approach to overcoming these issues is to move the signal processing closer to the array, minimizing the number of interconnects and the interconnect length the raw pixel signal outputs must travel prior to pre-processing, such as amplification, noise suppression, and digitization. One innovative approach to achieving this is to use 3-D stacking of the preprocessing electronics for each pixel directly behind the sensor array. This paper will describe the development of a high density, 3-D stacking technology that is being applied to an 8000 pixel array sensor.
Author Keywords: Array Interconnections; Array Sensors; Chip-on-Flex; Thinned Electronics; Three-D Stacking
Index Keywords: Array interconnections; Array sensors; Chip-on-flex; Thinned electronics; Three-D stacking; Analog to digital conversion; Arrays; Electric energy storage; Electromagnetism; Electron energy levels; Infrared imaging; Medical imaging; Microsensors; Microwaves; Noise abatement; Photolithography; Microelectronics

Authors: Lantz II L., Pecht M.G., Wood M.
Title: A comparison of ion diffusion and moisture diffusion in a commercial epoxy molding compound
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20740, United States; Army Research Lab., Adelphi, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lantz II, L., University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20740, United States; Pecht, M.G., University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20740, United States; Wood, M., Army Research Lab., Adelphi, MD, United States
Abstract: Ion-induced corrosion during long-term use and dormant storage are primary concerns related to the use of plastic encapsulated devices in high reliability programs. Though ionic contamination of a semiconductor device is known to accelerate failure of the device, the diffusion of ions in device encapsulants has not been measured, perhaps due to the difficulty of measuring ion diffusion in these heavily filled glassy polymers. In this article, the measurement of ion diffusion in common encapsulants for electronic devices by Dynamic Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (DSIMS) is discussed. This technique is well suited for the measurement of ions in encapsulant materials due to its ability to measure all elements of the periodic table including elemental hydrogen and its detection limit in the ppb range for most elements. The diffusion of chloride ions and moisture in a common encapsulant material were measured. Ion diffusion was shown to be slower than moisture diffusion by approximately nine orders of magnitude, in the encapsulant.
Author Keywords: Corrosion; Diffusion; Encapsulant; Ions; Moisture; Molding compounds; Reliability
Index Keywords: Die attach; Electrostatic analyzers; Encapsulants; Ion diffusion; Chemical bonds; Corrosion; Diffusion; Energy dispersive spectroscopy; Epoxy resins; Hydrogen; Metallizing; Moisture; Polymers; Reliability theory; Scanning electron microscopy; Secondary ion mass spectrometry; Sheet molding compounds

Authors: Heisler G.M., Grant R.H., Nowak D.J., Gao W., Crane D.E., Walton J.T.
Title: Inclusion of an Ultraviolet Radiation Transfer Component in an Urban Forest Effects Model for Predicting Tree Influences on Potential Below-Canopy Exposure to UVB Radiation
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: USDA Forest Service, 5 Moon Library, c/o SUNY Environ. Sci. and Forestry, Syracuse, NY 13210, United States; Department of Agronomy, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907-1150, United States; USDA UV-B Monitoring/Res. Program, Natural Resource Ecology Laboratory, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO 80523, United States
Authors with affiliations: Heisler, G.M., USDA Forest Service, 5 Moon Library, c/o SUNY Environ. Sci. and Forestry, Syracuse, NY 13210, United States; Grant, R.H., Department of Agronomy, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907-1150, United States; Nowak, D.J., USDA Forest Service, 5 Moon Library, c/o SUNY Environ. Sci. and Forestry, Syracuse, NY 13210, United States; Gao, W., USDA UV-B Monitoring/Res. Program, Natural Resource Ecology Laboratory, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO 80523, United States; Crane, D.E., USDA Forest Service, 5 Moon Library, c/o SUNY Environ. Sci. and Forestry, Syracuse, NY 13210, United States; Walton, J.T., USDA Forest Service, 5 Moon Library, c/o SUNY Environ. Sci. and Forestry, Syracuse, NY 13210, United States
Abstract: Evaluating the impact of ultraviolet-B radiation (UVB) on urban populations would be enhanced by improved predictions of the UVB radiation at the level of human activity. This paper reports the status of plans for incorporating a UVB prediction module into an existing Urban Forest Effects (UFORE) model. UFORE currently has modules to quantify urban forest structure, urban tree volatile organic compound emissions, carbon storage and sequestration in urban vegetation, dry deposition of air pollutants on trees, tree influences on energy use for heating and cooling buildings, tree pollen allergenicity index, and replacement cost of trees. These modeled effects are based upon field sampling to characterize land use, vegetation cover, and building features. The field sampling includes recording of tree species, total height, height to base of live crown, and crown width on randomly selected 0.04-ha (0.1 acre) plots. Distance and direction from sampled trees to buildings are also measured. The input for UFORE modeling of effects includes hourly meteorological data and pollution-concentration data. UFORE has already been used in assessing the urban forest function of 13 cities in the United States and 5 cities in other countries. The objective of the present work is to enable UFORE to predict the effect of different urban tree densities on potential average human exposure to UVB. The current version of UFORE is written using the Statistical Analysis System (SAS); a new version will be a user-friendly Windows application and will be available for wide distribution. Progress to date on the UVB module consists primarily of examining available modeling and data collection tools. Two methods are proposed for the UVB module. In Method 1, we will derive predicted UVB irradiance 〈I b〉 at person height, that is, below the urban tree and building canopy, using gap fractions (sky view portions) measured from digitized fisheye photos taken from each of the UFORE plot centers during a UFORE field survey. A promising method for analyzing the photos is the use of Gap Light Analyzer (GLA). A human thermal comfort model will be used to determine the times when people would be comfortable outdoors in light attire, and UVB 〈I b〉 will be determined for those times. Method 2 will be applied in cases where hemispherical photos cannot be made available, and for making predictions for cities where surveys have already been done. Method 2 will use a 3D canopy UV radiation transfer model to derive 〈I b〉 based on tree canopy cover maps from GIS analysis of aerial color IR photographs or Landsat TM images. The UV module addition to UFORE will make it useful in epidemiology of UV-related human disease and assessment of UV benefits, such as in vitamin D production, and it will also facilitate consideration of UV exposure in urban forest management.
Author Keywords: Computer modeling; Hemispherical photos; Human disease; Human thermal comfort; urban forest influences
Index Keywords: Canopy exposure; Hemispherical photos; Human thermal comfort; Urban forest influences; UVB radiation; Air pollution; Antigen-antibody reactions; Computer aided analysis; Earth atmosphere; Ecosystems; Forestry; Health risks; Medicine; Meteorology; Tumors; Vegetation; Ultraviolet radiation

Authors: Val C.
Title: New approaches to 3-D interconnection systems in package applications
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: 3D PLUS, 641, rue Helène-Boucher, 78532 Buc, France
Authors with affiliations: Val, C., 3D PLUS, 641, rue Helène-Boucher, 78532 Buc, France
Abstract: The 3-D interconnection is presented under the signal integrity aspect with the use of a new concept for power integration in a cube. A quick comparison between 2-D and 3-D is carried out from the electrical performance aspect. Additionally, the various interconnection technologies are compared from the signal integrity criteria and technologies compatible with the arrival of lead-free processes. The interconnection techniques called "BUS metal" are more particularly presented with memories and SiP applications. We emphasize that the interconnection techniques do not take into account the integration of passive components however, these are essential to the building of SiP. The perspectives of 3-D interconnections are excellent, particularly as for 2 or 3 years ago, and we will present a significant improvement in the interconnection process which in bearing standard components (chips, capacitors, resistors, inductance) will allow stacking 6 levels per mm. The thinning of the 3-D modules opens new perspectives for all electronics applications.
Author Keywords: Power network; Signal integrity; SiP; Stacking

Authors: Xu Y., Liu G., Fang J.

Abstract: Permanent magnet brushless direct current motor (BDCM) used in attitude control and energy storage flywheel system features large air gap and large radius-to-length ratio. The air gap flux density of this kind of BDCM along circumference orientation and axis one is analyzed. Equivalent flux leakage coefficient and equivalent flux density calculating coefficient are brought about and calculated in order to design the motor conveniently. The presented results are verified by prototype experiment.

Title: Theoretical analysis of a Q-switch erbium doped fiber laser

Argentina de la Empresa, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Andres, M.V., Depto. de Física Aplicada, Univ. de Valencia, Burjassot, Spain
Abstract: The performance of a Q-swilch fiber laser with two fiber Bragg gratings as cavity mirrors was theoretically analyzed employing a set of rate equations for the ion populations and the photon flux inside the cavity. The model simulates the emission in the 1550 nm spectral region of an erbium-doped fiber laser pumped at 980 nm, where the temporal modulation is performed fixing one of the gratings to a piezoelectric (PZT) element. The temporal evolution of different frequency components is governed by the instantaneous overlap between both gratings. A frequency sweep that is observed in the output contributes to broaden temporally the pulse. Theoretical results are in coincidence with experimental values previously reported.

Abstract: As the cellular phone evolves IG to 3G & 4G, it is required that the various hardware, i.e., still & video camera, memory card, Bluetooth module, and high density memories should be packaged into the limited space of phone case and onto the limited size of PCB. Compared with discrete packages, SIP & SOC can provide better solutions which cellular phone requires like power saving, EMI reduction, max frequency up-grade in spite of higher cost, low test yield, quality assurance, and complicated manufacturing processes. Although SIP [System in (a) Package] and SOC [System on (a) Chip] may be the solution for the limited size and space of the cellular phone, there are still so many arguments about which will be a winner. SIP has strong merits on cost, delivery, and manufacturing process, whereas it has demerits on power consumption, max frequency limitation, compared with SOC. 320FBGA_1717, 1.4mmt SIP in this paper accommodates 1 application processor silicon die, 1 Nand flash [256Mb (x8)] silicon die, 2 SDRAM [128Mb(x16)] silicon dies [256Mb(x32) SDRAM]. These devices are the most popular combination the 3G & 4G cellular phone makers require for SIP. Among the various SIP technologies, this paper especially focused on die stack processes to reduce package size using wire bonding and flip chip bonding technology, thermal engineering to define the operating temperature range of each semiconductor dies, and package reliability engineering to guarantee life of SIP under the environment which application sets operate.
Author Keywords: Cellular phone; Chip stack; Discrete package; Flip chip; PDA; SIP; SOC; Wire bonding
Index Keywords: Data storage equipment; Energy utilization; Flip chip devices; Packaging materials; Quality assurance; Silicon; Video cameras; Chip stack; System in (a) package (SIP); System on (a) chip (SOC); Wire bonding; Cellular telephone systems

Abstract: Optical data storage in nails using a femtosecond laser system is demonstrated. A bit is formed as a structural change of the nail by irradiation of a femtosecond laser pulse. The recorded bit is observed using a conventional microscope. The size of the bit increases with increasing irradiation pulse energy. The pulse energy necessary to form a bit depends on the recording depth and the surface condition of the nail.

Abstract: To dispose and reuse waste gunpowder, a kind of gel explosive, NJH-1 is designed. NJH-1 explosive comprises of one-based gunpowder grain, water, oxidizer, reducer, glue and cross-link reagent. Detonation properties of NJH-1 are introduced in this paper. Results shows: NJH-1 explosive has good initiating properties, energy properties, water- resistant property, storage property, and low cost at the same time.

Title: Optical Encoding for Quantum Computation Using Photonic Crystals
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Polytechnic College AOMORI, Japan; Graduate School of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan; Polytechnic College AOMORI, 2-171 Iizume, Goshogawara-shi, Aomori 037-0002, Japan; Graduate School of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Sapporo-shi, Hokkaido 062-8628, Japan

Abstract: We demonstrate optical encoding in an atomic device, considered as a key component in quantum computers. The atomic device consists of a three-level atom embedded in photonic crystals without external driving lasers. We find that a large amount of population trapping in the upper levels of the atom can be achieved, which is relevant for a strong optical memory effect. Furthermore, the trapped populations keep a memory of the initial atomic state including two-state quantum information, so that the atomic device can be used for a quantum bit encoding the quantum information.

Abstract: The effect of bias current on the performance of magnetic bearing (MB) is studied. Authors: Cheng C.-C., Wu F.-T.
Title: Reduction of flow-induced vibration of an optical disk drive
Source title: Proceedings of the Tenth International Congress on Sound and Vibration
Affiliations: National Chung Cheng University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Chia-Yi, 621, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, C.-C., National Chung Cheng University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Chia-Yi, 621, Taiwan; Wu, F.-T., National Chung Cheng University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Chia-Yi, 621, Taiwan
Abstract: With the increased demands in performance, the optical disk drive needs to be high speed and more stable. However, the flutter instability caused by fluid-structure interactions becomes apparent and leads to track misregistration as the rotating speed of the disk drive increases. The purpose of this research is to investigate the aerodynamic effect of the top cover of an optical disk drive on the disk stability using finite element method when the optical disk drive is rotating at high-speed. Three top covers with different cross sections of an optical disk drive have been chosen. Results show that the shape of disk top cover influences velocity fields of the rotating flow and then alters the characteristics of secondary recirculating vortex. Furthermore, coupling advection effects between streamlines affect the distribution of fluid pressure and leads to the disk self-excited vibration. Nevertheless altering the shape of disk top cover can improve the disk response caused by the effective pressure almost 50% when compared to the original shape of the top cover. Eventually, an optimization procedure combined with the algorithm developed here seems to be feasible to determine an optimal top cover that can effectively reduce the flow-induced vibration of a high-speed rotating optical disk.
Index Keywords: Aerodynamics; Finite element method; Fluid structure interaction; Kinetic energy; Optimization; Radial flow; Strain; Viscosity; Vortex flow; Angular velocity; Flow-induced vibration; Strain energy; Velocity fields; Optical disk storage

Authors: Moreira A., Flowers G., Gowayed Y.
Title: Effects of internal damping on the dynamic stability of high-speed composite rotor systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Tenth International Congress on Sound and Vibration
Affiliations: Auburn University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, 201 Ross Hall, Auburn, AL 36849, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moreira, A., Auburn University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, 201 Ross Hall, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Flowers, G., Auburn University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, 201 Ross Hall, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Gowayed, Y., Auburn University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, 201 Ross Hall, Auburn, AL 36849, United States
Abstract: Composite materials are used for a wide variety of aerospace applications, including advanced rotor designs. Their high strength to weight ratio makes them ideal for the high stress-level applications associated with advanced rotor systems. A natural next step in the evolution of such work is to develop flexible high-speed composite rotor designs that fully exploit the inherent advantages of such materials. To date, there have been quite a few studies that have examined the effects of internal damping in shafting on rotordynamic behavior. But there has been no systematic study of the effects of internal damping on the coupled disk-shaft dynamics of flexible composite disk rotor systems. It is important that such effects be well understood if flexible composite components are to be successfully used in high-speed rotor applications. In the present study, the objective was to develop an understanding of the impact of composite material damping on the dynamic behavior of high-speed rotating machinery that includes fiber reinforced and other composite materials. Analysis techniques, including the half-power method and the log decrement method, were used to identify the damping characteristics for material samples. The experimental setup and the resulting data is presented and discussed. The significance of nonlinear effects, the variation of internal dissipation levels with vibration amplitude and frequency and its effects on the dynamic behavior of high-speed rotating machinery are discussed.
Index Keywords: Aerospace applications; Damping; Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; Energy dissipation; Rotating machinery; Shafts (machine components); Vibrations (mechanical); Disk-shaft dynamics; Dynamic stability; Energy storage systems; Graphite fiber reinforced epoxy composites (GFRP); Rotors

Authors: Olena N., Elizabeth K., Galina M., Gennadiy M., Elizaveta S., Leach E.J.
Title: Potato minitubers under clinorotation - Model for storage carbohydrates study of potato production technology in celss
Source title: 54th International Astronautical Congress of the International Astronautical Federation (IAF), the International Academy of Astronautics and the International Institute of Space Law
Affiliations: Department of Cell Biology and Anatomy, Institute of Botany, Kiev, 01004, Ukraine; Plant Pathology Department, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506-55-02, United States
Authors with affiliations: Olena, N., Department of Cell Biology and Anatomy, Institute of Botany, Kiev, 01004, Ukraine; Elizabeth, K., Department of Cell Biology and Anatomy, Institute of Botany, Kiev, 01004, Ukraine; Galina, M., Department of Cell Biology and Anatomy, Institute of Botany, Kiev, 01004, Ukraine; Gennadiy, M., Department of Cell Biology and Anatomy, Institute of Botany, Kiev, 01004, Ukraine; Elizaveta, S., Department of Cell Biology and Anatomy, Institute of Botany, Kiev, 01004, Ukraine; Leach, E.J., Plant Pathology Department, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506-55-02, United States
Abstract: Potato was designated for food production in the controlled ecological life-support (CELSS) system, because its tubers as it is known contain starch and significant protein content and are edible food after the long-term storage. We used the cultivation of potato miniplants (cv Adreta) under influence of long-term horizontal clinorotation (2 rev/min), which imitated microgravity, as a model for the technology of potato food production in the CELSS. We manipulated some factors such as duration of day, irradiance and temperature to achieve the maximum yields of minitubers (to 100% their formation). It was found that the optimal conditions for minituber formation under clinorotation are the following: irradiance (4,000 lux of white-cool light) during 8 hours and darkness (night) - 16 hours; in the daytime temperature was +24°C and by night +18°C; and the relative humidity was 70% and the modificated Murashige and Skoog agar medium. There was the acceleration of minituber formation, the increase of their signs growth and the starch content, as well as the slight changes of cells structure of starch-storage parenchyma under the selected conditions in imitated microgravity. The ground-based testing of the proposed model in the space volume of the greenhouse is carried out. Copyright © 2003 by the International Astronautical Federation. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Carbohydrates; Computer simulation; Data processing; Ecology; Energy storage; Greenhouse effect; Microgravity processing; Proteins; Starch; Amyloplasts; Clinorotation; Controlled ecological life-supprt (CELSS) systems; Simulated microgravity; Life support systems (spacecraft)

Authors: McAndrews H.J., Baker A.M., Bond R., Roux J.P., Bidault C., Sweet D.
Title: Future power systems research for esa's solar system exploration programme
Source title: 54th International Astronautical Congress of the International Astronautical Federation (IAF), the International Academy of Astronautics and the International Institute of Space Law
Affiliations: QinetiQ Farnborough, Hampshire, United Kingdom; Surrey Satellites Ltd, Guildford, Surrey, United Kingdom; AEA Technology Space, Oxfordshire, United Kingdom; Technicatome, Saint Paul Lez Durance, France; Serco Assurance, Dorset, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: McAndrews, H.J., QinetiQ Farnborough, Hampshire, United Kingdom; Baker, A.M., Surrey Satellites Ltd, Guildford, Surrey, United Kingdom; Bond, R., AEA Technology Space, Oxfordshire, United Kingdom; Roux, J.P., Technicatome, Saint Paul Lez Durance, France; Bidault, C., Technicatome, Saint Paul Lez Durance, France; Sweet, D., Serco Assurance, Dorset, United Kingdom
Abstract: Since 2001 the European Space Agency (ESA) has been developing plans for exploration of the solar system under the Aurora programme. One area investigated was the provision of power and energy storage, which are of critical importance for long range, long lifetime robotic missions. This paper details the work done under the Future Power Systems for Space Exploration study, commissioned by ESA. Power requirements for several mission elements were taken from the architectures outlined in the S51 ESA 'European Mars Mission Architecture Study' and are in two categories; static and mobile elements. A series of non-nuclear technologies were investigated for their applicability. In addition, the work refined the design of a surface fission reactor using a compact liquid metal cooled design and a gas cooled concept, both of which make use of Martian atmospheric CO2 to enable convectively assisted cooling. Finally, a small experimental programme aimed at refining the European current knowledge base for In-Situ Resource Utilisation (ISRU) technology is detailed. The paper then provides an overview of, from a European viewpoint, the study roadmap which outlines those key preparatory activities and requirements for power systems. Ultimately, this present FPS activity will provide inputs to the formulation of plans for the robotic and human exploration of the solar system in the timeframe 2010-2030 under ESA's Aurora programme.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Energy storage; Extraterrestrial atmospheres; Liquid metals; Nuclear reactors; Propellants; Robot applications; Solar concentrators; Solar power generation; Solar power plants; Standby power systems; European Space Agency (ESA); In-Situ Resource Utilization (ISRU); Martian atmosphere; Rovers; Solar energy

Authors: Britton R.W.
Title: Air and waste management association clean air policy conference "A Glass Half Full"
Source title: Canadian Clean Air Policy Conference
Affiliations: Fuel Cells Canada, Canada

Abstract: The issues discussed at the Air and Waste Management Association Clean Air Policy Conference, held on November 20, 2003, are presented. The solutions to control air pollution and climate change include usage of renewables, and application technology such as ICE hybrids, and hydrogen fuel cell hybrids. Fuel cell technologies require improvements in cost, reliability and durability. Improvements in hydrogen storage including 10,000 psi storage tanks, metal hydrides, hydrogen on demand are demonstrated. Ballard AirGen provides backup power for high end users, 100 watts capacity, constant electricity, and surge protection.

Authors: Klug R.-D., Mertens A.
Title: Reliability of megawatt drive concepts
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Industrial Technology
Affiliations: Siemens AG, Automation and Drives - Large Drives, Vogelweiherstr. 1-15, D-90441 Nürnberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Klug, R.-D., Siemens AG, Automation and Drives - Large Drives, Vogelweiherstr. 1-15, D-90441 Nürnberg, Germany; Mertens, A., Siemens AG, Automation and Drives - Large Drives, Vogelweiherstr. 1-15, D-90441 Nürnberg, Germany
Abstract: In the process industries, reliability of the production machines has a strong influence on the profitability of a plant. Examples for such machines are mills, extruders, compressors, pumps, fans and others. Increasingly, such machines are equipped with megawatt rated electric variable speed drive systems (VSDS). The requirements to the reliability of VSDS in such applications are extraordinarily high. In this paper, a comparison of the potential reliability for a number of different high-power medium-voltage drive concepts is made, like load commutated inverters, voltage source inverters, and cellular converters based on building blocks. Redundancy is introduced as a means of increasing reliability, and different approaches to redundancy in a VSDS are discussed. Besides component reliability and redundancy, also the maintenance strategy has an impact on the reliability of a VSDS. As a result, recommendations for the choice of a drive concept and maintenance strategy are given. © 2003 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Harmonics reduction; Load-commutated inverters (LCI); Neutral-point clamped inverters (NPC); Voltage source inverters (VSI); Electric energy storage; Electric inverters; Electric loads; Electric potential; Electric rectifiers; Electric switchgear; Synchronous motors; Thyristors; Topology; Variable speed drives; Electric drives

Abstract: This paper presents an application concerning the SDRAM memory using VamSpiceDesigner 1. VamSpiceDesigner, is a tool created by the ET ENST Paris for aiding the design of multi-technological systems. For that, it uses free tools a schematic Electric™, a compiler VHDL-AMS SPICE named VamSpice and SPICE OPUS as a simulator. A block box and or a component drawn by the schematic is associated to VHDL-AMS model or SPICE netlist. The hierarchical property of the schematic allows to constitute a macro-component box and makes possible to navigate between various system level (top-down and bottom-up). ©2003 IEEE.

Authors: Tsuji T., Ohnishi K.
Title: Mechanism of attitude control device for floating object
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Industrial Technology
Affiliations: Faculty of Science and Technology, Department of System Design Engineering, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyosi, Yokohama, Kanagawa, 223-8522, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tsuji, T., Faculty of Science and Technology, Department of System Design Engineering, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyosi, Yokohama, Kanagawa, 223-8522, Japan; Ohnishi, K., Faculty of Science and Technology, Department of System Design Engineering, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyosi, Yokohama, Kanagawa, 223-8522, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes the new mechanism on attitude control device for unfixed objects. Flywheel is a common attitude control device on spacecraft that provides precise control at an easy rate. However, rapid response is hardly achieved since low reaction torque is available applying flywheel. The purpose in this paper is to improve the response of attitude control device with flywheel. Brake equipment is mounted on the flywheel in order to raise the maximum torque. Maximum torque is raised dramatically utilizing the braking torque to the attitude control. Twin drive system is applied to this attitude control device so that the braking torque works in both rotation directions. It also made possible to charge the momentum without any interference to attitude control. The prototype of the attitude control device is constructed in order to examine the performance of the proposed mechanism. Experimental results show that its response improved applying the suggested mechanism. The two actuators, an electric DC motor and a powder brake, were compared in detail. It was shown that powder brake can apply high torque without large power supply in any frequency. ©2003 IEEE.
Index Keywords: AC motors; Actuators; Control system analysis; Energy storage; Solar collectors; Spacecraft; Torque; Attitude control; Control moment gyro (CMG); Floating objects; Spin stabilization; Flywheels

Authors: Schmidhofer A., Zhang G., Weiss H.
Title: Range extender optimisation for electrical vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Industrial Technology
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, University of Leoben, Franz-Josef-Str. 18, 8700 Leoben, Austria; College of Mechanical and Automotive Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha 410012, Hunan, China
Authors with affiliations: Schmidhofer, A., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, University of Leoben, Franz-Josef-Str. 18, 8700 Leoben, Austria; Zhang, G., College of Mechanical and Automotive Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha 410012, Hunan, China; Weiss, H., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, University of Leoben, Franz-Josef-Str. 18, 8700 Leoben, Austria
Abstract: Electrical vehicles are disposing innovative drive systems but generally still rely on chemical batteries for power supply with their high mass and low stored energy. With e.g. the rugged lead-acid batteries, the covered ranges are about 50 to 100 km, and this is usually not enough to cover a typical transfer distance between the location of e.g. maintenance and the location of operation. Hybrid vehicles have the opportunity of running by means of the combustion engine and can cover long ranges but have to transport all the time the excessive mass and are much more expensive than electrical vehicles. Mountable range extenders are a flexible solution to increase the transfer range of a pure electrical vehicle. A range extender is composed of a thermo-dynamical machine driving an AC generator and a power conversion circuit to transfer the power into the DC battery circuit. For cost reasons, existing range extenders use standard emergency power supplies delivering 50 Hz in single-phase or three-phase circuits (higher power output). For the conversion of AC into battery level DC various circuit topologies are feasible. These topologies are evaluated with respect to weight, cost, losses. An optimised circuit design is composed of a higher frequency power conversion system using power electronics. The optimised configuration is described in this paper. © 2003 IEEE.
Author Keywords: AC/DC power conversion; Electrical vehicle; High frequency inverter
Index Keywords: Electric network topology; Energy storage; Lead acid batteries; Power electronics; Power supply circuits; Pulse width modulation; AC/DC power conversion; High frequency inverters; Hybrid vehicles; Range extender optimization; Three-phase circuits; Electric vehicles

Authors: Chambers A.V., Rodwell W.R., Kelly M., Hoch A.R., Baker A.J.
Title: Assessment of package performance during long-term storage of intermediate-level radioactive waste
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Serco Assurance, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Chambers, A.V., Serco Assurance, United Kingdom; Rodwell, W.R., Serco Assurance, United Kingdom; Kelly, M., Serco Assurance, United Kingdom; Hoch, A.R., Serco Assurance, United Kingdom; Baker, A.J., Serco Assurance, United Kingdom
Abstract: In the UK, the need for the long-term management of intermediate-level radioactive wastes arises from the absence of an established deep disposal option. As a consequence there is a requirement to demonstrate the 'passive safety' of waste packages in stores over a necessarily lengthy period (perhaps 150 years or more). 'Passive safety' is taken here to imply that the waste packages themselves would remain safe without intervention; it is assumed however, that the store building and associated infrastructure would need to be actively maintained and that the store may need to be ventilated. Importantly, methods for waste storage also need to ensure that possible future options for disposal are not foreclosed. An extended period of storage suggests that emphasis will need to be placed by waste producers on understanding a number of issues such as: the impact of corrosion on container integrity; the assessment of container vents and other features as a pathway for the release of radioactivity; the extent to which wastes are conditioned for storage and the selection of appropriate methods; the generation and behaviour of toxic or flammable gases in the storage facility; and the mitigating steps that might be needed to address adverse impacts (e.g. the type of ventilation that the store requires). In this paper, we review the requirements and current state of knowledge relevant to the assessment of operational releases of radioactive, flammable and toxic gases from wastes in long-term interim storage.
Index Keywords: Long-term storage; Package performance; Accident prevention; Approximation theory; Corrosion; Decommissioning (nuclear reactors); Heating; Ion exchange; Nuclear energy; Packaging; Radioactivity; Ventilation; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Ngan H.W., Pang C.F.
Title: A service focused approach to retailing electricity in open competitive power markets
Source title: Sixth International Conference on Advances in Power System Control, Operation and Management - Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Ngan, H.W., Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong; Pang, C.F., Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong
Abstract: This paper introduces a service focused approach for retailing electricity in open power markets. It shows how energy can be delivered as a spectrum of services with which interests of the industry players can be aligned as closely as possible with customer needs. The proposed approach starts by defining building blocks for identifying various energy services options. Various characteristics of competitive retail electricity markets for delivering the energy services to customers are analysed. Results show that the proposed approach satisfies the market reform objectives.

Authors: Sezer U., Chen G., Kandemir M., Saputra H., Irwin M.J.
Title: Exploiting bank locality in multi-bank memories
Source title: CASES 2003: International Conference on Compilers, Architecture, and Synthesis for Embedded Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sezer, U., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Chen, G., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, United States; Kandemir, M., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, United States; Saputra, H., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, United States; Irwin, M.J., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, United States
Abstract: Bank locality can be defined as localizing the number of load/store accesses to a small set of memory banks at a given time. An optimizing compiler can modify a given input code to improve its bank locality. There are several practical advantages of enhancing bank locality, the most important of which is reduced memory energy consumption. Recent trends indicate that energy consumption is fast becoming a first-order design parameter as processor-based systems continue to become more complex and multi-functional. Off-chip memory energy consumption in particular can be a limiting factor in many embedded system designs. This paper presents a novel compiler-based strategy for maximizing the benefits of low-power operating modes available in some recent DRAM-based multi-bank memory systems. In this strategy, the compiler uses linear algebra to represent and optimize bank locality in a mathematical framework. We discuss that exploiting bank locality can be cast as loop (iteration space) and array layout (data space) transformations. We also present experimental data showing the effectiveness of our optimization strategy. Our results show that exploiting bank locality can result in large energy savings. Copyright 2003 ACM.
Author Keywords: Affine Program; Bank Locality; Embedded Systems; Energy Consumption; Optimizing Compilers
Index Keywords: Affine program; Bank locality; Memory architectures; Optimizing compilers; Algorithms; Computer architecture; Dynamic random access storage; Electric power utilization; Embedded systems; Program compilers; Data storage equipment

Authors: Newsome J., Song D.
Title: GEM: Graph EMbedding for routing and data-centric storage in sensor networks without geographic information
Source title: SenSys'03: Proceedings of the First International Conference on Embedded Networked Sensor Systems
Affiliations: Carnegie Mellon University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Newsome, J., Carnegie Mellon University, United States; Song, D., Carnegie Mellon University, United States
Abstract: The widespread deployment of sensor networks is on the horizon. One of the main challenges in sensor networks is to process and aggregate data in the network rather than wasting energy by sending large amounts of raw data to reply to a query. Some efficient data dissemination methods, particularly data-centric storage and information aggregation, rely on efficient routing from one node to another. In this paper we introduce GEM (Graph EMbedding for sensor networks), an infrastructure for node-to-node routing and data-centric storage and information processing in sensor networks. Unlike previous approaches, it does not depend on geographic information, and it works well even in the face of physical obstacles. In GEM, we construct a labeled graph that can be embedded in the original network topology in an efficient and distributed fashion. In that graph, each node is given a label that encodes its position in the original network topology. This allows messages to be efficiently routed through the network, while each node only needs to know the labels of its neighbors. To demonstrate how GEM can be applied, we have developed a concrete graph embedding method, VPCS (Virtual Polar Coordinate Space). In VPCS, we embed a ringed tree into the network topology, and label the nodes in such a manner as to create a virtual polar coordinate space. We have also developed VPCR, an efficient routing algorithm that uses VPCS. VPCR is the first algorithm for node-to-node routing that guarantees reachability, requires each node to keep state only about its immediate neighbors, and requires no geographic information. Our simulation results show that VPCR is robust on dynamic networks, works well in the face of voids and obstacles, and scales well with network size and density. Copyright 2003 ACM.
Author Keywords: Data-centric storage; Routing; Sensor networks
Index Keywords: Data-centric storage; Relaxation algorithms; Routing; Sensor networks; Algorithms; Conformal mapping; Data processing; Data storage equipment; Embedded systems; Geographic information systems; Iterative methods; Monitoring; Sensors; Topology; Graph theory

Authors: Palem K.V.
Title: Energy aware algorithm design via probabilistic computing: From algorithms and models to moore's law and novel (Semiconductor)devices

Abstract: The significance of probabilistic computing to energy aware algorithm design, is discussed. The formulations of energy complexity characterizing the energy consumed in the context of RsBRAM and a network of switches, respectively, are dependent only on the thermodynamics and thus independent of specific technology parameters of a particular device implementation. Through the interpretation of probabilistic computing, energy savings can be achieved much as the purely mathematical formulations of probabilistic computing. They have been shown to yield algorithmic improvements using conventional measures of computational complexity such as the running time.

Title: Chilled Water Storage in Western Australia
Source title: ASHRAE Winter Meetings CD, Technical and Symposium Papers

Abstract: Chilled water storage has been in use in Western Australia for more than a decade and is recognized there as a valuable complement to chilled water systems serving campuses and other large loads. Factors affecting the application of thermal storage in Western Australia are discussed. Characteristics of four chilled water systems in or near Perth, the capital city, are described. Comparisons are drawn between conditions and practices in Australia and the United States. The success of chilled water storage projects in Western Australia without demand-side management incentives demonstrates its intrinsic benefits when appropriately applied.

Authors: Yan H.-X., Hu L.-M., Gao Z.
Title: Modified Simplified Rate Equation Model of Flowing Chemical Oxygen-Iodine Laser and its Application
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Institute of Mechanics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China
Authors with affiliations: Yan, H.-X., Institute of Mechanics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China; Hu, L.-M., Institute of Mechanics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China; Gao, Z., Institute of Mechanics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China
Abstract: A modified simplified rate equation (RE) model of flowing chemical oxygen-iodine laser (COIL), which is adapted to both the condition of homogeneous broadening and inhomogeneous broadening being of importance and the condition of inhomogeneous broadening being predominant, is presented for performance analyses of a COIL. By using the Voigt profile function and the gain-equal-loss approximation, a gain expression has been deduced from the rate equations of upper and lower level laser species. This gain expression is adapted to the conditions of very low gas pressure up to quite high pressure and can deal with the condition of lasing frequency being not equal to the central one of spectral profile. The expressions of output power and extraction efficiency in a flowing COIL can be obtained by solving the coupling equations of the deduced gain expression and the energy equation which expresses the complete transformation of the energy stored in singlet delta state oxygen into laser energy. By using these expressions, the RotoCOIL experiment is simulated, and obtained results agree well with experiment data. Effects of various adjustable parameters on the performances of COIL are also presented.
Author Keywords: Chemical oxygen-iodine laser (COIL); Homogeneous broadening; Inhomogeneous broadening; Performance analysis; Rate equation (RE) model; Voigt profile function
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Computer simulation; Energy storage; Mathematical models; Performance; Pressure effects; Chemical oxygen-iodine lasers (COIL); Laser cavity; Chemical lasers

Authors: Wessely U., Scheller G., Eichner S.
Title: Watermarking system for analog or compressed video
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Imaging Science, Systems and Technology, CISST
Affiliations: TU Ilmenau, Fakultät EI, FG ESS, PF 100565, 98684 Ilmenau, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wessely, U., TU Ilmenau, Fakultät EI, FG ESS, PF 100565, 98684 Ilmenau, Germany; Scheller, G., TU Ilmenau, Fakultät EI, FG ESS, PF 100565, 98684 Ilmenau, Germany; Eichner, S., TU Ilmenau, Fakultät EI, FG ESS, PF 100565, 98684 Ilmenau, Germany
Abstract: The paper describes a robust video watermarking system. It was developed and optimized to resist the distinct image alterations caused not only by digital video compression but also by analog video transmission and storage. After an extensive benchmark of image watermarking algorithms, a discrete wavelet transform based approach for the video watermarking system was chosen. It used a set of Walsh series modulated by the watermark content as additive pseudo-random noise and provided high robustness without visual image degradation. An alternating watermark sequence, content-adaptive energies, key frames and position markers were added to improve the robustness of the video watermarking system.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Image coding; Image compression; Motion compensation; Spurious signal noise; Video signal processing; Wavelet transforms; Analog video transmission; Discrete wavelet transform; Video watermarking system; Walsh series; Digital watermarking

Authors: Kavanaugh S.P.
Title: Impact of Operating Hours on Long-Term Heat Storage and the Design of Ground Heat Exchangers
Source title: ASHRAE Winter Meetings CD, Technical and Symposium Papers
Affiliations: University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kavanaugh, S.P., University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, United States
Abstract: The design of vertical ground-coupled heat pump (GCHP) systems requires an accounting of the amount of heat rejected and extracted aver an extended period. ASHRAE 1120-TRP revised the concept of equivalent full-load hours (EFLHs) as an alternative to a more elaborate energy analysis. This paper applies results of this project to study the impact of the recommended values with over- and underestimated EFLHs in three climates for three different building types. Results indicate the required design length for a vertical GCHP system can be substantially affected by the annual imbalance of heat rejected to and absorbed from the ground in nonporous formations. The impact is reduced for porous formations. Overestimation of the annual cooling energy by 50% resulted in increases in required lengths of 4% to 15% for nonporous formations. Overestimation of the annual heating energy by 50% resulted in a 13% increase in required length in Minneapolis and minimal change in St. Louis and Atlanta. The impact of bore-to-bore separation in nonporous formations is significant, and designers should weigh the option of increasing this value beyond 20 ft (6 m) in warm climate, high cooling load applications. Finally, the accuracy of determining EFLHs using ASHRAE 1120-TRP results is sufficient to perform GCHP system design, since gross errors (±50% and +100%) result in much smaller errors in required ground loop lengths.
Index Keywords: Energy analysis; Ground-coupled heat pumps (GCHP); Absorption; Air conditioning; Computer simulation; Cooling; Data reduction; Error analysis; Heat storage; Porous materials; Ventilation; Heat pump systems

Authors: Belevtsev A.A., Firsov K.N., Kazantsev S.Yu., Saifulin A.V.
Title: UV-preionization in non-chain HF lasers with a self-sustained volume discharge to initiate chemical reaction - Is it actually essential?
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Institute for High Energy Densities, RAS, Izhorskaya 13/19, 127412 Moscow, Russian Federation; General Physics Institute, RAS, Vavilov st.38, 119991 Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Belevtsev, A.A., Institute for High Energy Densities, RAS, Izhorskaya 13/19, 127412 Moscow, Russian Federation; Firsov, K.N., General Physics Institute, RAS, Vavilov st.38, 119991 Moscow, Russian Federation; Kazantsev, S.Yu., General Physics Institute, RAS, Vavilov st.38, 119991 Moscow, Russian Federation; Saifulin, A.V., General Physics Institute, RAS, Vavilov st.38, 119991 Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: A role of UV preionization in non-chain HF(DF) lasers has been investigated. The influence of preionization on the discharge uniformity and on the duration of stable burning of a self-sustained volume discharge (SSVD) in working mixtures of non-chain HF lasers as a function of the energy stored in capacitors are comprehensively studied. Also presented are discharge photographs taken under identical conditions with and without preionization. It is shown that SSVD characteristics and laser energy are scarcely affected by preionization if the discharge lasts more than 150ns and the cathode surface area is in excess of 300cm2. In HF lasers with the cathode surface area and discharge duration of less than 300cm2 and 150ns, respectively, preionization is essential for nothing but stabilization of the discharge voltage and breakdown delay and for improving discharge uniformity. If the opposite takes place preionization has no influence on the laser characteristics.
Author Keywords: Electronegative gases; Non-chain HF laser; Self-initiated volume discharge
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Combustion; Current density; Electric discharges; Electric field effects; Energy storage; Ionization; Lighting; Mixtures; Ultraviolet radiation; Electronegative gases; Non-chain HF lasers; Self-initiated volume discharges; Chemical lasers

Sector, Chandler, AZ, United States, Motorola Laboratories, Tempe, AZ, United States
Abstract: A low power 4Mb Magnetoresistive Random Access Memory (MRAM) with a new magnetic switching mode is presented for the first time. The memory cell is based on a 1-Transistor 1-Magnetic Tunnel Junction (1T1MTJ) bit cell. The 4 Mb MRAM circuit was designed in a five level metal, 0.18 μm CMOS process with a bit cell size of 1.55 μm 2. A new cell architecture, bit structure, and switching mode improve the operational performance of the MRAM as compared to conventional MRAM. The 4 Mb circuit is the largest MRAM memory demonstration to date.
Index Keywords: Energy barriers; Magnetic switching; Magnetoresistive random access memory (MRAM); CMOS integrated circuits; Electric conductors; Electric resistance; Electrodes; Ferromagnetic materials; Magnetic fields; Magnetic moments; Magnetoresistance; Networks (circuits); Switching; Transistors; Random access storage

Authors: Vettiger P., Albrecht T., Despont M., Drechsler U., Dürig U., Gotsmann B., Jubin D., Häberle W., Lantz M.A., Rothuizen H., Stutz R., Wiesmann D., Binnig G.K., Bächtold P., Cherubini G., Hagleitner C., Loeliger T., Pantazi A., Pozidis H., Eleftheriou E.
Title: Thousands of Microcantilevers for Highly Parallel and Ultra-dense Data Storage
