Pozidis, H., Storage Technologies Group, IBM Research, Zurich Research Laboratory, 8803 Rüschlikon, Switzerland; Eleftheriou, E., Storage Technologies Group, IBM Research, Zurich Research Laboratory, 8803 Rüschlikon, Switzerland
Abstract: Ultrahigh storage densities of up to 1 Tb/in.2 or more can be achieved by using local-probe techniques to write, read back, and erase data in very thin polymer films. The thermomechanical scanning-probe-based data-storage concept, internally dubbed "millipede", combines ultrahigh density, small form factor, and high data rates. High data rates are achieved by parallel operation of large 2D arrays with thousands micro-/nanomechanical cantilevers/tips that can be batch-fabricated by silicon surface-micromachining techniques. The inherent parallelism, the ultrahigh areal densities and the small form factor may open up new perspectives and opportunities for application in areas beyond those envisaged today.
Index Keywords: Atomic force microscopy; Dynamic random access storage; Energy efficiency; Error correction; Flash memory; Image analysis; Information technology; Magnetic recording; Micromachining; Multiplexing; Polymers; Scanning electron microscopy; Static random access storage; Microcantilevers; Power consumption; Ultra-dense data storage; Data storage equipment

Authors: McCombie C., Chapman N.
Title: Progress with multinational storage and disposal concepts
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Arius
Authors with affiliations: McCombie, C., Arius; Chapman, N., Arius
Abstract: The growing importance of finding shared solutions for countries with small arisings of long-lived wastes from nuclear power generation has been increasingly recognised over the last few years. In this paper, we take a systematic look at recent developments focusing in turn on: international initiatives (IAEA) regional initiatives the European Union (EU) national positions for in 3 categories of countries: those participating in the Arius association that was founded explicitly to promote the multinational concept those with specific interests in shared solutions those that might consider hosting a repository those with laws or policies requiring national disposal. Multinational concepts continue to face challenges that are more difficult than for national programmes. Nevertheless, progress to date indicates that the nuclear communities of the world may well be on the way to optimising radioactive waste management on a global scale.
Index Keywords: Disposal concepts; Multinational storage; Environmental protection; Geological repositories; International cooperation; Nuclear energy; Public policy; Radiology; Risk assessment; Safety factor; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Horsley D., McKirdy B.
Title: The management of historic intermediate level radioactive waste in the United Kingdom
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: BNFL, United Kingdom; United Kingdom Nirex Ltd., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Horsley, D., BNFL, United Kingdom; McKirdy, B., United Kingdom Nirex Ltd., United Kingdom
Abstract: Nirex is the organisation responsible for long-term radioactive waste management in the UK. Our Mission is to provide the UK with safe, environmentally sound and publicly acceptable options for the long-term management of radioactive materials. The United Kingdom has a significant legacy of long-lived intermediate level radioactive waste. This has arisen from 50 years of investigation and exploitation of nuclear technology. Some of the waste is stored in old facilities that do not provide the standards of containment that would be incorporated in modern facilities. Also the risk to people and to the environment from the inventory in these facilities will increase with time as the structures age and degrade, increasing the chance of containment failure. There is, therefore, a need to retrieve this raw waste and process and package it to make it demonstrably safe for continued storage, pending a decision on disposal of radioactive waste. This packaging should, as far as is practicable, be compatible with the UK long-term waste management strategy. Nirex has developed its Phased Disposal Concept for intermediate and low-level radioactive waste. Based on that concept, Nirex has developed waste package specifications and carries out assessments of waste packaging proposals. For legacy wastes it may not always practicable to demonstrate full compliance with all Nirex disposal criteria. This paper describes an approach, agreed between Nirex and BNFL, for managing these wastes. The proposed approach takes account of long-term waste management issues whilst recognising the need for timely improvement of storage conditions.
Index Keywords: Intermediate level wastes; Waste packages; Contamination; Environmental impact; Nuclear energy; Packaging; Radioactivity; Risks; Societies and institutions; Waste incineration; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Rowat J.
Title: Safety and sustainability implications of long term storage of radioactive waste
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: International Atomic Energy Agency
Authors with affiliations: Rowat, J., International Atomic Energy Agency
Abstract: The safety and sustainability implications of long term storage of radioactive waste are discussed. Storage is an important element in the safe management of radioactive waste. It is necessary to store spent nuclear fuel (SNF), high level waste (HLW) and some other types of waste for a period of time, to allow radioactive decay to reduce the levels of radiation and heat generation. Storage of radioactive waste is demonstrated to be safe over some decades and can be relied upon to provide safety as long as active surveillance and maintenance is assured.
Index Keywords: Intermediate level wastes; Long term storage; Accident prevention; Contamination; Environmental impact; Inspection; Mining; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuels; Radioactive waste vitrification; Safe handling; Solidification; Sustainable development; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Thomson M., Sims J.
Title: A temporary store for radioactive waste
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: MRP Systems Ltd.
Authors with affiliations: Thomson, M., MRP Systems Ltd.; Sims, J., MRP Systems Ltd.
Abstract: To provide an efficient process for the final disposal of radioactive wastes, some nuclear sites are currently building suitable, temporary stores for such material. This paper describes the practical construction programme recently completed at a UK power reactor site under decommissioning. This site has a number of half height ISO containers filled with solid radioactive material that needed a temporary storage area before being consigned for final disposal. As a result, the site, Hunterston A Decommissioning Site, needed to construct some temporary radiation shield walls to contain the half height ISO containers (HHISO) and safeguard staff and public during the storage period. The chosen location of the temporary store was the Charge Machine Maintenance Building (CMMB), which was surplus to requirements during the decommissioning programme, providing a weatherproof environment. Following an in-depth study of the different forms of construction available, the commercially available, hollow, interlocking polyethylene block system was adopted. Because of its modular form, it has the advantage that it can to be dismantled and re-used at other locations, if required. Being hollow, the block could be filled with a variety of materials, such as water, sand, lead or iron shot, depending on the radioactive shielding needs. An important aspect of the modular plastic block was that it could be more easily installed, decontaminated and decommissioned than the cheaper concrete block system, which produces copious quantities of waste for disposal. This paper describes the choice of interlocking block shielding after comparisons with more conventional forms of construction, the features of the HHISO store design, the short duration building programme and the on-site experiences of the construction period.
Index Keywords: Nuclear sites; Temporary stores; Concretes; Contamination; Costs; Decommissioning (nuclear reactors); Demolition; Environmental impact; Nuclear energy; Problem solving; Radiation shielding; Recycling; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Carr A., Clarke M.J., Langley G.E., Sanders N.C., Sunman C.R.J.
Title: Design of a storage facility for intermediate level waste at hunterston "a" decommissioning site
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: BNFL Environmental Services, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Carr, A., BNFL Environmental Services, United Kingdom; Clarke, M.J., BNFL Environmental Services, United Kingdom; Langley, G.E., BNFL Environmental Services, United Kingdom; Sanders, N.C., BNFL Environmental Services, United Kingdom; Sunman, C.R.J., BNFL Environmental Services, United Kingdom
Abstract: The design of a storage facility for intermediate level waste (ILW) at Hunterston A decommissioning site is discussed. The commercial approach adopted to develop the store design and subsequently construct and commission the store is also discussed. To develop an ILW store , the integrated Design and Safety Justification process is adopted through the feasibility and concept phases. The development phases addressed the technical and science issues, which determine the requirements for ILW Stores at decommissioning sites.
Index Keywords: Package handling machine (PHM); Storage facility; Accident prevention; Concretes; Decommissioning (nuclear reactors); Earthquake effects; Environmental protection; Graphite; Inspection; Nuclear energy; Problem solving; Project management; Seismology; Radioactive wastes

Authors: Zelmer R.L., Case G.G.
Title: Third update on environmental remediation of historic LLR waste sites in Canada (1997-2003)
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: AECL, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Zelmer, R.L., AECL, Canada; Case, G.G., AECL, Canada
Abstract: Canada's Low-Level Radioactive Waste Management Office (LLRWMO) continues to make significant progress toward the remediation of orphan sites contaminated with historic Low Level Radioactive (LLR) waste. Since its establishment in 1982, the LLRWMO, which is operated by Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, has acted as the agent of the federal government in this area, taking policy and priority direction from the federal department of Natural Resources Canada. The LLRWMO has investigated and decontaminated structures and properties at many sites across the country. It has removed contaminated soil, debris and radioactive artifacts to interim storage or interim, in situ containment. It has worked with communities and regulatory agencies to develop locally acceptable waste management solutions for the short- and long-term. This paper provides an update on the progress of environmental remediation programs and projects of the LLRWMO made since the last reporting at the Sixth ICEM Conference in Singapore in 1997. Emphasis is placed upon the areas of sustained interim waste management and community problem solving in this period. In addition, comment is provided on the future of the program. On behalf of the federal government, the LLRWMO was appointed in 2000 July to act as the proponent for the Port Hope Area Initiative (PHAI), a ten-year $260 M undertaking that will see historic LLR wastes currently found in various community locations consolidated into safe, long-term management facilities, yielding environmental benefits for present and future generations. This activity is breaking new ground in the implementation of community recommended solutions and signals the way forward in Canada's historic waste program.
Index Keywords: Environmental remediation; Waste sites; Accident prevention; Approximation theory; Contamination; Electricity; Environmental impact; Natural resources; Problem solving; Remediation; Uranium; Radioactive wastes

Authors: Atyeo P.
Title: Remediation of the southern storage area (SSA)
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: U. Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Atyeo, P., U. Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority, United Kingdom
Abstract: This large scale radioactive and chemical land remediation project is a recent example of UKAEA delivering safe and cost effective restoration of a nuclear legacy. The SSA was a 7-hectare part of the non-nuclear licensed area at Harwell, Oxfordshire. The Harwell site is steadily being redeveloped as a business centre. Restoration of the SSA was linked to an opportunity to develop adjacent land for new residential housing. The SSA shared a boundary with Chilton County Primary School and the remediation project had high stakeholder interest. The RAF used the SSA as an ammunition store until 1945. UKAEA used the site from 1946 for radioactive waste handling and for the burial of chemical, radioactive and beryllium contaminated wastes. Planning, characterisation and decommissioning has been ongoing since the late 1980's. Over the last two years a final clean-up operation has been completed. The project was managed by UKAEA and implemented through competitive contract by RWE Nukem and VHE Construction. The clean-up utilised stakeholder management and consultation methods to inform regulators and the local community. This included a formal public consultation concerning remedial options and the potential for environmental impact. The clean-up was designed against site specific risk based radionuclide and chemical clean-up targets. The project involved the survey, assay and clearance of 250,000 m3 of soils resulting in the segregation of 18,000 m 3 of general, chemical and exempt radioactive wastes. The SSA landfill pits were excavated inside double ventilated containment tents in order to ensure that emissions from the works did not affect the nearby public. The project has successfully restored the site to a condition suitable for unrestricted public access.
Index Keywords: Hygiene precautions; Nuclear legacy; Radiochemical facilities; Beryllium; Decommissioning (nuclear reactors); Environmental impact; Excavation; Health care; Land fill; Land reclamation; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive wastes; Radioisotopes; Risk assessment; Nuclear energy

Authors: Poskas P., Ragaisis V., Smaizys A.
Title: Experience from safety assessment of the existing storage facility for solid radwaste at Ignalina NPP
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Lithuanian Energy Institute, Lithuania
Authors with affiliations: Poskas, P., Lithuanian Energy Institute, Lithuania; Ragaisis, V., Lithuanian Energy Institute, Lithuania; Smaizys, A., Lithuanian Energy Institute, Lithuania
Abstract: There is only one nuclear power plant in Lithuania - Ignalina NPP (INPP). The INPP operates two similar units with present power level of about 1250 MW(e) each. They were commissioned (first grid connection) in 1983 and 1987 respectively and provide approximately 70-80 per cent of the electricity produced in Lithuania. From the beginning of INPP operation all power plant generated solid radwaste is collected and stored in the solid radwaste facility that is located in INPP sanitary protected area. The storage facility for solid radwaste at INPP consists of four above ground buildings, namely buildings No. 155, No. 155/1, No. 157 and No. 157/1. This facility is Soviet type facility designed for the interim storage of low and intermediate level radwaste arising as a consequence of operation of NPP. The institutional waste from industry, hospitals etc., including sealed sources as well, has been stored in this facility from 1990. At present this radioactive waste storage facility is still not licensed but SAR is prepared and licensing process is going on. The paper provides information on INPP solid radwaste storage facility and discusses problems met during the safety assessment of this facility: lack of the information on the inventory data, lack of design data for the buildings etc. Modeling results of the structural analysis, radiological data, shielding analysis and proposals to improve the safety of the facility also are discussed.
Index Keywords: Safety assessment; Storage facility; Accident prevention; Approximation theory; Concretes; Hospitals; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Problem solving; Societies and institutions; Structural analysis; Turbines; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Guppy P.M., Vines S.P., Wisbey S.J.
Title: The benefits of cementitious encapsulation matrices for the conditioning of intermediate level waste
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: UK Nirex Ltd., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Guppy, P.M., UK Nirex Ltd., United Kingdom; Vines, S.P., UK Nirex Ltd., United Kingdom; Wisbey, S.J., UK Nirex Ltd., United Kingdom
Abstract: The UK has significant quantities of radioactive waste, which have arisen over the past fifty years or so, largely as a result of nuclear power, reprocessing and defence programmes. The intermediate level wastes arising as a result of these activities, exhibit a high level of physical and chemical diversity, and must be managed safely in a way that protects existing and future generations and the environment. Development work has been conducted since the early 1980s to identify suitable conditioning materials and techniques that are compatible with the needs of safe long-term management, including interim storage, transport and future deep geological disposal. From these studies cementation emerged as the one medium which could satisfy all the key waste management criteria. Other materials were not ruled out and may offer benefits in specific applications. The advantages of conditioning ILW with cement include: the extensive experience of its use in a wide variety of contexts; the raw materials are relatively cheap and have a long shelf life; cement is processed in relatively simple plant at room temperature, with safety and cost benefits for plant operators; the product is fire resistant and of relatively low toxicity; cement is capable of immobilising a wide range of wastes ranging from solids to aqueous slurries; cement provides desirable product properties. Desirable properties include: suitable strength, chemical control of radionuclide leading to enhanced retention, good corrosion protection for steels, low permeability, tolerance to radiation, durability over extended timescales and; good radiation self-shielding properties. Several waste packaging plants are now operational in the UK using cement-based encapsulants. These are currently conditioning ILW for interim storage, in a manner suitable for future transport and compatible with the Nirex phased deep disposal concept. This paper will describe the development of cement-based encapsulants to meet the needs of UK radioactive wastes, and will provide examples of the supporting product quality data.
Index Keywords: Geological disposal; High level wastes (HLW); Low level wastes (LLW); Fire resistance; Laws and legislation; Nuclear energy; Radiation shielding; Radioactive waste encapsulation; Radioactive wastes; Radioisotopes; Toxicity; Waste management

Authors: Smith-Briggs J.
Title: DTI nuclear legacy programme: Andreeva Bay
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: RWE NUKEM Limited, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Smith-Briggs, J., RWE NUKEM Limited, United Kingdom
Abstract: Andreeva Bay is located in the Zapadnaya sea inlet at the extreme North-West of the Kola Peninsula (Russian Federation), about 40km from the Norwegian border. It is rather inaccessible, except by sea and the nearest town with facilities for Western visitors is Murmansk some 80km to the SE. Spent nuclear fuel (SNF) was initially stored in two large pools within building 5, however after serious leaks the fuel was transferred to an external "drystore" constructed by adapting three existing concrete tanks, previously allocated for the storage of liquid radwaste. There are currently approximately 20,000 spent fuel assemblies (SFA) stored within the three tanks. The storage conditions of the assemblies are less than adequate, the steel canisters used to store the assemblies are in poor condition and their standard of manufacture was not good. Shielding is locally inadequate and the concrete roof segments are ill fitting with snowmelt known to enter the tanks. Building 5 still contains some fuel fragments that could not readily be moved. The remaining water and structure remain highly active and this included some 4000Ci in sludge and debris at the bottom of the pool. The UK has agreed to support activities to improve the conditions at Andreeva Bay, with respect to SNF management, and DTI (Department of Trade and Industry) have appointed RWE NUKEM as their project management consultants for their Nuclear Legacy Programme in North-West Russia. A number of projects have been identified by the Russian Federation Ministry of Atomic Energy, MINATOM, and these are currently in the project definition stage. These include the characterisation of Building 5, an options study for SNF management at the site, and the construction of a cover for Tank 3a. This paper will describe the current conditions with respect to spent nuclear fuel at Andreeva bay and will discuss the proposed projects under consideration for funding by DTI.
Index Keywords: Spent fuel assemblies (SFA); Steel canisters; Accident prevention; Corrosion; Electricity; Fuel storage; Laws and legislation; Nuclear energy; Project management; Radioactive wastes; Risk assessment; Steel; Tanks (containers); Spent fuels

Authors: Willems M., Luycx P., Gilis R., Renard C.I., Reyniers H., Cuchet J.M.
Title: The HRA/Solarium project: Processing of historical waste
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Belgoprocess, Belgium; ONDRAF/NIRAS, Belgium; Belgatom, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Willems, M., Belgoprocess, Belgium; Luycx, P., Belgoprocess, Belgium; Gilis, R., Belgoprocess, Belgium; Renard, C.I., ONDRAF/NIRAS, Belgium; Reyniers, H., Belgatom, Belgium; Cuchet, J.M., Belgatom, Belgium
Abstract: A high-level radioactive waste (HRA)/Solarium project, which is planned for a period of 6 years, aims to process and condition the waste belonging to the constituent 221 classified as medium-level waste located on site 2 of Belgoprocess. The waste in the storage HRA is stored in concrete square or rectangular wells, generally still packed in its primary package. The design of the new facility and of the adaptation of existing ones must be based on proven equipment and devices, in order to avoid later surprises during operation. The waste at Solarium is stored in concrete secondary shielding containers which are piled on top of each other in the storage area covered by a roof.
Index Keywords: High-level radioactive waste (HRA); Radon gas; Aluminum; Composition; Hydraulics; Nuclear energy; Nuclear reactors; Radiology; Radium; Sand; Vitrification; Radioactive wastes

Authors: Nazzaro R., Swick W., Kintner-Meyer N., Perry T., Blackwell C., Hatscher C., Locke A.
Title: U.S. Department of Energy's high-level waste program: Opportunities and challenges in achieving risk and cost reductions
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: U.S. GAO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nazzaro, R., U.S. GAO, United States; Swick, W., U.S. GAO, United States; Kintner-Meyer, N., U.S. GAO, United States; Perry, T., U.S. GAO, United States; Blackwell, C., U.S. GAO, United States; Hatscher, C., U.S. GAO, United States; Locke, A., U.S. GAO, United States
Abstract: US Department of Energy's (DOE) high-level energy program for the disposal and treatment of highly radioactive nuclear waste was discussed. DOE had started the program to reduce the waste storage costs and time. It was observed that legal and technical challenges are the main problems in the potential savings. It was also observed that decision making without a supporting analysis, technology implementation without proper testing and design of complex nuclear facilities were the main hurdles in the proper management of the program.
Index Keywords: Cost reductions; Waste treatment facilities; Costs; Decision making; Estimation; Geological repositories; Industrial waste treatment; Project management; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive wastes; Risk assessment; Waste management

Authors: Riley P.
Title: Policy and law relating to radioactive waste: International direction and human rights
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: De Montfort University, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Riley, P., De Montfort University, United Kingdom
Abstract: The anticipated doubling of world demand for electricity over the next fifty years requires that the gift of nuclear energy that has served developed nations over the past half century must not be abandoned. However, the absence of a clear and unequivocal policy regarding the storage and disposal of radioactive waste is seen by a significant section of the public as a threat to their rights and the non-existence of dedicated regulation of radioactive waste based on law has become an obstacle to the development of nuclear energy in Europe and the USA. A European survey of public opinion carried out at the request of the European Commission revealed that three-quarters of the respondents to sixteen thousand interviews believed that 'all radioactive waste is very dangerous'. The public perception of threat has been fostered by the general lack of appreciation of the cautious system of radiation protection that has evolved from scientific observation and prediction of the risk of cancer from exposure to low level radiation. The concept of collective dose based on the system of radiation protection and applied to accident scenarios with remote possibilities, but in the absence of scientific assessment of the balance afforded by the pragmatism that man applies to everyday risks including the risk of cancer from the ever-present background of natural radiation, has added a measure of dread to the public sense of threat. That dread has been exacerbated by the emergence since September 2001 of the possibility of the use of radioactive waste as a terrorist weapon and for radioactive waste storage facilities to be seen as terrorist targets. International policy has moved from the comprehensive coverage of nuclear regulation with radioactive waste as an integral, but minor player, in the nuclear energy process to particular consideration with radioactive waste requiring specific regulation. This paper identifies the vectors that determine the direction of the policy governing radioactive waste, the moves toward consolidation of international policy separate from the body of existing nuclear law and future direction that will clear the way for a sustained, appropriate use of nuclear energy.
Index Keywords: Nuclear safety; Radioactive waste management; Accident prevention; Energy policy; Environmental impact; Environmental protection; Health risks; Laws and legislation; Nuclear energy; Radiation protection; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Sustainable development; Waste management; Radioactive wastes

Authors: Speara T.J., McCullough J.W., Harmon H.D., Leugemors R.K.
Title: Status of the salt waste processing facility at the Savannah river site
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: U.S. Department of Energy, United States; Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Speara, T.J., U.S. Department of Energy, United States; McCullough, J.W., U.S. Department of Energy, United States; Harmon, H.D., Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, United States; Leugemors, R.K., Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, United States
Abstract: The Department of Energy's (DOE) Savannah River Site (SRS) High-Level Waste (HLW) Program is responsible for storage, treatment, and immobilization of HLW for disposal. The Salt Processing Program (SPP) is the salt (soluble) waste treatment portion of this effort. The overall SPP encompasses the selection, design, construction and operation of treatment technologies to prepare the salt waste feed material for the site's Saltstone Facility and vitrification facility (Defense Waste Processing Facility). Major constituents that must be removed from the salt waste include actinides, strontium, cesium, and entrained sludge. In fiscal year (FY) 2002, research and development (R&D) on the actinide and strontium removal and Caustic-Side Solvent Extraction (CSSX) processes transitioned from technology development for baseline process selection to providing input for conceptual design of the Salt Waste Processing Facility (SWPF), a key component at the SRS SPP. This work included laboratory studies, bench-scale tests, and prototype equipment development. To implement the salt waste treatment technologies, DOE initiated a competitive procurement process to select Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC) contractors for design of the SWPF. The Department awarded EPC contracts to Parsons Infrastructure & Technology Group, Inc. and Foster Wheeler USA Corporation for preparation of conceptual designs (Phase I) for the SWPF. The two EPC contractors began conceptual design activities in September 2002 and are scheduled to complete this work in January 2004. After evaluation of the conceptual designs, DOE will down select one EPC contractor to continue with final design, construction, and hot commissioning (Phase II). Hot startup of the SWPF is targeted for December 2009.
Index Keywords: Hig-level waste (HLW); Salt waste; Actinides; Cesium; Environmental impact; Evaporation; Removal; Risk assessment; Strontium; Vitrification; Waste disposal; Waste treatment; Chemical wastes

Authors: Bonnet C., Potier P., Ashton B.M.
Title: DFR decommissioning: The breeder fuel removal project: Retrieval and processing facilities
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: SGN, France; FRAMATOME ANP; UKAEA, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bonnet, C., SGN, France; Potier, P., FRAMATOME ANP; Ashton, B.M., UKAEA, United Kingdom
Abstract: The Dounreay site, in North Scotland, was opened in 1955 and a wide range of nuclear facilities have been built and operated there by UKAEA (The United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority) for the development of atomic energy research. The Dounreay Fast Reactor (DFR) was built between 1955 and 1957, and operated until 1977 for demonstration purposes and for producing electricity. Today, its decommissioning is a key part of the whole Dounreay Site Restoration Plan that integrates the major decommissioning activities such as the fuel treatment and the waste management. The paper presents the contract strategy and provides an overview of the BFR project which consists in the removal of the breeder elements from the reactor and their further treatment. It mainly provides particular details of the Retrieval and Processing Facilities design.
Index Keywords: Fuel loading; Fuel treatment; Breeder reactors; Electric power generation; Fast reactors; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuel cladding; Nuclear fuel elements; Nuclear fuel reprocessing; Radiation decontamination; Radiation protection; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste transportation; Decommissioning (nuclear reactors)

Authors: Gupta A.K.
Title: Terrestrial energy
Source title: Aerospace America
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, A.K.
Abstract: Alternative energy sources, increased energy storage capability, and increased emphasis on smaller, more efficient, and less polluting combustion systems are gaining importance. Wind power is the world's fastest growing energy technology, with 25% annual growth in industry in recent years. The use of lithium-ion battries for high performance commercial applications such as cell phones and laptop computers is increasing. Lithium-ion battries are best suited for space applications as they can operate over a very wide temperature range (-40 C to +65 C), very long cycle life, and long calender life.

Authors: Krolick C.F., Goodson D., Grizzard J.
Title: CAPS Simulation as a Tool in Superconductivity Research
Source title: Annual Review of Progress in Applied Computational Electromagnetics
Affiliations: Syntek Technologies, BMT Group of Companies, United States
Authors with affiliations: Krolick, C.F., Syntek Technologies, BMT Group of Companies, United States; Goodson, D., Syntek Technologies, BMT Group of Companies, United States; Grizzard, J., Syntek Technologies, BMT Group of Companies, United States
Abstract: The Center for Advanced Power Systems (CAPS) at Florida State University is currently involved in research of superconductivity technology to support industry and military applications. As CAPS capabilities expand and mature, increased capabilities for simulation and modeling of superconductivity applications in the power industry will emerge. These include real-time simulation, using the CAPS Real-Time Simulator, Hardware-in-the-Loop (HWIL) component testing, including the capability for testing of large-scale superconducting motors, transformers, components and control architectures. The core of the CAPS real-time simulation and modeling capability is the Real-Time Digital Simulator (RTDS) provided by RTDS Technologies. This state of the art system simulator has been in use at CAPS since September 2002. The simulator allows detailed modeling of components, with capability to introduce increasing levels of fidelity as models' behavior is better understood. The flexibility and speed of the simulator system allows component or system performance to be studied over a wide range of parameters and configurations. The simulator supports stand alone modeling of complex devices or systems, and will also serve as an integral part of the CAPS HWIL test bed.
Index Keywords: Loop testing; Real-time digital simulators (RTDS); Semiconducting magnetic energy storage (SEMS); Computer simulation; Cooling systems; Cryogenic equipment; Dynamometers; Electric lines; Electric motors; Electric power systems; Electric transformers; Hardware; Magnetic materials; Military applications; Real time systems; Simulators; Superconducting materials; Switching systems; Superconductivity

Authors: Hayat M.M., Kwon O.-H.
Title: High Speed Heterostructure Avalanche Photodiodes
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: University of New Mexico, Department of Electrical Engineering, Albuquerque, NM 87131-1356, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hayat, M.M., University of New Mexico, Department of Electrical Engineering, Albuquerque, NM 87131-1356, United States; Kwon, O.-H., University of New Mexico, Department of Electrical Engineering, Albuquerque, NM 87131-1356, United States
Abstract: It has been shown recently that the noise and speed characteristics of avalanche photodiodes (APDs) can greatly benefit from the presence of moderate amounts of an initial energy stored in the injected carriers that initiate the avalanche multiplication process. The benefits range from reduced excess noise factor, increased abruptness in the breakdown probability, as well as an increase in the bandwidth. The key mechanism for the improved performance is the significant reduction of the first dead space in the ionization process. The dead space is the minimum distance a carrier must travel before acquiring sufficient kinetic energy enabling it to impact ionize. The reduction of the first dead space has the effect of localizing the first impact ionization and forcing it to occur quickly near the edge of the multiplication region. This, in turn, will have the effect of nearly inducing two avalanche processes which run in parallel and whose combination will yield the total gain. In this paper, a theoretical model for the avalanche multiplication is utilized to examine the fundamental limits of the gain-bandwidth product in light of the initial-energy effect in practical APD structures.
Author Keywords: Dead space; Excess noise factor; Frequency response; Gain-bandwidth product; Heterostructure APDs; Impact ionization; Initial-energy effect; Ionization threshold energy; Thin avalanche photodiodes
Index Keywords: Avalanche photodiodes (APD); Dead space; Excess noise factor; Gain-bandwidth product; Heterostructure APD; Initial-energy effect; Ionization threshold energy; Bandwidth; Energy dissipation; Energy storage; Frequency response; Heterojunctions; Impact ionization; Ionization; Multilayers; Phonons; Photodiodes; Avalanche diodes

Authors: Lopes J.E.G., Barros M.T.L., Brandão J.L.B.
Title: A Multi Purpose Model for São Francisco Hydropower System, Brazil
Source title: World Water and Environmental Resources Congress
Affiliations: University of São Paulo, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Lopes, J.E.G.; Barros, M.T.L., University of São Paulo, Brazil; Brandão, J.L.B., University of São Paulo, Brazil
Abstract: Brazil is a country plenty of water resources. Due to that 90% of its electricity is produced by hydropower plants. The Brazilian hydropower system has four major sub- systems, North, Northeast, Southeast and South, with 61,000 MW of installed capacity. The São Francisco river system is located in the Northeast area and has seven power plants with three storage and six run of river reservoirs. It has 10,229 MW of installed capacity and it is the biggest system in the Northeast, Brazil. The São Francisco drainage area is 640,000 square km and its water resources are used for energy, irrigation, water supply and navigation. During the rainy season the three storage reservoirs are used for flood control. Part of the São Francisco basin is located in a very dry and poor area. There are many irrigation projects designed for the dry areas, including a huge water transfer system from São Francisco River to the neighbor basins. Due to that the conflict between irrigation, flood control and energy is increasing. In order to analyze these conflicts a multi purpose non linear model for multi reservoir operation was developed. The multi objective model uses the constraint methodology. Considering different scenarios for irrigation demands and flood control volumes a set of trade-off curves were calculated. These graphs show the relationship between three purposes: energy, irrigation and flood control and can support the decision processes on the São Francisco system operation. This paper shows the multi purpose model, its methodology and its preliminary results. Some analyses on the São Francisco water resources conflicts are also presented.
Index Keywords: Non-consumptive uses; Water management; Electric power generation; Flood control; Irrigation; Mathematical models; Navigation; Reservoirs (water); River basin projects; Water pollution control; Water resources; Water supply; Hydroelectric power plants

Authors: Christensen K.J.
Title: The next frontier for communications networks: Power management
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, University of South Florida, Tampa, FL 33620, United States
Authors with affiliations: Christensen, K.J., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, University of South Florida, Tampa, FL 33620, United States
Abstract: Performance evaluation is used to gain an understanding of how to make the best use of scarce resources. Storage, memory, processing, and communications bandwidth are all relatively plentiful and inexpensive. What is the next frontier for communications networks and performance evaluation? I will argue that it is power management to achieve cost-effective operation. In the past few years, entirely new network protocols have been developed for battery-hungry sensor networks. But, what about the existing Internet? Estimates place the Internet as consuming from 2% to 8% of the total electricity produced in the USA - much of this power consumption is unnecessary. Do our "always on" desktop computers really need to be fully powered-up all the time? What can be done to achieve power-savings in these computers? The goal is to eliminate unnecessary energy usage by desktop computers in the near future and by networked embedded systems in the longer term. Traffic characterization is the first step towards this goal. Traffic characterization at inter-flow, intra-flow, and protocol levels is being done to investigate power management. The resulting savings achievable from relatively simple power management schemes are measured in TWh per year - or roughly equivalent to the electricity generated by one nuclear power plant. This is cost-effectiveness on a large scale!
Author Keywords: Cisco NetFlow; Power management; Traffic characterization
Index Keywords: Cisco NetFlow; Power management; Traffic characterization; Bandwidth; Electric power utilization; Interfaces (computer); Network protocols; Packet switching; Personal computers; Internet

Abstract: Lithium intercalated carbon nanotubes have attracted considerable interest as perspective components for energy storage devices. We performed 13C Nuclear Magnetic Resonance spin lattice relaxation measurements in a temperature range from 4 K up to 300 K on alkali intercalated Single Walled Carbon Nanotubes in order to investigate the modifications of the electronic properties. The density of states at the Fermi level were determined for pristine, lithium and cesium intercalated carbon nanotubes and are discussed in terms of intercalation and charge transfer effects.

Abstract: In this paper we propose a generalized robust method for correcting the coarseness error in TLM simulations involving field singularities. This method is shown to be effective for a variety of structures and material properties. Authors: Moldt V.
Title: Remote Sensing for Homeland Defense/Emergency Response
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Ambient Control Systems, 1810 Gillespie Way, El Cajon, CA 92020-1094, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moldt, V., Ambient Control Systems, 1810 Gillespie Way, El Cajon, CA 92020-1094, United States
Abstract: In recent years, there has been increased emphasis on remote sensing as an alternative to traditional systems that rely heavily on the deployment of extensive manpower for surveillance and security. Unattended sensors provide for continuous, widespread coverage and are more cost-effective than the deployment of personnel for many Homeland Defense and Law Enforcement applications. Such applications include international border security, perimeter defense of military installations, nuclear and other critical facilities, as well as detection of chemical or bio-terrorism attacks. Sensor technology has experienced significant advances in recent years. However, remote sensors still rely on batteries, which are short-lived and notoriously unreliable, thereby potentially compromising Homeland Security. There is a critical need for a long-term, reliable energy source to power remote sensor networks. Such a battery-free alternative technology has been developed by Ambient Control Systems. Ambient has developed an advanced mid-door photovoltaic technology, which converts light to energy over a wide range of lighting conditions. The energy is then stored in supercapacitors, a highly robust, long-term storage medium. Ambient's advanced energy management technology can power remote sensor and control systems 24 hours/day, 7 days/ week for over 20 years, without batteries and with virtually no maintenance, providing for ongoing monitoring and control.
Author Keywords: Energy; Remote; Sensors; Unattended; Uninterrupted power
Index Keywords: Bio-terrorism attacks; Uninterrupted power; Command and control systems; Control systems; Energy management; Law enforcement; Sensors; Space surveillance; Uninterruptible power systems; Remote sensing

Abstract: The decommissioning nuclear power plants, policies, strategies and costs commissioned by Nuclear Energy Agency (NEA) was discussed. The NEA and European Commission identified pre-decommissioning activities, facility shutdown activities, water treatment and project management in joint publication. The current value and net present value were used to calculate financial liabilities for decommissioning. The decommissiong costs included de-fuelling, on-site fuel storage, removal of non-radioactive structures and contaminated ground remediation.

Abstract: This paper presents an efficient system level power saving method for DRAM with multiple power modes. The proposed method is based on the power aware scheduling algorithm that controls DRAM modules in coarse grain in which the scheduler assigns appropriate power modes to memory banks at context switching time. The method controls the transition of multiple power modes, which is currently available technology, based on the history of gaining processor and memory bank usage of each process. The experimental results demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed schemes in multiprogramming environment.

Engineering-Systems, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: The 2-D discrete cosine transform (DCT) is an integral part of video and image processing; it is used in both the JPEG and MPEG encoding standards. As streaming video is brought to mobile devices, it becomes important that it is possible to calculate the DCT in an energy-efficient manner. In this paper, we present a new algorithm and processing element (PE) architecture for computing the DCT with a linear array of PEs. This design is optimized for energy efficiency. We analyze the energy, area, and latency tradeoffs available with this design and then compare its energy dissipation, area, and latency to those of Xilinx's optimized IP core.

Title: The Effect to the Toner of Various Properties of the Crystalline Polyester
Source title: International Conference on Digital Printing Technologies
Affiliations: Kao Corporation, Perf. Chem. Research Laboratories, Wakayama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shirai, E., Kao Corporation, Perf. Chem. Research Laboratories, Wakayama, Japan; Aoki, K., Kao Corporation, Perf. Chem. Research Laboratories, Wakayama, Japan; Maruta, M., Kao Corporation, Perf. Chem. Research Laboratories, Wakayama, Japan
Abstract: The regulation for the energy consumption of printers and copiers are getting severe year by year. And with the speed up of the machine system, the fusing of toner on the paper gets more difficult. So the toner which can be fused in lower energy is expected. There are still several ways for that problem. To use low Tg and low Tm resin for binder is the typical one for instance, but there is a barrier to improve more by just controlling the Tg and Tm of the resin. In NIP18 the effect of crystalline polyester for low energy fusing was reported; the properties of the toner that contains crystalline polyester, the quantitative effect of crystalline polyester for toner, the effect of the dispersion size of crystalline polyester in toner and the way to disperse the crystalline polyester. In this report, by controlling the kinds of monomers and the reaction hours, various kinds of crystalline polyester are prepared. And the effects of its melting point and molecular weight for the fusing ability and the storage stability of toner are investigated. Also the property of the toner which contains the crystalline polyester with small amount of the monomer which has a long chain is investigated. As the result, one type of crystalline polyester, which is better for toner, is reported.
Index Keywords: Copying; Crystalline materials; Energy utilization; Melting; Molecular weight; Monomers; Polyesters; Printers (computer); Printing; Resins; Copiers; Fusing ability; Ink

Abstract: Scientific research and practical applications of solar physics require data and computational services to be integrated seamlessly and efficiently. The European Grid for Solar Observations (EGSO) leverages grid-oriented concepts and technology to provide a high-performance infrastructure for solar applications. In this paper, we describe the active brokerage technique adopted in EGSO to improve the access to and flow of solar data. The technique is based on a multi-tier management of metadata.

Authors: Tredennick N., Shimamoto B.
Title: The Rise of Reconfigurable Systems
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Engineering of Reconfigurable Systems and Algorithms
Affiliations: Gilder Technology Report, Los Gatos, CA, United States; Gilder Technology Report, Great Barrington, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tredennick, N., Gilder Technology Report, Los Gatos, CA, United States; Shimamoto, B., Gilder Technology Report, Great Barrington, MA, United States
Abstract: The rise of reconfigurable systems is inevitable. The PC's system components have dominated the industry for twenty years, but, with the market moving to value PCs, the engineering design emphasis is shifting from cost-performance to cost-performance-per-watt. The new emphasis is on untethered systems. Today's digital cameras, MP3 players, cell phones, GPS receivers, and PDAs are early untethered examples. They carry their own power sources. PC memory components are unsuitable for untethered systems; this enables a new generation of memory components. Microprocessors and DSPs are unsuitable for untethered systems because their instruction-based processing is both computationally and energy inefficient. New programmable logic devices based on next-generation non-volatile memory will enable efficient reconfigurable systems.
Index Keywords: Engineering design; Reconfigurable systems; Functions; Global positioning system; Integrated circuits; Microprocessor chips; Microscopes; Optimization; Performance; Product design; Random access storage; Transistors; Personal computers

Authors: Yim K.S., Koh K., Bahn H.
Title: A Compressed Page Management Scheme for NAND-type Flash Memory
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on VLSI
Affiliations: Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul 151-742, South Korea; Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Ewha Womans University, Seoul 120-750, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Yim, K.S., Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul 151-742, South Korea; Koh, K., Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul 151-742, South Korea; Bahn, H., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Ewha Womans University, Seoul 120-750, South Korea
Abstract: Compressed data management in NAND-type flash memory is difficult because it only supports page I/O. For example, when the size of compressed data is smaller than page size, internal fragmentation occurs, and this degrades the effectiveness of compression seriously. To reduce internal fragmentation, the compression unit should be sufficiently large. However, larger compression unit induces longer read and write latencies for random accessing. We, therefore, present a novel compressed page management scheme that stores several small compressed pages to one physical page by using a write buffer. Simulation results show that our proposed scheme can significantly expand storage capacity without having to delay read and write latencies.
Author Keywords: Data compression; Flash memory; Latency reduction
Index Keywords: Cameras; Computer simulation; Data compression; Data reduction; Data storage equipment; Energy utilization; Input output programs; Logic gates; Magnetic disk storage; Digital cameras; Latency reduction; Flash memory

Authors: Vivekanandarajah K., Srikanthan T., Clarke C., Bhattacharya S.
Title: Static pattern predictor (SPP) based low power instruction cache design
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Embedded Systems and Applications
Affiliations: Ctr. for High Perf. Embedded Systems, School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Electron. and Electrical Engineering, University of Bath, Claverton Down, Bath, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Vivekanandarajah, K., Ctr. for High Perf. Embedded Systems, School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Srikanthan, T., Ctr. for High Perf. Embedded Systems, School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Clarke, C., Electron. and Electrical Engineering, University of Bath, Claverton Down, Bath, United Kingdom; Bhattacharya, S., Ctr. for High Perf. Embedded Systems, School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: Energy dissipation in cache memories is becoming a major design issue in embedded microprocessors. Predictive filter cache based instruction cache hierarchy is effective in reducing the access energy substantially at the cost of certain performance degradation. Here, the energy-delay product reduction heavily depends on the prediction accuracy of the predictor. In this paper, a simplified pattern prediction algorithm, which maximizes power savings in the novel filter cache prediction hierarchy, is proposed. The prediction mechanism relies on the static nature of the hit or miss pattern of the instruction access stream over the past filter cache line accesses. These static patterns are stored in a 32-entry single-bit Pattern Table (PT). The entries could be dynamically changed during run time to provide options for real-time adaptation in a complex application. The proposed prediction algorithm results in better prediction for all the benchmarks simulated. Energy delay product reduction of up to 8.19% over existing NFPT prediction scheme was reported for the benchmarks simulated.
Author Keywords: Filter-Cache; Hit-Miss Pattern; NFPT; Static Pattern Prediction
Index Keywords: Benchmarking; Computer simulation; Electric power utilization; Energy dissipation; Microprocessor chips; Real time systems; Filter-cache; Static pattern prediction; Buffer storage

Authors: De Rossi U., Litz U., Blendl C.
Title: Activation Energy of Dye Degradation Processes on Different Inkjet Papers
Source title: International Conference on Digital Printing Technologies
Affiliations: Tetenal Photowerk GmbH and Co KG, Norderstedt, Germany; University of Applied Science, Cologne, Germany
Authors with affiliations: De Rossi, U., Tetenal Photowerk GmbH and Co KG, Norderstedt, Germany; Litz, U., University of Applied Science, Cologne, Germany; Blendl, C., University of Applied Science, Cologne, Germany
Abstract: Understanding light- and storage stability is of utmost importance in inkjet printing. In this paper we present investigations of light-induced kinetics of dye degradation. Magenta, black and cyan dyes are irradiated on typical glossy and matt media using a Xenon lamp and the decrease of remission intensity with irradiation time is recorded using UV-Vis spectroscopy. Most dye kinetics can be described as 1st order reaction at least in the beginning of the reaction. From temperature dependence of 1st order kinetics we are able to determine activation energies for the decay process allowing us a detailed media-dependent comparison of kinetic behaviour. Furthermore an analysis of UV-Vis spectra show that not only one single degradation channel is responsible for light fading processes. In order to define the contribution of oxidative nonlight induced processes UV-Vis data of dark storage under oxidative atmosphere are compared in shape and intensity allowing a separation of light and oxidative decay channels. For most ink-paper combinations a superposition of light-induced and oxidative mechanisms are likely. Using activation energies as parameter for dye-paper stability also the influence of room humidity on stability of inkjet prints can be estimated.
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Atmospheric humidity; Catalysis; Degradation; Dyes; Environmental impact; Ink; Irradiation; Oxidation; Ozone; Paper; Pigments; Reaction kinetics; Xenon; Inkjet papers; Remission curves; Printing

Authors: Niar S., Eeckhout L., De Bosschere K.
Title: Comparing multiported cache schemes
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Processing Techniques and Applications
Affiliations: University of Valenciennes, Valenciennes, France; Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Niar, S., University of Valenciennes, Valenciennes, France; Eeckhout, L., Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium; De Bosschere, K., Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium
Abstract: The performance of the data memory hierarchy is extremely important in current and near future high performance superscalar microprocessors. To address the memory gap, computer designers implement caches to reduce the high memory latencies that are observed in the processor. Due to the ever increasing instruction window sizes and issue widths in new microprocessor designs, designers will need to implement multiported caches in order to be able service multiple memory requests per clock cycle. Several studies have been conducted in previous work dealing with the performance in terms of Instructions Per Cycle (IPC) for such cache designs. However, little is known about the access time, the energy consumption and the required chip area for multiported caches. This paper quantifies these aspects for several multiported cache designs.
Author Keywords: Cache memories; Computer architecture; Multibanked caches; Multiported caches
Index Keywords: Computer architecture; Reduced instruction set computing; Scheduling; Systems analysis; Time division multiplexing; Access time; Instruction per cycle; Interleaving; Multiported caches; Buffer storage

Authors: Singh P., Cabillic G.
Title: Successive Checkpointing Approach for Mobile Computing Environment
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Wireless Networks
Affiliations: INRIA-Rennes, Universite de Rennes 1, Rennes, France
Authors with affiliations: Singh, P., INRIA-Rennes, Universite de Rennes 1, Rennes, France; Cabillic, G., INRIA-Rennes, Universite de Rennes 1, Rennes, France
Abstract: Mobile computing environment has features tike high mobility, frequent disconnections, and lack of resources. Such features make applications, running on mobile devices, more susceptible to faults. Checkpointing is a major technique to confine faults and restart applications faster. In this paper, we introduce concept of successive checkpoints, which is based on delayed checkpointing approach. We are using partial blocking alongwith successive checkpointing to achieve a consistent checkpoint state. Our approach saves energy by avoiding unnecessary computation and useless checkpoints. Our blocking is restrictive in nature and preserve consistency without unnecessarily delaying computation. We ask only minimum number of processes to take the checkpoint and take in to account the limited storage available at mobile devices.
Author Keywords: Mobile Computing; Partial Blocking; Successive Checkpoints; Wireless Networks

Authors: Varin R.A., Guo L.
Title: Application of Controlled Reactive Mechanical Alloying (CRMA) for the Synthesis of Nanocrystalline Mg2CoH5 Hydrogen Storage Intermetallic Alloy
Source title: Processing and Fabrication of Advanced Materials XII
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont. N2L 3G1, Canada

Abstract: Mg-based complex hydrides are very attractive as potentially convenient hydrogen storage materials in application for fuel cells as well as materials for thermochemical thermal energy storage in heat storage systems. Among them, the hydride Mg2CoH5 has theoretical hydrogen capacity of about 4.5wt%, which is higher than 3.6wt% for the Mg2NiH4 compound. However, as opposed to the Mg2Ni intermetallic which exists in the equilibrium Mg-Ni system, the Mg2Co compound only exists in its hydrided form. In this paper we present the results of our efforts to directly synthesize Mg2CoH5 in a nanocrystalline form by controlled reactive mechanical alloying (CRMA) in a magneto-mill Uni-Ball-Mill 5 under hydrogen atmosphere.
Index Keywords: Cryogenics; Gravimetric analysis; Hydrides; Hydrogen; Intermetallics; Mechanical alloying; Polycrystalline materials; Volumetric analysis; Controlled reactive mechanical alloying (CRMA); Magneto-mill; Proton exchange membrane (PEM); Magnesium alloys

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Imperfect harmony
Source title: Nuclear Engineering International
Abstract: The European Commission's (EC) propose directives on nuclear safety and radwaste management. The General for Transport and Energy (TREN) presents legislation on nuclear safety, radwaste management and uranium imports termed as 'nuclear package'. The two directives of this package such as setting out basic obligations, safety of nuclear installations and management of spent nuclear fuel are also suggested. The European Council's Atomic Questions Group (AQG) includes removal of proposals for specific European safety standards and deadlines to find sites for radwaste storage and disposal.
Index Keywords: Decommissioning (nuclear reactors); Nuclear engineering; Nuclear fuels; Radiation hazards; Radioactive wastes; Uranium; Waste management; Nuclear safety; Radwaste management; Nuclear industry

Authors: Williams O.P.
Title: Steel-lined tunnels at ffestiniog power station
Source title: Proceedings - Institute of Corrosion, UK Corrosion 2003

Abstract: The Edision Mission Energy subsidiary that owns and operates Ffestiniog and Dinorwig pumped-storage hydroelectric generating schemes in Snowdonia, Wales, is the First Hydro Company (FHC) in UK. The stations have a total installed capacity of 2088 MW and provide significant support services to the UK electricity system. The Ffestiniog power station contains four pumps-turbines rated at 90 MW each and is the first large pump-storage scheme in the world. The future of the tunnels and penstocks, and their coatings at Ffestiniog are linked to the future of the station as whole, which itself is dependent on the UK electrical system.

Abstract: We have developed manganese-based lithium secondary battery technology as a part of 10-year national project of The Development of Dispersed Type Battery Energy Storage Technology. Most of the target items for the battery performance were accomplished and proved. Thus the basis for practical application was developed, however, some subjects on further durability in various circumstances and conditions still remain to be accomplished. Continuous development for mass production and cost reduction is also expected for this technology to contribute to the industry and the society.

Authors: Tam K.-S.
Title: A data model for electricity usage patterns
Source title: Proceedings of the IASTED International Conference on Modelling and Simulation
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytech. Inst./Stt. Univ., Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tam, K.-S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytech. Inst./Stt. Univ., Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Abstract: Conventionally, electricity usage patterns are handled in the time domain. This paper demonstrates the efficacy and benefits of a new data model to store and process these patterns using harmonics. It is demonstrated that daily and weekly patterns can be accurately represented by their essential harmonics. Storing shape information in the form of essential harmonics instead of time-domain data is demonstrated to result in significant savings in data storage requirement, especially for patterns of long time period such as weekly patterns. These savings are important in the coming years as customers, electricity suppliers and utilities will have to deal with more electricity usage data. The essential harmonics display trends that can be used as the new basis to categorize electric loads and to support new business such as load aggregation. The new data model also supports automated discovery of hidden trends and relationships.
Author Keywords: Data modeling; Energy demand
Index Keywords: Data reduction; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electricity; Fourier transforms; Time domain analysis; Electricity usage patterns; Electric power utilization

Authors: Berry K.J.
Title: Fuel cell commercialization: Hydrogen infrastructure economic and technical barriers
Source title: Electrical Insulation Conference and Electrical Manufacturing and Coil Winding Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Kettering University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Berry, K.J., Kettering University, United States
Abstract: Fuel cells have the potential to provide a significant shift in global politics as the United States shift to a hydrogen-fueled economy and alter its dependency on foreign petroleum. Fuel cells, however, despite their potential to provide U.S. energy security and providing a key technology against global warming, must overcome several economic and technical barriers, one of which is the development of a hydrogen fuel infrastructure. This paper provides a basic overview of these barriers and summarizes the necessary challenges.
Author Keywords: Automotive electric power; Fuel cells; Hydrogen infrastructure; Hydrogen storage; Thermal management
Index Keywords: Automotive electric power; Hydrogen infrastructures; Hydrogen storage; Thermal management; Automobile electric equipment; Automotive fuels; Cryogenic liquids; Electric power systems; Fuel economy; Gas fuel storage; High pressure effects; Hydrogen fuels; Industrial economics; Liquid fuels; Thermoelectricity; Fuel cells

Authors: Yensco Jr. A.M.
Title: Solar power: Control systems, the integrating of components with the grid system, and the effective management/control of both
Source title: Electrical Insulation Conference and Electrical Manufacturing and Coil Winding Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Indiana Institute of Technology, United States; Indust. Mfg. Engineering Program, Indiana Institute of Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yensco Jr., A.M., Indiana Institute of Technology, United States, Indust. Mfg. Engineering Program, Indiana Institute of Technology, United States
Abstract: The intent of this paper is to discuss and examine the integration of a solar (alternative) power source, with the traditional power grid. This discussion will be limited to solar photovoltaic PV, wind generators, and battery storage that must be integrated and controlled in a safe and predictable way while interfacing with the public's power source.The paper will show that the individual components of an "alternative" power supply can be managed and controlled in a safe and responsible way and that such a system can be beneficial to the owners of both the alternative power system and the traditional power company. It will be explained how, through technical advancement, it is possible for the two technologies to coexist as well as being mutually complementary. The benefits will be far-reaching and long lasting to all that wish to partake in the emerging technologies.
Index Keywords: Battery storage; Power grids; Control system analysis; Doping (additives); Electric batteries; Electric potential; Electric power systems; Laws and legislation; Permanent magnets; Photovoltaic effects; Solar energy

Authors: Chen S.C., Yang H.T.
Title: Implementation of a virtual-instrument for non-intrusive intelligent real-time load monitoring
Source title: Proceedings of the IASTED International Conference on Neural Networks and Computational Intelligence
Affiliations: Department of Electric Engineering, Chung-Yuan Christian University, Chung-Li 32023, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chen, S.C., Department of Electric Engineering, Chung-Yuan Christian University, Chung-Li 32023, Taiwan; Yang, H.T., Department of Electric Engineering, Chung-Yuan Christian University, Chung-Li 32023, Taiwan
Abstract: A load monitoring system can be used to monitor the power consumption of a load. Traditionally, a measurement device is needed for an individual load. In this paper, a real-time load recognition algorithm is applied to a non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) system. Data for voltages and currents are acquired through the monitoring device installed in the power entrance. To achieve real-time load recognition, the Self-Organizing Maps (SOM) based on effective input features is used to classify the loads on line. The system performing the NILM is developed on virtual instrument (VI) using Lab VIEW software associated with a data acquisition (DAQ) card. The performance of the system has been tested and verified by using practical combinations of loads. Promising results have been obtained and presented in this paper.
Author Keywords: Lab VIEW; Non-intrusive Measurement; Real-time Load Recognition; SOM
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Data reduction; Electric energy storage; Electric potential; Electric power utilization; Energy management; Neural networks; Real time systems; Non-intrusive measurements; Real-time load recognition; Electric load management

Authors: Enseñat-Acevedo J.F., Hernández-Cajigas M., Rodríguez-Martínez M.
Title: Design of a registration server for the nettraveler middleware system
Source title: Proceedings of the IASTED International Conference on Internet and Multimedia Systems and Applications
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, University of Puerto Rico, Mayagüez Campus, Puerto Rico
Authors with affiliations: Enseñat-Acevedo, J.F., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Puerto Rico, Mayagüez Campus, Puerto Rico; Hernández-Cajigas, M., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Puerto Rico, Mayagüez Campus, Puerto Rico; Rodríguez-Martínez, M., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Puerto Rico, Mayagüez Campus, Puerto Rico
Abstract: In recent years, mobile devices (e.g. cell phones, PDAs, and notebooks) have had a high increase in their networking, computational and storage power. The mobile nature of these devices causes a new set of problems not seen in conventional wired networks. Mobile devices can go off-line, experience network outages, have batteries with limited power-life, and require energy efficient components. As users start to move their application to these devices, it becomes to have a middleware infrastructure that can integrate the different data held by mobiles users. Unfortunately, existing middleware technologies are ill-equipped to overcome these new set of problems since they are designed for application that reside in workstations and mainframes. To address these issues, we are developing NetTraveler, a database middleware system to integrate mobile devices reliably in a computer network. In this paper, we present the Registration Server for NetTraveler. Registration Servers are directory managers, located at cooperative local execution environments (e.g. LANs) that work together to keep track of moving data sources and route query request as appropriate. Registration Servers are implemented as Java Web Services. We describe the architecture of the Registration Server, define its tasks, operational modes, and discuss the current state of our prototype.
Author Keywords: Database Middleware; Internet Architectures; NetTraveler; Web Services
Index Keywords: Internet architecture; NetTraveler; Registration serversd; Computational methods; Java programming language; Mobile telecommunication systems; Query languages; Servers; Software prototyping; Systems analysis; World Wide Web; Middleware

Authors: Thomson H., Meggitt D., Saade E.
Title: Ascension island hydroacoustic data system
Source title: Oceans Conference Record (IEEE)
Affiliations: Naval Facilities Eng. Serv. Ctr., Port Hueneme, CA, United States; South and Sea Technology, Edmonds, WA, United States; Thales Geosolutions (Pacific) Inc., San Diego, CA, United States

Abstract: The Hydroacoustic Data Acquisition System (HDAS) is an essential part of the US Atomic Energy Detection System (USAEDS). The HDAS consists of underwater sensor systems linked to shore facilities with undersea data transmission cables, and shore based computers for data storage and transmission to the National Data Center (NDC). This paper describes the background of the HDAS installation and previous surveys at Ascension Island and provides an overview of completed and planned operations.
Index Keywords: Computers; Data communication systems; Hydrophones; Nuclear explosions; Regulatory compliance; Sensors; Submarine cables; Underwater acoustics; Hydroacoustic data system; Nuclear testing; Undersea data transmission cables; Underwater sensor system; Oceanography

Authors: Ataei N.
Title: Simulation of brushless exciter model for a three-machine-system
Source title: Proceedings of the IASTED Multi-Conference- Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: University of Dortmund-Germany, Department of Electrical Machines, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ataei, N., University of Dortmund-Germany, Department of Electrical Machines, Germany
Abstract: In this paper a special brushless exciter model in form of three synchronous machines in power stations has been investigated. Synchronous machines have been generally modelled according to the d-q axis theory. The exciter system has been modelled by dynamic blocks with nonlinear characteristic curves which represent the behavior of machine terminal well, but for representing the behavior of the internal stressing of the exciter system are insufficient. These concepts are not suitable for calculating the stressing of different parts of the excitation system. The main emphasis of this article is an investigated model consisting of the generator, the main exciter and the auxiliary exciter as well as diodes and thyristors in the excitation system.
Author Keywords: Brushless Model; Exciter system; Synchronous machines

Authors: Wies R.W., Agrawal A.N.
Title: Modeling and optimization of hybrid electric power systems for remote locations in extreme climates
Source title: Proceedings of the IASTED Multi-Conference- Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK 99775-5915, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wies, R.W., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK 99775-5915, United States; Agrawal, A.N., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK 99775-5915, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the modeling and optimization of a hybrid electric power system for remote locations in extreme climates. The hybrid model presented incorporates the added features of dynamic modeling and graphical user interface available in the Power System Blockset and MATLAB™ Simulink. The model currently consists of a diesel-electric generator and a battery storage module connected to a common grid to form the hybrid system with photovoltaic cells and wind generation systems to be incorporated in the future. This simulation tool will help designers determine the best hybrid mix of diesel generation, battery storage, photovoltaics, and wind generation for optimal performance of the system in remote cold regions like Alaska. Many software programs are currently available for simulating the operation of hybrid electric power systems under normal operating conditions. The work presented in this paper considers the optimal operation of hybrid systems in extreme cold climates like those found in the remote villages of Alaska. An example is presented based on an actual test system in the remote Alaskan community of Lime Village.
Author Keywords: Battery storage; Diesel generator; Hybrid power system; Modeling; Optimization; Photovoltaics
Index Keywords: Climatology; Computer simulation; Computer software; Electric batteries; Electric energy storage; Graphical user interfaces; Optimization; Performance; Photovoltaic cells; Battery storage; Diesel generators; Electric power systems

Authors: Lai J.-S.
Title: Designing the next generation distribution transformers: New power electronic-based hybrid and solid-state design approaches
Source title: Proceedings of the IASTED Multi-Conference- Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Virginia Polytec. Inst./Stt. Univ., Bradley Dept. of Elec. Engineering, Blacksburg, VA 24061-0111, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lai, J.-S., Virginia Polytec. Inst./Stt. Univ., Bradley Dept. of Elec. Engineering, Blacksburg, VA 24061-0111, United States
Abstract: The advancement and availability of high-voltage semiconductor devices have shed a light on economically viable solid-state based or hybrid transformers for distribution systems. With incorporation of the solid-state technology into the distribution transformer, many new features can be realized through power electronics control and dc bus energy storage. This paper first defines these new features that largely enhance the functionality of distribution transformers. Two circuit topologies including a high-voltage device based multilevel and a hybrid approach that mixes with conventional transformer and solid-state circuitry are proposed. Simulation results are then showing how some of the key features can be achieved. Finally the cost of semiconductor is surveyed to project the cost of the entire solid-state distribution transformer. Given the cost figure modularity, there is a good chance for either hybrid or pure solid-state design approach to become the next generation distribution transformer.
Author Keywords: Hybrid transformer; Solid-state distribution transformer; Universal transformer
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric network topology; Electrical engineering; Energy storage; Networks (circuits); Power electronics; Semiconductor devices; Sensors; Switching; Hybrid tranformers; Solid-state distribution transformers; Universal transformers; Electric transformers

Title: Grain Size Effects in Nanocrystalline Electrodeposits
Source title: Processing and Properties of Structural Nanomaterial: Proceedings of Symposia held at the Materials Science and Technology 2003 Meeting
