Abstract: Spot sizes are measured for medium energy x-ray generators. The Cygnus x-ray source [1] is developed for support of the Sub-Critical Experiments Program at the Nevada Test Site. Cygnus uses proven pulsed power technology to drive a rod pinch diode at 2.25 megavolts. Four rads at one meter is achieved in a 50-ns FWHM pulse and the radiographic spot size is as small as 1 mm-diameter. Radiographic spot size is measured employing roll bars and resolution targets. Images are recorded on film and storage phosphor, digitized, and analyzed. The Febetron 705 x-ray source operates at 2.3 megavolts and is rated at 500 millirads at one meter. A demountable diode tube provides the ability to replace the standard diode with custom hardware. Spot sizes for standard hardware are measured. New diode designs are investigated in an effort to generate smaller radiographic spot sizes to produce improved radiographic images.
Index Keywords: Cathodes; Diodes; Electric currents; Fourier transforms; Optimization; Phosphors; Radiography; Thermoluminescence; Tungsten; Energy spectrum; X-ray generators; X-ray sources; X ray apparatus

Authors: Lindblom A., Appelgren P., Larsson A., Nyholm S.E., Isberg J., Bernhoff H.
Title: High-voltage transmission line transformer based on modern cable technology
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: FOI, Swedish Defence Research Agency, Grindsjön Research Centre, SE-14725 Tumba, Sweden; Division for Electricity, Angströmlaboratoriet, Uppsala University, SE-75121 Uppsala, Sweden; Division for Electricity, Angströmslaboratoreiet, Uppsala University, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Lindblom, A., FOI, Swedish Defence Research Agency, Grindsjön Research Centre, SE-14725 Tumba, Sweden, Division for Electricity, Angströmslaboratoreiet, Uppsala University, Sweden; Appelgren, P., FOI, Swedish Defence Research Agency, Grindsjön Research Centre, SE-14725 Tumba, Sweden; Larsson, A., FOI, Swedish Defence Research Agency, Grindsjön Research Centre, SE-14725 Tumba, Sweden; Nyholm, S.E., FOI, Swedish Defence Research Agency, Grindsjön Research Centre, SE-14725 Tumba, Sweden; Isberg, J., Division for Electricity, Angströmlaboratoriet, Uppsala University, SE-75121 Uppsala, Sweden; Bernhoff, H., Division for Electricity, Angströmlaboratoriet, Uppsala University, SE-75121 Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: A high-voltage transmission line pulse transformer has been constructed based on modern cable technology. The transformer has been successfully tested for secondary voltages up to 85 kV. The high-voltage cable is equipped with a resistive layer (semicon) on the inner conductor and on the inside of the outer conductor. Semicon cables are commonly used in high-voltage transmission of electrical power. This article describes a transformer design that uses the screen in the coaxial cable as primary winding and the inner conductor as secondary. The coupling factor for the single layer transformer is 0.8. This high coupling factor is achieved due to the coaxial structure. The single layer transformer was tested in an existing power-conditioning system, in which an output voltage of 85 kV was achieved. The pulse had 1-μs duration over a 15-ω load. The high voltage cable with PEX insulation proved to withstand very high stress (85 kV/mm). This type of transformer is useful in applications where weight is an important factor. The simple design ensures low cost manufacturing.
Index Keywords: High-voltage transmission line transformers; Power-conditioning systems; Capacitance; Coaxial cables; Computer simulation; Electric energy storage; Electric insulation; Electric lines; Electric power transmission; Electric switches; Electric wire; Inductance; Magnetic field effects; Mathematical models; Product design; Transfer functions; Pulse transformers

Authors: Lu X., Laroussi M., Kolb J., Kono S., Schoenbach K.H.
Title: Temporal emission behavior of pulsed discharge in water
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA 23529, United States; Kumamoto University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lu, X., Electrical Engineering Department, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA 23529, United States; Laroussi, M., Electrical Engineering Department, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA 23529, United States; Kolb, J., Electrical Engineering Department, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA 23529, United States; Kono, S., Kumamoto University, Japan; Schoenbach, K.H., Electrical Engineering Department, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA 23529, United States
Abstract: To move high energy pulsed power systems from the laboratory to practice requires the development of compact lightweight drivers. To reduce the size and weight of high voltage components, increase in the energy density in dielectrics at high electric stress is required. Therefore, an in-depth understanding of the hold-off voltage and breakdown properties of liquid dielectrics can lead to the optimization of energy storage. When breakdown is initiated in liquid dielectrics, vapor bubbles are generated, which first expand and later collapse. The total time of expansion and collapse of these bubbles determines the repetition rate, at which high voltage switches can be operated. In this paper, a Blumlein pulse forming network (PFN) and sphere-plane electrode configuration is used for studying a pulsed discharge in water. The diameter of the spherical electrode is 1.7mm and the gap distance between the electrodes is several hundred micrometers. The temporal development of the optical emission in the UV and visible after breakdown was measured by means of an imaging spectrograph. The radiation intensity reaches its maximum 5ns after breakdown. It remains at this level for about 100ns, and then the light intensity decreases to 30% of its peak value on a 10ns time scale. The current was found to be 800A during the pulse. The radiation spectrum of the plasma in the bubble during the 100ns after breakdown was also measured. No line radiation was observed. The measured spectrum was found to follow a blackbody radiation law. Therefore by comparing the measured spectrum with that of calculated blackbody radiation at different temperatures, the plasma temperature was determined. It was found to be in the 1-2 eV range.
Index Keywords: Blackbody radiation; Pulse forming network (PFN); Computer simulation; Dielectric materials; Electric impedance; Electric power systems; Electric switches; Emission spectroscopy; Energy storage; Energy transfer; Photomultipliers; Plasmas; Pulse generators; Spectrographs; Switching; Electric discharges

Authors: Hernández J.-C., Neuber A.A., Dickens J.C., Kristiansen M.
Title: Small sized MFCG for driving a high impedance load
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Ctr. Pulsed Pwr./Pwr. Electron. Res., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech. University, Lubbock, TX 79409-3102, United States

University, Lubbock, TX 79409-3102, United States; Dickens, J.C., Ctr. Pulsed Pwr./Pwr. Electron. Res., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech. University, Lubbock, TX 79409-3102, United States; Kristiansen, M., Ctr. Pulsed Pwr./Pwr. Electron. Res., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech. University, Lubbock, TX 79409-3102, United States
Abstract: End-initiated small volume magnetic flux compression generators (MFCG) have at least one order of magnitude higher energy density (by weight or volume) than capacitive energy storage with similar discharge time characteristics. Since the prime energy is built into the MFCG in form of HE, the capacitor looses even more ground if the necessary prime energy source and the charging supply are included in the weight/ volume balance. However, simple MFCGs with a single helix produce high output energy only into low inductance loads, thus producing several 100 kA of current at a voltage level of only a few 10 kV. Many pulsed power devices require less current but a considerably higher voltage level. Two approaches for achieving a higher output voltage level, both utilizing two staged MFCGs, have been reported in the open literature. The first employs a more traditional transformer coupling, the second relies on a dynamic transformer or flux-trapping scheme. Although the traditional transformer coupling has theoretically the better efficiency, we chose the latter approach for our generator design, mostly since it requires a smaller number of components. Our generator has a total length of 250 mm, a helix inner diameter of 51 mm, and is wound with Teflon insulated stranded wire of different sizes in the range from AWG 12 to AWG 22. We have presently achieved an energy gain of ∼ 8 and will discuss the generator performance based on experimental current/voltage waveforms.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric breakdown; Electric generators; Electric impedance; Electric transformers; Inductance; Insulation; Magnetic flux; Waveform analysis; High impedance load; Magnetic flux compression generators (MFCG); Electric loads

Authors: LeChien K.R., Gahl J.M., Kemp M.A., Curry R.D., Elizondo J.M., Struve K.W.
Title: Development of a terawatt test stand at the university of Missouri for fast, multichannel switching analysis
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, 349 Engineering Building West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: LeChien, K.R., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, 349 Engineering Building West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Gahl, J.M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, 349 Engineering Building West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Kemp, M.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, 349 Engineering Building West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Curry, R.D., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, 349 Engineering Building West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Elizondo, J.M., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Struve, K.W., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Abstract: The University of Missouri Terawatt Test Stand (MUTTS) began assembly in January 2003. Construction of MUTTS is progressing rapidly with the design and development of its high energy Marx bank. The Marx bank consists of 32, 100 kV, 0.7 μF capacitors switched by 16 Physics International T508 spark gaps. The Marx is switched into two parallel 7 nF, intermediate storage capacitors, which are fired into a dummy load through a fast multi-channeling output switch. The Marx stores 100 kJ and can deliver a voltage of 2 MV at 500 kA into a 4 Ω load delivering 1 TW to the load. Initial testing will be of a multichanneling 2 MV output switch, which scales nicely to a 6 MV switch design for future very high energy machines at Sandia National Laboratories. The output switch is to reliably multichannel, or close with many parallel arc channels. The goal is to adapt an existing multichanneling switch to create a multichanneling output switch with significant operational advantages, including lower inductance, compared to existing multichannel switches. The target switch inductance is 100 nH or less. The facility and tank were assembled from January to June 2003, with testing to begin in July 2003. Simulations of the test stand and specifications of the output switch will be presented. Electrode configurations and switch augmentations that will facilitate a reliable multi-channeling switch will be introduced. Details describing the development of the MUTTS facility will be included.
Index Keywords: Exponential switch models; Laser triggered switches; Multichannel switching; Capacitors; Computer simulation; Electric arcs; Electric currents; Electric potential; Electric resistance; Electrodes; Inductance; Laser applications; Switching

Abstract: A 2.4 MJ pulse power system (PPS) has been applied to electrothermal-chemical (ETC) propulsion study for three years successfully. The 2.4 MJ PPS consists of 8 modular capacitor banks (CB) with energy of 300 kJ each. The 300kJ CB modules are designed to operate independently and have a charging voltage of 22 kV and a current capability of 150kA. In the course of the application of the PPS, several modifications and improvement have been done in order to enhance safety and reliability. In this paper, we summarized some problems that take place during multiple modules operation and suggested the countermeasures against the problems. The performance of PPS has been improved and we show some experimental results which we have carried out by an application of the improved 2.4MJ PPS to various kinds of loads.

Authors: Smith D.L., Michael Wilson J., Slattery M.J., Tabor D.A., Donovan G.L.
Title: Two ZR Marx generator operating configurations that make possible their rolling upgrade integration into Z
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1178, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D.L., Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1178, United States; Michael Wilson, J., Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1178, United States; Slattery, M.J., Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1178, United States; Tabor, D.A., Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1178, United States; Donovan, G.L., Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1178, United States
Abstract: If the Sandia National Laboratories' Z-Machine Marx generators and the Z-Refurbishment (ZR) Marx generators are mixed to drive like-modules in parallel, the ZR banks need to be temporarily reconfigured to closely match the output waveforms of the Z banks. Otherwise, there would be significant module-to-module variations and a loss of consistency at the central target region. Sandia has explored two solutions for operating the ZR Marx generators to meet this requirement. One method involves charging the ZR banks to about 72 kV along with the 90-kV charge for the Z banks, thus requiring two power supplies and charge busses plus a different SF6 pressure in the Marx switches. The other method is to short or bypass an appropriate number of ZR Marx stages so the remaining "reduced" Marx generator may be charged to the same 90-kV level. Some hardware, labor, and bank inductance tuning are needed to match output timing to the original pulsed power. This paper examines how to implement both solutions and compares their advantages and disadvantages with the goal of choosing only one of them. Models supporting this effort take into account measurements obtained from existing Marx generators that have been reconfigured in similar ways.

Authors: Swett D.W., Blanche J.
Title: Hi-voltage flywheel charging module for capacitor banks used in pulsed power applications
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference

Abstract: Optimal Energy Systems is currently designing and manufacturing flywheel based energy storage systems that are being used to provide pulses of energy for charging high voltage capacitors in a mobile military system. These systems receive their energy from low voltage vehicle buss power (28 VDC) and provide output power at over 10,000 VDC without the need for DC-DC voltage conversion electronics. This energy conversion is accomplished through the use of OES patented ultra high-speed flywheel power module (FPoM) technology.

Abstract: This paper presents an overview of custom design requirements for components and power supplies used in pulsed power systems as well as some interesting examples. Various custom design criteria for energy storage capacitors, energy-absorbing resistors, high current fuses, and capacitor charging power supplies are described. In addition, specially designed components are characterized through both simulation and experimental measurements for pulse power system applications.

Title: Investigations on a 5-Level VSI-Chopper for a Superconductive Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) Power Conditioning System

Affiliations: Dept. of ECE, FAMU-FSU College of Engineering, Tallahassee, FL 32310, United States; Center for Advanced Power Systems, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL 32310, United States; Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL 32310, United States

Abstract: The introduction of multilevel converters makes possible the use of pulse width modulation (PWM) converters and medium power devices like insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs) for high-voltage, high-power applications, such as flexible ac transmission systems (FACTS). This paper proposes a 5-level voltage source inverter-chopper topology for a superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) power conditioning system (PCS). The topological structure and operation principles of 5-level VSI and 5-level chopper are discussed. The performance of the proposed converter system has been compared with a traditional transformer coupled multi-pulse VSI - chopper topology. The application of the proposed 5-level SMES PCS to static var compensator (SVC) has been investigated and verified by computer simulations.

Abstract: This paper presents a novel power compensation system for a photovolataic (PV) array that is partially covered by a shade. The control strategy utilizes Electric Double Layer Capacitors (EDLC) as a energy storage device, which brings some advantages into the system configuration of both main and control system over using a battery or DC-DC converters. In addition, the energy flow of the EDLC can be simply controlled by a relay with only detecting the terminal voltage of the EDLC. The control characteristics of the proposed system are examined by the experimental analyses. And, the system feasibility is demonstrated and verified from the viewpoint of power compensation effect.

Authors: Muljadi E., Bialasiewicz J.T.
Title: Hybrid Power System with a Controlled Energy Storage
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: National Wind Technology Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 1617 Cole Boulevard, Golden, CO, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Colorado at Denver, Campus Box 110, P.O. Box 173364, Denver, CO 80217-3364, United States

Box 173364, Denver, CO 80217-3364, United States
Abstract: We investigated a small isolated hybrid power system that used two types of power generation; wind turbine and diesel generation. The interaction of diesel generation, the wind turbine, and the local load is complicated because both the load and the wind turbine fluctuate during the day. These fluctuations create imbalances in power distribution (energy sources are not equal to energy sinks) that can affect the frequency and the voltage in the power system. The addition of energy storage will help balance the distribution of power in the power network. For this paper, we studied the interaction among hybrid power system components and the relative size of the components. We also show how the contribution of wind energy affects the entire power system and distribution and the role of energy storage under the transient conditions caused by load changes and wind turbine start ups.
Author Keywords: Diesel generator; Energy storage; Hybrid power system; Renewable energy; Wind turbine

Authors: Norman P., Dudgeon G., McDonald J.R.
Title: A Review Of The Current and Future Role of Power Electronics Within Marine More-Electric Environments
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Inst. for Energy and Environment, University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom; Institute for Energy and Environment, Department of Electronic Engineering, University of Strathclyde, 204 George Street, Glasgow G1 1XW, United Kingdom

Abstract: Recent years have seen an increasing trend towards more-electric power distribution, which aims to replace mechanical and hydraulic power systems with electrical equivalents. The more-electric concept has been considered in marine applications for many years, but has only recently become feasible due to advancements in the necessary underpinning technologies. One of the key enabling technologies is power electronics, which enables more efficient conversion between ac and dc, provides higher quality power conditioning and allows effective use of energy storage media within the more-electric environments. This paper aims to contribute a unique perspective on the more-electric environment by focusing primarily on the role of power electronics. The discussion will draw not only on application within the marine sector, but will also consider possible read-across from other applications of power electronics, in order to consider potential avenues for overcoming future challenges.
Index Keywords: Integrated full electric propulsion (IFEP); Low voltage (LV); Electric converters; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric network topology; Electric power distribution; Gas turbines; Gears; Hydraulics; Marine engineering; Uninterruptible power systems; Power electronics

Abstract: Fuel cells represent a potentially main source of electrical power for the future. This paper discusses the dynamic behaviour of a fuel cell system for stationary power generation fuelled with natural gas. The mathematical model of such a system has been derived and the results of simulated step change scenarios discussed. Based on the simulation results, suitable applications for such fuel cell power plants have been suggested.

Abstract: The various aspects of a generalized net (GN) model of the system 'object interior/exterior environment' are discussed. The GN models are extensions of the Petri nets. The model represents the functioning of an abstract system, having memory, effectors and receptors, and its relations with its interior and exterior environment. The apparatus of the Intuitionistic Fuzzy Sets (IFS) gives the possibility of the estimations of the GN-components. The GN model is used for simulation, investigation and control of relationships 'object-environment'.

Title: Investigation of IGBT-devices for pulsed power applications
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Fr.-Ger. Res. Inst. of Saint-Louis, BP 34, F-68301 Saint-louis Cedex, France; ABB Switzerland Ltd, Semiconductors, Fabrikstr. 3, CH-5600 Lenzburg, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Scharnholz, S., Fr.-Ger. Res. Inst. of Saint-Louis, BP 34, F-68301 Saint-louis Cedex, France; Schneider, R., Fr.-Ger. Res. Inst. of Saint-Louis, BP 34, F-68301 Saint-louis Cedex, France; Spahn, E., Fr.-Ger. Res. Inst. of Saint-Louis, BP 34, F-68301 Saint-louis Cedex, France; Welleman, A., Fr.-Ger. Res. Inst. of Saint-Louis, BP 34, F-68301 Saint-louis Cedex, France, ABB Switzerland Ltd, Semiconductors, Fabrikstr. 3, CH-5600 Lenzburg, Switzerland; Gekenidis, S., Fr.-Ger. Res. Inst. of Saint-Louis, BP 34, F-68301 Saint-louis Cedex, France, ABB Switzerland Ltd, Semiconductors, Fabrikstr. 3, CH-5600 Lenzburg, Switzerland
Abstract: IGBT-switches from ABB Switzerland have been characterised at ISL with regard to civil and military pulsed power applications. The investigated devices are press-pack IGBT modules with a blocking voltage of 2.5 kV and a continuous current rating of 2 kA. Using capacitive energy storage systems the IGBT was investigated as closing switch with the objective of generating short current pulses with high amplitudes, as they are e. g. required for driving a High Power Microwave (HPM) source. Inductive energy storage systems have a higher energy density than capacitive systems. The drawback, however, is the need of opening switches in order to commutate the current into the load. For such a system we investigated the turn-off behaviour of the IGBT. The experiments show that the IGBT modules used are capable to generate 12 kA pulses with switching times below one microsecond. Investigating the IGBT as opening switch in an inductive storage circuit has proved its superiority over comparable switching configurations using power MOSFETs. Comparing IGBT and MOSFET configurations with the same total die size and same on-state resistance and therefore same price allows to gain advantage from a much higher commutation voltage in case of the IGBT, which in turn allows for a much shorter commutation time.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Capacitors; Electric loads; Electric resistance; Electric switches; Microwave devices; MOSFET devices; Pulse generators; Thyristors; Waveform analysis; Inductive storage circuits; Solid state switches; Insulated gate bipolar transistors

Authors: Pokryvailo A., Ziv I., Shviro E.
Title: Status of 5MW inductive storage facility at soreq NRC
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne 81800, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Pokryvailo, A., Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne 81800, Israel; Ziv, I., Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne 81800, Israel; Shviro, E., Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne 81800, Israel
Abstract: A laboratory repetitive inductive storage power supply (IPS) for the ignition of an Electrothermal Chemical (ETC) gun is described. Eight years ago, it was designed for delivering to an ET load the energy of 500kJ in a shot. This paper gives an updated status of this facility. The IPS is battery-based. Originally, the battery had a peak power of 5MW and was able to charge a cylindrical coil to 700kJ. The batteries degradation during the years was observed and documented. Fringe fields of Brooks-type coils with and without screens were analyzed. A conclusion is drawn that a screen of reasonable weight cannot reduce the stray field below a susceptibility level of electronic devices that should be shielded individually. A major facility improvement was in the field of switching. A compact hybrid repetitive opening switch (HOS) rated 50kA, 7kV was developed. This HOS can be used in long-charge inductive storage systems that look promising for many applications, such as uninterruptible power supplies, driving ET loads, protection of DC circuits, etc. The HOS design and testing is given in detail. The design limitations and trade-offs are discussed. A commercial vacuum circuit breaker serves as the first stage. It provides the high-current carrying capability during the inductor charge. At a desired moment, it is opened, and the current is transferred to the second stage comprising two gate commutated thyristors (GCTs) connected in series; they break the current during several microseconds. A pause of 1-2ms is provided for the vacuum breaker recovery. A novel approach allowing the enhancement of an order of magnitude of the turn-off capability of fully-controlled semiconductor devices was developed. It comprises the inverse current injection into the second stage assisted by a precisely timed gate turn-off. The main benefit of this technique is the reduction of the quantity of the semiconductor devices in the second stage.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric coils; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric inductors; Electrochemistry; Thyristors; Vacuum; Electrothermal chemical (ETC) guns; Inductive storage; Electric power systems

Authors: MacDougall F.W., Ennis J.B., Cooper R.A., Bates J., Seal K.

Abstract: Pulsed power in mobile systems requires high energy density capacitors as energy storage and power compression devices. Applications range from medical defibrillators to naval artillery, with a wide envelope of operating conditions requiring several technology approaches. The ongoing, multi-faceted development effort on high energy density pulsed power capacitors at General Atomics Energy Products has yielded capacitors with significantly higher energy densities (> 5 J/cc) than were available a few years ago. Substantially higher energy densities are also being achieved in capacitors designed for microsecond discharge applications. This paper describes this progress and the state of the art in pulsed power capacitors.
Index Keywords: Defibrillators; Electric discharges; Electric potential; Inductance; Nuclear energy; Pulse width modulation; Thermoanalysis; Mobile systems; Power compression devices; Pulsed power capacitors; Capacitor storage

Authors: Giesselmann M., McHale B., Crawford M.
Title: Fast, real-time monitoring of AC-Alternators under heavy transient loading conditions
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Ctr. for Pulsed Pwr./Pwr. Electron., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409-3102, United States; Institute for Advanced Technology, University of Texas at Austin, 3925 W. Braker Lane, Austin, TX 78759-5316, United States
Authors with affiliations: Giesselmann, M., Ctr. for Pulsed Pwr./Pwr. Electron., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409-3102, United States; McHale, B., Ctr. for Pulsed Pwr./Pwr. Electron., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409-3102, United States; Crawford, M., Institute for Advanced Technology, University of Texas at Austin, 3925 W. Braker Lane, Austin, TX 78759-5316, United States
Abstract: This paper describes work towards controlling the output of fast AC-Alternators to drive transient loads through intelligent triggering of SCR (Thyristor) switches. The project entails the extension of methods and techniques that have been developed for high performance control of relatively small and slow turning industrial machines, to the more demanding regime of AC-machines used for kinetic energy storage and fast AC-servos for military applications. One of these techniques is a rotational transformation, where the (sinusoidal) AC output voltage of an alternator is converted to a DC level representing the instantaneous amplitude. This transformation, also called 'Vector Rotation' can be used for very fast observation of the momentary amplitudes of all electrical machine quantities, since no averaging is necessary. Through the use of vector rotations, advanced sensors and real time signal processing it is possible to demonstrate fast real-time monitoring of the energy extraction from a high frequency AC-Alternator with a full-bridge SCR converter. A low-voltage DC machine was selected as the load for the system, which closely resembles the transient impedance of an electric launcher.
Index Keywords: Electric launchers; Position encoder; Electric converters; Electric loads; Energy storage; Kinetic energy; Microcontrollers; Military applications; Sensors; Signal encoding; Signal processing; Thyristors; Transients; Synchronous generators

Abstract: Five different types of high voltage capacitors have been tested to determine their maximum high voltage overstress coefficient. Chicago Condenser, Reynolds Industries, Hivolt, and TDL capacitors of capacitance 100 nF and different nominal voltages were tested in the single shot mode. Experiments have shown that the energy stored under overstress conditions in all types of the capacitors tested is 10 to 20 times more than the nominal energy.

Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference

Abstract: The energy efficiency of a pulsed-power conditioning system is examined. The system under study converts a relatively slow high-current impulse to a fast high-voltage impulse. The operative parts of the system are an inductive energy storage coil in series with an electrically exploded opening switch (wire fuse). In parallel to the fuse, a closing switch (spark gap) and the load are placed in series. The energy efficiency is measured as the quotient between the energy dissipated in the load and the energy in the storage inductor at the instant of operation of the fuse switch. In such a power conditioning system the main energy consumer is the wire fuse. The analysis is accompanied with electric equivalent circuit simulations.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric energy storage; Electric load flow; Electric loads; Electric resistance; Electric switches; Electric wire; Energy dissipation; Energy efficiency; Inductance; Mathematical models; Microwaves; Energy flow analysis; Pulsed-power conditioning systems; Electric power systems

Abstract: The design of a compact pulse generator with sub-ns rise time for the study of short pulse cell electroperturbation is presented. The generator is based on a small, water dielectric Blumlein PFN (Pulse Forming Network) switched with an overvolted air spark gap. This arrangement delivers 3-5-nanosecond long pulses with sub-nanosecond rise time to the cuvette load. In order to minimize the spark gap distance, and thus the rise time, the Blumlein PFN is charged within 500 ns by a MOSFET-based high-voltage resonant charger.

Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Bechtel Nevada, 316 East Atlas Circle, North Las Vegas, NV 89030, United States; KTECH Corporation, 2201 Buena Vista SE, Albuquerque, NM, United States

Abstract: Optimizing the design of the upgrade to the Z pulser at Sandia National Laboratories renewed interest in the ubiquitous Scyllac-cased capacitor. For the Z upgrade, the desired capacitance value in each case is different than those built before, and double that of the existing units in Z. The cost and fundamental importance of the Marx capacitors in pulsers like Z prompted the decision to build a test facility that could evaluate sample units from capacitor manufacturers. The number of interested vendors and the expected lifetime indicated about 350 thousand capacitor-shots for the capacitors in a plus-minus configuration. The project schedule demanded that the initial testing be completed in a few months. These factors, and budget limitations, pointed to the need for a system that could test multiple pairs of capacitors at once, without a full-time attendant. The system described here tests up to ten pairs of 2.6 μF capacitors charged to 100 kV in 90 seconds, then discharged at 150 kA and 35 percent reversal. Unattended operation requires sophisticated fault detection, and so much attention has been paid to this. This paper will describe the system, and the key components including the control system, the switches, and the load resistors. The paper will also show some lifetime and performance data from commonly used 200 kV spark gap switches.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Capacitor storage; Control systems; Electric switches; Energy transfer; Equipment testing; Error analysis; Jitter; Reliability; Resistors; Waveform analysis; Power dissipation; Spark gap switches; Capacitors

Authors: De Lamare J.E.
Title: The abort kicker system for the PEP-II storage rings at SLAC
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94309, United States
Authors with affiliations: De Lamare, J.E., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94309, United States
Abstract: The PEP-II project has two storage rings. The HER (High Energy Ring) has up to 1.48 A of election beam at 9 GeV, and the LER (Low Energy Ring) has up to 2.14 A of positron beam at 3.1 GeV. To protect the HER and LER beam lines in the event of a ring component failure, each ring has an abort kicker system which directs the beam into a dump when a failure is detected. Due to the high current of the beams, the beam kick is tapered from 100% to 80% in 7.33 μS (the beam transit time around the ring). This taper distributes the energy evenly across the window which separates the ring from the beam dump such that the window is not damaged. The abort kicker trigger is synchronized with the ion clearing gap of the beam allowing for the kicker field to rise from 0-80% while there is no beam in the kicker magnet. Originally the kicker system was designed for a rise time of 370nS, but because the ion clearing gap was reduced in half, so was the rise time requirement for the kicker. This report discusses the design of the system interlocks, diagnostics, and modulator with the modifications necessary to accommodate an ion clearing gap of 185nS.
Index Keywords: Damping; Electric currents; Electric potential; Electric transformers; Inductance; Magnetic field effects; Magnets; Modulators; Positrons; Resistors; High energy rings (HER); Low energy rings (LER); Electron beams

Authors: Grekhov I.V., Ivanov P.A., Khristyuk D.V., Korotkov S.V.
Title: Semiconductor opening switches based on 4H-SIC p+p on+-diodes
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Ioffe Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, 26 Polytechnicheskaya, St. Petersburg 194021, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Grekhov, I.V., Ioffe Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, 26 Polytechnicheskaya, St. Petersburg 194021, Russian Federation; Ivanov, P.A., Ioffe Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, 26 Polytechnicheskaya, St. Petersburg 194021, Russian Federation; Khristyuk, D.V., Ioffe Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, 26 Polytechnicheskaya, St. Petersburg 194021, Russian Federation; Korotkov, S.V., Ioffe Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, 26 Polytechnicheskaya, St. Petersburg 194021, Russian Federation
Abstract: 4H-SiC p+non+- and p+p on+-type diodes have been fabricated and evaluated as opening switch devices which are known in Si to employ the effect of fast reverse current break after switching the diodes from forward to reverse bias conditions. The recovery properties of p+pon +-diodes were found to be drastically differ from those of p +non+-type ones. In p+n on+-diodes, recombination processes predetermine soft recovery behavior in a time of approximately 16 ns. In p+n on+-type diodes, purely drift mechanism was found to be responsible, under proper condititions, for the very fast reverse current break in a time less than 1 ns. p+non+-diodes were utilized in a pulse generator which was fabricated with an inductive energy storing unit. The rise time of 400-V pulses generated, about 3 ns, was found to be equal to the quarter of the oscillation period of the LCtank consisting of 2-μH storing inductance and 2-pF 4H-SiC diode capacitance. The possibility to construct, 100-kV, 1-ns 4H-SiC pulse generators is considered.
Index Keywords: Capacitance measurement; Carrier concentration; Carrier mobility; Current density; Electric conductivity; Electric current distribution; Electric energy storage; Inductance measurement; Plasma flow; Semiconductor diodes; Semiconductor junctions; Silicon carbide; Switching circuits; Voltage measurement; Inductive storage; Recombination processes; Semiconductor opening switches; Semiconductor switches

Authors: Kovalchuk B.M., Kim A.A., Kumpjak E.V., Tsou N.V.
Title: Air insulated LTD stage with stored energy of 5.5 KJ and output power of 14 GW
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: High Current Electronics Institute, Academichesky Ave. 4, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kovalchuk, B.M., High Current Electronics Institute, Academichesky Ave. 4, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation; Kim, A.A., High Current Electronics Institute, Academichesky Ave. 4, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation; Kumpjak, E.V., High Current Electronics Institute, Academichesky Ave. 4, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation; Tsou, N.V., High Current Electronics Institute, Academichesky Ave. 4, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: In the report we present the design and test results of the Linear Transformer Driver (LTD) stage that does not need any liquid or compressed gas for insulation inside the cavity and operation of the switches. The only gas which is used is air at atmospheric pressure. At peak charge voltage of 85 kV the stage delivers to the matched load of ∼ 0.15 Ohms the 14 GW power pulse with the rise time of ∼180 ns. The stage is developed to demonstrate the possibility to simplify the LTD technology of the primary energy storages in maintenance and application.

Authors: Zhong H., Xu Z., Zou X., Zou Y., Yang L., Chao Z.
Title: Current Characteristic of High Voltage Capacitor Charging Power Supply Using a Series Resonant Topology
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci./Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430074, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhong, H., Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci./Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430074, China; Xu, Z., Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci./Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430074, China; Zou, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci./Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430074, China; Zou, Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci./Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430074, China; Yang, L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci./Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430074, China; Chao, Z., Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci./Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430074, China
Abstract: Pulse power supply applications usually require short and intense bursts of energy that may be derived by rapidly discharging an energy storage capacitor. Series resonant topology is used in capacitor charging power supply because of its approximate constant current characteristic from zero volts to maximum voltage. But the series resonant topology with open-loop control is not accurate constant current charging characteristic because the DC bus voltage is variable and the transformer is not ideal. Furthermore, the high voltage rectifier diodes are also not ideal. This paper presents the current characteristic of series resonant power supply with ideal and actual components, respectively. And moreover, some valuable figures given in this paper can be used during the course of designing and debugging.

Authors: Papanikolaou A., Miranda M., Catthoor F., Corporaal H., De Man H., De Roest D., Stucchi M., Maex K.
Title: Global Interconnect Trade-off For Technology Over Memory Modules To Application Level: Case Study
Source title: International Workshop on System Level Interconnect Prediction
Affiliations: IMEC, Kapeldree 75, Leuven, Belgium; Katholieke Universiteit, Leuven, Belgium; Technical University of Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Papanikolaou, A., IMEC, Kapeldree 75, Leuven, Belgium; Miranda, M., IMEC, Kapeldree 75, Leuven, Belgium; Catthoor, F., Katholieke Universiteit, Leuven, Belgium; Corporaal, H., Technical University of Eindhoven, Netherlands; De Man, H., Katholieke Universiteit, Leuven, Belgium; De Roest, D., IMEC, Kapeldree 75, Leuven, Belgium; Stucchi, M., IMEC, Kapeldree 75, Leuven, Belgium; Maex, K., Katholieke Universiteit, Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: In this paper we show how to exploit energy-delay trade-offs that exist due to the variation of the technology parameters for the implementation of interconnect wires. We also evaluate how these trade-offs can be propagated to the memory module level, so we can minimise the power consumption of the entire memory organisation (i.e., memories and connections between them). Our approach is that at future technology nodes the delay problem can be handled at the application level, so given any delay slack obtained at that level, we can exploit it to make the switching on the interconnect wires slower and thus less energy consuming. In this way, we have shown that for real-life applications the power consumption at future technology nodes can be reduced by about 34%, when compared to the option provided by the ITRS roadmap. This is achieved by, instead of using the very fast and power hungry wires, selectively using slower and thinner interconnect wires while still meeting the application real-time constraints.
Author Keywords: Interconnect wire processing; Intra/inter-memory interconnect; Pareto-optimal energy/delay interconnect exploration
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Constraint theory; Data storage equipment; Data transfer; Electric resistance; Logic design; Parallel processing systems; Systems analysis; Delay interconnect exploration; Interconnect wire processing; Intra/inter-memory interconnect; Pareto-optimal energy; Interconnection networks

Authors: Rose W.G., Gupta N.K.
Title: Interrupting the uninterruptible - An overview of UPS maintenance at BP Grangemouth
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: BP Grangemouth, Stirlingshire, United Kingdom; Napier University, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; BP Grangemouth, FPSI Hydrocarbons Logistics Group, Bo'ness Road, Grangemouth FK3 9XQ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Rose, W.G., BP Grangemouth, Stirlingshire, United Kingdom, BP Grangemouth, FPSI Hydrocarbons Logistics Group, Bo'ness Road, Grangemouth FK3 9XQ, United Kingdom; Gupta, N.K., Napier University, Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: There are many electronic safety and control systems within a modern petrochemical installation that require standby power supplies to mitigate mains power failure and BP Grangemouth (BPG) uses uninterruptible power supplies (UPSs) for this purpose. This paper discusses the importance of UPS design and the potential effects of neglecting routine maintenance; it also considers the risks associated with allowing personnel who do not have the correct competencies to carry out such maintenance. A quantitative risk analysis of the short-term risks associated with routine maintenance is discussed along with how these risks are balanced against the long-term protection provided by the UPS in normal operation.
Index Keywords: Float voltage; Power failure; Control systems; Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Machine design; Risk assessment; Security systems; Systems analysis; Standby power systems

Authors: Abdelhamid T.H.
Title: Input power factor corrected switched reluctance motor based variable speed drive system
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: College of Technological Studies, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Abdelhamid, T.H., College of Technological Studies, Kuwait
Abstract: This paper presents input PFC of SRM based variable speed drive system. The SRM is fed from a single-switch per phase converter topology with an energy recovery storage capacitor. Input PFC is achieved by a single-switch boost converter which is ideal for appliance drives within the power levels of 1kW and mostly operates from a single-phase utility input. The proposed converter exhibits some advantages like; single-switch per phase, common return point of phase switches, snubberless operation, and four-quadrant operation simply by changing phase firing sequence and position. A position sensing encoder is used to provide information to an EPROM that is programmed to decide the firing sequence and generates the appropriate firing signals. The principle of operation is presented and the different modes of operation are illustrated with some analytical derivations. Simulation and experimental results have been provided to verify theoretical results.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Computer simulation; Electric converters; Electric drives; Electric switches; Reluctance motors; Systems analysis; Tracking (position); Power factor correction (PFC); Switched reluctance motors (SRM); Variable speed drives

Authors: Chang J., Wang A., Sun T.
Title: VF-Input and High-Frequency Matrix Converter - Recent Development and Evaluation
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Rockwell Scientific Company, United States; College of Engineering, Florida A and M University, Florida State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chang, J., College of Engineering, Florida A and M University, Florida State University, United States; Wang, A., Rockwell Scientific Company, United States; Sun, T., Rockwell Scientific Company, United States
Abstract: The proposed VF-Input matrix converter accepts a wide frequency variation of input power. For many applications of on-board power generation systems or distributed power systems, this new capability of one-stage VF-VF conversion eliminates a conventional speed regulation stage between the shafts of engine and alternator, thus improving, the energy conversion efficiency. The converter is 100% regenerative with no DC-link and has high power density. New capability operating at hundred hertz of fundamental frequencies at both input and output sides of the converter is also developed and demonstrated. The high frequency excitation further reduces the size and weight of the generating and motoring apparatus. The system has good potential to support multiple applications.

Authors: Morán L.

Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Universidad de Concepción, Casilla 160 - C, Concepción, Chile
Authors with affiliations: Morán, L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Universidad de Concepción, Casilla 160 - C, Concepción, Chile
Abstract: Utility systems using power electronics in power distribution systems, are discussed. Flexible transmission system (FACTS) identify alternating current transmission systems and incorporate power electronics based controllers to enhance the controllability and increase power transfer capability. Flexible, reliable and electric energy delivery system (FRIENDS) aids in the development of a desirable structure for power delivery systems where distributed generators (DG) and distributed energy storage systems are located near the demand side. The implementation of these systems with high power compensators and controllers had improved the over all reliability and associated quality with significant reduction of operating cost in power distribution systems.
Index Keywords: Deregulation; Electric converters; Electric potential; Electric power generation; Electric power transmission; Quality of service; Thyristors; Distributed generation (DG) systems; Power quality; Power transfer capabilities; Power electronics

Authors: Gundersen M., Dickens J., Nunnally W.

Abstract: We describe an academic research program designed to investigate fundamental issues that will impact future pulsed power technology. The project is intended to enhance the scientific footing for pulsed power, and to address issues in the development of compact, repetitive pulsed power. These include physics issues implicit in switch development, including both solid state and gas-phase, pulse generation at various levels from extremely small for fast high field generation to >100kV, and applications including ignition of jet fuels and biological response to electric fields.

Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, Mail Stop H-827, PO Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reass, W.A., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Mail Stop H-827, PO Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Apgar, S.E., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Mail Stop H-827, PO Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Baca, D.M., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Mail Stop H-827, PO Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Doss, J.D., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Mail Stop H-827, PO Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Gonzales, J.M., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Mail Stop H-827, PO Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Gribble, R.F., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Mail Stop H-827, PO Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Trujillo, P.G., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Mail Stop H-827, PO Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: The design methodologies of the polyphase resonant converter-modulator system for the spallation neutron source (SNS) linear accelerator are discussed. The SNS is a 1.4 MW average power beam, 1 GeV accelerator and requires 15 long pulse converter-modulator stations which provide a maximum of 11 MW pulses with a 1.1 MW average power. The compact and modular design minimizes on-site construction, and the simplified utility interconnection reduces installation costs. The results show that when loads become available, the operation to the full system average power should be achieved within specifications.

Authors: Giesselmann M., Heeren T., Helle T.
Title: Compact, high power capacitor charger
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Ctr. for Pulsed Pwr./Pwr. Electron., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409-3102, United States
Authors with affiliations: Giesselmann, M., Ctr. for Pulsed Pwr./Pwr. Electron., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409-3102, United States; Helle, T., Ctr. for Pulsed Pwr./Pwr. Electron., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409-3102, United States
Abstract: We are developing compact, high-power chargers for rapid charging of energy storage capacitors. The main application is presently rapid charging of the capacitors inside of compact Marx generators for rep-rated operation. Compact Marx generators produce output pulses with amplitudes above 300kV with ns or sub-ns rise-times. A typical application is the generation of High Power Microwaves. Initially all energy storage capacitors in a Marx generator are charged in parallel. During the so-called erection cycle, the capacitors are connected in series. The charging voltage in the parallel configuration is around 40-50kV. The input voltage of our charger is in the range of several hundred volts. Rapid charging of the capacitors in the parallel configuration will enable a high pulse repetition-rate of the compact Marx generator. The high power charger uses state-of-the-art IGBTs (Isolated Gate Bipolar Transistors) in an H-Bridge topology and a compact, high frequency transformer. The IGBTs and the associated controls are packaged for minimum weight and. maximum power density. The packaging and device selection makes use of burst mode operation (thermal inertia) of the charger. The present charger is considerably smaller than the one presented in [1].
Index Keywords: Capacitor chargers; High power microwaves; Electric charge; Electric converters; Electric energy storage; High frequency transformers; Insulated gate bipolar transistors; Microwaves; Printed circuit boards; Topology; Capacitors

Authors: Ye Y., Zhang S.C., Dogan F., Schaimiloglu E., Gaudet J., Castro P., Roybal M., Joler M., Christodoulou C.
Title: Influence of nanocrystalline grain size on the breakdown strength of ceramic dielectrics
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Ceramic Engineering Department, University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO 65409, United States; ECE Department, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ye, Y., Ceramic Engineering Department, University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO 65409, United States; Zhang, S.C., Ceramic Engineering Department, University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO 65409, United States; Dogan, F., Ceramic Engineering Department, University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO 65409, United States; Schaimiloglu, E., ECE Department, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States; Gaudet, J., ECE Department, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States; Castro, P., ECE Department, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States; Roybal, M., ECE Department, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States; Joler, M., ECE Department, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States; Christodoulou, C., ECE Department, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States
Abstract: In an effort to develop transmission lines with higher energy storage capabilities for compact pulsed power applications, the University of Missouri-Rolla (UMR) and the University of New Mexico (UNM) have undertaken a collaborative approach to developing and studying ceramic dielectrics. At UMR, the electrical breakdown strength (BDS) of TiO2-based materials is investigated for high energy density applications. The results of research to-date show that dense titania ceramics with nanocrystalline grain size (∼200 nm) exhibit significantly higher BDS as compared to ceramics made using coarse grain materials. Processing-microstructure-property relationships in TiO2 systems are found to play a role with respect to increasing the BDS. At UNM, a pulsed power system is being assembled to perform BDS studies of the ceramic materials produced at UMR- Electromagnetic simulations in support of this work will also presented. The long-term aim of this research is to enable the fabrication of large sizes of high energy density ceramics for use in pulsed power systems.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Dielectric materials; Electric lines; Electrical engineering; Grain size and shape; Magnetoelectric effects; Nanostructured materials; Permittivity; Thickness measurement; Titanium dioxide; Waveform analysis; Weibull distribution; Breakdown strength (BDS); Capacitive energy; High power microwaves (HPM); Ceramic materials

Authors: Ibuka S., Tsunoda R., Shiina J., Koyama T., Yasuoka K., Ishii S., Shimizu N., Imanishi Y.
Title: Compact fast high-voltage pulse generator utilizing turn-off capability of SI-thyristor
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1, O-okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152-8552, Japan; NGK Insulators, Ltd., 2-56, Suda-cho, Mizuho-ku, Nagoya 467-8530, Japan

Abstract: A compact high-voltage pulse generator utilizing turn-off capability of a SI-thyristor is characterized. A newly developed turn-off scheme with the SI-thyristor assisted by MOSFETs makes the circuit configuration extremely simple. Incorporating the inductive energy storage scheme, the circuit can be operated by primary dc voltage as low as 40V. The high-voltage pulse with the amplitude of 18.7kV and the pulse width of 74ns is successfully obtained in the primary voltage of 100V. Energy transfer efficiency and the feasibility of applying to a pulsed power application are discussed.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric potential; Electric resistance; Energy efficiency; Energy transfer; Energy utilization; Inductance; MOSFET devices; Power control; Thyristors; Waveform analysis; Load resistance; Plasma reactors; Pulse generators

Authors: Waganaar W.J., Cochrane J.C., Hosack K.W., Intrator T., Sanchez P., Taccetti J.M., Thompson M.C., Grabowski C.
Title: Design and performance of the pre-fire detection system for the FRX-L main capacitor
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Sci. Appl. International Corporation, United States
Authors with affiliations: Waganaar, W.J.; Cochrane, J.C.; Hosack, K.W.; Intrator, T.; Sanchez, P.; Taccetti, J.M.; Thompson, M.C.; Grabowski, C., Sci. Appl. International Corporation, United States
Abstract: The Main Capacitor Bank of the FRX-L (Field-Reversed Configuration experiment) supplies current (1.6 Meg amp) to a single-turn coil that is used to create high-density plasmas for magnetized-target fusion (MTF) experiments. The energy stored in the main bank (200 kJ) is transferred to the load coil via an array of four Maxwell rail-gap switches in parallel. Each switch is capable of transferring approximately a quarter of the main bank charge flow without damage. Therefore, if a single switch pre-fires it is subject to much greater stress than it is able to tolerate. In this paper, we discuss the design and performance of a system that is able to discriminate between a switch pre-fire, trigger noise, and normal operation and initiate a trigger in time to safely prevent damage. This system consists of innovative electric field detectors, fiber-optic isolation of signals and high-speed solid-state circuitry that interfaces with the Maxwell trigger system without modification.
Index Keywords: Fire detection system; Magnetized target fusion (MTF); Capacitor storage; Capacitors; Electric breakdown; Electric discharges; Electric fields; Inertial confinement fusion; Ionization; Magnetization; Plasma density; Fire detectors

Authors: Rim G.H., Pavlov E.P.
Title: Pulse generator based on an inductive energy storage and a ferromagnetic opening switch with a resistive load
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Korea Electrotech. Res. Institute, Kyung-Nam, Chang-won, Sung-Ju Dong 28-1, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Rim, G.H., Korea Electrotech. Res. Institute, Kyung-Nam, Chang-won, Sung-Ju Dong 28-1, South Korea; Pavlov, E.P., Korea Electrotech. Res. Institute, Kyung-Nam, Chang-won, Sung-Ju Dong 28-1, South Korea
Abstract: Commutation of high energy stored in inductive energy storage system is a difficult task due to absence of reliable indestructible high power opening switches [1-4]. This circumatance provokes research on various types of opening switches. This study presents some experimental results with a ferromagnetic opening switch (FOS), that consists of a toroidal ferromagnetic core and two orthogonal windings: One winding winds the outside of the core creating toroidal component Bθ of magnetic induction in the core. And the other is located inside the core generating poloidal component B φ in the core. Simultaneous presence of both magnetic components that are orthogonal demagnetizes the core fast and resulting in abrupt inductance increase, which is equivalent to an opening pulse-switch. Using a laboratory experimental set-up the possibility of FOS based on the idea is experimentally verified on a resistive load.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Damping; Demagnetization; Electric conductivity; Electric loads; Electric windings; Energy storage; Ferromagnetism; Switching; Ferromagnetic opening switch (FOS); Resistive load; Pulse generators

Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference

Abstract: A compact high switching frequency rapid capacitor charging supply was designed and implemented. The challenges of topology design, component selection and implementation are discussed. The end goal is a supply capable of achieving 40kW at 40kV on the output and 100-300V input. The gate driver design is discussed with particular emphasis on gate voltage rise-time and propagation delay. Switching frequencies from 100 kHz to 1 MHz are explored. Transformer and output voltage multiplier designs are also described with expected performance parameters based upon computer simulations.

Title: Digest of Technical Papers - IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Abstract: The proceedings contains 338 papers from the Digest of Technical papers - IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference. The topics discussed include: on the road to compact pulsed power: adventures in materials, electromagnetic modeling, and thermal management; compact, portable pulsed power: physics and applications; the role of pulsed power in international security and counterterrorism; status of the diode research programme at AWE; pulsed-power applications to materials science; low wire count loads and study of characteristics of wire array compression in R-Z and R-PHI geometries.

Authors: Kekez M.M.
Title: High repetition rate compact Marx generator
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: High-Energy Frequency Tesla Inc., NRC Site, Bldg. M-51, 1200 Montreal Road, Ottawa, Ont., K1A 0R6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kekez, M.M., High-Energy Frequency Tesla Inc., NRC Site, Bldg. M-51, 1200 Montreal Road, Ottawa, Ont., K1A 0R6, Canada
Abstract: The charging of a compact generator has been accomplished with the network suggested by O'Loughin et al.. The research for the suitable ceramic magnet cores was carried out for square-shaped output pulses lasting 1000 ns in duration. The generator is used to broaden our knowledge in the radio frequency (RF) generation and supplement the data obtained at low RF range at 1 GW power levels reported in reference [2].

Authors: Nie Z., Bekiarov S.B., Emadi A.
Title: An On-Line UPS System with Power Factor Correction and Electric Isolation Using BIFRED Converter
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Grainger Pwr. Electron./Motor D.L., Elec. Pwr./Power Electronics Center, Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616-3793, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nie, Z., Grainger Pwr. Electron./Motor D.L., Elec. Pwr./Power Electronics Center, Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616-3793, United States; Bekiarov, S.B., Grainger Pwr. Electron./Motor D.L., Elec. Pwr./Power Electronics Center, Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616-3793, United States; Emadi, A., Grainger Pwr. Electron./Motor D.L., Elec. Pwr./Power Electronics Center, Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616-3793, United States
Abstract: This paper presents design consideration and performance analysis of an on-line, low-cost, high performance single-phase Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) system based on Boost Integrated Flyback Rectifier/Energy storage DC/DC (BIFRED) converter. The system consists of an isolated AC/DC BIFRED converter, a bi-directional DC/DC converter, and a DC/AC inverter. It has input power factor correction, electric isolation of the input from the output, and control simplicity. Detailed circuit operation, analysis, as well as simulation and experiment results are presented.
Author Keywords: Battery chargers; BIFRED converter; Uninterruptible power supply systems; Unity power factor
Index Keywords: Battery chargers; BIFRED converter; Unity power factor; Capacitors; Charging (batteries); Electric converters; Electric potential; Electric rectifiers; Energy storage; Harmonic distortion; Online systems; Uninterruptible power systems

Authors: Nakamura M., Fujii Y., Shiraishi K., Hiraki E., Nakaoka M.
Title: A Pulse Current Regenerative Auxiliary Resonant Bridge Leg Link Snubber-Assisted Three-Phase Soft Switching PWM Inverter
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Yamaguchi University, 2-16-1, Tokiwadai, Ube, Yamaguchi 755-8611, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakamura, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yamaguchi University, 2-16-1, Tokiwadai, Ube, Yamaguchi 755-8611, Japan; Fujii, Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yamaguchi University, 2-16-1, Tokiwadai, Ube, Yamaguchi 755-8611, Japan; Shiraishi, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yamaguchi University, 2-16-1, Tokiwadai, Ube, Yamaguchi 755-8611, Japan; Hiraki, E., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yamaguchi University, 2-16-1, Tokiwadai, Ube, Yamaguchi 755-8611, Japan; Nakaoka, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yamaguchi University, 2-16-1, Tokiwadai, Ube, Yamaguchi 755-8611, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, a novel circuit topology of active auxiliary edge resonant snubber suitable for high power soft switching PWM inverter applications, which has some salient features as compared with previously developed auxiliary resonant commutated pole (ARCP) snubber is proposed in order to minimize the switching power losses of IGBTs in addition to the switching surge related electromagnetic noises in three-phase power conversion circuits on the basis of the sinewave PWM inverter and sinewave PWM PFC rectifier as well as bi-directional PWM converter used as the battery energy storage system. This resonant snubber-assisted inverter suitable for high power conversion is described and discussed on the basis of soft switching transition and commutation operation of the high efficient pulse modulated inverter. The working principle and operating characteristics of this active auxiliary snubber circuit are described, together with the practical design procedure of this unique edge resonant snubber. This paper shows actual efficiency vs. output power characteristic of three-phase soft switching PWM double converter system designed for 10kVA UPS composed of three phase soft switching PWM rectifier and inverter. The total actual efficiency of three phase soft switching PWM double converter is 88.6% as compared with that of hard switching double converter is 87.0% under a rated load.
Author Keywords: Bridge leg soft-commutation; Power electronics; Pulse width modulated inverters; Resonant snubber circuit
Index Keywords: Bridge leg soft-comutation; Resonant snubber circuits; Soft switching; Electric currents; Electric loads; Power converters; Power electronics; Pulse width modulation; Switching; Topology; Electric inverters

Authors: Ehsani M., Gao Y., Gay S.
Title: Characterization of Electric Motor Drives for Traction Applications
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Adv. Vehicle Syst. Research Program, Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ehsani, M., Adv. Vehicle Syst. Research Program, Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States; Gao, Y., Adv. Vehicle Syst. Research Program, Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States; Gay, S., Adv. Vehicle Syst. Research Program, Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States
Abstract: The ideal characteristics of an electric motor drive for traction application in an electric and hybrid electric vehicle are high torque at low speed region for fast acceleration, hill climbing and obstacle negotiation, and low torque at high speed for normal driving. To minimize the power rating of the motor drive, therefore, the energy storage power rating, at the given vehicle performance, the electric motor drive is required to have a long constant power range to meet the torque and speed demand. In this paper, the effect of the motor characteristics on the vehicle performance is analyzed, and the characteristics of three major electric motors - induction motor, permanent magnet brushless DC motor and switched reluctance motor are investigated.
Index Keywords: Field orientation control (FOC); Vehicle electrification; Acceleration; DC motors; Electric traction; Electric vehicles; Permanent magnets; Reluctance motors; Speed control; Switching systems; Torque control; Induction motors

Authors: Ramachandran J., Pearsall N.M., Putrus G.A.
Title: Impact of inverter size on PV system energy production and cost
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Northumbria Photovoltaics Appl. Ctr., School of Engineering and Technology, Northumbria University, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom; NPAC, School of Engineering and Technology, Northumbria University, Newcastle upon Tyne NE1 8ST, United Kingdom

Ctr., School of Engineering and Technology, Northumbria University, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom; Putrus, G.A., Northumbria Photovoltaics Appl. Ctr., School of Engineering and Technology, Northumbria University, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom
Abstract: In grid connected PV systems, selecting an inverter capacity lower than the PV array capacity usually leads to better economy where the duration of peak irradiance values is limited. This paper discusses the technical and economic issues regarding selection of the optimal size of the inverter. The additional energy generated by selecting the optimal size for different types of inverters used in grid connected PV systems is evaluated. Different economic issues relating to the choice of the inverter are discussed. This paper also considers issues related to standard inverter rating selection (higher or lower than the optimal size) due to the restricted sizes available on the market.
Index Keywords: Costs; Electric energy storage; Electric inverters; Electric transformers; Energy efficiency; Mathematical models; Photovoltaic cells; Power conditioning units (PCU); Electric power systems

Authors: Roch M., Dobrucky B., Hosny W.M.
Title: Modular single phase active power filters
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: University of Zilina, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Zilina, Slovakia; University of East London, School of Engineering, London, United Kingdom; University of Zilina, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, V. Diel ND 219, SK-010 26 Zilina, Slovakia
