Abstract: This paper investigates a modular and/or a decentralised single-phase active power filter control strategy. It is based on the evaluation of the harmonic reference load currents for the active power filter blocks operating under specific harmonic frequencies. The underlying principle of the modular active power filter is explained and it is shown how the reference harmonic currents required can be evaluated. Simulation results demonstrated the improvement in the dynamic performance of the modular active power filter presented here in comparison with the conventional type.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric power systems; Electric power transmission; Harmonic analysis; Power control; Power converters; Non-linear loads; Power filters; Electric filters

Authors: Kalantar M., Sedighizadeh M.
Title: Comparison between batteries and fuel cells and environmental evaluation of the PV-fuel cell hybrid power plant
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Iran Univ. of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran; Electrical Engineering Dept., IUST University, Narmak, Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Kalantar, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Iran Univ. of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran, Electrical Engineering Dept., IUST University, Narmak, Tehran, Iran; Sedighizadeh, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Iran Univ. of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran, Electrical Engineering Dept., IUST University, Narmak, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: Both batteries and fuel cells have their own unique contributions to electric power systems. Those two power sources also contain a great potential to back up severe PV power fluctuations under inclement weather conditions. In this paper comparison between batteries and fuel cells is carried out in detail only for their PV power backup options, so their common attributes and different attributes will be discussed. Then, environmental evaluation of the proposed hybrid plant was made in terms of plant's land requirement and lifetime CO2 emissions, and then compared with that of the conventional fossil-fuel power generating forms.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Cost effectiveness; Electric batteries; Electric energy storage; Electric power generation; Electric utilities; Environmental impact; Fossil fuels; Global warming; Power converters; Power plants; Hybrid power plants; Power conversion; PV-Fuel cells; Fuel cells

Authors: Barnea G.
Title: Detective quantum efficiency of a storage phosphor imaging plate: Monte Carlo study and experimental results
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Rafael, P.O. Box 2250, Haifa 31021, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Barnea, G., Rafael, P.O. Box 2250, Haifa 31021, Israel
Abstract: The performance of an x-ray imaging detector is generally evaluated by considering its detective quantum efficiency (DQE), which measures the ability of the detector to preserve the image information contained in the incident x-ray fluence. The DQE is also an important factor in Figures-of-Merit used to compare the performance of various radiographic machines and experimental setups. A simple expression is derived for the DQE of a storage-phosphor imaging plate (SPIP) and it is calculated as a function of the incident x-ray energy. The results are compared with measured data acquired from exposing the SPIP to Co60 gamma radiation. An excellent agreement with theory is obtained.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electron scattering; Energy absorption; Energy storage; Gamma radiography; Gamma rays; Image sensors; Imaging systems; Monte Carlo methods; Phosphors; Photocathodes; Photomultipliers; Signal to noise ratio; X ray radiography; Compton scattering; Detective quantum efficiency (DQE); Quantum efficiency

Authors: Mallick J., Crawford M., Elmore M.
Title: Direct modeling methods for air-cored pulsed alternators
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Institute for Advanced Technology, University of Texas at Austin, 3925 W. Braker Lane, Austin, TX 78759-5316, United States; BAE Systems Controls, Johnson City, NY 13790, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mallick, J., Institute for Advanced Technology, University of Texas at Austin, 3925 W. Braker Lane, Austin, TX 78759-5316, United States; Crawford, M., Institute for Advanced Technology, University of Texas at Austin, 3925 W. Braker Lane, Austin, TX 78759-5316, United States; Elmore, M., Institute for Advanced Technology, University of Texas at Austin, 3925 W. Braker Lane, Austin, TX 78759-5316, United States, BAE Systems Controls, Johnson City, NY 13790, United States
Abstract: A railgun launcher requires very high-current pulsed power over the period of a few milliseconds. For laboratory systems, capacitor banks have traditionally been used to provide this energy, but field applications require a system with significantly higher energy storage density. Rotating machines that store the energy in the form of rotational kinetic energy and can quickly convert it to high-current electrical energy have been designed and built. These low-impedance multi-phase, multi-pole synchronous generators are referred to as pulsed alternators. The AC output of the pulsed alternator is rectified to provide DC to power the railgun, and the design of the rectifier set and control circuitry is very dependent on the alternator characteristics. To facilitate the design and evaluation of the overall pulsed power system, a modeling tool which accurately represents the performance of the pulsed alternator while allowing easy changes to the external circuitry and controls is needed. This paper describes a manner in which these pulsed alternators can be accurately modeled. The validity of the model is established by comparing it to experimental data gathered from the "Subscale" alternator built by the Center for Electromechanics at The University of Texas under the Focused Technology Program (FTP).
Index Keywords: Mutual inductance; Pulsed alternators; Rotational kinetic energy; Self-inductance; Computer simulation; Electric conductivity; Electric currents; Electric impedance; Electric inductors; Flywheels; Kinetic energy; Machine windings; Magnetic circuits; Magnetic cores; Mathematical models; Rotating machinery; Torque control; Synchronous generators

Authors: Michalczyk P., Friel C., Vincent C., Marret J.P., Mexmain J.M., Rubin de Cervens D., Père P.
Title: Failure mode analysis on Capacitor Energy Banks
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: TPC, Av. Colonel Prat, 21850 Saint Apollinaire, France; CEA DAM, BP 12, 91680 Bruyères le Chatel, France; CEA DPLP CESTA, BP2, 33114 Le Barp, France

Colonel Prat, 21850 Saint Apollinaire, France; Marret, J.P., CEA DAM, BP 12, 91680 Bruyères le Chatel, France; Mexmain, J.M., CEA DAM, BP 12, 91680 Bruyères le Chatel, France; Rubin de Cervens, D., CEA DAM, BP 12, 91680 Bruyères le Chatel, France; Père, P., CEA DPLP CESTA, BP2, 33114 Le Barp, France
Abstract: Capacitor Energy Banks can be considered as power converters in which the energy storage is charged within a long time (some tenths of seconds) and the energy released within a short time (from microseconds to milliseconds). The converter function is provided by a capacitor, which has to withstand two constraints: - high stored energy which relates to electrostatics: a high electric field is applied to the dielectric of the capacitor. - high output current which relates to electrodynamics: stress is applied to the galvanic circuit of the capacitor. The evolution of the requirement in terms of stored energy (both increase of and density of) necessitates the most exhaustive analysis of the induced risks and consequences. This analysis has been conducted for the MegaJoule Laser Project. Its energy bank will store within one minute 450MJ at 24kV. Then, the bank should be able to deliver a 135MA pulse current within 360μs. This study will analyze the failure modes of the capacitors and their effects will be experimentally verified.
Author Keywords: DISFIM 3: DIScharge Film Impregnated Metallized Level 3, technology developed by TPC to meet MegaJoule Laser requirements; LMJ: MegaJoule Laser; Rape seed oil: Canola oil
Index Keywords: Electric charge; Electric currents; Electric fields; Electrodynamics; Electrostatics; Energy storage; Failure analysis; Capacitor energy bank; External shunt impedence; Short circuit; Capacitor storage

Authors: Matty T., Nechev K.
Title: Li Ion energy storage for pulse Power applications
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: SAFT America, Cockeysville, MD 21030, United States
Authors with affiliations: Matty, T., SAFT America, Cockeysville, MD 21030, United States; Nechev, K., SAFT America, Cockeysville, MD 21030, United States
Abstract: The uses and high power capability of lithium ion battery technology are discussed. Li ion operates using two intercalation electrodes with the positive side which is the source of Li ions during charge, and a negative electrode which accepts the ions. During the early phases of the Compact high power sources (CHPS) program, an investigation was started using 500-amp commercial test equipment to evaluate and characterize the pulse power performance of development and production cells to improve the Li ion technology. Results indicate that present products can provide very high rate capability, long life, low maintenance and long-term affordability without environmental sensitivities.
Index Keywords: Lithium ion batteries; Pulse power systems; Electric batteries; Electric discharges; Electrodes; Energy storage; Gravimetric analysis; Intercalation compounds; Solid state lasers; Volumetric analysis; Lithium batteries

Authors: Weise Th.H.G.G.
Title: High energy density pulsed power supply system for large calibre ETC-Guns ready for platform integration
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Rheinmetall W and M GmbH, Heinrich-Ehrhardt-Strasse 2, D-29345 Unterluesz, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Weise, Th.H.G.G., Rheinmetall W and M GmbH, Heinrich-Ehrhardt-Strasse 2, D-29345 Unterluesz, Germany
Abstract: Due to the limited electric energy requirements ETC-Technologies are investigated by many nations as a first candidate of the electric gun family for realization. The combination of the properties of the ETC Plasma-ignition with improved high energy propellants leads to a performance increase of solid propellant guns. Improvement of ignition precision, propellant temperature compensation and access to LOVA propellants are further advantages of an ETC-gun. The paper presents the set-up and the test results of a capacitive high energy density pulsed power supply system being designed and developed at Rheinmetall for ETC gun application. The system consists of a compact 2MJ/m 3 capacitor module with semiconducting crowbar diodes, optical triggered thyristor switches and a toroidal pulse forming inductor. For charging a 35kW switching power supply was developed at Magnet Motor and applied in the system set-up. Controls are provided from a digitized control system with fully automatic firing features. Test results obtained from the operation with a 120mm ETC-Gun will be presented.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Control system analysis; Electric charge; Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Electric power systems; Ignition; Solid propellants; High energy density; Pulsed power supply systems; High energy physics

Authors: Sincerny P.S., Lam S.K., Miller R., Tucker T., Sanders L.
Title: Fast discharge energy storage development for improving x-ray simulators
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Titan, Pulse Sciences Division, 2700 Merced Street, San Leandro, CA 94577-0599, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sincerny, P.S., Titan, Pulse Sciences Division, 2700 Merced Street, San Leandro, CA 94577-0599, United States; Lam, S.K., Titan, Pulse Sciences Division, 2700 Merced Street, San Leandro, CA 94577-0599, United States; Miller, R., Titan, Pulse Sciences Division, 2700 Merced Street, San Leandro, CA 94577-0599, United States; Tucker, T., Titan, Pulse Sciences Division, 2700 Merced Street, San Leandro, CA 94577-0599, United States; Sanders, L., Titan, Pulse Sciences Division, 2700 Merced Street, San Leandro, CA 94577-0599, United States
Abstract: Design studies have been completed to investigate the impact of improvements in fast energy storage systems on the designs of: larger future simulators (such as a 15-MA PRS simulator), simulator upgrades of operational machines (such as Double-EAGLE), and for very compact, smaller simulators. The fast energy storage system that has been investigated and is presently under development (see companion papers) is a Fast Marx Generator (FMG) with (LC) 1/2 = 200 ns and (LC) 1/2 = 300 ns, depending on the capacitance per stage. This new Fast Marx energy storage system uses newly developed, low-inductance rail switches and low-inductance capacitors. These components are configured in a low-inductance FMG stage and then stacked in series to form a unit for the voltage required and a number of units in parallel for the required system inductance and stored energy. A four-stage Fast Marx prototype has been demonstrated with a total of 60 kJ energy stored and an output voltage of 680 kV. A design sketch of a 15-MA PRS machine driven by a Fast Marx will be presented. This generator would consist of 48 eight-stage FMG units and would drive the PRS directly without further pulse compression. The second concept presented will be a very compact e-beam or Bremsstrahlung machine. This concept will consist of an eight-stage FMG driving a vacuum-inductive store. The vacuum store will be switched into an e-beam load using a plasma opening switch (POS).
Index Keywords: Fast marx generators (FMG); Plasma radiation sources (PRS); Capacitance; Capacitors; Electric energy storage; Electric impedance; Electric potential; Electric switches; Electron beams; Inductance; Simulators; Electric discharges

Authors: Kuthi A., Young C., Wang F., Wijetunga P., Guildersen M.
Title: Rapid charger for high repetition rate pulse generator
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089-0271, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kuthi, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089-0271, United States; Young, C., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089-0271, United States; Wang, F., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089-0271, United States; Wijetunga, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089-0271, United States; Guildersen, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089-0271, United States
Abstract: The design and operation of a command resonant charger feeding a high repetition rate pulse generator using an advanced Pseudospark device is presented. An application - corona assisted flame ignition and combustion - is discussed briefly. This application requires operation of the Pseudospark switch at 30kV charging voltage and 1 kHz repetition rate. The charging time of the 6nF / 30kV quasi Blumlein pulse forming circuit capacitance is 50ns. Operation is burst mode, with maximum 100 pulses per burst.

Title: Ceramics joining using explosive metal foil
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Iwate University, 4-3-5 Ueda, Morioka, Iwate 020-8551, Japan; Iwate Industrial Promotion Center, 2-9-4 Nishidohri, Morioka, Iwate 020-0045, Japan; Iwate Industrial Research Institute, 3-35-2 Iioka-Nitta, Morioka, Iwate 020-0852, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takaki, K., Iwate University, 4-3-5 Ueda, Morioka, Iwate 020-8551, Japan; Takada, Y., Iwate University, 4-3-5 Ueda, Morioka, Iwate 020-8551, Japan; Itagaki, M., Iwate University, 4-3-5 Ueda, Morioka, Iwate 020-8551, Japan; Mukaigawa, S., Iwate University, 4-3-5 Ueda, Morioka, Iwate 020-8551, Japan; Fujiwara, T., Iwate University, 4-3-5 Ueda, Morioka, Iwate 020-8551, Japan; Ohshima, S., Iwate Industrial Promotion Center, 2-9-4 Nishidohri, Morioka, Iwate 020-0045, Japan; Takahashi, I., Iwate Industrial Research Institute, 3-35-2 Iioka-Nitta, Morioka, Iwate 020-0852, Japan; Kuwashima, T., Iwate Industrial Research Institute, 3-35-2 Iioka-Nitta, Morioka, Iwate 020-0852, Japan
Abstract: A capacitor discharge joining technique used to fabricate alumina (Al 2O3) tile - titanium foil - Al2O3 tile joint was investigated with focusing to increase the bonding strength. Several kAs pulse current was supplied from 8.28 μF storage capacitor to the 50 μm thickness titanium foil which was sandwiched between the A1 2O3 tiles with various pressures. The temperature of the foil was rapidly increased owing to ohmic heating with the large current, and then the foil was liquefied and vaporized. The Al2O3 tiles were successfully bonded when the input energy to the titanium foil was higher than the energy required for the foil vaporization. The bonding strength increases with increasing the energy input to the foil. However, the foil explosion cracked the tiles when the input energy exceeds a critical value. Increasing the circuit inductance from 1.13 μH to 64.8 μH, the critical energy of tile cracking increases from 160 J to 507 J. The maximum bonding strength of 3200 N was obtained when the circuit inductance was 21.8 μH. An investigation of the interfacial structure of the joints using electron probe microanalysis revealed that distinct reaction areas existed in the interlayer.
Index Keywords: Alumina; Bond strength (materials); Capacitors; Ceramic materials; Crack initiation; Energy efficiency; Energy transfer; Inductance; Joining; Microstructure; Shear strength; Vaporization; Electron probe micro analysis (EPMA); Ignitron closing switch (IGS); Metal foil

Authors: Rathi M., Bhiwapurkar N., Mohan N.
Title: Dual Voltage Controller Based Power Factor Correction Circuit for Faster Dynamics and Zero Steady State Error
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Dept of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rathi, M., Dept of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Bhiwapurkar, N., Dept of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Mohan, N., Dept of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Abstract: This paper analyzes dual voltage controllers for single-phase Power Factor Correction(PFC) Circuits using boost topology. The proposed scheme uses dual voltage controllers, one of the voltage controller having low bandwidth operates only during steady condition, other voltage controller with high bandwidth operates during the transient condition. At any given instant only one voltage controller is in circuit. Lower bandwidth controller, operating during steady state condition, maintains the THD within the required limits and the dc-bus voltage at its reference value. High bandwidth controller improves the transient performance by having faster response to the disturbance. Faster response to disturbances necessitates less energy storage in the dc-bus capacitor, hence a smaller capacitance value is required which resulting in a compact and a light-weight circuit. The comparative study between the proposed scheme and the conventional PFC circuit is carried out. The experimental results for the proposed scheme are also presented.
Author Keywords: Boost Topology; Dual voltage controller; Power factor correction (PFC)
Index Keywords: Boost topology; Dual voltage controller; Power factor correction (PFC); Bandwidth; Capacitance; Electric network topology; Electric power factor correction; Harmonic distortion; Voltage control

Authors: Ed Bargar H., Li J., Goering D.J., Lee J.H.
Title: Modeling and Verification of Hybrid Electric HMMWV Performance
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK 99775-5905, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ed Bargar, H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK 99775-5905, United States; Li, J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK 99775-5905, United States; Goering, D.J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK 99775-5905, United States; Lee, J.H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK 99775-5905, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Military, through the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) and the U.S. Army Tank-automotive and Armaments Command (TACOM) have sponsored the development of three different versions of the Hybrid Electric High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle (HE-HMMWV). The most recent version of this vehicle was designed by PEI Electronics, Inc. (PEI) and a limited number of prototypes have been constructed. This paper describes the modeling of this vehicle using a set of customized model components that have been formulated using the PNGV Systems Analysis Toolkit (PSAT). Model output has been obtained for the standard Federal Urban Drive Cycle (FUDS). In an effort to provide model verification, the model output data is compared to field test results obtained from a prototype vehicle driven to mimic the FUDS profile. Comparison between model output and field data shows generally good agreement demonstrating the value of model performance prediction. Additional improvements are expected to result from continuing analysis of field data and more accurate incorporation of vehicle control strategies and component behavior.
Index Keywords: Auxiliary power units (APU); High mobility multipurpose wheeled vehicles (HMMWV); Internal combustion engines (ICE); Acoustic noise; Auxiliary power systems; Computer simulation; DC motors; Diesel engines; Energy storage; Fuel consumption; Mathematical models; Permanent magnets; Traction motors; Electric vehicles

Authors: Morris S., Dash P.K., Basu K.P., Sharaf A.M.
Title: UPFC Controller Design for Power System Stabilization with Improved Genetic Algorithm
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Multimedia University, Cyberjaya, Malaysia; University of New Brunswick, Canada; M.M.U., Malaysia; Silicon Institute of Technology, Bhubaneswar, India
Authors with affiliations: Morris, S., Multimedia University, Cyberjaya, Malaysia; Dash, P.K., Multimedia University, Cyberjaya, Malaysia, M.M.U., Malaysia, Silicon Institute of Technology, Bhubaneswar, India; Basu, K.P., Multimedia University, Cyberjaya, Malaysia; Sharaf, A.M., University of New Brunswick, Canada
Abstract: This paper presents the genetic optimization of the parameters of a fuzzy PI controller for UPFC( Unified Power flow controller) using an improved genetic algorithm to enhance the transient stability performance of power systems. The function based Takagi-Sugeno-Kang (TSK) fuzzy controller uses minimum number of rules(two rules) and generates the proportional action which by one-to-two inference mapping gives a variable gain PI controller. This single input function based scheme dispenses the gain dependency of the proportional or integral gains and generates independent control actions. Computer simulation results on a 2-area 4-machine 12-bus power system with an UPFC installed between buses s and r confirm the efficacy of the new approach in damping the local-mode and inter-area mode of oscillations.
Author Keywords: Crossover; Fitness function; Improved genetic algorithm; Mutation; One-to-two inference mapping; Takagi-Sugeno-Kang (TSK) fuzzy control; Unified power flow controller (UPFC)

Authors: Elter J.F., Austin II D.G.
Title: Power Conditioning in Fuel Cell Systems
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: V.P Research and System Architecture
Authors with affiliations: Elter, J.F., V.P Research and System Architecture; Austin II, D.G.
Abstract: The Power Conditioning Module (PCM) in a residential fuel cell system manages the electrical interfaces between the fuel cell stack DC electrical output and the AC electrical outlet of the residential customer. The power-conditioning module can be ideally considered a power amplifier with an intermediate storage element. The role of this module is to provide sinusoidal voltage to loads when operated independent of the grid, and a sinusoidal current (power) source when operated in parallel with the grid. The output of the fuel cell stack is unregulated DC voltage with the added constraint that its output power cannot be rapidly varied to follow the instantaneous power requirements of the AC loads. Therefore, an electrical energy storage module (EESM) is used along with the fuel cell stack to form a DC bus for the DC to AC power conversion that can provide the instantaneous power requirements of the AC residential load. With the integration of a fully digital implemented control algorithm that provides flexibility for any of the control tasks.
Index Keywords: Electrical energy storage modules (EESM); Power conditioning; Algorithms; Control system analysis; Electric currents; Electric potential; Optimization; Power amplifiers; Robustness (control systems); Voltage control; Fuel cells

Authors: Han S.-K., Moon G.-W., Youn M.-J.
Title: A Novel Current-fed Energy Recovery Sustaining Driver for Plasma Display Panel (PDP) - IECON'03
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Science, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, 373-1, Kusong-Dong, Yusong-Gu, Taejon 305-701, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Han, S.-K., Department of Electrical Science, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, 373-1, Kusong-Dong, Yusong-Gu, Taejon 305-701, South Korea; Youn, M.-J., Department of Electrical Science, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, 373-1, Kusong-Dong, Yusong-Gu, Taejon 305-701, South Korea
Abstract: A novel current-fed energy-recovery sustaining driver (CFERSD) for a PDP is proposed in this paper. Its main idea is to recover the energy stored in the PDF or to inject the input source energy to the PDP by using the current source built-up in the energy recovery inductor. This method provides zero-voltage-switching (ZVS) of all main power switches, the reduction of EMI, and more improved operational voltage margins with the aid of the discharge current compensation. In addition, since the current flowing through the energy recovery inductor can compensate the plasma discharge current flowing through the conducting power switches, the current stress through all main power switches can be considerably reduced. Furthermore, it features a low conduction loss and fast transient time. Operations, features and design considerations are presented and verified experimentally on a 1020×106mm sized PDP, 50kHz-switching frequency, and sustaining voltage 140V based prototype.
Index Keywords: Electric current distribution; Electric discharges; Electric drives; Electric energy storage; Electric switches; Flat panel displays; Frequency response; Inductance measurement; Power inductors; Signal interference; Switching circuits; Voltage measurement; Current compensation; Energy recovery systems; Plasma discharges; Plasma display devices

Abstract: An optimal coordinated excitation and SMES (Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage) controller is proposed in this paper. In the analysis, the voltage source SMES system is considered as a controllable voltage source whose magnitude and phase can be changed rapidly, and the system model for the design of the optimal coordinated controller is established. Then optimal coordinated control for generator excitation and SMES is deduced. In the proposed controller, the control variables are the excitation voltage, the magnitude and phase angle of the controllable voltage source. Simulation results show that the proposed controller can provide good control performance under different disturbances, improve the system transient stability effectively.

Title: Control and monitoring of data acquisition and trigger system (TRIDAQ) for backing calorimeter (BAC) of ZEUS experiment

Abstract: The paper presents idea and realization of hardware (photonics and electronics) and software diagnostic layers of TRIDAQ for BAC calorimeter of ZEUS experiment at HERA accelerator. The aim of diagnostic system (DS) is to provide high reliability of the BAC. The diagnostic system localizes, in the fastest possible way, place, time and cause of any breakdown inside the BAC. Functionalities of diagnostic system were discussed. Construction of distributed, diagnostic hardware layer was presented. The software layer of the system was designed using the object-oriented approach. Object oriented virtual classes were defined. These classes control electronics and photonics devices and subsystems. Application examples were presented. The implementation results of DS for TRIDAQ were discussed.

Abstract: NAS battery is an advanced secondary battery, having superior features such as high energy density and high pulse power capability. Malaysia is located within tropical area and subjected to high number of lightning that may cause voltage sags thus causing serious damages to sensitive industrial customers. In consideration of NAS battery characteristics, a hybrid system will be designed for load leveling and power quality support suitable for Malaysian condition. A demonstration facility is planned to be commissioned in 2003.

Authors: Colquhoun J.F., Dong Z.Y., Bones D.
Title: Identify the needs to install interconnectors to the national electricity market of Australia
Source title: IPEC 2003 - 6th International Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sch. Info. Technol. and Elec. Eng., University of Queensland, Australia; NEMMCO, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Colquhoun, J.F., Sch. Info. Technol. and Elec. Eng., University of Queensland, Australia; Dong, Z.Y., Sch. Info. Technol. and Elec. Eng., University of Queensland, Australia; Bones, D., NEMMCO, Australia
Abstract: The National Electricity Market (NEM) in Australia is a gross pool market facilitating the wholesale trade of electrical energy. The NEM consists of infrastructure to supply and deliver electricity to the consumers when demanded. The NEM is currently divided into five pricing regions. Interconnectors enable the flow of electricity between the regions. This paper aims at identifying the costs and benefits of augmenting interconnectors in the NEM. Through the comparison of the costs and benefits a basic forecast of the requirement for interconnectors can be established. It is important that the market identifies the needs for investment prior to the time of investment so that market benefits are not foregone as a result of late investment. Correct signaling also maximises the probability of efficient investments in both interconnectors and supply or demand side options.

Abstract: Current source resonant inverter (CSRI) is the heart of many systems and equipment. Many topologies shown in open literature are series resonant converters and parallel resonant converters that consist of two or three energy storage elements. However, they have lots of limitations, which can be overcome by adding a fourth energy storage element. This paper introduces a Cascade Double Γ-CL CSRI, which has very smooth waveforms of output voltage and current, and very low THD value. It effectively reduces the power losses and largely increases the power transfer efficiency. Testing results verified our design and analysis.

Title: Power system stability improvement using Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage unit

Abstract: This paper discusses the power quality benefits for power systems by using Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) unit. The application of SMES unit in mitigating voltage sags and in damping dynamic oscillations in power systems is discussed. To show the effectiveness of the proposed controller in providing continuous voltage regulation and in enhancing power system dynamics, a three-phase short circuit is applied to the system and simulation is carried out with and with no SMES connected to the system. The results of these investigations are studied using the well-developed graphic facilities available in an industry standard power system package, namely PSCAD/EMTDC. Results have shown that SMES unit can effectively improve system stability and power quality of power systems.

Title: Experimental studies on multi-agent based automatic generation control for isolated power system
Source title: IPEC 2003 - 6th International Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Kumamoto University, Japan; Meidensha Corporation, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hiyama, T., Kumamoto University, Japan; Esaki, H., Kumamoto University, Japan; Mori, K., Kumamoto University, Japan; Funabashi, T., Meidensha Corporation, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a multi-agent based Automatic Generation Control(AGC) scheme for isolated power systems with dispersed power sources such as photovoltaic units, wind generation units, diesel generation units, and an Energy Capacitor System(ECS) for the energy storage. An advanced AGC scheme has been proposed through the coordination of controllable power sources such as the diesel units and the Energy Capacitor System(ECS) with small capacity. All the required information for the proposed AGC is transferred between the diesel units and the ECS through computer networks. All the AGC functions have been achieved by using the proposed multi-agent based control system. Experimental studies have been performed on the laboratory system to investigate the efficiency of the proposed multi-agent based control scheme. The proposed multi-agent based AGC scheme has provided the highly improved AGC performance even in the existence of the communication delay through the computer network.

Title: Fuel cell power plant: Modeling and its application in an isolated system

Abstract: The paper examines fuel cell as a possible method of distributed generation. Based on an existing model, simplified dynamic model is derived to predict the open-loop behavior of the fuel cell power plant. The model is then incorporated in an isolated system whereby the relationship between the fuel cell, energy storage and load is studied during a short transient. By analyzing the transfer functions derived from the model, some insights into the behavior of isolated fuel cell power plant during the transient period are obtained.

Abstract: A discussion on LPG as an ideal alternative fuel, presented at the Hart World Fuels Conference, Sydney, Australia, covers the benefits of using LPG, e.g., lower greenhouse emissions (NO x, fine particles, and hydrocarbons), widespread availability, and energy security; comparison of automotive emissions on low sulfur diesel, petrol, and LPG; air pollution damage costs for buses operating on different fuels in urban areas; alternative fuel availability, e.g., LNG, ethanol, biodiesel, LPG, and CNG; on-board storage; operating economics; and supply and energy security.

Authors: Ren L., Liu L., Liu D., Zhang J.
Title: Time-space dynamics of holographic recording and fixing in LiNbO 3:Fe:Mn crystal
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Shanghai Inst. of Opt./Fine Mech., Chinese Academy of Sciences, P. O. Box 800-211, Shanghai 201800, China
Authors with affiliations: Ren, L., Shanghai Inst. of Opt./Fine Mech., Chinese Academy of Sciences, P. O. Box 800-211, Shanghai 201800, China; Liu, L., Shanghai Inst. of Opt./Fine Mech., Chinese Academy of Sciences, P. O. Box 800-211, Shanghai 201800, China; Liu, D., Shanghai Inst. of Opt./Fine Mech., Chinese Academy of Sciences, P. O. Box 800-211, Shanghai 201800, China; Zhang, J., Shanghai Inst. of Opt./Fine Mech., Chinese Academy of Sciences, P. O. Box 800-211, Shanghai 201800, China
Abstract: The time-space dynamics of the recording and fixing of photorefractive holograms in doubly-doped LiNbO3:Fe:Mn crystals are analyzed by jointly and numerically solving the set of time-differential two-center material equations and the set of space-differential coupled-wave equations. In the formulation, the absorption of both the recording light and the sensitizing light is included. The results for optimizing the holographic recording are similar to those obtained by the previous steady-state solving. In this paper, therefore, a special attention is paid on the time-space evolution of the intensity and phase distributions of the induced space-charge fields and the exciting interference pattern of the two beams for recording or the readout and diffracted beams for coherent erasing. It is interesting to find that during the time development of hologram there is a spatially changed direction of energy transferring between the two-coupled beams, which depends spatially on the relative phase difference between the induced space-charge field and the exciting interference pattern. The energy transferring direction will be reversed as the relative phase difference becomes opposite in the sign. As a result, the spatial figures of the isophase and the recording or recorded holographic fringes are depicted, which gives a full understanding for the formation of photorefractive hologram in LiNbO3:Fe:Mn.
Author Keywords: Band-transport model; Coupled-wave theory; LiNbO3:Fe:Mn; Photorefractive volume hologram

Authors: Kesheng W., Zhang W.-M., Sim A., Gu J., Shoshani A.
Title: Grid collector: An event catalog with automated file management
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium Conference Record
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley National Lab., Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Kent State University, Kent, OH 44242, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kesheng, W., Lawrence Berkeley National Lab., Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Zhang, W.-M., Kent State University, Kent, OH 44242, United States; Sim, A., Lawrence Berkeley National Lab., Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Gu, J., Lawrence Berkeley National Lab., Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Shoshani, A., Lawrence Berkeley National Lab., Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: High Energy Nuclear Physics (HENP) experiments such as STAR at BNL and ATLAS at CERN produce large amounts of data that are stored as files on mass storage systems in computer centers. In these files, the basic unit of data is an event. Analysis is typically performed on a selected set of events. The files containing these events have to be located, copied from mass storage systems to disks before analysis, and removed when no longer needed. These file management tasks are tedious and time consuming. Typically, all events contained in the files are read into memory before a selection is made. Since the time to read the events dominate the overall execution time, reading the unwanted event needlessly increases the analysis time. The Grid Collector is a set of software modules that works together to address these two issues. It automates the file management tasks and provides "direct" access to the selected events for analyses. It is currently integrated with the STAR analysis framework. The users can select events based on tags, such as, "production date between March 10 and 20, and the number of charged tracks > 100." The Grid Collector locates the files containing relevant events, transfers the files across the Grid if necessary, and delivers the events to the analysis code through the familiar iterators. There has been some research efforts to address the file management issues, the Grid Collector is unique in that it addresses the event access issue together with the file management issues. This makes it more useful to a large varieties of users.
Index Keywords: Data sets; File management; Grid Collector; High energy nuclear physics (HENP); Computer programming; Computer software; Database systems; File organization; High energy physics; Magnetic fields; Mathematical models; Nuclear physics; Query languages; Servers; Data communication systems

Authors: Geralis T., Fanourakis G., Giomataris Y., Zachariadou K.
Title: The data acquisition of the micromegas detector for the CAST experiment
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium Conference Record
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, NCSR Demokritos, GR-15310 Ag. Paraskevi - Attiki, Greece; DAPNIA, SED, Gif-Sur-Yvette, France
Authors with affiliations: Geralis, T., Institute of Nuclear Physics, NCSR Demokritos, GR-15310 Ag. Paraskevi - Attiki, Greece; Fanourakis, G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, NCSR Demokritos, GR-15310 Ag. Paraskevi - Attiki, Greece; Giomataris, Y., DAPNIA, SED, Gif-Sur-Yvette, France; Zachariadou, K., Institute of Nuclear Physics, NCSR Demokritos, GR-15310 Ag. Paraskevi - Attiki, Greece
Abstract: The Micromegas (μM) detector [1] is one of the three types of detectors (CCD, μM and TPC) that are used for solar Axion detection at the CAST experiment [2]. The μM detector is sensitive to X-rays, originating from a conversion of axion to photon in a strong magnetic field (9T), in the range of a few hundred eV to 10keV. Good detection efficiency, energy resolution, spatial resolution and extremely low background are the characteristics of this type of detector. The Data Acquisition of the Micromegas detector is presented here. The Front End cards are using multiplexed analog integrated circuits. A set of VME modules performs the readout that is expandable to read up to 2×19×2048 (77824) channels. The system has the capability to apply online, per individual channel, a threshold and a subsequent pedestal subtraction. At the CAST experiment rates the dead time is negligible. A PCI - MXI2 - VME interface is used to read out the data to a PC, to perform monitoring and to Display Events. The system is based on the National Instruments' LabView software and is running both in Windows 2000 and Linux operating systems. The data are automatically archived on storage media at the central CERN computing facilities and the PC clock is synchronized periodically with the GPS time using the CERN time servers. This allows the precise event time stamping for the possibility to correlate them to astrophysical phenomena. The precision of the clock update is of the order of 50μs. The same system has been used for Medical Imaging R&D programs [3] and Dark Matter searches.
Index Keywords: Analog integrated circuits; CERN axion solar telescope (CAST); Linux; Micromegas detector; Charge coupled devices; Computer operating systems; Data acquisition; Global positioning system; Integrated circuits; Magnetic field effects; Medical imaging; Multiplexing; Object oriented programming; Research and development management; Signal processing; Synchronization; Telescopes; X rays; Detectors

Authors: Hegde A., Vijaykrishnan N., Kandemir M., Irwin M.J.
Title: VL-CDRAM: Variable Line Sized Cached DRAMs
Source title: Hardware/Software Codesign - Proceedings of the International Workshop
Affiliations: Micro Systems Design Lab., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hegde, A., Micro Systems Design Lab., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, United States; Vijaykrishnan, N., Micro Systems Design Lab., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, United States; Kandemir, M., Micro Systems Design Lab., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, United States; Irwin, M.J., Micro Systems Design Lab., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, United States
Abstract: Many of the current memory architectures embed a SRAM cache within the DRAM memory. These architectures exploit a wide internal data bus to transfer an entire DRAM row to the on-memory cache. However, applications exhibit a varying spatial locality across the different DRAM rows that are accessed and buffering the entire row may be wasteful. In order to adapt to the changing spatial locality, we propose a Variable Line size Cached DRAM (VL-CDRAM) that can buffer portions of an accessed DRAM row. Our evaluation shows that the proposed approach is effective in not only reducing the energy consumption but also in improving the performance across various memory configurations.
Author Keywords: CDRAM; Energy; Variable Line; VL-CDRAM

Authors: Worthington P.F., Cosentin L.
Title: The Role of Cut-offs in Integrated Reservoir Studies
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Gaffney, Cline and Associates, United Kingdom; ENI E and P Division
Authors with affiliations: Worthington, P.F., Gaffney, Cline and Associates, United Kingdom; Cosentin, L., ENI E and P Division
Abstract: There have been many different approaches to quantifying cut-offs, with no single method emerging as the definitive basis for delineating net pay. Yet, each of these approaches yields a different reservoir model, so it is imperative that cutoffs be fit-for-purpose, i.e. they are compatible with the reservoir mechanism and with a systematic methodology for the evaluation of hydrocarbons in place and for the estimation of reserves. These different requirements are accommodated by basing the quantification of cut-offs on reservoir-specific criteria that govern the storage and flow of hydrocarbons. In so doing, particular attention is paid to the relationships between the identification of cut-offs and key elements of the contemporary systemic practice of integrated reservoir studies. The outcome is a structured approach to the use of cut-offs in the estimation of reserves. The principal benefits of a properly conditioned set of petrophysical cut-offs are a more exact characterization of the reservoir with a better synergy between the static and dynamic reservoir models, so that an energy company can more fully realize the asset value.

Authors: Park C., Seo J., Bae S., Kim H., Kim S., Kim B.
Title: A Low-Cost Memory Architecture with NAND XIP for Mobile Embedded Systems
Source title: Hardware/Software Codesign - Proceedings of the International Workshop
Affiliations: Software Center, SAMSUNG Electronics, Co., Ltd., Seoul 135-893, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Park, C., Software Center, SAMSUNG Electronics, Co., Ltd., Seoul 135-893, South Korea; Seo, J., Software Center, SAMSUNG Electronics, Co., Ltd., Seoul 135-893, South Korea; Bae, S., Software Center, SAMSUNG Electronics, Co., Ltd., Seoul 135-893, South Korea; Kim, H., Software Center, SAMSUNG Electronics, Co., Ltd., Seoul 135-893, South Korea; Kim, S., Software Center, SAMSUNG Electronics, Co., Ltd., Seoul 135-893, South Korea; Kim, B., Software Center, SAMSUNG Electronics, Co., Ltd., Seoul 135-893, South Korea
Abstract: NAND flash memory has become an indispensable component in mobile embedded systems because of its versatile features such as non-volatility, solid-state reliability, low cost and high density. Even though NAND flash memory is gaining popularity as data storage, it can be also exploited as code memory for XIP (execute-in-place). In this paper, we present a new memory architecture which incorporates NAND flash memory into an existing memory hierarchy for code execution. The usefulness of the proposed approach is demonstrated with real embedded workloads on a real prototyping board.
Author Keywords: Memory architecture; NAND XIP; Priority-based caching
Index Keywords: Memory architecture; NAND XIP; Priority-based caching; Buffer storage; Computer architecture; Cost effectiveness; Data storage equipment; Energy utilization; Flash memory; Mobile computing; NAND circuits; Software prototyping; Embedded systems

Authors: Chen G., Vijaykrishnan N., Kandemir M., Irwin M.J., Wolczko M.
Title: Tracking Object Life Cycle for Leakage Energy Optimization
Source title: Hardware/Software Codesign - Proceedings of the International Workshop
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Sun Microsystems, Inc., 2600 Casey Ave., Mountain View, CA 94043, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, G., Department of Computer Science, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Vijaykrishnan, N., Department of Computer Science, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Kandemir, M., Department of Computer Science, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Irwin, M.J., Department of Computer Science, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Wolczko, M., Sun Microsystems, Inc., 2600 Casey Ave., Mountain View, CA 94043, United States
Abstract: The focus of this work is on utilizing the state of objects during their lifespan in optimizing the leakage energy consumed in the data caches when executing embedded Java applications. Our analysis reveals that a major portion of the leakage energy is actually wasted in retaining the objects beyond their last use. In order to eliminate this wastage, we investigate three approaches that use the garbage collector, escape analysis and last use analysis for reducing leakage energy. Finally, we track the access gap between successive object accesses to reduce leakage energy of live objects. A combination of these schemes is shown to provide 21% data cache leakage energy reduction in our default configuration.
Author Keywords: Cache; Java; Leakage energy
Index Keywords: Cache lines; Leakage energy; Budget control; Cache memory; Codes (symbols); Costs; Data storage equipment; Electric potential; Embedded systems; Energy utilization; Java programming language; Optimization; Leakage currents

Authors: Blue R.C., Bolotin G.S.
Title: X2000 advanced avionics project development of a new generation of avionics for space applications
Source title: IEEE Aerospace Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91 109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blue, R.C., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91 109, United States; Bolotin, G.S., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91 109, United States
Abstract: The X2000 Advanced Avionics Project has developed a new generation of avionics building block modules for use by multiple deep space missions, including future missions to Europa, Mars, and a comet. The key developments of the X2000 Avionics are a high performance flight computer, solid-state mass data storage, high-speed system I/O, solid-state power distribution, and power regulation and conversion. These components enable a modular and scalable design approach that results in a wide variety of avionics system architectures to meet diverse mission requirements and environments. The X2000 Avionics have been developed for use in extreme radiation environments such as those at Jupiter. The use of commercial standard interfaces and buses throughout the X2000 Avionics allow system designers to add functionality and further customize spacecraft architectures. This paper will describe the system architecture, the avionics components, the key performance and reliability requirements, and the current development status of the X2000 Avionics. © 2003 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Commercial standards; Deep space missions; Mission requirements; Performance and reliabilities; Project development; Radiation environments; Spacecraft architecture; System architectures; Energy policy; Power quality; Space applications; Space flight; Avionics

Abstract: The electrical characteristics of two polar liquids, water and propylene carbonate, under high electric stress have been studied. The liquids were placed between a hemispherical electrode of 1.7 mm diameter and a plane electrode with gap distances of 200 μm and 400 μm. A voltage pulse of 200 ns duration was applied by means of a Blumlein pulse generator. The increase in current with voltage was recorded up to the breakdown voltage, including the transition phase to breakdown. Schlieren diagnostics, with a temporal resolution of 2 ns, was used to study the changes in the index of refraction of water when it was used as the switch medium, both before and during breakdown. The results of our measurements showed that the electrodes determine, to a large extent, the hold-off voltage. By polishing the stainless steel electrodes, the breakdown strength was increased from 1 MV/cm to 2.2 MV/cm for propylene carbonate as dielectric. Similar increases were found for water as dielectric between polished electrodes. The rate of current rise after breakdown was measured as 4.5-1011 A/s for distilled water, a value which is comparable to that measured in gas switches. The Schlieren photographs showed that, depending on the polarity, the breakdown is preceded by the treeing of streamers into the gap.
Index Keywords: Carbonates; Computer simulation; Current voltage characteristics; Dielectric properties; Electric breakdown; Electric energy storage; Electric fields; Electric impedance; Electrodes; Switching; Dielectric strength; Gas switches; Pulse generators

Abstract: In the quest to develop current generators for high energy density physics experiments, Sandia National Laboratories has long used water as an insulating media. Its high electrical breakdown strength and high dielectric constant corresponds to relatively compact energy storage components as well as low inductance spark gap switches. With the refurbishment of the Z machine underway, and with an eye towards the next generation of high current accelerators, an extensive research effort into water switches has been undertaken. A facility, called Z-20, has been built 1 to within ZR operational levels to test the geometry transition and a variety of configurations of water switches. Particular parameters of interest are polarity and field enhancement dependence, prepulse level, gap spacing and threshold voltage levels.
Index Keywords: Current viewing resistors (CVR); Pulse forming lines (PFL); Capacitance; Electric generators; Electric shielding; Electric switches; Electrodes; Inductance; Optimization; Particle accelerators; Permittivity; Threshold voltage; Electric breakdown of liquids

Abstract: The researches on a laboratory source of powerful soft x-ray radiation are considered. This project develops by cooperation from Kurchatov Instinute, TRINITI, Efremov Institute and VNIITF. The compression of fast liners is considered as the most perspective source for produsing of x-ray pulses at MJ range. The project is based on inductive stores of energy, which as a result of consecutive transformations generate an electrical pulse with parameters necessary for compression of liners.

Abstract: The source of high-power ultrawideband (UWB) radiation based on single compact antenna excited with 1 -ns bipolar pulse have been created. Antenna input pulse amplitude is up to 120-kV and pulse repetition rate up to 100 Hz. The antenna efficiency by peak power was 60%. The peak power of the source was 170 MW. The antenna pattern width by half-power is 100° for the H-plane and 105° for the E-plane. The efficient voltage of the source equal to product of the peak field strength and the distance made ∼130 kV.

Abstract: The National Ignition Facility (NIF) Power Conditioning System (PCS) is a modular capacitive energy storage system that will be capable of storing nearly 400 MJ of electrical energy and delivering that energy to the nearly 8000 flashlamps in the NIF laser. The first sixteen modules of the power conditioning system have been built, tested and installed. Activation of the first nine power conditioning modules has been completed and commissioning of the first "bundle" of laser beamlines has begun. This paper will provide an overview of the power conditioning system design and describe the status and results of initial testing and activation of the first "bundle" of power conditioning modules.

Authors: Clyne M., Mullarkey T.
Title: Wave Models with Energy Dissipation using two Representations of Potential
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore and Polar Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dept. of Civil Engineering, NUI, Galway. Co., Galway, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Clyne, M., Dept. of Civil Engineering, NUI, Galway. Co., Galway, Ireland; Mullarkey, T., Dept. of Civil Engineering, NUI, Galway. Co., Galway, Ireland
Abstract: A wave propagation model for linear periodic waves in a coastal sea region is developed. The model includes refraction and diffraction of gravity waves on water over arbitrary bathymetry. Energy dissipation in the form of wave breaking and turbulent bottom friction is modeled. The authors discuss the use of the computer model in simulating waves nearshore in the absence of any current. The method of solution involves complex potential theory. This complex potential can be decomposed in two ways: (a) real and imaginary parts and (b) amplitude and phase. The authors compare solutions from both techniques, regarding such issues as mesh resolutions, storage requirements, and computation times.

Authors: Oh B.T., Hong S.H., Yang Y.M., Yoon I.S., Kim Y.K.
Title: The Development of KOGAS Membrane for LNG Storage Tank
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore and Polar Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Korea Gas Corp., R and D Center, In-Chon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Oh, B.T., Korea Gas Corp., R and D Center, In-Chon, South Korea; Hong, S.H., Korea Gas Corp., R and D Center, In-Chon, South Korea; Yang, Y.M., Korea Gas Corp., R and D Center, In-Chon, South Korea; Yoon, I.S., Korea Gas Corp., R and D Center, In-Chon, South Korea; Kim, Y.K., Korea Gas Corp., R and D Center, In-Chon, South Korea
Abstract: Liquefied Natural Gas(LNG) demand has been rapidly increasing in Korea for many reasons such as a stable supply, pollution-free energy, and an energy diversification policy. As a result, the construction and expansion of LNG storage facilities have been performing at a vigorous pace. Korea Gas Corp. (KOGAS) has developed a design technology for LNG storage tanks. One of the most important structural core elements of the LNG storage tank is the stainless steel membrane. The membrane installed inside of LNG storage tank is provided with corrugations to absorb thermal contraction and expansion caused by LNG temperature. Analytical results have been performed to investigate the proper behavior of the membrane and the constraint force at the anchor point. Experimental studies are performed to investigate the deformation and strength of the membrane which is designed by KOGAS. All experiments are conducted on the basis of RPIS (Recommended Practice for LNG In-ground Storage), and we found the results are fully satisfied with the RPIS.

Title: Installation of a Scaleable Wave Energy Conversion System in Oahu, Hawaii

Abstract: Ocean Power Technologies, Inc. has been contracted by the U.S. Navy to install a demonstration version of their modular PowerBuoy wave energy conversion system off of the island of Oahu, Hawaii. The primary goal of this five-year test is to obtain operational data to validate the long-term performance of a multi-unit wave energy conversion system. This scaleable system holds the promise of providing non-polluting, reliable, and inexpensive power to civilian and military coastal sites around the world. This paper will discuss aspects of the design and phased installation process of the array of PowerBuoy units.

Authors: Btirchell T., Howe J., Gabbard A., Rogers M.
Title: Adsorbent carbon fiber composites for the storage of natural gas
Source title: International SAMPE Symposium and Exhibition (Proceedings)
Affiliations: Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6088, United States
Authors with affiliations: Btirchell, T., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6088, United States; Howe, J., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6088, United States; Gabbard, A., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6088, United States; Rogers, M., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6088, United States
Abstract: Natural gas is an attractive fuel for vehicles because it is a relatively clean-burning fuel compared with gasoline. Moreover, methane can be stored in the physically adsorbed state [at a pressure of 3.5 MPa (500 psi)] at energy densities comparable to methane compressed at 24.8 MPa (3600 psi). Here we report the development of porous carbon fiber composite natural gas storage media. The composite manufacture and activation method are reported along with pore structure characterization data. Characterization of the microporosity (pore width < 2 nm) and mesoporosity (pore width 2-50 nm) has been performed using standard nitrogen gas adsorption methods, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and Small Angle Neutron Scattering (SANS). The methane storage capacities of these composites were measured gravimetrically at a pressure of 3.5 MPa (500 psi) and ambient temperature. Storage capacities of > 150 V/V (stp volume of gas per unit volume of storage vessel) were demonstrated. The methane adsorption capacity of the composites is correlated with the micropore volume. Direct evidence (from in-situ SANS experiments) of the adsorption of gasses in the micropores is reported.
Author Keywords: Applications-Energy; Carbon-Carbon Composites; Natural Gas Vehicles (NGV)
Index Keywords: Applications-energy; Natural gas vegicles (NGV); Small angle neutron scattering (SANS); Activated carbon; Adsorbents; Adsorption isotherms; Carbon carbon composites; Gas adsorption; Gas fuel storage; Gasoline; Microporosity; Natural gas; Neutron scattering; Scanning electron microscopy; Thermal conductivity; Transmission electron microscopy; Carbon fibers

Abstract: A new statistical model of Stress-Induced Leakage Current (SILC) will be implemented and used to predict data retention and program disturbs of state-of-the-art Flash memories, and to correlate oxide characterization outputs (density, cross section, energy level of defects) to Flash memory reliability. Physical mechanisms inducing the largest threshold voltage (V T) degradation will be explained, and tunnel oxide scaling effects on Flash reliability will be predicted.

Authors: Basso T.S., DeBlasio R.D.
Title: IEEE P1547-Series of Standards for Interconnection
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Power Engineering Society Transmission and Distribution Conference
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 1617 Cole Blvd., Golden, CO 80401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Basso, T.S., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 1617 Cole Blvd., Golden, CO 80401, United States; DeBlasio, R.D., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 1617 Cole Blvd., Golden, CO 80401, United States
Abstract: The IEEE P1547 Standard For Interconnecting Distributed Resources With Electric Power Systems is the first in the P1547-series of planned interconnection standards, and, there are additional standards needed. There are major issues and obstacles to an orderly transition to using and integrating distributed power resources with electric power systems (grid or utility grid). The lack of uniform national interconnection standards and tests for interconnection operation and certification, as well as the lack of uniform national building, electrical, and safety codes, are understood, and, resolving that needs reasonable lead time to develop and promulgate consensus. The P1547 standard is a benchmark milestone for the IEEE standards consensus process and successfully demonstrates a model for ongoing success in developing further national standards and for moving forward in modernizing our nation's electric power system.

Title: Few Electron Memories: Finding the Compromise between Performance, Variability and Manufacturability at the Nano-Scale
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Sch. of Appl./Engineering Physics, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Authors with affiliations: Silva, H., Sch. of Appl./Engineering Physics, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Kim, M.K., School of Electrical Engineering, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Kumar, A., School of Electrical Engineering, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Avci, U., Sch. of Appl./Engineering Physics, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Tiwari, S., School of Electrical Engineering, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Abstract: The key challenges for memories that operate at the nano-scale, and are compatible with mainstream nano-scale CMOS, are in achieving the performance characteristics that are useful at massive integration and in the reproducibility necessary for manufacturing. Use of single or few electrons by utilizing the reduced dimensions - smaller number of states and larger charging energies - while appealing as a concept, needs to address the increased variance, smaller signal, and numerous other consequences of reduced collective phenomena. Several key ideas of recent times, from the use of nanocrystals to defects and decoupling of storage from read process, provide paths where power, speed, technology compatibility, and variability is addressed. This paper discusses several of these approaches and their attributes focusing on finding the design compromises for usability and manufacturability.
Index Keywords: Electron memories; Single-electron transmission; Capacitance measurement; Coulomb blockade; Electric currents; Electric impedance; Electric resistance; Electron beam lithography; Growth (materials); Interconnection networks; Nanostructured materials; Oxidation; Polysilanes; Polysilicon; Product design; Silica; Thermal effects; Transistors; CMOS integrated circuits

Authors: Johnson B.K.
Title: An Assessment of Enabling Technologies for Transmission and Distribution Applications of Superconductors
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Power Engineering Society Transmission and Distribution Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Idaho, Moscow, ID 83844-1023, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, B.K., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Idaho, Moscow, ID 83844-1023, United States
Abstract: The discovery of high temperature superconductivity sparked renewed interest in its application to power transmission and distribution systems. There are several technical bottlenecks that need to be overcome prior to the widespread use of superconductivity in power systems. There are also several key cross-cutting technologies that impact many different applications, such as efficient refrigeration systems, materials developments, and in several cases power electronics.
Author Keywords: Power electronics; Refridgeration; Superconductivity
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric fault currents; Electric power systems; Electric power transmission; Electric sparks; Limiters; Magnetic fields; Power electronics; Superconductivity; Magnetic energy storage; High temperature superconductors

Authors: Steurer M., Ribeiro P.F., Noe M.
Title: Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage and Fault Current Limiters Projects, Considerations, and Outlook
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Power Engineering Society Transmission and Distribution Conference
Affiliations: Center for Advanced Power Systems, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL 32310, United States; Department of Engineering, Calvin College, Grand Rapids, MI 49546, United States; Karlsruhe Research Center, Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Steurer, M., Center for Advanced Power Systems, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL 32310, United States; Ribeiro, P.F., Department of Engineering, Calvin College, Grand Rapids, MI 49546, United States; Noe, M., Karlsruhe Research Center, Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: Novel technologies such as superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) and non-disruptive fault current limiters (FCL) are both of increasing interest to the electric power industry. The latter will have to cope with significant technical challenges due to new restrictions on plans to expand transmission capabilities, the increasing demand for better power quality, and other reasons in the future. This paper reviews the fundamental operating principles of SMES and FCL, provides and overview on the status of research projects worldwide, and outlines some of the technical challenges still to be overcome for product development. Several aspects of SMES and FCL applications are discussed from the utility's point of view. Furthermore, estimated costs are presented for SMES and FCL. It is concluded that both technologies, while still too costly for a wide marked introduction, may already be beneficial for selected pilot applications such as, for SMES, custom power enhancement or, for FCL, closing bus ties and connecting independent energy providers (IEPs) to the transmission grid.
Author Keywords: Energy storage; Fault current limiter; Solid-state witch; Superconductor; Voltage source converter
Index Keywords: Costs; Electric converters; Electric energy storage; Electric fault currents; Electric potential; Electric power transmission; Superconducting magnets; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Limiters

Authors: Woodworth J.J., Gravunder J.
Title: Energy Handling Considerations for Transmission Line Arresters
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Power Engineering Society Transmission and Distribution Conference
Authors with affiliations: Woodworth, J.J.; Gravunder, J.
Abstract: The application of transmission line arresters (TLA) is the fastest growing segment of over voltage protection of power systems today. It has gained its appeal because it is a rapid and cost effective means of increasing system reliability. The most common use of this arrester is for the mitigation of lightning induced momentary outages on transmission and sub-transmission circuits. The purpose of this paper is to clarify the confusion that surrounds the selection of this device. Along with all the normal arrester characteristics that need to be taken into consideration, extra consideration must be given to the energy handling capabilities of the unit. In some applications, extra high energy capability is not necessary; however in other cases energy ratings similar to station arresters are a must.
Author Keywords: Arresters; Lightning; Power systems; Surge protection; Transmission lines; Varistors
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric lines; Electric potential; Electric power systems; Surge protection; Varistors; Transmission lines arresters (TLA); Lightning arresters
