Authors: Roberts K., Foster P.
Title: Dealing with sediment
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Affiliations: Energy Ltd; MWH
Authors with affiliations: Roberts, K., Energy Ltd; Foster, P., MWH
Abstract: In 1996, the Electricity Corporation of New Zealand transferred its hydro generation and storage dams on the Clutha river to Contact Energy. Contact Energy has been required to apply under New Zealand's Resource Management Act for resource consents to operate its dams and reservoirs for the next 35 years. Dealing with the historic and potential future effects of sedimentation in the Clutha river has been an important issue in this process. In 1956, the Roxburgh dam was constructed on the Clutha river in New Zealand to provide hydroelectricity. Lake Roxburgh, the reservoir created by Roxburgh dam, has an operating range of 1.85m. It is a long narrow lake with an approximate length of 30km and a width varying from typically 150m to 300m. In the late 1950's a dam was also built upstream of Lake Roxburgh at the outlet of the natural Lake Hawea to raise the lake and provide water storage for use in the winter when natural river flows are generally lowest and the demand for electricity is highest. The present normal operating range of Lake Hawea is 8m. Lake Dunstan, which is formed by the Clyde dam and is situated between Lakes Roxburgh and Hawea, commenced filling in 1992. The operating range of Lake Dunstan is 1m. Figure 1 shows the Clutha catchment and the hydro dam locations. In the period from 1956 to 1992, Lake Roxburgh was progressively filling with sediment, sourced mainly from the Shotover river. After 1992 this sediment began to be trapped in Lake Dunstan.
Index Keywords: Catchments; Electricity; Hydroelectric power; Rivers; Sedimentation; Sediments; Storage dams; Dams; flood control; flushing; hydroelectric power; lake; sediment transport; New Zealand

The development of transistor technology that allows more number of transistors on a single chip is also discussed.

Abstract: A solar-powered building heating system designed to be discretely hidden under roof of a home or office was developed at the Sustainable Energy Centre of the University of South Australia. The size and weight of the phase change storage system depends on the application, with the weight of a housing application ranging from 100 kg to 300 kg. The system was found to be modular, which enables the load to be split into manageable weights for lifting into the roof space.

Authors: Ho A.T.S., Zhu X., Shen J.
Title: Slant transform watermarking for digital images
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Ho, A.T.S., Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Zhu, X., Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Shen, J., Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Abstract: In this paper, we propose a digital watermarking algorithm based on the Slant transform for the copyright protection of images. Our earlier research work associated with the fast Hadamard transform for robust watermark embedding and retrieval of images and characters suggests that this transform could also provide a good "hidden" space for digital watermarking. The Slant transform has many similar properties to the Walsh-Hadamard transform. In terms of transform coding, the Slant transform is considered to be a sub-optimum orthogonal transform for energy compaction. For digital watermarking, the energy spread becomes a significant advantage, as there is now a good spread of middle to higher frequencies with significant energies for robust information hiding. In this paper, an analytical comparative study on the performance of the Slant transform adapting our earlier watermarking schemes for fast Hadamard transform will be performed based on its robustness against various Stirmark attacks. The performance results of the Slant transform for image watermarking against other transforms such as Cosine transform will also be presented.
Author Keywords: Copyright protection; Digital watermarking; Slant transform
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Copyrights; Digital image storage; Image coding; Image reconstruction; Image retrieval; Mathematical transformations; Multimedia systems; Security of data; Digital images; Hadamard transform; Slant transform; Walsh-Hadamard transform; Digital watermarking

Abstract: A study was presented on a systematic design procedure used to construct a servo controller for any type of dual-stage actuator. To compare control strategies on performance and energy consumption and to study the benefits of a dual-stage actuator, the Single Input Single Output (SISO) and Single Input Multiple Output (SIMO) controller configurations were analyzed. Abstract: Minimum energy paths and energy barriers were calculated for the free data layer in magnetic random access memory (MRAM) elements. A method combining the climbing image nudged elastic band (CINEB) method with finite element micromagnetics, calculated the magnetic states along the most probable reversal paths for applied fields below the zero temperature switching field. Results showed that for fields smaller than ≡ 50 Oe, the energy barrier was larger than 100 kBT which ensured stability in the time range of years.

Authors: Talarico C., Semeraro L., Lo Bue A., Gambitta A., Turchet A., Wei F., Cassani C.
Title: Survey and alignment of ELETTRA storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Assoc. EURATOM-ENEA sulla Fusione, Via Enrico Fermi, 45, 00044 Frascati (RM), Italy; Sincrotrone Trieste S.C.p.A., Strada Statale 14-km 163, 5 34012 Basovizza, Trieste, Italy; Paul Scherrer Institut, CH-5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland; Leica Geosystems S.p.A., Via Gargano, 7, 20139 Milano, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Talarico, C., Assoc. EURATOM-ENEA sulla Fusione, Via Enrico Fermi, 45, 00044 Frascati (RM), Italy; Semeraro, L., Assoc. EURATOM-ENEA sulla Fusione, Via Enrico Fermi, 45, 00044 Frascati (RM), Italy; Lo Bue, A., Assoc. EURATOM-ENEA sulla Fusione, Via Enrico Fermi, 45, 00044 Frascati (RM), Italy; Gambitta, A., Sincrotrone Trieste S.C.p.A., Strada Statale 14-km 163, 5 34012 Basovizza, Trieste, Italy; Turchet, A., Sincrotrone Trieste S.C.p.A., Strada Statale 14-km 163, 5 34012 Basovizza, Trieste, Italy; Wei, F., Paul Scherrer Institut, CH-5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland; Cassani, C., Leica Geosystems S.p.A., Via Gargano, 7, 20139 Milano, Italy
Abstract: ELETTRA is an intermediate energy Synchrotron Light Source located in the outskirts of Trieste, Italy, open to researchers of basic and applied fields such as material and life sciences, physics, chemistry and geology. The synchrotron is operated 24 hours/day, 7 days/week with few periods of shutdown, mostly dedicated to maintenance. During one of these periods, in August 2001, ENEA Fusion Technology Division (Italy), in collaboration with ELETTRA Accelerator Sector and Paul Scherrer Institut (PSI, Switzerland), carried out the 3D dimensional survey of the storage ring using its own optical metrology system (Leica laser tracker LTD500). The aim of the survey was the realignment of the storage ring magnets of the synchrotron. Within a two-weeks time shutdown, more than 2300 single measurements were taken on the 24 bending magnets, 108 quadrupoles and 72 sextupoles placed in the 259.2 m circumference storage ring. The overall root mean square error of the oriented network were less than 0.1 mm, thus making possible a subsequent and successful one-week alignment of one fourth of the storage ring (October 2001). This performance completely fulfilled the very demanding survey specifications in terms of accuracy, time required, and usability of the measurements. This paper illustrates the survey, the method and the instrumentation adopted and the results obtained. Moreover, it gives guidelines to be taken into account when planning the alignment of accelerators or large and heavy components.
Index Keywords: Chemistry; Geology; Magnets; Materials science; Physics; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Optical metrology system; Synchrotron light source; Light sources

Authors: Bhavnagarwala A.J., Kosonocky S.V., Immediate M., Knebel D., Haen A.-M.
Title: A Pico-Joule Class, 1 GHz, 32 KByte × 64b DSP SRAM with Self Reverse Bias
Source title: IEEE Symposium on VLSI Circuits, Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: IBM T J Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bhavnagarwala, A.J., IBM T J Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Kosonocky, S.V., IBM T J Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Immediate, M., IBM T J Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Knebel, D., IBM T J Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Haen, A.-M., IBM T J Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: New SRAM circuit techniques implemented in a standard 0.13 μm bulk Si CMOS process are reported in this work that (i) enable pico-joule energy dissipation per accessed bit at 1 GHz, (ii) lower total leakage power by over 80% from all unaccessed cells, during both active and standby modes, using a rigorous, self reverse biasing scheme that addresses leakage due to quantum tunneling and thermal excitation in all cell transistors, with an area, performance and noise margin penalty of less than 3% each and (iii) enable a programmable leakage reduction option that lowers leakage by over 90% when stored data is no longer desired.
Index Keywords: Cache memory; Leakage currents; Static random access storage; Self reverse bias; CMOS integrated circuits

Authors: Wu R., Myers J.D., Myers M.J., Rapp C.
Title: Fluorescence lifetime and 980nm pump energy transfer dynamics in erbium and ytterbium co-doped phosphate laser glasses
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Kigre, Inc., 100 Marshland Road, Hilton Head Island, SC 29926, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, R., Kigre, Inc., 100 Marshland Road, Hilton Head Island, SC 29926, United States; Myers, J.D., Kigre, Inc., 100 Marshland Road, Hilton Head Island, SC 29926, United States; Myers, M.J., Kigre, Inc., 100 Marshland Road, Hilton Head Island, SC 29926, United States; Rapp, C., Kigre, Inc., 100 Marshland Road, Hilton Head Island, SC 29926, United States
Abstract: Phosphate glasses are attractive laser oscillator/amplifier materials because unlike fluoride, silicate, and other laser glass materials they combine such useful properties as good chemical durability, ion-exchangeability, high gain, low concentration quenching, and low upconversion losses. Phosphate glasses also exhibit a very high solubility for rare earth ions. This feature permits the introduction of large concentrations of active ions into relatively small volumes resulting in smaller laser devices with high-energy storage capabilities. These high dopant concentrations also result in very rapid and efficient energy transfer between rare earth ions. This allows for the effective use of Yb3+ as a sensitizer for the Er3+ laser ion. Effective Er:Yb:Glass pumping, energy storage, and energy extraction involves the population of the 2F5/2 level of Yb 3+ (∼2ms fluorescence lifetime); a moderately rapid and efficient nonradiative transfer of energy to the 4I11/2 level of Er3+ (about 500 μsec transfer time); and a very rapid (< 1μ,sec) nonradiative decay of the Er3+ from the 4I11/2 to the metastable 4I13/2 state (with an 8ms fluorescence lifetime). In this study we measured the fluorescence lifetime for the 4I13/2 level of Er +3 on different glass samples with various concentrations of erbium. The data indicate that for doping levels up to 7 wt.% Er2O 3 the lifetime remains above 7.0 ms. Theoretically, this highly doped glass could produce over 18 dB gain in a 1cm path length. In additional fluorescence lifetime testing, ytterbium doped and erbium/ytterbium co-doped glasses were evaluated for concentration quenching and energy transfer rate as a function of the Er3+ concentration. The effect on the energy transfer efficiency and laser efficiency was analyzed.
Author Keywords: Diode pump; Erbium Glass; Fluorescence
Index Keywords: Doping (additives); Energy transfer; Fluorescence; Optical pumping; Pumping (laser); Quenching; Rare earth elements; Diode pumps; Solid state lasers

Authors: Mu X., Artiklar M., Hassoun M.H., Watta P.
Title: An RCE-based associative memory with application to human face recognition
Source title: Proceedings of the International Joint Conference on Neural Networks
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Michigan-Dearborn, Detroit, MI 48128, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mu, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, United States; Artiklar, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, United States; Hassoun, M.H., Department of Electrical Engineering, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, United States; Watta, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Michigan-Dearborn, Detroit, MI 48128, United States
Abstract: In this paper we construct an associative memory model based on the restricted Coulomb energy (RCE) network. We propose a simple architecture and training algorithm for this RCE-based associative memory. We study the capacity of this memory model on the practical problem of human face recognition. In this case, capacity is described by two measures: the ability of the system to correctly identify known individuals, and the ability of the system to reject individuals who are not in the database. Experimental results are given which show how the performance of the system varies as the size of the database increases - up to 1000 individuals.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Associative storage; Computer architecture; Database systems; Face recognition; Signal to noise ratio; Restricted coulomb energy (RCE); Neural networks

Authors: Choi S., Govindu G., Jang J.-W., Prasanna V.K.
Title: Energy-efficient and parameterized designs for fast fourier transform on FPGAs
Source title: ICASSP, IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing - Proceedings
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering-Systems, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089, United States; Electronic Engineering, Sogang University, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Choi, S., Electrical Engineering-Systems, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089, United States; Govindu, G., Electrical Engineering-Systems, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089, United States; Jang, J.-W., Electronic Engineering, Sogang University, Seoul, South Korea; Prasanna, V.K., Electrical Engineering-Systems, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we develop energy efficient designs for the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) on FPGAs. Architectures for FFT on FPGAs are designed by investigating and applying techniques for minimizing the energy dissipation. Architectural parameters such as degrees of vertical and horizontal parallelism are identified and a design domain is created through a combination of design choices. We determine design trade-offs using high-level performance estimation to obtain energy-efficient designs. We implemented a set of parametrized designs having parallelism, radix and choice of storage types as parameters, on Xilinx Virtex-II FPGA to verify the estimates. Our designs dissipate 57% to 78% less energy than the optimized designs from the Xilinx library. In terms of a comprehensive metric such as EAT (Energy-Area-Time), our designs offer performance improvements of 3-13x over the Xilinx designs.
Index Keywords: Xilinx designs; Energy dissipation; Energy efficiency; Fast Fourier transforms; Optimization; Field programmable gate arrays

Abstract: In this paper, a self-organizing fuzzy neural network controller (SOFNC) is design for high-speed flywheel energy storage system (FESS) to improve the transient stability and increase transfer capability of power systems. The main feature over traditional control approach lies in the model-free description of control system and parallel computing capability. Simulation results in Taiwan power system (Taipower) show that the FESS with the proposed controller has produced significant improvement in the power system performance.

Title: A New Design Method for Complex-Valued Multistate Hopfield Associative Memory
Source title: Proceedings of the International Joint Conference on Neural Networks
Affiliations: Computational Intelligence Lab., University of Louisville, 40292 Louisville, KY, United States; Elec. and Electronics Engineering, Dokuz Eylül University, 35160 Buca, Izmir, Turkey; Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Louisville, 40292 Louisville, Kentucky, United States
Authors with affiliations: Müezzinoǧlu, M.K., Computational Intelligence Lab., University of Louisville, 40292 Louisville, KY, United States; Güzeliş, C., Elec. and Electronics Engineering, Dokuz Eylül University, 35160 Buca, Izmir, Turkey; Zurada, J.M., Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Louisville, 40292 Louisville, Kentucky, United States
Abstract: A method to store each element of an integer-valued memory set M ⊂ {1, 2,..., K}n as a fixed point into a complexvalued multistate Hopfield network is introduced. The method employs a set of inequalities to render each memory pattern as a strict local minimum of a quadratic energy landscape, and based on the solution of this system, gives a recurrent network of n multistate neurons with complex and symmetric synaptic weights, which operates on the finite state space {1, 2,..., K}n to minimize this quadratic functional. Maximum number of integer-valued vectors that can be embedded into the energy landscape of the network by this method is investigated by computer experiments. The paper also enlightens the performance of the proposed method in reconstructing noisy gray-scale images.
Index Keywords: Associative storage; Matrix algebra; Vectors; Hopfield associative memory; Recurrent neural networks

Authors: Lerner I.
Title: R&D is Critical for Specialty Chemicals Improvement
Source title: Chemical Market Reporter
Authors with affiliations: Lerner, I.
Abstract: The importance of research and development (R&D) resources for improving specialty chemicals is discussed. The comments of Richard E. Claar, founding partner of the Chicago-based consultancy Martec Group Inc., on the technological developments for saving specialty chemicals sector are also presented. Many chemical companies have been investing in hot technology areas in an effort to increase their businesses. The hot technology includes bioprocessing, energy storage (fuel cells),drug delivery, and nanotechnology.
Index Keywords: Competitive intelligence; Industrial chemicals; Industrial economics; Raw materials; Research and development management; Sales; Strategic planning; Drug delivery; Chemical industry

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: DOE's OFE, NARUC launch LNG public awareness campaign
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: DOE's Office of Fossil Energy (OFE) and the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners launched a new LNG education campaign to dispel what energy regulators say are popular misconceptions about the fuel. The new OFE-funded project aims to enhance communication between critical energy stakeholders to ensure the responsible development and deployment of LNG. According to DOE, there are currently 17 LNG export terminals, and 136 LNG tankers worldwide. In the past 2 yr, the US has imported LNG from Trinidad and Tobago, Algeria, Australia, Nigeria, Oman, Qatar, Indonesia, and the UAE. FERC approved for construction the first new LNG terminal to be built in the US in 25 yr. Sempra Energy LNG Corp's Cameron LNG facility near Hackberry, LA, will include a terminal with three storage tanks that will hold the equivalent of 3.5 bcfe, and a 35.4-mi pipeline that will extend from the terminal to an interconnection with facilities operated by Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corp.

Title: The methanol economy
Source title: Chemical and Engineering News

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government Developments: A new US natural gas...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: A new US natural gas storage technology consortium will include industry, academics, and government officials and is scheduled through 2007. Pennsylvania State University will establish and operate the $3 million consortium under an agreement between the school and the US DOE's National Energy Technology Laboratory Strategic Center for Natural Gas. According to DOE, an 18-mo first phase will involve formation of the consortium structure. Research supported by the consortium will include, but not be limited to, technologies to limit and remediate the progressive damage caused by the repeated injection and withdrawal of gas in existing and future facilities, as well as innovative reservoir development and management techniques that can maximize performance.

Authors: Chiu Y., Wu M., Shieh H.P.D., Sun Y.T., Chou H.L., Hsu W.
Title: Integrated near-field optical head for hybrid recording
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical and Control Eng., National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Institute of Electro-Optical Eng., National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chiu, Y., Dept. of Electrical and Control Eng., National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Wu, M., Institute of Electro-Optical Eng., National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Shieh, H.P.D., Institute of Electro-Optical Eng., National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Sun, Y.T., Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chou, H.L., Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Hsu, W., Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: As the recording density of longitudinal magnetic storage increases at a 100% annual growth rate, it will soon approach the superparamagnetic limit where the thermal energy at room temperature starts to induce thermal instability to the grains in the small recorded marks. Thermal magnetic recording schemes, such as those used in magneto-optical recording, help alleviate the problems with the superparamagnetic limit. Recently, a hybrid recording system was proposed where data were recorded thermal magnetically on a magneto-optical disk and read back with a GMR head. In this paper, we propose an integrated planar head that combines an optical fiber lens, a solid immersion lens, a sub wavelength aperture, a micro coil, an air bearing surface, and a GMR head for such a hybrid recording system. Preliminary fabrication and calculation are discussed.
Author Keywords: Air bearing surfaces; Fiber lens; Hybrid recording; Micro coil; Near-field recording; Solid immersion lens; Sub-wavelength aperture
Index Keywords: Calculations; Giant magnetoresistance; Lenses; Magnetic heads; Magnetic storage; Magnetooptical devices; Optical fibers; Optical recording; Thermodynamic stability; Hybrid recording; Magneto-optical disk; Magneto-optical recording; Micro coil; Near-field recording; Optical fiber lens; Solid immersion lens; Sub-wavelength aperture; Thermal magnetic recording; Magnetic recording

Authors: Yen B.J., Shapiro J.H.
Title: Error models and error mitigation for long-distance, high-fidelity quantum secret sharing
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Research Laboratory of Electronics, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139-4307, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yen, B.J., Research Laboratory of Electronics, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139-4307, United States; Shapiro, J.H., Research Laboratory of Electronics, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139-4307, United States
Abstract: A quantum communication architecture is being developed for long-distance, high-fidelity transmission and storage of Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger states. This system uses an ultrabright narrowband source of polarization-entangled photons plus trapped-atom quantum memories, and it is compatible with long-distance transmission over standard telecommunication fiber. An error model for the preceding architecture is derived, and the use of quantum error correction or entanglement purification protocols to improve the performance of this quantum communication system is also discussed.
Author Keywords: Entanglement purification protocols; Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger states; Quantum communication; Quantum error-correcting codes
Index Keywords: Electron energy levels; Error correction; Errors; Mathematical models; Mathematical operators; Optical fibers; Photons; Polarization; Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger states; Quantum communication; Quantum secret sharing; Quantum optics

Authors: Zhu J., Ou D.R., Zhu R.J., Wang J.
Title: Optical films with nanometer structures
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dept. of Materials Science and Eng., Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Dept. of Precision Instrument, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, J., Dept. of Materials Science and Eng., Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Ou, D.R., Dept. of Materials Science and Eng., Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Zhu, R.J., Dept. of Precision Instrument, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Wang, J., Dept. of Precision Instrument, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Abstract: Two kinds of films with nanometer structure. Sb-type super-resolution near-field structure (Sb-SR) and random Sb-SiN film were studied in this paper. Sb-SR is the sandwich structure SiN(20nm)/Sb(15nm)/SiN(20nm). Experimental results show that the super-resolution performance of amorphous Sb-SR is considerably better than crystal Sb-SR. Considering that Sb is a semiconductor with small energy gap, a three-order nonlinear response of surface plasmons is deduced to explain the performance of amorphous Sb-SR. Estimation is made, and the calculated results are in agreement with the experimental results. Random Sb-SiN film is the film in which Sb nano-particles are randomly dispersed. Results show that the random Sb-SiN films possess high transmittance and low reflectivity. When the random Sb-SiN film was prepared close to a phase-change-recording layer, it decreases the threshold of input power for recording and speeds up the phase transition of recording media.
Author Keywords: Nonlinear optics; Optical storage; Random Sb-SiN film; Sb-type super-resolution near-field structure
Index Keywords: Amorphous materials; Antimony; Energy gap; Film preparation; Nonlinear optics; Optical data storage; Optical films; Phase transitions; Silicon nitride; Nanometer structures; Phase change recording layer; Surface plasmons; Three order nonlinear response; Nanostructured materials

Authors: Sim P.H.
Title: Former enron MTBE plant to close
Source title: Chemical Week
Authors with affiliations: Sim, P.H.
Abstract: EOTT Energy stated that it will end production of methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) on October 1 2003, due to weak profitability and an uncertain outlook in the U.S. EOTT produces MTBE at a 15,000-bbls/day plant at La Porte, TX. EOTT will focus on its natural gas liquids (NGL) tolling, terminaling, transportation, and storage operations. EOTT has an NGL pipeline in the Houston Ship Channel and 10 million bbls of NGL storage capacity at Mont Belvieu, TX. EOTT is the third company in the U.S. to exit the MTBE markets in 2003 due to rising energy costs and declining demand resulting from the ban on MTBE as a gasoline additive in California by January 1, 2004.
Index Keywords: Additives; Chemical industry; Chemical plants; Gasoline; Industrial management; Isomerization; Natural gas; Petrochemical plants; Productivity; Societies and institutions; EOTT Energy (CO); Gasoline additives; Natural gas liquids (NGL); Storage operations; Plant shutdowns

Authors: Kapteyn C., Ehehalt J., Heitz R., Bimberg D., Cirlin G.E., Ustinov V.M., Ledentsov N.N.
Title: Optical memory concepts with self-organized quantum dots - Material systems and energy-selective charging
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Inst. für Festkörperphysik, Technische Universität Berlin, Hardenbergstraße 36, 10623 Berlin, Germany; Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kapteyn, C., Inst. für Festkörperphysik, Technische Universität Berlin, Hardenbergstraße 36, 10623 Berlin, Germany; Ehehalt, J., Inst. für Festkörperphysik, Technische Universität Berlin, Hardenbergstraße 36, 10623 Berlin, Germany; Heitz, R., Inst. für Festkörperphysik, Technische Universität Berlin, Hardenbergstraße 36, 10623 Berlin, Germany; Bimberg, D., Inst. für Festkörperphysik, Technische Universität Berlin, Hardenbergstraße 36, 10623 Berlin, Germany; Cirlin, G.E., Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St Petersburg, Russian Federation; Ustinov, V.M., Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St Petersburg, Russian Federation; Ledentsov, N.N., Inst. für Festkörperphysik, Technische Universität Berlin, Hardenbergstraße 36, 10623 Berlin, Germany, Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: For memory structures based on optically induced charge in self-organized quantum dots, the concept of wavelength-domain multiplexing in the quantum dot ensemble is an essential prerequisite. The electric properties of quantum dots in various material systems as studied by time-resolved capacitance spectroscopy are summarized, and candidates suitable for future memory applications are discussed. By combining optical excitation and capacitance spectroscopy, direct evidence is obtained for energy-selective hole charge generation and storage in InAs/GaAs quantum dots. A clear dependence of the activation energy of the emitted holes on the energy of the excitation is observed.
Author Keywords: Absorption; Capacitance spectroscopy; Charging; Memory; Quantum dot
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Capacitance; Charge carriers; Electric energy storage; Electron transitions; Optical data storage; Photoemission; Semiconducting gallium arsenide; Semiconducting indium compounds; Spectroscopy; Wavelength division multiplexing; Capacitance spectroscopy; Semiconductor quantum dots

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Quick Takes: Dominion Cove Point LNG terminal has received...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Dominion Cove Point LNG Terminal has received its first commercial cargo of LNG in 23 yr. BP PLC subsidiary BP Energy delivered 130,000 cu m of LNG from Trinidad and Tobago's Atlantic LNG project to Dominion Resources Inc's dock in southern Maryland on 8/22/2003. The cargo will be regasified into 2.9 bcf of natural gas. Dominion invested $180 million to reactivate the facility since purchasing it in September 2002, and has started construction on a new 2.5 bcf storage tank, scheduled for service in January 2005. Dominion Cove Point will process LNG for BP, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and Stratoil ASA, each of which holds a one-third access right to processing facilities and storage as well as capacity on Dominion 87 mi pipeline linked to markets and storage fields. Meanwhile, Statoil received its first LNG cargo at the Cove Point terminal on 9/2/2003. The delivery, acquired as a spot purchase from Spain's Repsol-YPF SA, will be regasified into 2.8 bcf of natural gas. The group will receive as additional spot cargo later September 2003 from another supplier, and negotiations are under way for long-term LNG deliveries until Snohvit comes on stream in 2006.

Authors: Bayliss C.R., Langley K.F.
Title: Nuclear Decommissioning, Waste Management, and Environmental Site Remediation
Source title: Nuclear Decommissioning, Waste Management, and Environmental Site Remediation
Affiliations: Department of the Major Projects and Engineering Division
Authors with affiliations: Bayliss, C.R.; Langley, K.F., Department of the Major Projects and Engineering Division
Abstract: Decommissioning nuclear facilities is a relatively new field, which has developed rapidly in the last ten years. It involves materials that may be highly radioactive and therefore require sophisticated methods of containment and remote handling. The wastes arising from decommissioning are hazardous and have to be stored or disposed of safely in order to protect the environment and future generations. Nuclear decommissioning work must be carried out to the highest possible standards to protect workers, the general public and the environment. This book describes the techniques used for dismantling redundant nuclear facilities, the safe storage of radioactive wastes and the restoration of nuclear licensed sites. * Describes the techniques used for dismantling nuclear facilities, safe storage of radioactive wastes, and the restoration of nuclear licensed facilities. * Provides the reader with decommissioning experience accumulated over 15 years by UKAEA. * Contains valuable information to personnel new to decommissioning and waste management. © 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Decommissioning (nuclear reactors); Environmental protection; Human resource management; Materials handling; Nuclear energy; Radioactive wastes; Radioactivity; Restoration; Future generations; General publics; Nuclear decommissioning; Nuclear facilities; Remote handling; Safe storage; Site remediation; Waste management

Authors: Arnold C.B., Wartena R.C., Swider-Lyons K.E., Piqué A.
Title: Fabrication of mesoscale energy storage systems by laser direct-write
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium - Proceedings
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6372, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6171, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arnold, C.B., Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6372, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Wartena, R.C., Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6171, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Swider-Lyons, K.E., Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6171, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Piqué, A., Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6372, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Abstract: Over the last two decades, there has been a trend towards the development of smaller and more autonomous electronic devices, yet the question of how to power these microdevices with correspondingly small power sources remains. To address this problem, we employ a laser forward-transfer process in combination with ultraviolet laser micromachining, to fabricate mesoscale electrochemical power sources, such as microbatteries and micro-ultracapacitors. This direct-write laser-engineering approach enables the deposition of battery materials (hydrous ruthenium oxide, manganese oxide, lithium cobalt oxide, etc.) under ambient temperature and atmospheric conditions, resulting in films with the desired morphological and electrochemical properties. Planar and stacked cell configurations are produced and tested for their energy storage and power delivery capabilities and exhibit favorable performance in comparison to current battery technology.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electrochemistry; Electron devices; Energy storage; Integrated circuit layout; Laser applications; Morphology; Electrochemical power source; Laser direct write; Mesoscale energy storage; Microbatteries; Semiconductor device manufacture

Shwartz, B., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk 630 090, Russian Federation
Abstract: Two-pion production reactions in proton-proton collisions have been studied using the PROMICE/WASA detector and an internal cluster gas-jet target at the CELSIUS storage ring in Uppsala. The total cross sections for the pp → ppπ+π-, pp → ppπ0π 0 and the pp → pnπ0π- reactions are presented at beam energies ranging from 650 to 775 MeV. An isospin analysis of the amplitudes involved in these three reactions indicates that the excitation of the N* (1440) followed by direct two pion emission can be the most important amplitude when allowed. However, large contributions from other production mechanisms must also be prevalent to explain the large pp → pnπ0π+ cross section. The data are compared to an extensive model including non-resonant as well as resonant production via N* and δ excitation.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Monte Carlo methods; Phosphors; Photons; Resonance; Beam energy; Protons

Authors: Meyer H.O.
Title: Polarization experiments with storage rings
Source title: Physica Scripta T
Affiliations: Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, H.O., Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Abstract: The technical issues that arise in hadron storage ring with a polarized beam and a polarized internal target were discussed in the article. The ring environment determines most beam properties. It was demonstrated that the crossing of an induced resonance flips the sign of the polarization of protons with better than a few percent loss in polarization.
Index Keywords: Continuum mechanics; Deuterium; Polarization; Protons; Resonance; Hadron storage rings; High energy physics

Authors: Jungmann K.P.
Title: A precise measurement of the muon magnetic anomaly
Source title: Physica Scripta T
Affiliations: Kernfysisch Versneller Instituut, Rijksuniversiteit Groningen, Zernikelaan 25, 9747 AA Groningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Jungmann, K.P., Kernfysisch Versneller Instituut, Rijksuniversiteit Groningen, Zernikelaan 25, 9747 AA Groningen, Netherlands
Abstract: At the Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) a precision experiment of the muon magnetic anomaly aμ in a magnetic storage ring is on its way. Measurements carried out on positive muons in 1999 have resulted in a μ+ = 11.659.202(14)(6) × 10-10 (1.3ppm). A difference between this value and the theoretical value at the time of publication has lead to a careful reevaluation of all contributions. At present there are several independent theoretical values which are based on standard theory. They agree with each other and are within one to two standard deviations of the above value. The goal of the experiment is a precision of 0. 35 ppm. About eight times more data are being analyzed and additional data taking is foreseen. Eventual agreement with experiment would allow to put stringent limits on parameters in theoretical approaches beyond the standard model. Disagreement could indicate new physics.
Index Keywords: Fermions; Magnetic moments; Magnetic storage; Photons; Quantum theory; Electric dipole moment; High energy physics

Authors: Andersson M., Bargholtz Chr., Fransson Kj., Fumero E., Gerén L., Holmberg L., Lindberg K., Lindh K., Mårtensson L., Sitnikova I., Tegnér P.-E., Weiss G., Wilhelmsen Rolander K.
Title: Pionic fusion, a tool to study cluster correlations in halo nuclei
Source title: Physica Scripta T
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, M., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Bargholtz, Chr., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Fransson, Kj., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Fumero, E., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Gerén, L., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Holmberg, L., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Lindberg, K., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Lindh, K., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Mårtensson, L., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Sitnikova, I., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Tegnér, P.-E., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Weiss, G., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Wilhelmsen Rolander, K., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: We are investigating the halo nucleus 6He and its isobaric analogue state at 3.56 MeV excitation energy in 6Li in a series of pionic fusion experiments at the CELSIUS storage ring facility in Uppsala. The 4He(d, 6He)π+ reaction was studied 0.6-5.4 MeV above threshold in the centre-of-mass frame with a deuteron beam incident on a 4He gas target. The 6He ions were detected in a ΔE - E solid-state detector telescope inserted into the CELSIUS ring. Preliminary results are presented and compared to results for the analogue reaction producing 6L3.56*.
Index Keywords: Helium; Solid state physics; Storage rings; Excitation energy; Nuclear physics

Authors: Franzke B., Beckert K., Beller P., Dolinskii A., Nolden F., Steck M.
Title: Storage ring complex for rare isotope beams in the GSI future project
Source title: Physica Scripta T
Affiliations: GSI, Planckstrasse 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Franzke, B., GSI, Planckstrasse 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Beckert, K., GSI, Planckstrasse 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Beller, P., GSI, Planckstrasse 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Dolinskii, A., GSI, Planckstrasse 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Nolden, F., GSI, Planckstrasse 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Steck, M., GSI, Planckstrasse 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The operation of the experimental storage ring ESR with beams of highly charged heavy ions has been studied at GSI over more than a decade. Beam cooling, either stochastic or by electrons, and internal gas jet target have been applied routinely. The conceptual design of a new storage ring complex at GSI is based mainly on experimental data for equilibrium beam parameters and cooling times measured at that ring. The generation of intense rare isotope beams is one of the pillars for the proposed GSI Future Project [www.gsi.de/ GSI-future/project] which makes use of the existing UNILAC/SIS18 as injector for a new 100Tm-synchrotron, SIS100. Especially nuclear physics experiments with stored and cooled rare isotope beams at essentially increased beam intensities will deliver important information on properties and structure of nuclei far from stability.
Index Keywords: Electrons; Isotopes; Storage rings; Isotope beams; High energy physics

Authors: Andersson M., Bargholtz Chr., Chernyshev B., Gerén L., Gornov M., Grebenev V., Gurov Y., Höistad B., Sandukovsky V., Shafigullin R., Tegnér P.-E., Wilhelmsen Rolander K.
Title: The observation of deeply bound pionic states of xenon produced in d+ AXe → A-1Xeπ + 3He reactions at CELSIUS
Source title: Physica Scripta T
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Dept. of Elementary Particle Physics, Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, Kashirskoe sh. 31, RU-115409 Moscow, Russian Federation; Department of Radiation Sciences, Uppsala University, Box 535, SE-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden; Laboratory of Nuclear Problems, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Joliot-Curie Street, RU-141980 Dubna, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, M., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Bargholtz, Chr., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Chernyshev, B., Dept. of Elementary Particle Physics, Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, Kashirskoe sh. 31, RU-115409 Moscow, Russian Federation; Gerén, L., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Gornov, M., Dept. of Elementary Particle Physics, Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, Kashirskoe sh. 31, RU-115409 Moscow, Russian Federation; Grebenev, V., Dept. of Elementary Particle Physics, Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, Kashirskoe sh. 31, RU-115409 Moscow, Russian Federation; Gurov, Y., Dept. of Elementary Particle Physics, Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, Kashirskoe sh. 31, RU-115409 Moscow, Russian Federation; Höistad, B., Department of Radiation Sciences, Uppsala University, Box 535, SE-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden; Sandukovsky, V., Laboratory of Nuclear Problems, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Joliot-Curie Street, RU-141980 Dubna, Russian Federation; Shafigullin, R., Dept. of Elementary Particle Physics, Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, Kashirskoe sh. 31, RU-115409 Moscow, Russian Federation; Tegnér, P.-E., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Wilhelmsen Rolander, K., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, SE-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: A search for deeply bound pionic states of xenon produced in d+ AXe → A-1Xeπ+3He reactions at CELSIUS was reported. In the 3He energy spectrum two peaks were observed corresponding to the production of pionic atoms in the 1s states. It was concluded that the production of deeply bound pionic states in the mixture of xenon isotopes were observed in this reaction.
Index Keywords: Electron energy levels; Isotopes; Storage rings; Xenon; Pionic states; Nuclear physics

Authors: Katayama T., Suda T., Tanihata I.
Title: Status of MUSES project and electron RI collider at RIKEN

Abstract: At RIKEN a versatile heavy ion accelerator system composed of a cascade of cyclotrons is under construction. As a second phase of the project. MUSES, an accumulator ring for an RI beam, and an electron-RI collider were planned and R&D works have been performed. Due mainly to budgetary problems, MUSES is now unlikely to be realized with its initial designed concept and with the expected schedule. In the present paper, the essence of design works of accelerator and electron-RI collision experiments are discussed.

Source title: Physica Scripta T

Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The ITEP-TWAC is a new heavy ion accumulator facility under construction at ITEP in Moscow [B. Sharkov et al., Nucl. Instr. Meth. A415, 20(1998)]. The TWAC project directs on development and promotion of high intensity and high power heavy ion beam technology. The main goal of the TWAC project is accumulation in the storage ring of intense ion beam, its longitudinal compression and using the extracted beam for plasma experiments. An electron cooler with electron energy of 380 keV provides a small ion bunch size during charge-exchange injection into the U10 accumulator ring [I, Meshkov et al., Design project of electron cooling system for TWAC accumulator ring (Dubna, 2001)]. The cooling time is compared with the storage time during charge-exchange multi-turn injection. The electron cooler allows us to significantly improve the beam parameters at the target (specific energy, specific power and so on) and to suppress the beam losses by an order of magnitude. The application of electron cooling allows an increase in of the final power of an extracted ion beam on a target by a factor 2-3.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Heavy ions; Ion beams; Ion exchange; Nuclear physics; Plasma theory; Storage rings; Accumulators; Electron coolers; Electron beams

Abstract: The pd → pdη reaction has been measured in a kinematically complete experiment at 927, 961, 1032, and 1096 MeV. The CM angular distributions are quite flat and distributions of the pd and pη invariant mass are close to that of phase space. However, the dη invariant mass shows significant structure in the first few MeV above threshold. This behaviour is similar to that observed in the energy variation of the pn → dη total cross section and is a signal of strong η-deuteron scattering which has been predicted in many theoretical models.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Monte Carlo methods; Photons; Scattering; Beam energy; Storage rings

Abstract: The projectile fragmentation wall [Budzanowski, A. et al., Nucl. Instr. Meth. A482, 528 (2002).] (PFW) is a part of a bigger detection system comprising of the CHICSi detector [Jakobsson, B., Nucl. Phys. News Int. 9:2, 22 (1999). Siwek, A., Nucl. Phys., A654, 2695 (1999)] and a recoil detectors array [Kuznetsov, A. V. et al. Nucl. Instr. Meth. A452, 525 (2000)]. The system is designed to register products of proton- and heavy ion-induced reactions at the energies 50-450 MeV/nucleon (see Bo Jakobsson's contribution to this conference). The aim of PFW is to register and identify projectile like fragments emitted in forward direction not covered by the CHICSi detector.
Index Keywords: Heavy ions; Particle detectors; Phosphors; Protons; Projectile fragmentation; Storage rings

Authors: Bosch F.
Title: Proposal for new storage ring activities at GSI
Source title: Physica Scripta T
Affiliations: Gesell. fur Schwerionenforsch. GSI, Planckstr. 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bosch, F., Gesell. fur Schwerionenforsch. GSI, Planckstr. 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The paper gives an overview on a proposed major facility at GSI and its main scientific aims. By means of innovative accelerators and storage-cooler rings, high-energy beams of all elements as well as rare isotope- and antiproton beams of unprecedented intensity and quality can be provided. There with long-standing questions in different fields of physics can be addressed, most of them related to the basic structure of hadronic matter, such as: nuclear structure far from stability; explosive stellar nucleosynthesis; fundamental symmetries, in particular of weak interaction; origin of hadronic mass; restoration of chiral symmetry; quark deconfinement at high density; plasmas under extreme conditions; strong-field atomic physics. A unique feature of the new facility is that different research programs can be performed to a large extent in truly parallel operation.
Index Keywords: Nuclear physics; Plasma applications; Storage rings; Antiproton beams; High energy physics

Uppsala, Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: Recently GSI presented the plans for a major new international research facility [http://www.gsi.de/GSI-future/]. Highly luminous secondary beams with excellent quality encompassing the production of antiprotons will be delivered. In a High Energy Storage Ring (HESR) with a bending power of 50 Tm antiprotons will be cooled either stochastically or by electrons. The envisaged limits are a momentum range of 1.5 to 15GeV/c and a luminosity of 2 * 10 32cm-2s-1. Four major physical research goals can be addressed: high precision charmonium spectroscopy, medium effects of open and hidden charm, the search for glueballs and hybrids, and the production of hypernuclei.

Authors: Egelhof P., Kisselev O., Müzenberg G., Neumaier S.R., Weick H.
Title: Nuclear structure studies by direct reaction experiments with stored radioactive beams
Source title: Physica Scripta T
Affiliations: Gesell. Schwerionenforsch. (GSI), D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Egelhof, P., Gesell. Schwerionenforsch. (GSI), D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Kisselev, O., Gesell. Schwerionenforsch. (GSI), D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Müzenberg, G., Gesell. Schwerionenforsch. (GSI), D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Neumaier, S.R., Gesell. Schwerionenforsch. (GSI), D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Weick, H., Gesell. Schwerionenforsch. (GSI), D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The experimental conditions at the next generation facilities for stored radioactive ion beams presently proposed or under construction will provide unique opportunities for nuclear structure studies on nuclei far off stability and will enable to explore completely new and unknown regions in the chart of nuclides. In particular, the predicted luminosities will allow for the investigation of direct reactions with stored and cooled radioactive beams in inverse kinematics using internal H, He, etc. targets. Such light-ion induced direct reactions, as for example elastic and inelastic scattering, transfer, charge exchange, or knock-out reactions, have been proved in the past, for the case of stable nuclei, to be powerful, tools for obtaining nuclear structure information, and were also applied within the last decade for the investigation of light exotic nuclei with radioactive beams bombarding external targets. A brief overview on the physics program planned at the future NESR storage ring at GSI, the physics questions to be addressed, the dedicated reactions to be used, and the regions of interest in the chart of nuclides is given. The advantage of using stored beams and internal targets for such investigations will depend on the specific exotic nuclei and reactions chosen. This is discussed by a comparison of the conditions for the application of internal and external targets for reaction experiments with exotic beams. For the special case of elastic proton scattering at intermediate energies a feasibility study is presented, including a discussion of the experimental scenario. This method was applied recently for the investigation of nuclear matter distributions of the light neutron-rich halo nuclei 6.8He and 11Li using external targets. A few examples of the results are briefly discussed. The use of internal targets and stored beams will allow in future to extend such investigations to a wide range of medium heavy and heavy nuclei far off stability, and will therefore be one of the key reactions of the experimental program at the future NESR facility.
Index Keywords: Heavy ions; Inverse kinematics; Ion beams; Ion bombardment; Protons; Radioactive materials; Scattering; Storage rings; Nuclear structures; Nuclear physics

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Proceedings of the 5th international conference on nuclear physics at storage rings
Source title: Physica Scripta T
Abstract: The proceedings contains 39 papers from the 5th International conference on nuclear physics at storage rings. The topics discussed include: two-pion production in proton-proton collisions near threshold; protron induced deutron break-up with emission of a fast forward proton pair; studies of inelastic scattering of fast heavy ions; performance of the projectile fragmentation wall at CELSIUS storage ring; and method of measurement of cross sections of heavy nuclei fission induced by intermediate energy protons.

Inst. of Radiological Science, 4-9-1, Anagawa, Inage-ku, Chiba-shi 263-8555, Japan; Tanabe, T., High Ener. Accel. Res. Organisation, Oho, Tsukuba 305-0801, Japan
Abstract: The application of an electrostatic ring for storage of ions with energies of several tens of keV is attractive for atomic and molecular science. The main goal of the KEK electrostatic ring is the storage of bio-molecular ions with atomic numbers of A ≈ 1000-10,000. An electron-beam cooler/target was installed in the KEK electrostatic ring for electron cooling and studying of electron-ion collisions. In accordance with simulations application of an electron cooler permits one to suppress multiple scattering of the stored ions with the residual gas atoms and thereby to increase the ion lifetime several times.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Cooling; Electrons; Electrostatic accelerators; Electron cooling; Storage rings

Authors: Steck M., Beckert K., Beller P., Franczak B., Franzke B., Nolden F., Popp U., Schwinn A.
Title: Recent results from ESR
Source title: Physica Scripta T
Affiliations: GSI, Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Steck, M., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Beckert, K., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Beller, P., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Franczak, B., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Franzke, B., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Nolden, F., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Popp, U., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Schwinn, A., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The ESR storage ring has been designed for high resolution and high precision experiments with highly charged ions, both stable and radioactive species. Stochastic and electron cooling provide fast and powerful cooling for the preparation of cold ion beams. For small ion beam intensities beams of unprecedented quality can be obtained by electron cooling. The internal gas jet target allows operation with a variety of gases. The highly charged ions can be decelerated to reduce the resolution limitation originating from Doppler effects. The decelerated ions are either used for internal experiments or extracted to a fixed target area with an ultraslow extraction mode. For the determination of the masses of radioactive nuclei two methods have been developed. Schottky mass spectrometry of cooled ions with nuclear lifetimes of the order of seconds or longer allows mass measurements by determination of the revolution frequency from the Schottky noise with a mass resolution of 1 ppm. Tuning of the focusing structure of the storage ring to the transition energy of 344 MeV/u is applied to measure the masses of short-lived nuclei by a time of flight method.
Index Keywords: Doppler effect; Electrons; Ion beams; Mass spectrometry; Shot noise; Storage rings; Radioactive nuclei; Paramagnetic resonance

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Recognition for excellence
Source title: Electrical World
Abstract: The benefits and the need for natural gas cogeneration plants for electric power supply industry is discussed. It is found that natural gas cogeneration plant is an energy sufficient technology that allows energy consumers to meet their business needs without compromising the environment. The environmental performance of these cogeneration plants is well under emission standards required by the Environmental Protection Authority (EPA). Besides environmental benefits the cogeneration plant reduces energy costs and improves the quality and reliability of electricity supply.

(EDMI) (CO); Regional utility management systems (RUMS); Remote monitoring; Cogeneration plants

Authors: Ellis R.
Title: Industrial facilities commissioning
Source title: Engineered Systems
Affiliations: Sebesta Blomberg and Associates, Minneapolis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ellis, R., Sebesta Blomberg and Associates, Minneapolis, United States
Abstract: Commissioning plays a vital role in bringing about significant developments in industrial projects. Developing the design intent document for an industrial facility involves understanding the requirements of the equipment used in the production process, and as such, the role of compressed air, steam, exhaust, and humidity control systems may be of primary importance. Energy reduction opportunities typically revolve around occupancy patterns in commercial and institutional facilities, while energy reduction opportunities in industrial facilities revolve around the production schedule. However, in either case, the importance of commissioning those strategies cannot be emphasized enough to realize the benefits of including the energy conservation measures in a project. The design intent goals also are well defined during the conceptual/product development stage of any new project, which include customized definitions of quality, certain measurement tolerances, and rate of production.
Index Keywords: Design intent; Development stages; Energy conservation measures; Energy reductions; Humidity control systems; Industrial facilities; Industrial projects; Production processes; Production Scheduling; Rate of production; Atmospheric humidity; Cold storage; Compressed air; Conservation; Energy conservation; Energy management; Energy policy; Fluid mechanics; Humidity control; Pressure vessels; Process engineering; Control systems

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Italy to join international partnership for the hydrogen economy
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Following a meeting with Italy's minister of productive activities, Antonio Marzano, US energy secretary Spencer Abraham has welcomed Italy's intention to join the International Partnership for the Hydrogen Economy (IPHE). The IPHE aims to coordinate global hydrogen and fuel cell technology research, development, and demonstration activities. International cooperation is key to achieving hydrogen and fuel cell program goals. The Italian government has a well developed R&D program addressing hydrogen and fuel cell technology applications in transportation and electric utilities. The IPHE will support the deployment of hydrogen energy technologies, establishing collaborative efforts in hydrogen production, storage, transport and end-use technologies; common codes and standards for hydrogen fuel utilization; and sharing of information necessary to develop a hydrogen fueling infrastructure.

Authors: Harte A.
Title: Melding hope and high tech
Source title: American Forests
Authors with affiliations: Harte, A.
Abstract: The New Jersey tree foundation (NJTF) is cooperating with Hopeworks to study the city's existing tree cover. The project help NJTF and the Camden Public Housing Authority find the most suitable locations for trees while quantifying the air quality, energy conversation and water storage benefits provided by the exixting tree canopy. Engaging more that 400 at-risk youth, the nonprofit has completed more than 30 major munciple geographic information systems (GIS) projects. With this data layer in its portfolio, the contracts keep pouring in. And so do the the city's youth, looking for scant opportunities in a city with a high school dropout rate of 70 percent and more than half its residents below the poverty line.
Index Keywords: Poverty lines; Skateboarding; Tree canopy; Computer software; Energy conversion; Geographic information systems; Project management; Societies and institutions; Websites; Forestry; Computer Programs; Energy Conservation; GIS; Organizations; Planing; Trees

Authors: Mackey S.
Title: A strategy for storage
Source title: Computer Bulletin (London, 1986)
Affiliations: ADIC, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mackey, S., ADIC, United Kingdom
Abstract: The issues involved with data storage, including data loss due to hardware failure and system insecurity, are discussed. Organizations need to develop a comprehensive strategy for data storage for addressing the issues. The data storage strategy should involve balancing a broad range of considerations, including reliability, serviceability, space, accessing speed and costs. Power consumption and maintenance are two major cost centers for a data storage device as well as the capital purchase.

Affiliations: EPRI-PEAC Corp., United States
Authors with affiliations: McGranaghan, M., EPRI-PEAC Corp., United States
Abstract: Since a large portion of power supply systems experiences a voltage sag whenever a fault occurs, voltage sags are much more common than actual interruptions. Thus, it is important to understand the sensitivity of the equipment to voltage sags and the options available for protecting the equipment and systems. With the interconnected nature of many industrial processes, even if a voltage sag affects just one piece of equipment, it may affect a whole manufacturing process.
Index Keywords: Distribution voltage restorer; Voltage sags; Electric circuit breakers; Electric energy storage; Electric equipment protection; Electric power distribution; Electric power plant loads; Electric power transmission; Outages; Process control; Programmable logic controllers; Short circuit currents; Uninterruptible power systems; Electric breakdown

Authors: Farrauto R.J.
Title: Catalysts for the hydrogen economy
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Engelhard Corporation, 101 Wood Avenue, Iselin, NJ 08830, United States
Authors with affiliations: Farrauto, R.J., Engelhard Corporation, 101 Wood Avenue, Iselin, NJ 08830, United States
Abstract: Pollution emissions from mobile sources have been controlled for the last 30 yr by monolithic catalysts in the exhaust system. The catalysts enhance the rate of conversion of unburned CO, hydrocarbon, and NOx to harmless products. The problem of limited energy supply, generation of primary pollutants and green house gases is raising the importance of a hydrogen economy and the need to study alternative means of power generation from reliable and ideally renewable sources of fuel. The most highly visible fuel cell applications are for vehicles. Most automobile companies have abandoned the concept of generating hydrogen on-board from gasoline in favor of hydrogen storage. An early market for proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells would be residential or distributed power for homes. The concept is to reform natural gas or LPG in the home to provide H2 for the anode of the PEM fuel cell. The principles of the PEM fuel cell and the unit operations for the catalytic generation of hydrogen from fossil fuels are described.

Authors: Wu Y., Brady J.C., Kelly M.T., Ortega J.V., Snover J.L.
Title: Synthesis of sodium borohydride for energy applications
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Millennium Cell Inc., 1 Industrial Way West, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, Y., Millennium Cell Inc., 1 Industrial Way West, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States; Brady, J.C., Millennium Cell Inc., 1 Industrial Way West, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States; Kelly, M.T., Millennium Cell Inc., 1 Industrial Way West, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States; Ortega, J.V., Millennium Cell Inc., 1 Industrial Way West, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States; Snover, J.L., Millennium Cell Inc., 1 Industrial Way West, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States
Abstract: The synthesis of NaBH4 was studied for energy applications, e.g., as a hydrogen storage material. Na2CO3 was used instead of NaOH. Yields were 6-25%, with higher concentration Na2CO3 and greater ratio of Na2CO3 to B2H6 giving rise to higher yields. The technique of ball-milling was then employed to study the direct interaction of the gaseous diborane and the solid Lewis bases. Using this method, higher yields of NaBH4 were achieved, from 15 to 65%. The yield was further increased by increasing B2H6 pressure within the reaction vessel.

Authors: Viswanathan B., Sankaran M., Ganesan R.
Title: Can Heteroatoms be the activators for hydrogen storage in carbon nanotubes?
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras 600036, India
Authors with affiliations: Viswanathan, B., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras 600036, India; Sankaran, M., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras 600036, India; Ganesan, R., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras 600036, India
Abstract: Various heteroatoms (N, P and S) were substituted at different positions of the cluster to study the influence of heteroatoms toward the activation of hydrogen. In the presence of heteroatoms, the dissociation energy of hydrogen molecule was considerably decreased compared to that of pure carbon nanotubes. To understand the role of hetero atoms in hydrogen activation in carbon nanotubes, the calculations were performed to estimate the value of activation energy value of each of the steps of hydrogen activation and migration within the framework of Transition state theory.

Authors: Cosgriff L.M., Baaklini G.Y.
Title: Ultrasonic Spectroscopy of Composite Rings for Space Station Flywheel Rotors
Source title: Materials Evaluation
Affiliations: Cleveland State University, NASA Glenn Research Center, MS 6-1, 21000 Brookpark Rd., Cleveland, OH 44115, United States; Natl. Aero./Space Administration, Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cosgriff, L.M., Cleveland State University, NASA Glenn Research Center, MS 6-1, 21000 Brookpark Rd., Cleveland, OH 44115, United States; Baaklini, G.Y., Natl. Aero./Space Administration, Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: Flywheel energy storage devices consisting of multiple layered composite materials are being studied extensively for utilization in the International Space Station, These composite material systems were investigated with a recently developed ultrasonic spectroscopy technique. The system employs a swept frequency approach and performs a fast Fourier transform on the frequency spectrum of the response signal. In addition, the system allows for equalization of the frequency spectrum, providing all frequencies with equal amounts of energy to excite higher order resonant harmonics. Interpretation of the second fast Fourier transform, along with equalization of the frequency spectrum, offers greater assurance in acquiring and analyzing the fundamental frequency or spectrum resonance spacing. The system can sweep a range of frequencies from an audible range up to 8 MHz, depending on the material and geometry of the component. Single and multiple layered material samples, with and without known discontinuities, were tested to determine how the constituents of a composite material ring system affect the resonant frequency.
Author Keywords: Flywheel rotors; Nondestructive testing; Polymer matrix composite material; Resonance; Ultrasonic spectroscopy
Index Keywords: Flywheels; Nondestructive examination; Resonance; Rotors; Space stations; Spectroscopic analysis; Ultrasonics; Composite rings; Rings (components)

Authors: Baboescu F., Singh S., Varghese G.
Title: Packet classification for core routers: Is there an alternative to CAMs?
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE INFOCOM
Affiliations: Comp. Sci./Engineering Department, Univ. California, San Diego (UCSD), San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baboescu, F., Comp. Sci./Engineering Department, Univ. California, San Diego (UCSD), San Diego, CA, United States; Singh, S., Comp. Sci./Engineering Department, Univ. California, San Diego (UCSD), San Diego, CA, United States; Varghese, G., Comp. Sci./Engineering Department, Univ. California, San Diego (UCSD), San Diego, CA, United States
Abstract: A classifier consists of a set of rules for classifying packets based on header fields. Because core routers can have fairly large (e.g., 2000 rule) database and must use limited SRAM to meet OC-768 speeds, the best existing classification algorithms (RFC, HiCuts, ABV) are precluded because of the large amount of memory they need. Thus the general belief is that hardware solutions like CAMs are needed, despite the amount of board area and power they consume. In this paper, we provide an alternative to CAMs via an Extended Grid-of-Tries with Path Compression (EGT-PC) algorithm whose worst-case speed scales well with database size while using a minimal amount of memory. Our evaluation is based on real databases used by Tier 1 ISPs, and synthetic databases. EGT-PC is based on a observation that we found holds for all the Tier 1 databases we studied: regardless of database size, any packet matches only a small number of distinct source-destination prefix pairs. The code we wrote for EGT-PC, RFC, HiCuts, and ABV is publicly available, providing the first publicly available code to encourage experimentation with classification algorithms.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Classification (of information); Database systems; Energy utilization; Packet networks; Quality of service; Routers; Static random access storage; Cams; Codes (symbols); Hardware; Path compressions; Associative storage; Classification algorithm; Core routers; Database size; Hardware solutions; Packet classification; Path compression; Prefix-pair; Real database; Set of rules; Synthetic database

Authors: Zane F., Narlikar G., Basu A.
Title: CoolCAMs: Power-efficient TCAMs for forwarding engines
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE INFOCOM
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Lucent Technologies, 700 Mountain Ave, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zane, F., Bell Laboratories, Lucent Technologies, 700 Mountain Ave, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Narlikar, G., Bell Laboratories, Lucent Technologies, 700 Mountain Ave, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Basu, A., Bell Laboratories, Lucent Technologies, 700 Mountain Ave, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Abstract: Ternary Content-Addressable Memories (TCAMs) are becoming very popular for designing high-throughput forwarding engines on routers: they are fast, cost-effective and simple to manage. However, a major drawback of TCAMs is their high power consumption. This paper presents architectures and algorithms for making TCAM-based routing tables more power efficient. The proposed architectures and algorithms are simple to implement, use commodity TCAMs, and provide worst-case power consumption guarantees (independent of routing table contents).

Title: 13-kV rectifiers: Studies on diodes and asymmetric thyristors

Abstract: For rectifiers with high blocking voltages, the application of field stop layers reduces power losses. Preliminary experimental results are presented from asymmetric 13-kV thyristor samples based on a conventional field stop concept. By connecting a 13-kV diode in series to this asymmetric thyristor, a symmetricallyblocking tandem device can be built. Numerical studies show that the turn-off behavior of the 13kV diode required for the tandem solution can be significantly improved by a new field stop concept based on an n layer buried in the weakly-doped region of the P+-n--n+ power diode.
Index Keywords: Current voltage characteristics; Diodes; Electric losses; Energy storage; Thyristors; High-voltage diodes; Electric rectifiers

Authors with affiliations: McDaniel, F.D., Ion Beam Materials Research Laboratory, Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM  87185-1056, United States, Ion Beam Modification and Analysis Laboratory, Dept. of Physics, University of North Texas, PO Box 311427, Denton, TX  76203-1427, United States; Doyle, B.L., Ion Beam Materials Research Laboratory, Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM  87185-1056, United States; Vizkelethy, G., Ion Beam Materials Research Laboratory, Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM  87185-1056, United States; Dodd, P.E., Ion Beam Materials Research Laboratory, Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM  87185-1056, United States; Rossi, P., Ion Beam Materials Research Laboratory, Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM  87185-1056, United States, University of Padova, via Marzolo 8, Padova, 35131, Italy, INFN, via Marzolo 8, Padova, 35131, Italy
Abstract: Electronics in spacecraft and satellites are exposed to high-energy cosmic radiation. In addition, terrestrial radiation can also affect earth-based electronics. To study the effects of radiation upon integrated circuits and to insure the reliability of electronic devices, cosmic and terrestrial radiations are simulated with ion beams from particle accelerators. A new, higher Linear Energy Transfer (LET) acceleration system for heavy ions has been developed at Sandia National Laboratories. Heavy ions from a 6.5 MV EN tandem Van de Graaff accelerator at 0.25 MeV/amu are injected into a two-stage Radio Frequency Quadrupole (RFQ) linac, which accelerates the ions to 1.9 MeV/amu. These ions together with those from the Brookhaven National Laboratory MP Tandem have been used to measure single event upset (SEU) cross sections as a function of LET for both bulk and Silicon on Insulator (SOI) Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor, Static Random Access Memories. The magnitudes of these cross sections indicate that the upsets in both the SOI and bulk parts are caused by OFF-drain strikes. © 2003 American Institute of Physics.

Abstract: Recent improvements to the synchrotron ultraviolet radiation facility led to unprecedented performance. High injection currents and beam stability, as well as tunable electron energies over a wide range make this storage ring a prime source for synchrotron radiation from the extreme-ultraviolet to far-infrared spectral regions. We will discuss plans to capitalize on this unprecedented performance through implementation of new experimental stations and extension of existing ones. It also will be shown that for applications using extreme-ultraviolet to infrared synchrotron radiation a low electron energy storage ring has distinct advantages. © 2003 American Institute of Physics.
