Abstract: The proceedings contain 262 papers. The topics discussed include: target and projectile K-vacancy production by fast heavy ions in the molecular orbital regime; high resolution study of the K X-ray spectra of 3D transition elements induced in collisions with fast heavy ions; doubly-excited KLL states formed in triple electron capture; secondary electron production and transport induced by fast protons in thin foils; excitation-ionization of helium in high energy collisions; transfer ionization in MeV p-He collisions studied by pulsed recoil-ion-momentum spectroscopy in a storage ring/gas target experiment; and bond-rearrangement in water ionized by fast ion impact.

Authors: Zhang Y., Possnert G., Whitlow H.J.
Title: Application of Time of Flight-Energy Elastic Recoil Detection for Information-Storage Media Analysis
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Division of Ion Physics, Ångström Laboratory, Uppsala, Sweden; Division of Nuclear Physics, Lund Institute of Technology, Lund, Sweden; School of Technology and Society, Malmö Högskola, Malmö, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Y., Division of Ion Physics, Ångström Laboratory, Uppsala, Sweden; Possnert, G., Division of Ion Physics, Ångström Laboratory, Uppsala, Sweden; Whitlow, H.J., Division of Nuclear Physics, Lund Institute of Technology, Lund, Sweden, School of Technology and Society, Malmö Högskola, Malmö, Sweden
Abstract: The challenge of meeting the ever-increasing demands for elemental profile information with high sensitivity and improved depth resolution has prompted development of sophisticated ion beam analysis methods, including elastic recoil detection analysis (ERDA). In combination with a time of flight (ToF) spectrometry, ToF-E (energy) ERDA has been widely employed as a powerful material analysis tool in a broad range of applications. Thin-film media for magnetic and optical information storage represents one of the most difficult classes of material from an ion beam analysis viewpoint. The suitability of ToF-E ERDA to analyze commercial hard disc, CD-ROM and CD-RW structures has been investigated. A complex Co/Cr/Ni-P/Al multilayer structure taken from a standard hard disc and up to 8 elements in CD samples could be distinguished simultaneously. The results demonstrate the unique power of this technique for characterizing the composition and depth profile of the multi-layers as well as the ingress and influence of foreign species. © 2003 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Film preparation; Industrial research; Ion beams; Magnetic storage; Elastic recoil detection; Elastic recoil detection analysis; Elemental profile; Ion beam analysis; Material analysis; Multilayer structures; Optical information; Time-of-flight spectrometry; Magnetic film storage

Title: High Resolution Recombination Measurements of Stored Ions
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, Alba Nova (SCFAB), Stockholm, SE106 91, Sweden; Department of Physics and Applied Physics, University of Strathclyde, Glasglow, G4 0NG, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Fogle, M., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, Alba Nova (SCFAB), Stockholm, SE106 91, Sweden; Badnell, N., Department of Physics and Applied Physics, University of Strathclyde, Glasglow, G4 0NG, United Kingdom; Eklöw, N., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, Alba Nova (SCFAB), Stockholm, SE106 91, Sweden; Lindroth, E., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, Alba Nova (SCFAB), Stockholm, SE106 91, Sweden; Madzunkov, S., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, Alba Nova (SCFAB), Stockholm, SE106 91, Sweden; Mohamed, T., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, Alba Nova (SCFAB), Stockholm, SE106 91, Sweden; Schuch, R., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, Alba Nova (SCFAB), Stockholm, SE106 91, Sweden; Tokman, M., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, Alba Nova (SCFAB), Stockholm, SE106 91, Sweden
Abstract: The accuracy obtained in electron-ion recombination experiments at storage rings has reached a level which allows strenuous tests of theoretical models and the ability to derive accurate, and useful, information for applications such as plasma modeling and diagnostics. Here we present two such recombination experiments performed at the heavy ion storage ring CRYRING. First, we investigated the possibility to derive a temperature dependent plasma rate coefficient for Na-like Ni, which has been observed in emission lines from active solar regions and laboratory plasmas. Second, we determined the 2s1/2-2p1/2 energy splitting in Li-like Kr. Such a highly charged ion exhibits large QED contributions (∼1.5 eV) which are difficult to represent in theoretically calculations. The experimental value for the splitting was determined to within 8 meV while the theoretically determined value is only accurate to within 19 meV. © 2003 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Heavy ions; Storage rings; Electron-ion recombinations; Energy splittings; Experimental values; Heavy-ion storage ring; Highly charged ions; Laboratory plasma; Rate coefficients; Temperature dependent; Industrial research

We have refined the COLTRIMS (COLd Target Recoil-Ion-Momentum Spectroscopy) technique by applying time-varying fields in the recoil-ion-momentum spectrometer to block random singly charged helium ions from single-ionization events. © 2003 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Wang M.
Title: Quick takes: Hydrogen a transportation fuel (with reply)
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Affiliations: Center for Transportation Research, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Ill., United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, M., Center for Transportation Research, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Ill., United States
Abstract: Michael Wang of Center for Transportation Research in Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, made a comment on Tom Standing's letter "Making Hydrogen" (OGJ, 1/14/2003, page 10), which raised the issue that energy expenditure for hydrogen production needs to be taken into account in promoting hydrogen as a new transportation fuel. Contrary to Standing's simplistic energy calculations, those efforts produced detailed, thorough evaluation of hydrogen's energy and emission effects on a total life-cycle basis including energy feedstock production, hydrogen production, hydrogen distribution and storage, and hydrogen use in fuel-cell vehicles. One examples in the joint study by Argonne national Laboratory, GM, and several energy companies. A response to Michael Wang's letter was also presented, describing Argonne's conclusion regarding electrolysis of water as a poor choice for producing hydrogen.

Authors: Clark J.
Title: Buckyballs and all
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Authors with affiliations: Clark, J.
Abstract: According to Chevron Texaco Corp, its Energy research & Technology Co in Richmond, CA, had discovered a new class of molecular building blocks in December 2002 called "high diamondoids" Found in petroleum, these nanometer-sized carbon-based materials may be instrumental in advancing the field of nanotechnology. Another major oil company, ConocoPhillips, invested in February 2002 capital and intellectual property rights in SouthWest NanoTechnologies Inc, which enabled SouthWest to begin construction of a pilot plant to manufacture its "CoMoCAT" single-wall carbon nanotubes at a cost low enough to accelerate their commercialization. Altair Nanotechnolgies Inc also reported in August 2003 that Telecordia Technologies, using Altair's nanomaterials, has developed battery proto-types based on Altair's nano-sized lithium titanate spinel. The proto-type, developed for use in hybrid automobiles, exceeds DOE' standards for battery-specific energy storage and power delivery at 95% efficiency.

Authors: Schupbach R.M., Balda J.C., Zolot M., Kramer B.
Title: Design methodology of a combined battery-ultracapacitor energy storage unit for vehicle power management
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States; Ctr. for Transportation Technologies, Syst. Natl. Renewable Ener. Lab., Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schupbach, R.M., University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States; Balda, J.C., University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States; Zolot, M., Ctr. for Transportation Technologies, Syst. Natl. Renewable Ener. Lab., Golden, CO, United States; Kramer, B., Ctr. for Transportation Technologies, Syst. Natl. Renewable Ener. Lab., Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: Hybrid and Electric Vehicles (HEV, EV) require some form of energy storage in order to achieve load leveling or efficiently manage power flows, mainly when accelerating or decelerating. Traditionally, batteries have been used but recently ultracapacitors have become potential candidates for energy storage in HEV/EV applications. To this end, this paper first presents a methodology for determining whether an Energy Storage Unit (ESU) should consist of only batteries, only ultracapacitors or a combination of both. An example illustrates the feasibility of the proposed ideas. Finally, the paper concludes with a cost analysis of the different ESU alternatives.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Cost effectiveness; Electric batteries; Electric power measurement; Energy management; Power electronics; Systems analysis; Electric power management; Electric vehicles

Authors: Yuwen B., Jiang X., Zhu D.
Title: Structure optimization of the fuel cell powered electric drive system
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Yuwen, B., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China; Jiang, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China; Zhu, D., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China
Abstract: In this paper, an optimized structure of the Fuel Cells (FCs) powered electric drive system is proposed. In this structure the super capacitor is used to not only absorb the feedback energy of the motor but also store the unwanted output power of the FCs. So the power loss of the drive system will be reduced to minimum. The super capacitor also is used to smooth the power output of the FCs. So the FCs can operation more efficiently. By proper control strategy the total efficiency of the drive system will be greatly improved. The system performance is simulated using MATLAB®/SIMULINK and will be validated experimentally.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Computer simulation; Electric drives; Electric motors; Electric vehicles; Energy storage; Super capacitors; Fuel cells

Authors: Aeloiza E.C., Enjeti P.N., Morán L.A., Pitel I.
Title: Next generation distribution transformer: To address power quality for critical loads
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Concepción, Casilla 53-C, Concepción, Chile; Magna-Power Electronics, Inc., 81 Fulton Street, Boonton, NJ 07005, United States
Authors with affiliations: Aeloiza, E.C., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States; Enjeti, P.N., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States; Morán, L.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Concepción, Casilla 53-C, Concepción, Chile; Pitel, I., Magna-Power Electronics, Inc., 81 Fulton Street, Boonton, NJ 07005, United States
Abstract: In this paper a new single phase distribution transformer concept is proposed to improve power quality for critical loads. The secondary of the proposed transformer Is composed of two windings, one of them equipped with a power electronic ac-ac converter. With the choice of proper turns ratio and the design of the PWM ac-ac converter, the proposed transformer has the following capabilities: (a) can compensate for 50% voltage sag and swells (b) can continuously shape the output voltage to be sinusoidal (low THD) even when the input voltage is distorted (c) can disconnect the load rapidly under fault conditions. The proposed approach does not employ any energy storage devices, such as large capacitors or inductors. The PWM ac-ac converter consists of four switching devices (IGBT) and Is controlled with a four-step switching technique to achieve snubber-less operation. A design example is presented for a 480V/120V, 5 kVA transformer. Simulation results are discussed and experimental results on a 2kVA unit are presented.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric converters; Electric loads; Switching systems; Power quality; Electric transformers

Authors: Cárdenas R., Peña R., Clare J., Asher G.
Title: Power smoothing in a variable speed wind-diesel system
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: University of Magallanes, Department of Electrical Engineering, P.O. Box 113-D, Punta Arenas, Chile; University of Nottingham, Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., University Park, Nottingham NG7 2RD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Cárdenas, R., University of Magallanes, Department of Electrical Engineering, P.O. Box 113-D, Punta Arenas, Chile; Peña, R., University of Magallanes, Department of Electrical Engineering, P.O. Box 113-D, Punta Arenas, Chile; Clare, J., University of Nottingham, Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., University Park, Nottingham NG7 2RD, United Kingdom; Asher, G., University of Nottingham, Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., University Park, Nottingham NG7 2RD, United Kingdom
Abstract: In wind-diesel systems wind speed variations can produce frequent start/stop cycles of the diesel engine in response to periods of low wind speed. Consequently, an energy buffer is very important in these schemes to avoid unnecessary deterioration of the diesel engine. In this paper, control systems for the operation of a variable speed wind-diesel system, including power smoothing, are analyzed. The power smoothing system comprises a front-end converter, a flywheel energy store and a vector controlled induction machine. The wind energy conversion system comprises a variable speed wind turbine and back to back converters for interfacing the variable speed generator to the load. Control of the power smoothing system compensates for the effects of wind variation and load disturbances. The operation of the whole system including the wind turbine, front-end converter, control of active and reactive power supply is discussed as well as the vector control system of the induction machine driving the flywheel. Simulation results for the entire system for a number of operational conditions are presented. Experimental results are provided for the control of the flywheel energy store.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Diesel engines; Electric converters; Energy storage; Flywheel propulsion; Variable speed transmissions; Wind power; Wind-diesel system; Wind turbines

Authors: Wei L., Lipo T.A., Chan H.
Title: Robust voltage commutation of the conventional matrix converter
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53705, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wei, L., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53705, United States; Lipo, T.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53705, United States; Chan, H., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53705, United States
Abstract: The three-phase ac-ac converter termed the matrix converter can provide high quality input/output waveforms and adjustable input power factor without any large energy storage component. However, it has not yet found much acceptance in industry. The main reason is that it requires a complicated commutation scheme to prevent input side short circuits and output side open circuits. This paper develops a new voltage commutation scheme for the conventional matrix converter. One advantage of this scheme is that it provides robust voltage commutations for the converter without sacrificing the quality of the line side current waveforms. The second advantage is that it needs the least information from the system than any algorithm yet reported. It only detects the line side synchronization angle which can have detection errors within ±π/6 radians under unity input power factor to provide accurate commutation. The last advantage of this scheme is that it can provide easier shut down sequences for the system. Theoretical analysis, simulation and experimental results are provided to verify its effectiveness in the paper.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric commutation; Electric potential; Electric power factor; Energy storage; Synchronization; Waveform analysis; Matrix converters; Electric converters

Authors: Tolbert L.M., Xu Y., Chen J., Peng F.Z., Chiasson J.N.
Title: Application of compensators for non-periodic currents
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996-2100, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1226, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tolbert, L.M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996-2100, United States; Xu, Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996-2100, United States; Chen, J., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996-2100, United States; Peng, F.Z., Department of Electrical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1226, United States; Chiasson, J.N., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996-2100, United States
Abstract: Based on a new definition of non-active current/power, this paper presents the application of a parallel active filter for the compensation of non-periodic currents. Analysis of the compensation characteristics required for a variety of non-periodic currents such as those associated with arc furnaces is presented. In addition, the corresponding current rating and energy storage requirements of the compensator are also presented.
Author Keywords: Active filter; Arc furnace; Compensator; Non-active power; Non-periodic current
Index Keywords: Active filters; Energy storage; Furnaces; Power electronics; Non-periodic currents; Electric currents

Authors: Ruan X., Wei J., Xue Y.
Title: Three-level converters with the input and output sharing the ground
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Aero-Power Sci-tech Center, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing Univ. of Aero./Astronautics, Nanjing, 210016, Jiangsu Provice, China
Authors with affiliations: Ruan, X., Aero-Power Sci-tech Center, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing Univ. of Aero./Astronautics, Nanjing, 210016, Jiangsu Provice, China; Wei, J., Aero-Power Sci-tech Center, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing Univ. of Aero./Astronautics, Nanjing, 210016, Jiangsu Provice, China; Xue, Y., Aero-Power Sci-tech Center, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing Univ. of Aero./Astronautics, Nanjing, 210016, Jiangsu Provice, China
Abstract: The six non-isolated Three-Level (TL) converters proposed in [2] have two advantages: 1) the voltage stress of the switches is the half of that of their original converters; and 2) the energy-storage components such as inductances and capacitors can be reduced significantly. However, the applications are limited because the input and output do not share the ground. In this paper, these TL converters are modified so that the input shares the ground with the output, and in the meanwhile, all the advantages are remained. Buck TL converter is taken as the example to be verified by the experimental results.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric potential; Inductance; Voltage stress; Electric converters

Authors: LiJun, Cheng K.W.E., Xu D., Sutanto D.
Title: Multi-modular current-source based hybrid converter for SMES
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Institute of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China; Power Electronics Research Centre, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong SAR, Hong Kong

Abstract: A multi-modular current-source based hybrid converter mainly designed for superconducting magnetic energy storage system (SMES) is investigated in this paper. The converter consists of a four-module current source converter and one module of voltage source converter to reach high power rate and low harmonics. Circuit topology, control method and simulation results are given.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric current distribution; Electric network topology; Harmonic generation; Magnetic storage; Phase shift; Power converters; Superconducting devices; Voltage control; Voltage converters; Energy storage

Authors: Rocco T., Duke R.M., Round S.D.
Title: Development and control of an alkaline fuel cell power conditioner
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Canterbury, Canterbury, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Rocco, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Canterbury, Canterbury, New Zealand; Duke, R.M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Canterbury, Canterbury, New Zealand; Round, S.D., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Canterbury, Canterbury, New Zealand
Abstract: This paper presents the development of a prototype 400W alkaline fuel cell power conditioner. The power conditioner serves to boost the 4V DC produced by the fuel cell into 400V DC suitable for conversion to 230Vrms AC to power domestic loads. To compensate for the slow transient behaviour of the fuel cell a power flow buffer, incorporating supercapacitor energy storage has been developed which interfaces directly to the 400V DC bus. The result is a modular system where communication between system blocks is minimal and control is achieved by monitoring the 400V DC bus. Experimental measurements from the prototype system illustrate the performance of the system during load transient conditions. Several practical design issues of the power electronic converters designed to operate with high voltage transformation ratios are discussed in detail.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric potential; Power electronics; Power conditioners; Fuel cells

Authors: Choi W., Enjeti P., Howze J.W.
Title: Fuel cell powered UPS systems: Design considerations
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Pwr. Electron./Fuel Cell Pwr.-C.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Authors with affiliations: Choi, W., Pwr. Electron./Fuel Cell Pwr.-C.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Enjeti, P., Pwr. Electron./Fuel Cell Pwr.-C.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Howze, J.W., Pwr. Electron./Fuel Cell Pwr.-C.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Abstract: In this paper a 1-kVA fuel cell powered line-interactive UPS system employing modular (fuel cell & power converter) blocks is introduced. Two commercially available PEMFC Fuel Cell (25-39V, 500W) modules along with suitable DC/DC and DC/AC power electronic converter modules are employed. A Supercapacitor module is also employed to compensate for the instantaneous power fluctuations and overcome the slow dynamics of the fuel processor such as reformers. Further energy stored in the supercapacitor is also utilized to handle a momentary overload such as 200% for a short duration. Due to the absence of batteries, the system satisfies the demand for an environmentally friendly clean source of energy. A complete design example illustrating the amount of hydrogen storage required for 1hr power outage, and sizing of supercapacitors for transient load demand is presented for a 1kVA UPS. Simulation and experimental results show the validity and feasibility of the 1kVA fuel cell power plant.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric energy storage; Power converters; Power electronics; Systems analysis; Uninterruptible power systems; Supercapacitors; Fuel cells

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Market hotline: US gas market a two-headed Ilama?
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: The price increase for natural gas in 2003 stemmed largely from a DOE report that injection into storage totaled 74 bcf. There were several factors contributing to the general uncertainty over the direction of natural gas storage injection. The falloff in storage injection at the first of the month came amid indications of increased fuel-switching to gas from oil, a return to more-normal temperatures, and a consequent surge in US electricity demand of 2%. According to Ron Denhardt of Strategic Energy & Economic Research Inc, the 74 bcf injection indicated that 1-1.5 bcf/day of demand had returned as a result of lower gas prices. While the year-on-year storage deficit has fallen sharply in recent months, it remained 234 bcf below the previous 5 yr avg with the latest injection report.

Authors: Ramachandran A., Jacome M.F.
Title: Xtream-Fit: An energy-delay efficient data memory subsystem for embedded media processing
Source title: Proceedings - Design Automation Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ramachandran, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, United States; Jacome, M.F., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, United States
Abstract: In this paper we propose a novel special-purpose data memory subsystem, called Xtream-Fit, aimed at achieving high energy-delay efficiency for streaming media applications. A key novelty of Xtream-Fit is that it exposes a single customization parameter, thus enabling a very simple and yet effective design space exploration methodology. A second key contribution of this work is the ability to achieve very high energy-delay efficiency through a synergistic combination of: (1) special purpose memory subsystem components, namely, a Streaming Memory and Scratch-Pad Memory; and (2) a novel task-based execution model that exposes/enhances opportunities for efficient prefetching, and aggressive dynamic energy conservation techniques targeting on-chip and off-chip memory components. Extensive experimental results show that Xtream-Fit reduces energy-delay product by 46% to 83%, as compared to general-purpose memory subsystems enhanced with state of the art Cache Decay and SDRAM power mode control policies.
Author Keywords: Configurability; Design space exploration; Energy delay product; Low power; Media processing; Scratch-pad; Streaming memory
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Dynamic random access storage; Energy efficiency; Microprocessor chips; Embedded media processing; Embedded systems

Authors: Pierce J.
Title: Staying cool by getting plastered
Source title: Engineer
Authors with affiliations: Pierce, J.
Abstract: The article discusses that a paraffin-based wall coating material will prevent heat build-up in modern homes and offices, making them more pleasant places in which to live and work. The material, developed by the Fraunhofer Institute for Solar Energy Systems (ISE) with the help of chemicals firm BASF, consists of micro-balls of paraffin distributed within wall plaster. The material is designed to improve temperature control in modern buildings that have thin walls made of lightweight materials.
Index Keywords: Thermal energy; Coatings; Heat storage; Light weight building materials; Plaster; Solar energy; Temperature control; Paraffins

Authors: Excell J.
Title: Smooth sensation
Source title: Engineer
Authors with affiliations: Excell, J.
Abstract: A new sensing technology has been developed which is an invaluable tool in the semiconductor industry. The Scanning Contact Potential Difference Sensor (CPD) can detect small changes on a range of surfaces. CPD provides a high quality of information and senses geometrical as well as chemical changes over a moving surface, in a high-speed non-contact manner.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Computer software; Digital storage; Electric currents; Electric potential; Electrons; Energy absorption; Machine tools; Real time systems; Surface phenomena; Vibrations (mechanical); Scanning contact potential difference sensors (CPD); Sensors

Authors: Glushko E.Ya., Legusha S.L., Zakhidov A.
Title: Electromagnetic field structure and quenching in one-dimensional photonic crystals
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Institute of Semiconductor Physics, NAS of Ukraine, Nauki Prosp., Kiev, Ukraine; Pedagogical University, Gagarin Avenue 54, 50086 Krivoy Rog, Ukraine; University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX 75083-0688, United States
Authors with affiliations: Glushko, E.Ya., Institute of Semiconductor Physics, NAS of Ukraine, Nauki Prosp., Kiev, Ukraine; Legusha, S.L., Pedagogical University, Gagarin Avenue 54, 50086 Krivoy Rog, Ukraine; Zakhidov, A., University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX 75083-0688, United States
Abstract: The study is devoted to closed and transferred electromagnetic field in one-dimensional both transparent photonic crystals and crystals containing layers which absorb irradiation alternated by transparent layers. General theory of irradiation closed inside the crystal is developed both in case transparent and adsorbing metallic photonic crystals in wide frequency range. True or absolute photonic gaps existing in the total reflection angle range are analyzed on the base of internal problem's analytical solution for 1D layered superlattices. We have investigated the frequency-angle diagrams for TM and TE photonic spectra trapped inside the whole reflection range for mesoscopic and macroscopic hierarchical 1D photonic crystals of varied topologies, geometry and materials. The effects of double refraction in binary multi-layered system and photon localization in finite periodic layered structures are investigated analytically and numerically. Energy storage and energy decay time in photonic crystals are considered with account for field amplitudes distribution inside the structure and angular band kinetics. The effect of sharp focusing of the butt-end emission for closed electromagnetic waves in 1D photonic crystals is discussed.
Author Keywords: Layered structures; Photon localization; Photonic band gap materials; Quenching; Trapped irradiation
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic fields; Irradiation; Quenching; Superlattices; Topology; Photonic crystals; Photons

Authors: Pei X.-D., Xia Y.-X., Huang H., Xie C.-S., Wang H.-W.
Title: Study on the near-field recording spot
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: National Storage System Lab., HUST, Wuhan 430074, China
Authors with affiliations: Pei, X.-D., National Storage System Lab., HUST, Wuhan 430074, China; Xia, Y.-X., National Storage System Lab., HUST, Wuhan 430074, China; Huang, H., National Storage System Lab., HUST, Wuhan 430074, China; Xie, C.-S., National Storage System Lab., HUST, Wuhan 430074, China; Wang, H.-W., National Storage System Lab., HUST, Wuhan 430074, China
Abstract: Evanescent energy can be used to get extremely small optical spots. For the data storage applications, optical near field is defined in terms of Evanescent coupling between the system used to read or write data and recording layer. Near-field techniques can be applied to optical data storage systems to greatly increase recording density. So near-field recording technique has great potential in optical disc recording system and hybrid recording system. The characteristic of near-field recording spot is of vital importance in the data storage system basing the near-field theory, so it is absolutely necessary to be analyzed and measured. This paper analyses characteristic of near-field spots. The heat response time of the near field to overcome super paramagnetic effect is calculated basing the heat transfer theory. A novel measuring method for the diameter of near-field recording spot is also presented. Since the grain of the recording media is tiny enough, with the aid of atomic force microscope (AFM), near-field optical lithography can be accomplished, The diameter of near-field recording spot can be obtained by specifically designed computer either. So the relationship between the near-field recording spot diameter and the probe size of near-field recording system, the near field recording distance coupling between head and disc can be got.
Author Keywords: AFM; Evanescent energy; Near-field optical lithography; Near-field recording spot
Index Keywords: Atomic force microscopy; Optical data storage; Paramagnetism; Photolithography; Near-field recording spots; Optical recording

Authors: Jákli A., Chien L.-C., Krüerke D., Rauch S., Sawade H., Bault P., Heppke G., Fodor-Csorba K., Nair G.G.
Title: Light shutters and electro-optical storage devices from antiferroelectric liquid crystals of bent-shape molecules
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Liquid Crystal Institute, Kent State University, Kent, OH 44242, United States; Stranski-Institute, Technical University, Berlin, Germany; Res. Inst. Solid Stt. Phys./Optics, P.O. Box, 49, H-1525 Budapest, Hungary; Centre for Liquid Crystal Research, P.B. No. 1329, Bangalore 560013, India
Authors with affiliations: Jákli, A., Liquid Crystal Institute, Kent State University, Kent, OH 44242, United States, Res. Inst. Solid Stt. Phys./Optics, P.O. Box, 49, H-1525 Budapest, Hungary; Chien, L.-C., Liquid Crystal Institute, Kent State University, Kent, OH 44242, United States; Krüerke, D., Stranski-Institute, Technical University, Berlin, Germany; Rauch, S., Stranski-Institute, Technical University, Berlin, Germany; Sawade, H., Stranski-Institute, Technical University, Berlin, Germany; Bault, P., Stranski-Institute, Technical University, Berlin, Germany; Heppke, G., Stranski-Institute, Technical University, Berlin, Germany; Fodor-Csorba, K., Res. Inst. Solid Stt. Phys./Optics, P.O. Box, 49, H-1525 Budapest, Hungary; Nair, G.G., Centre for Liquid Crystal Research, P.B. No. 1329, Bangalore 560013, India
Abstract: Novel scattering-type displays using antiferroelectric smectic phases of liquid crystals of bent-shape molecules are reviewed and discussed. There can be two distinct states ("racemic" and "chiral") that work in opposite ways. The racemic structure is scattering in the OFF state and is optically clear under sufficiently large (E∼4-6V/μm) electric fields. The chiral structure is transparent at zero fields and scattering in the field ON state. These two structures may be reversibly interchanged implying their use in devices that consume energy only during switching from one stable state to the other. After summarizing the previous results on the film thickness, driving voltage and temperature dependences of the light shutters, new results will be presented on a banana smectic material, which has an optically isotropic transparent antiferroelectric OFF state. We show that the optically isotropic and transparent OFF state can be reversibly switched to birefringent and scattering ferroelectric states in less than hundred microseconds.
Author Keywords: 'Banana liquid crystals"; Antiferroelectric; Optically isotropic; Scattering display; Storage device
Index Keywords: Birefringence; Electrooptical devices; Ferroelectricity; Molecular dynamics; Optical data storage; Optical shutters; Scattering; Light shutters; Liquid crystals

Authors: Zheng W., Zhao L., Wang R., Xu Y.
Title: Study on growth and properties of a new holographic storage material - CE:Pr:LiNO3 crystal
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Sch. of Mat. Sci. and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China; Electric-optics Information Center, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China
Authors with affiliations: Zheng, W., Sch. of Mat. Sci. and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China; Zhao, L., Sch. of Mat. Sci. and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China; Wang, R., Electric-optics Information Center, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China; Xu, Y., Electric-optics Information Center, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China
Abstract: Pr:LiNbO3 crystal can be used in two-color gated storage process for its special energy- level structure. Compared with other crystals used as volume holographic storage media, it has a great merit that an image recording does not erase the recorded one in multiplex storage process. But its photorefractive effect appears weaker than other crystals in the same conditions. We doped photorefractive sensitizing element Ce into Pr:LibNO3 to get Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 crystal with Czochralski method. The structure of crystals has been determined by X-ray powder diffraction method. The results indicate Pr:LiNbO3 and Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 keep the same structural characteristics as pure lithium niobate. In the absorption spectra of Pr:LiNbO3 and Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 samples with non-polarized light in wavelength of 300-900nm, the absorption edge of Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 shifts to the red compared with that of Pr:LiNbO3. The diffraction efficiency, writing time and especially erasing time of Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 have been measured. We find that maximum diffraction efficiency of Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 has increased without at cost of decreasing the erasing time. The effect of doping ions on the optical properties of Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 crystal as holographic recording media has been studied systematically.
Author Keywords: Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 crystal; Erasing; Holographic storage; Photorefractive
Index Keywords: Color; Crystal growth from melt; Electron energy levels; Holography; Light polarization; Photorefractive materials; Holographic storage; Lithium niobate

Authors: Wang J., Zhang Z., Wang R.
Title: Study on stoichiometric Ce:Mn:LiNbO3 crystal as a new nonvolatile holographic storage medium
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Authors with affiliations: Wang, J., Natl. Key Lab. Tunable Laser Tech., Institute of Opto-Electronics, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China; Zhang, Z., Natl. Key Lab. Abstract: Stoichiometric Ce:Mn:LiNbO3 crystal was grown by the TSSG method for the first time. The congruent Ce:Mn:LiNbO3 (CCe:Mn:LiNbO3) crystal was grown by the Czochralski method. The lattice constant was tested. The lattice constant of the Stoichiometric Ce:Mn:LiNbO3 (SCe:Mn:LiNbO3) crystal was less than that of CCe:Mn:LiNbO3 crystal. The absorption spectrum of the crystals was tested, the absorption edge of SCe:Mn:LiNbO3 crystal has violet shift comparing with that of CCe:Mn:LiNbO3 crystal. The exponential gain coefficient, the concentration of effective carrier, diffraction efficiency and response time were tested. Those properties of SCe:Mn:LiNbO3 crystal mentioned above have been improved. SCe:Mn:LiNbO3 crystal possesses the property of holographic storage for long.
Author Keywords: Ce:Mn:LiNbO3 crystal; Holographic storage; Lattice constant
Index Keywords: Crystal growth from melt; Diffraction; Energy absorption; Holographic optical elements; Lattice constants; Lithium niobate; Manganese; Nonvolatile storage; Stoichiometry; Holographic storage; Cerium

Authors: Zhou Y., Xu Z., Liu C., Wang R., Xu Y.
Title: Study on holographic storage thermal fixing of Ce:Fe:LiNbO3 crystal
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Technol. Center, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China
Abstract: Ce: Fe: LiNbO3 crystal co-doped with CeO2 and Fe2O3 is grown by Czochralski method with Si-C bars as heaters. The exponential gain coefficient, diffraction efficiency and respond time of Ce:Fe:LiNbO3 crystal are measured by two-wave-coupling technology. The results indicate that the exponential gain coefficient of Ce:Fe:LiNbO3 is up to 22cm-1 and the diffraction efficiency is 78% and the photorefractive effect is better than that of Fe:LiNbO3 crystal. A thermal fixing experiment is carried on the Ce:Fe:LiNbO3 crystal, which conditions are that the crystal is heated to 120°C, the activated energy and the developing efficiency of Ce:Fe:LiNbO3 crystal are measured, and the decay time of a fixed grating is up to 110 years at the room temperature (20 °C).
Author Keywords: Ce:Fe:LiNbO3 crystal; Holographic storage; Thermal fixing

Authors: Talmud P.J.
Title: APOA5—a recent addition to genes determining plasma triglycerides
Source title: International Congress Series
Affiliations: Division of Cardiovascular Genetics, British Heart Foundation Laboratories, Rayne Building, Department of Medicine, Royal Free and University College Medical School, 5 University Street, London WC1E 6JJ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Talmud, P.J., Division of Cardiovascular Genetics, British Heart Foundation Laboratories, Rayne Building, Department of Medicine, Royal Free and University College Medical School, 5 University Street, London WC1E 6JJ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Raised plasma triglyceride (TG) levels is an independent risk factor for coronary artery disease (CAD), thus, understanding the genetic and environmental determinants of TG levels is of major importance. TG metabolism is a process for delivering free fatty acids for energy storage or β-oxidation, involving a number of different hydrolytic enzymes and apolipoproteins (apo). The genes encoding these proteins are, therefore, candidates for determining plasma TGs. There is evidence that common variations in LPL, apo CIII (APOC3) and apo E (APOE) have the strong effect on plasma TG levels at the population level. More recently, the latest recognized member of the apolipoprotein gene family, APOA5, identified by comparative sequencing between human and mouse DNA, was located approximately 27 kb distal to APOA4 in the APOA1–C3–A4 gene cluster on chromosome 11q23, and variation in APOA5 was shown to be associated with plasma TG levels. The involvement of variation in the APOA1–C3–A4 locus in determining differences in lipid levels is well documented. We have examined the relative influence of APOA5 variants on plasma lipids, compared to the impact of variation in other genes within the cluster to determine if these effects are independent or a consequence of the strong linkage disequilibrium across the locus. © 2002 Elsevier Science B.V.
Author Keywords: Animal models; APOA1–C3–A4–A5 gene cluster; Triglycerides

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: In Brief: Disputed study on potential ozone impact of hydrogen leaks
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Leakage from a future hydrogen infrastructure could cause damage to the ozone layer, according to a recent, and hotly disputed, study from California Institute of Technology published in Science, which examined the potential effects of a future economy in which hydrogen is stored and shipped in place of natural gas, gasoline and other fuels. However, the group's findings were immediately disputed by a number of energy experts. According to the Schatz Energy Research Center at Humboldt State University in California, hydrogen losses from storage and pipelines should be much lower than the 10-20% assumed by CalTech, and in any case intentionally vented hydrogen could easily be destroyed by catalytic oxidation.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Hybrid systems
Source title: Plant Engineering (Barrington, Illinois)
Abstract: The advantages of hybrid natural gas and electric energy sources are discussed. By combining the best that both energy forms offer, hybrid systems can provide significant advantages. Hybrid gas/electric systems provide better energy efficiency, better emissions control and lower overall cost. Three hybrid applications that combined gas and electricity to produce systems that do their job better than could be done with either gas or electricity alone are also presented.
Index Keywords: Catalysts; Costs; Electricity; Energy efficiency; Infrared radiation; Magnetoelectric effects; Natural gas; Temperature control; Electric energy; Hybrid technology; On-site emissions; Process technologies; Electric energy storage

Authors: Zuercher J.
Title: What to expect from an air audit
Source title: Plant Engineering (Barrington, Illinois)
Affiliations: Air Science Engineering, Chandler, AZ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zuercher, J., Air Science Engineering, Chandler, AZ, United States
Abstract: Compressed air and vacuum audits which offer an opportunity to improve the productivity of plant while reducing operating costs, are discussed. In addition to lower energy costs, another benefits of having this system are improved plant or process productivity, higher product quality, reduced scrap rates and reduced maintenance costs. Fluctuating pressure and vacuum levels inside production equipment is a leading cause of limited production rates and scrap expense that goes unidentified in most plants. An audit must include all aspects of system operation consisting the compressor and pump room, distribution piping and storage, as well as the demand or production users of the system.
Index Keywords: Air audits; Cost reduction; Energy savings; Vacuum systems; Competition; Compressors; Cost effectiveness; Electric power systems; Energy utilization; Investments; Leak detection; Optimization; Plant management; Vacuum pumps; Compressed air

Authors: Rogers D.R.
Title: Gas 'interchangeability' and its effects on U.S import plans
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Affiliations: LNG Practice Group, Chadbourne and Parke LLP, Houston, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rogers, D.R., LNG Practice Group, Chadbourne and Parke LLP, Houston, TX, United States
Abstract: The US natural gas production levels decreased continuously for several years while domestic natural gas storage levels remained well below their historical low points. Liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports from vast but remote supply sources are likely to play an increasingly important role in supplying future US and Canadian natural gas supply requirements. The present role and impact on LNG can be observed primarily in the eastern US, where it plays an important role in satisfying regional energy requirements.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Enthalpy; Gas fuel storage; Natural gas transportation; Natural gas production; Liquefied natural gas

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Newsletter: Market movement: Gas futures price hits 7-month low
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Energy futures prices dropped on 7/22/2003 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with natural gas hitting a 7 mo low of $4.87/million cu ft as a tropical storm dissipated in the Carribean. As of 7/18/2003, US natural gas storage totaled 1.95 tcf, down 537 bcf from 2002 levels and 286 bcf below the 5-yr average. According to API, US oil inventories declined by 655,000 to little > 277 million bbl during the week ended 7/18/2003. US gasoline stocks dropped 1.1 million to 208.4 million bbl, while distillate inventories increased by 372,000 to 113.8 million bbl.

Authors: Pierce J.
Title: City lite
Source title: Engineer
Authors with affiliations: Pierce, J.
Abstract: Methods to increase the efficiency of urban delivery vehicles are discussed. To make best use of the stored electricity, the engine is designed to switch off instead of idling. The electromagnetic clutch is made from a rare earth magnetic coupling surrounding a conventional friction clutch, allowing for frequent, wear-free engine starting without clutch slip.
Index Keywords: Urban delivery vehicle; Air pollution; Electric drives; Energy storage; Magnetic couplings; Synchronous generators; Ground vehicles

Authors: Zhao W.W., Graca S.
Title: Evidence of Ti-related inclusions in an Al alloy interconnecting layer for nanometer 256Mbit DRAM semiconductor devices characterized by TEM, STEM, EELS elemental mapping, and XEDS linescan
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium - Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Technology Transfer, Infineon Technologies Richmond, 6000 Technology Blvd., Sandston, VA 23150, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhao, W.W., Department of Technology Transfer, Infineon Technologies Richmond, 6000 Technology Blvd., Sandston, VA 23150, United States; Graca, S., Department of Technology Transfer, Infineon Technologies Richmond, 6000 Technology Blvd., Sandston, VA 23150, United States
Abstract: With the introduction of high aspect ratio and steep geometries in deep-subquarter-micron dynamic random access memory (DRAM) device, it becomes more and more critical to understand the formation of undesired intermetallic Ti-Al phases in Al-metallization and thus better-control the profile of interconnectors. In this article, Ti-related inclusions in Metal 1 (M1) interconnecting layer (an AlCu-0.5% alloy) originated from the bottom Ti liner were characterized with an Analytical TEM. Samples were cleaved from nanometer 256Mbit dynamic random access memory DRAM devices. The TEM employed is a JEOL 2010F with a field emission gun (PEG) and running at 200KV acceleration voltage. Correlations among transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) elemental mapping, and x-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (XEDS) elemental linescan were established. The results here not only provide important feedbacks to semiconductor product integration and optimization, but also demonstrate the full-functionality of the start-of-the-art analytical TEM in investigations of nanometer semiconductor devices.
Author Keywords: DRAM; Dynamic random access memory; EDS; Elemental mapping; Energy loss electron spectroscopy EELS; Linescan; Scanning transmission electron microscopy STEM; Semiconductor; TEM; Transmission electron microscopy

Authors: Kroutvar M., Ducommun Y., Finley J.J., Bichler M., Abstreiter G., Zrenner A.
Title: Wavelength selective charge storage in self-assembled InGaAs-GaAs quantum dots
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium - Proceedings
Affiliations: Walter Schottky Institut, Technische Universitat Munchen, D-85748, Garching, Germany; University Paderborn, FB6, Warburger Str. 100, 33098 Paderborn, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kroutvar, M., Walter Schottky Institut, Technische Universitat Munchen, D-85748, Garching, Germany; Ducommun, Y., Walter Schottky Institut, Technische Universitat Munchen, D-85748, Garching, Germany; Finley, J.J., Walter Schottky Institut, Technische Universitat Munchen, D-85748, Garching, Germany; Bichler, M., Walter Schottky Institut, Technische Universitat Munchen, D-85748, Garching, Germany; Abstreiter, G., Walter Schottky Institut, Technische Universitat Munchen, D-85748, Garching, Germany; Zrenner, A., University Paderborn, FB6, Warburger Str. 100, 33098 Paderborn, Germany
Abstract: We present the first demonstration of spectrally selective charge storage in self-assembled quantum dots that utilizes optical charge generation and readout of the stored charge distribution. Resonant optical excitation charges only a sub-ensemble of the inhomogeneous broadened dots. The optical readout process directly recovers the spectral distribution of stored charges. Wavelength selectivity is demonstrated in a two-color experiment exhibiting charge storage in two independent QD sub-ensembles. Resonant charge storage is observed at least up to 85K depending on excitation energy. Lack of time evolution of the spectral emission indicates charge storage times Δt much longer than 25μs.
Index Keywords: Electric fields; Excitons; Self assembly; Semiconducting gallium arsenide; Semiconducting indium compounds; Optical charge generation; Optical readout processes; Resonant charge storage; Self-assembled quantum dots; Semiconductor quantum dots

Authors: Wu L.C., Shi J.J., Chen K.J., Xu J., Li W., Ma Z.Y., Dai M., Wu D., Li A.D., Huang X.F.
Title: New nanocrystalline Si floating gate structure for nonvolatile memory application
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium - Proceedings

Solid State Microstruct., Department of Physics, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, China; Huang, X.F., Natl. Lab. Solid State Microstruct., Department of Physics, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, China
Abstract: We report a direct experiment evidence for holes and electrons charging in a new nanocrystalline Si (nc-Si) floating gate structure (SiO2/nc-Si/SiO2/c-Si) fabricated in-situ by plasma oxidation and layer by layer deposition technique in a plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) system. In this nc-Si floating gate structures, the thickness of tunneling SiO2 layer is about 2 nm and the mean grain size of nc-Si is 6 nm obtained from Raman scattering and AFM measurements. The discrete quantum level and Coulomb charging energy for a single electron have been observed in large ensemble of nc-Si dots by frequency dependent capacitance spectroscopy, which demonstrates that the Coulomb blockade for electron in nc-Si dots is larger than size fluctuation effects on the quantum confinement for our nc-Si floating gate structure. Quantitatively, the experiment results of capacitance spectroscopy are in good agreement with the theoretical calculations. By contrasted with silicon single electron transistor memory made by using ultra fancy nanotechnology, nc-Si based memory can be fabricated with a minimum perturbation of conventional silicon technology and may be closet to industrial application.

Authors: Krishnan R., Krauss T.D., Fauchet P.M.
Title: Charge retention in single silicon nanocrystal layers
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical and Comp. Eng., University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States; Dept. of Chemistry, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States
Authors with affiliations: Krishnan, R., Dept. of Electrical and Comp. Eng., University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States; Krauss, T.D., Dept. of Chemistry, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States; Fauchet, P.M., Dept. of Electrical and Comp. Eng., University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States
Abstract: Silicon (Si) nanocrystals formed by controlled thermal crystallization of amorphous silicon dioxide (a-SiO2)/amorphous silicon (a-Si)/amorphous silicon dioxide (a-SiO2) layers hold considerable promise for application in non-volatile memory products and optoelectronic devices. The size of the nanocrystals is fixed by the thickness of the Si layer and strong quantum confinement is provided in the vertical (growth) direction by the insulating a-SiO2 layers. However, the extent of quantum confinement in the lateral dimensions remains to be established. Electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) measurements performed within a scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) indicate that the nanocrystals are laterally isolated by approximately 2nm of a-SiO2. The confinement potential provided by this barrier is insufficient to localize carriers within a nanocrystal for prolonged durations and can permit quantum mechanical tunneling via wave function overlap between adjacent nanocrystals. Charge leakage kinetics within a sheet of Si nanocrystals was studied using electric force microscopy. Approximately 750 electrons were injected within a 100nm radius circular patch with an atomic force microscope cantilever. The entire charge dissipated from this area in 70min via lateral conduction routes. With a goal of localizing the injected charge and enhancing its retention time, the samples were subjected to relatively low temperature dry oxidation at 750°C. After 20 min of oxidation, retention times above 400 minutes were observed.
Index Keywords: Amorphous silicon; Crystallization; Electron energy loss spectroscopy; Interfaces (materials); Nanostructured materials; Nonvolatile storage; Optoelectronic devices; Oxidation; Quantum theory; Scanning electron microscopy; Silica; Transmission electron microscopy; Charge retention; Electric force microscopy; Low temperature dry oxidation; Nanocrystal layers; Quantum confinement; Quantum mechanical tunneling; Semiconducting silicon

Authors: Huang S., Banerjee S., Oda S.
Title: Observation of quantum confinement effects in nanocrystalline silicon dot floating gate single electron memory devices
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium - Proceedings

Authors with affiliations: Huang, S., Res. Ctr. Quantum Effect Electronics, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-Ku, Tokyo 152-8552, Japan; Banerjee, S., Res. Ctr. Quantum Effect Electronics, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-Ku, Tokyo 152-8552, Japan; Oda, S., Res. Ctr. Quantum Effect Electronics, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-Ku, Tokyo 152-8552, Japan
Abstract: Electron charging and discharging processes in floating gate MOS memory based on nanocrystalline silicon (nc-Si) dots were investigated at room temperature using capacitance-voltage (C-V) and conductance-voltage (G-V) measurements. Sequential electron discharging processes from nc-Si dots manifest themselves clearly in G-V spectroscopy after charging of the dots. According to the conductance peak structure resulting from the Coulomb blockade as well as quantum confinement effects of nc-Si dots, electron-addition energy is estimated to be 50 meV. Taking the electron-charging energy between the silicon substrate and the floating dot (30 meV) into account, the quantum confinement energy is found to be comparable to the electron charging energy for an nc-Si dot of 8 nm in diameter embedded in the silicon oxide.
Index Keywords: Data storage equipment; Electric conductance; Electron devices; Electron energy levels; Nanostructured materials; Quantum theory; Scanning electron microscopy; Semiconducting silicon; Capacitance-voltage characteristics; Electron charging; Electron discharging; Nanocrystalline silicon dot floating gate; Quantum confinement effects; Quantum confinement energy; Single electron memory devices; Semiconductor quantum dots

Authors: Mohapatra S., Venkatasubramanian N.
Title: PARM: Power aware reconfigurable middleware
Source title: Proceedings - International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems
Affiliations: Dept. of Information and Comp. Sci., University of California, Irvine, CA 92697-3425, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mohapatra, S., Dept. of Information and Comp. Sci., University of California, Irvine, CA 92697-3425, United States; Venkatasubramanian, N., Dept. of Information and Comp. Sci., University of California, Irvine, CA 92697-3425, United States
Abstract: In distributed environments, generic middleware services (e.g. caching, location management etc.) are widely used to satisfy application needs in a cost-effective manner. Such middleware services consume system resources such as storage; computation and communication and can be sources of significant power overheads when executed on low-power devices. We present a distributed middleware framework (PARM), that is inherently power-aware and reconfigures itself to adapt to diminishing power levels of low-power devices. In this paper, we i) determine whether a reconfigurable component-based middleware framework can be utilized to achieve energy gains in low-power devices, while preserving the semantics of the middleware services, ii) present and evaluate a graph theoretic approach for dynamically determining middleware component reconfigurations and ascertaining the optimal frequency at which the restructuring should occur, for maximal energy gains at the device. We use extensive profiling to chart the energy usage patterns of middleware components and applications, and use the profiled data to drive our reconfiguration decisions. Our simulation results demonstrate that our framework is able to save 5% to 35% of energy depending on the nature and class of applications and middleware components used.
Index Keywords: Cache memory; Computer simulation; Cost effectiveness; Distributed computer systems; Graph theory; Semantics; Storage allocation (computer); Caching; Location management; Power aware reconfigurable middleware; Middleware

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Statoil buys into BP's stake in Algerian natural gas
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Multinational oil and gas companies have negotiated major international deals recently, including a transaction that marks Statoil ASA's entry into Algeria. Statoil ASA agreed to buy 49% of BP PLC's interest in the In Salah natural gas fields and 50% of BP's interest in the In Amenas gas development project, both in Algeria, for $740 million total. Statoil and BP also agreed to work with Sonatrach to jointly operate the two projects, aimed at delivering gas to the European markets. A discussion covers BP PLC and the Alfa Group and Access-Renova's sale and purchase agreement, moving them closer to finalizing the completion of combining their Russian businesses into a new joint venture, TNK-BP; Cairn Energy's offer to sell 85% of its stake in two oil and gas blocks in the Krishna-Godavari basin to Oil & Natural Gas Corp (ONGC) for $100 million and 15% equity in two ONGC blocks; Unocal Corp's unit Unocal North Sumatra Geothermal Ltd's agreement to sell its rights and interest in the Sarulla geothermal project of Northwest Sumatra to PLN for $60 million; the offer of ChevronTexaco Corp's European upstream business unit to sell its equity in three North Sea fields, i.e., Galley, Orwell, and Statfjord; and Plains All American Pipeline LP's (Houston, TX) acquisition of interest in three pipelines and an LPG storage asset for a total of $29 million.

Authors: Duncan T.S., Sichler M.S.
Title: High bandwidth scientific data management using storage area networking: Lessons learned at the starfire optical range
Source title: Digest of Papers - IEEE Symposium on Mass Storage Systems

Abstract: Advances in sensor technology, electronic devices, digital processing hardware, and computation systems have vastly increased the volume of data available for collection at scientific research sites. The Starfire Optical Range of the Air Force Research Laboratory Directed Energy Directorate is responsible for the research and development of advanced techniques for atmospheric compensation for large telescopes. Recent experiments have been completed which encompassed more that 100TB of collected data. The collection, processing, archival, and analysis of these data required an entirely new approach for the facility staff. This paper presents the architecture, hardware and software components, integration difficulties, and performance results in a "lessons learned" format focused on specific implementation choices, interoperability lessons and issues, and results and capabilities.

Authors: Sauert F.
Title: Contop®: A cost-effective recycling technology for the steel and automotive-scrap industry
Source title: Metallurgia Italiana
Affiliations: VOEST-ALPINE I. GmbH/C., Linz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Sauert, F., VOEST-ALPINE I. GmbH/C., Linz, Austria
Abstract: The well proven CONTOP® technology, extensively applied in the non-ferrous metals industry for more than two decades, has been adapted to treat and recycle zinc-enriched steel works dust as well as automotive shredder residue and other wastes. In a highly compact water-cooled cyclone dust and/or small-sized residuals are thermally treated at high temperatures to volatize the zinc and produce a liquid slag. Following combustion of the process gas, the zinc is concentrated as an oxide and subsequently sold. The solidified slag can be used, for example, in the construction industry. A highlight of the CONTOP® process is that the excess process energy from the cyclone and offgas can be utilized to generate steam and electrical energy.
Index Keywords: Automation; Construction industry; Cost effectiveness; Electric energy storage; Heat treatment; High temperature effects; Recycling; Slags; Steel scrap; Water cooling systems; Zinc; Liquid slags; Iron and steel industry

Title: DRPM: Dynamic speed control for power management in server class disks
Source title: Conference Proceedings - Annual International Symposium on Computer Architecture, ISCA
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Science and Eng., The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; IBM Research Division, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gurumurthi, S., Dept. of Computer Science and Eng., The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Sivasubramaniam, A., Dept. of Computer Science and Eng., The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Kandemir, M., Dept. of Computer Science and Eng., The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Franke, H., IBM Research Division, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: A large portion of the power budget in server environments goes into the I/O subsystem - the disk array in particular. Traditional approaches to disk power management involve completely stopping the disk rotation, which can take a considerable amount of time, making them less useful in cases where idle times between disk requests may not be long enough to outweigh the overheads. This paper presents a new approach called DRPM to modulate disk speed (RPM) dynamically, and gives a practical implementation to exploit this mechanism. Extensive simulations with different workload and hardware parameters show that DRPM can provide significant energy savings without compromising much on performance. This paper also discusses practical issues when implementing DRPM on server disks.
Author Keywords: Power management; Server disks
Index Keywords: Client server computer systems; Dynamic programming; Power control; Speed control; Dynamic speed control; Power management; Server class disks; Hard disk storage

Authors: Zhu Y., Benaissa M.
Title: A novel ACS scheme for area-efficient viterbi decoders
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electronic Engineering, University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield S1 3JD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, Y., Department of Electronic Engineering, University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield S1 3JD, United Kingdom; Benaissa, M., Department of Electronic Engineering, University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield S1 3JD, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper presents a novel ACS scheme that enables high-speeds to be achieved in area-efficient Viterbi decoders without compromising area and power efficiency. This is achieved by introducing multi-level pipelining into the ACS feedback loop. As a proof of concept, a constraint-7 Viterbi decoder using 8 ACS units has been designed with 5 pipeline levels. This design has been implemented successfully on an FPGA device. The results obtained confirm functionality, speed improvements and the expected low resource usage. To quantify these, a state-parallel Viterbi decoder design has also been implemented on the same FPGA device and performance comparisons made.
Index Keywords: Computational complexity; Energy efficiency; Field programmable gate arrays; Parallel algorithms; Random access storage; State feedback; Pipelining schemes; Viterbi decoders; Decoding

Authors: Zhang H., Mazumder P., Ding L., Yang K.
Title: Performance modeling of resonant tunneling based RAMS
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Dept. of EECS, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Dept. of EECS, KAIST, Taejeon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, H., Dept. of EECS, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Mazumder, P., Dept. of EECS, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Ding, L., Dept. of EECS, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Yang, K., Dept. of EECS, KAIST, Taejeon, South Korea
Abstract: Tunneling based random-access memories (TRAM's) have recently garnered a great amount of interests among the memory designers due to their intrinsic merits such as reduced power consumption by elimination of refreshing operation, faster read and write cycles, and improved reliability in comparison to conventional silicon DRAM's. In order to understand the precise principle of operation of TRAM's, an in-depth circuit analysis has been attempted in this paper and analytical models for memory cycle time, soft error rate, and power consumption have been derived. The analytical results are then validated by simulation experiments performed with HSPICE, These results are then compared with conventional DRAM's to establish the claim of superiority of TRAM performance to DRAM performance.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric network analysis; Energy utilization; Resonant tunneling; Power consumption; Dynamic random access storage

Authors: Macii A., Macii E., Poncino M.
Title: Increasing the locality of memory access patterns by low-overhead hardware address relocation
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Università di Verona, Verona, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Macii, A., Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Macii, E., Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Poncino, M., Università di Verona, Verona, Italy
Abstract: Increasing the locality of a memory access profile is an interesting optimization problem, whose solution has implications on both performance and energy consumption of a processor-based system. High-locality memory access patterns are normally obtained through software-driven transformations, applied either at the source-code level or during compilation and machine-code generation. For some specific classes of systems, e.g., embedded systems, hardware-oriented, on-the-fly access pattern modification is also an option, as it trades generality in the applicability for better performance. This paper presents a class of algorithms for improving the locality of a given memory access profile through selective address relocation that require a very low-overhead custom hardware unit. Results obtained on a set of typical embedded applications show an average reduction in the complexity of the address relocation unit around 40%, yet with the best achievable increase in memory access locality.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Codes (symbols); Computer software; Embedded systems; Memory access patterns; Data storage equipment

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Quick takes: Woodside Energy Ltd. has awarded...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Woodside Energy Ltd has awarded a contract to Samsung Heavy Industries Co Ltd to construct the hull for a floating production, storage, and offloading vessel for its Enfield oil development off Western Australia. The 150,000 dwt, double-hull vessel will be 260 m long and will have a storage capacity of 900,000 bbl of oil. Woodside holds a 100% interest in the Enfield project. The fields' combined proven oil reserves are estimated at 146.4 million bbl. Combined probable oil reserves are currently 216.4 million bbl, and the combined probable scope for recovery volumes are estimated at 103.1 million bbl.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Quick takes: Progas Pakistan, formerly Keloil Pakistan...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Progas Pakistan has awarded a $38 million contract for the second phase of its Port Qasim LPG terminal at Karachi. SNC Lavalin Energy Control Systems Inc and China Shanghai (Group) Corp for Foreign Economic and Technological Cooperation will engineer and construct 4500 ton of LPG storage and an LPG import handling terminal at the site, enabling the facility to handle vessels of 1500-50,000 dwt. Usmani Associates is constructing the first phase of the project, which includes 2000-ton LPG storage and a fully automated, 12-filling-head operation capable of handling 5000 ton/mo of LPG at Port Qasim. Three regional distribution centers are being set up in Islamabad, Quetta, and Muzaffargarh with 300 ton bulk storage and semiautomated LPG bottling operations. In the third phase, the firm plans to increase the capacity of its import jetty to 15,000-50,000 ton.

Authors: D'Aquino S., Palma A., Agabbio M.
Title: Response of three citrus species to different hygrometric conditions
Source title: Acta Horticulturae
Affiliations: CNR. Institute of Sciences of Food Production, Section of Sassari, Via Dei Mille 48, 07100 Sassari, Italy
Authors with affiliations: D'Aquino, S., CNR. Institute of Sciences of Food Production, Section of Sassari, Via Dei Mille 48, 07100 Sassari, Italy; Palma, A., CNR. Institute of Sciences of Food Production, Section of Sassari, Via Dei Mille 48, 07100 Sassari, Italy; Agabbio, M., CNR. Institute of Sciences of Food Production, Section of Sassari, Via Dei Mille 48, 07100 Sassari, Italy
Abstract: The effect of two levels of humidity (LH with RH<65%; HH with RH>95%) on the physiology and quality of satsumas cv Miho, tangelos cv Nova and lemons cv Monachello stored at 20°C for 4, 8 and 12 weeks respectively was studied. LH fruit exhibited higher transpiration rates, earlier ageing and degradation of visual appearance than fruit stored at HH. The three cultivars behaved differently. LH satsumas and LH tangelos lost about 23-26% of the initial weight after the 4 weeks of storage against 4-6% of HH fruit of the same cultivars. LH lemons lost 16,8% of the initial weight after 4 weeks of storage and 33% after 12 weeks, whereas in the same periods in HH lemons weight loss were respectively 9% and 18%. After three weeks of storage, the total amount of satsuma LH fruit was unmarketable and only 8% of the tangelos were marketable; 100% of HH fruit of both cultivars were still saleable after 4 weeks of storage and free of decay. The level in humidity less affected visual appearance of lemons. In fact, after 4 weeks of storage more than 90% of LH fruit were marketable even when the degree of freshness was less compared to HH fruit. HH lemons maintained freshness sufficient for sale up to 12 weeks. Respiration activity decreased in both experimental conditions. Internal CO2 showed an increasing trend, and a decreasing trend in internal O2 partial pressure. All these changes were pronounced at LH conditions, while only moderate at HH conditions. In particular, the highest differences in respiration activity between HH fruit and LH were detected in satsumas; while the least differences were detected in lemons. The results show that: 1) the response at different hygrometric conditions differs greatly between cultivars; 2) elevated hygrometric conditions can prolong postharvest life markedly; 3) storage of citrus fruit can be done at temperatures between 5 and10°C higher than those normally used if elevated levels of humidity are applied and fruit are adequately protected against decay with an effective fungicide, with the advantage of saving energy and reducing the risk of physiological alterations caused by prolonged exposure to low temperatures.
Author Keywords: Citrus fruit; Fruit quality; Relative humidity; Respiration activity; Storage

Authors: Baranowski P., Mazurek W., Walczak R.T.
Title: The use of thermography for pre-sowing evaluation of seed germination capacity
Source title: Acta Horticulturae
Affiliations: Institute of Agrophysics, Polish Academy of Sciences, 20-290 Lublin, Doswiadczalna 4, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Baranowski, P., Institute of Agrophysics, Polish Academy of Sciences, 20-290 Lublin, Doswiadczalna 4, Poland; Mazurek, W., Institute of Agrophysics, Polish Academy of Sciences, 20-290 Lublin, Doswiadczalna 4, Poland; Walczak, R.T., Institute of Agrophysics, Polish Academy of Sciences, 20-290 Lublin, Doswiadczalna 4, Poland
Abstract: The evaluation of seed and fruit quality is a very important research problem and a practical problem. In case of the investigation of seed germination capacity, germination tests used these days are lengthy procedures. In this paper, a fast thermographic method is proposed to evaluate germination capacity of leguminous plant seeds. A thermographic AGEMA 880 LWB camera and a CCD camera (for imaging in visible range) were used to register and process the images. The set of elaborated measurements and the methodology applied made it possible to determine the average temperature of the seeds and their parts and to identify specific fragments of the image due to simultaneous registration in the visible and IR range. Considerable differences were noted in average temperature of seeds at the initial stage of the swelling process depending on the storage time and germination energy. The courses of temperature changes in time of viable pea seeds showed a considerable decrease in the radiation temperature (more than 1°C) during the first 12 hours.
Author Keywords: Plant material quality; Seed germination; Thermography

Its centerpiece is a compressed air energy storage (CAES) system incorporating a number of technologies including wind power. CAES is a technology to store energy in the form of compressed air in an underground facility for use in later generation.
