Authors: Gemmell D.S.
Title: Nuclear Transitions Induced by Synchrotron X-rays
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Physics Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL  60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gemmell, D.S., Physics Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL  60439, United States
Abstract: We discuss two rare but interesting processes by which synchrotron x-rays with energies up to about 100 keV may be used to induce nuclear transitions. In the NEET (Nuclear Excitation by Electronic Transition) process, an intense x-ray beam is employed to make vacancies, e.g. K-holes, in the atoms of a specific nuclear isotope. When a vacancy is filled by an electronic transition from a higher atomic level, there is some probability that instead of the usual x-ray or Auger emission, the nucleus of the atom itself will be excited. This is then followed by a nuclear decay exhibiting characteristic gamma-rays or other types of radiation, with time delays typical of the nuclear states involved. The probability for NEET increases when the energies of the atomic and the nuclear transitions become close. We address some theoretical aspects of the process and describe experimental efforts to observe it in 189Os and 197Au. The second process to be discussed is the possibility of "triggering" the decay of a nuclear isomer by irradiation with an x-ray beam. We focus on the case of the 31-year, 2.4-MeV, 16+ isomer of 178Hf. There has been speculation that if one could isolate gram quantities, say, of this isomer and then have the capability to accelerate its decay in a controlled way, one would have a powerful triggerable source of enormous energy. This could be used to generate explosions, for rapid irradiations, or for more general energy-storage applications, depending on the rate of energy release. We describe attempts to observe this process. © 2003 American Institute of Physics
Index Keywords: Atoms; Energy storage; Gamma rays; Irradiation; Isomers; Electronic transition; Energy storage applications; Gram quantities; Nuclear excitation; Nuclear isotopes; Nuclear transitions; Synchrotron x rays; Theoretical aspects; X rays

Authors: Ma X., Stöhlker Th., Bosch F., Gumberidze A., Kozhuharov C., Muthig A., Mokier P.H., Warczak A.
Title: X-ray emission from highly charged heavy ions studied at storage rings
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Institute of Modern Physics, Lanzhou, 730000, China; Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, Darmstadt, 64291, Germany; Tbilisi State University, Chavchavadze Avenue, Tbilisi, 380028, Georgia; Institue of Physics, Jagiellonian University, Cracow, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Ma, X., Institute of Modern Physics, Lanzhou, 730000, China; Stöhlker, Th., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, Darmstadt, 64291, Germany; Bosch, F., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, Darmstadt, 64291, Germany; Gumberidze, A., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, Darmstadt, 64291, Germany, Tbilisi State University, Chavchavadze Avenue, Tbilisi, 380028, Georgia; Kozhuharov, C., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, Darmstadt, 64291, Germany; Muthig, A., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, Darmstadt, 64291, Germany; Mokier, P.H., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, Darmstadt, 64291, Germany; Warczak, A., Institue of Physics, Jagiellonian University, Cracow, Poland
Abstract: Radiative electron capture at low projectile energies is studied via angular differential cross sections for collisions of bare uranium with low-Z target atoms. Our results show that for high-Z systems relativistic effects such as spin-flip transitions show up in an unambiguous fashion which still persist even in the low-energy domain. Moreover, following REC into the 2p3/2 state a strong alignment of this level was observed by measuring the angular distribution of the Lyα1 transition in H-like uranium. Here, an interference between the leading E1 decay channel and the much weaker M2 multipole transition gives rise to a remarkable modified angular distribution of the emitted photons. For the particular case of hydrogen-like uranium the former variance of the experimental data with theoretical findings is removed when this E1/M2 multipole mixing is taken into account. Finally, with respect to atomic structure studies, a very recent experiment will be discussed aiming on a precise determination of the electron-electron QED contribution to the groundstate ionization potential in He-like uranium. © 2003 American Institute of Physics
Index Keywords: Angular distribution; Digital storage; Dynamic mechanical analysis; Heavy ions; Ionization potential; Spin fluctuations; Uranium; Differential cross section; Emitted photons; Highly charged heavy ions; Precise determinations; Projectile energy; Radiative electron capture; Relativistic effects; Spin flip transitions; X rays

Authors: Harmon L.M., Baaklini G.Y.
Title: Ultrasonic spectroscopy of developmental composite rotors
Source title: ASTM Special Technical Publication
Affiliations: Cleveland State University, MS 6-1, 21000 Brookpark Road, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; NASA Glenn Research Center, MS 6-1, 21000 Brookpark Road, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harmon, L.M., Cleveland State University, MS 6-1, 21000 Brookpark Road, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Baaklini, G.Y., NASA Glenn Research Center, MS 6-1, 21000 Brookpark Road, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: Multilayered composite materials are being studied extensively for implementation in flywheel systems for the International Space Station (ISS). Rotor standard sections have been developed to determine damage tolerance levels of the multilayered composite materials in these flywheel systems. Four such rotor sections with simulated delaminations, foreign material inserts, and notches were investigated with a recently developed ultrasonic spectroscopy technique. The ultrasonic system employs a continuous swept sine waveform and performs an FFT on the frequency spectrum, In addition, the system is capable of equalizing the amount of energy at each frequency. Equalization of the frequency spectrum, along with interpretation of the second FFT aids in the evaluation of the spectrum resonance spacing, or fundamental frequency. The ultrasonic responses from defect free regions of the multilayered rotor sections are compared with responses from regions with simulated delaminations, foreign material inserts, and notches to establish the potential of this nondestructive evaluation (NDE) method for the evaluation of flywheel rotor systems.
Author Keywords: Composite materials; Flywheel rotors; Resonance; Ultrasonic spectroscopy

Authors: Thompson R.C., Pak T.T., Rech B.M.
Title: Hydroburst test methodology for evaluation of composite structures
Source title: ASTM Special Technical Publication
Affiliations: Center for Electromechanics, MC R7000, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, R.C., Center for Electromechanics, MC R7000, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Pak, T.T., Center for Electromechanics, MC R7000, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Rech, B.M., Center for Electromechanics, MC R7000, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Abstract: The University of Texas at Austin Center for Electromechanics (UT-CEM) is under contract to develop high-speed composite flywheel systems for a number of energy and power averaging applications in the transportation and space industries. Safe and reliable design of composite flywheels requires well-characterized material properties. Efforts have been focused on design optimization of a hydroburst test technique that demonstrates a useful method for characterizing the hoop (circumferential) properties of filament wound composite rings, and those results are then available to predict the performance of full-scale flywheels. To demonstrate the usefulness of this method, this paper discusses typical hydroburst techniques to determine material properties for filament-wound composite rings. Test results are also presented. Seal design is a key element of this fixture, and a design has evolved that provides nearly uniform radial loading on the inside surface of the composite ring, while minimizing axial bending. Correlations of tow strand data with hydroburst lamina data are presented. Also discussed are hydroburst test applications for flaw assessment and fatigue property evaluation.
Author Keywords: Composites; Filament winding; Hydroburst; Material properties
Index Keywords: Electromechanical devices; Energy storage; Fatigue of materials; Flywheels; Optimization; Space applications; Strain rate; Strength of materials; Axial bending; Flaw assessment; Hydroburst; Material properties; Composite structures

Authors: Saleeb A.F., Arnold S.M., Al-Zoubi N.R.
Title: A study of time-dependent and anisotropic effects on the deformation response of two flywheel designs
Source title: ASTM Special Technical Publication
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, University of Akron, Akron, OH 44325, United States; NASA Glenn Research Center, Mail Stop 49-7, 21000 Brookpark Rd., Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Saleeb, A.F., Civil Engineering Department, University of Akron, Akron, OH 44325, United States; Arnold, S.M., NASA Glenn Research Center, Mail Stop 49-7, 21000 Brookpark Rd., Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Al-Zoubi, N.R., Civil Engineering Department, University of Akron, Akron, OH 44325, United States
Abstract: The influence of material time dependency and anisotropy in the context of two specific flywheel designs-preload and multi-directional composite (MDC)- is investigated. In particular, we focus on the following aspects: 1) geometric constraints, 2) material constraints, 3) loading type, and 4) the fundamental character of the time-dependent response, i.e., reversible or irreversible. The bulk of the results presented were obtained using a composite (PMC IM7/8552 @135°C) material system. The material was characterized using a general multimechanism hereditary (viscoelastoplastic) model. As a general conclusion, the results have clearly shown that both the preload and the MDC rotor designs are significantly affected by time-dependent material behavior, which may impact the state of rotor balance and potentially reduce its operating life. In view of the results of the parametric studies and predictions made in the present study, the need for actual experimentation focusing on the time-dependent behavior of full-scale flywheel rotors is self-evident.
Author Keywords: Composite flywheel; PMC; Rotating disk; Time-dependent material; Viscoelasticity; Viscoplasticity

Authors: Fischer G., Grothaus R., Hufenbach W.
Title: Experimental failure effect analysis of composite high-speed flywheel rotors
Source title: ASTM Special Technical Publication
Affiliations: BMW AG, D-80788 München, Germany; EAST-4D GmbH Lightweight Structures, Annabergerstr. 240, D-09125 Chemnitz, Germany; TU Dresden, Inst. F. Leichtbau/Kunststofftechnik, D-01062 Dresden, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fischer, G., BMW AG, D-80788 München, Germany; Grothaus, R., EAST-4D GmbH Lightweight Structures, Annabergerstr. 240, D-09125 Chemnitz, Germany; Hufenbach, W., TU Dresden, Inst. F. Leichtbau/Kunststofftechnik, D-01062 Dresden, Germany
Abstract: Due to their high specific strength and the possibility of creating a load-adapted property profile, composite materials are ideally suited for the design of high-speed flywheel rotors. The rotors are exposed to extreme loading conditions by high centrifugal forces, partially superposed by elevated temperatures due to an integrated electrical machine, bearings or air friction. A sophisticated fail-safe design of composite flywheel rotors has been applied here, which allows the rotor to fail catastrophically. To withstand the manifold burst behavior safely the exact loading of the containment must be known within a simultaneous engineering approach of rotor and containment. Therefore, adapted rotor rigs and devices for measuring the burst effects in the axial, radial and circumferential direction have been designed and successfully tested. Experimental failure studies on the fiber composite flywheel rims prove the manifold burst behavior and containment interactions. Extreme axial shock waves due to the composite fragment movement have been measured experimentally, which are principally not known for isotropic rotor failure.
Author Keywords: Composite rotor; Containment; Failure effects; FEA; Flywheel; Spin testing
Index Keywords: Carbon fiber reinforced plastics; Composite materials; Energy storage; Finite element method; Flywheels; Friction; Impurities; Machine design; Shock waves; Strength of materials; Air friction; Composite rims; Composite rotors; failure effects; Spin testing; Rotors

Authors: Ratner J.K.H., Chang J.B., Christopher D.A.
Title: Composite flywheel rotor technology - A review
Source title: ASTM Special Technical Publication
Affiliations: Vehicle Systems Division, Engineering and Technology Group, Aerospace Corporation, CA, United States; Systems Engineering Division, Engineering and Technology Group, Aerospace Corporation, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ratner, J.K.H., Vehicle Systems Division, Engineering and Technology Group, Aerospace Corporation, CA, United States; Chang, J.B., Vehicle Systems Division, Engineering and Technology Group, Aerospace Corporation, CA, United States; Christopher, D.A., Systems Engineering Division, Engineering and Technology Group, Aerospace Corporation, CA, United States
Abstract: Flywheels with composite rotors are being developed as energy storage devices to replace conventional chemical batteries in satellites and other space systems, and are currently being used in terrestrial systems. The main advantages of composite flywheel systems are their ability to provide high instantaneous power and a capacity for large energy storage over many charge/discharge cycles. Currently, an industry working group is in the process of developing a standard that can be used to certify a composite rotor for safe and reliable operation in space. To assist in the development of such a standard, a review of state-of-the-art composite rotor technologies has been conducted. The goal of the review was to provide a clear picture of composite flywheel rotor technologies, and identify areas that require further development. Technical areas covered in the review were: rotor design approaches; composite analysis methods; composite materials' static strength, fatigue, creep, and stress rupture data; spin test and other test methods; nondestructive evaluation (NDE) methods; in-service health monitoring techniques; and fracture control requirements. This paper summarizes the review and provides recommended research and development topics that are needed to fill the technology gap.
Author Keywords: Composite rotor; Energy storage; Flywheel; Fracture control; Nondestructive evaluation; Spin test; Stress rupture life
Index Keywords: Composite materials; Energy storage; Fatigue of materials; Flywheels; Fracture toughness; Kinetic energy; Machine design; Satellite links; Strength of materials; Stress analysis; Composite rotor; Fracture control; Nondestructive evaluation; Spin test; Stress rupture life; Rotors

Authors: Kawanaka J., Yamakawa K., Nishioka H., Ueda K.-I.
Title: Multi-ten-milli-joule operation of diode-pumped Yb:LiYF4 chirped-pulse regenerative amplifier
Source title: OSA Trends in Optics and Photonics Series
Affiliations: Advanced Photon Research Center, Japan Atom. Ener. Research Institute, 8-1 Umemidai, Kizu-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto 619-0215, Japan; Institute for Laser Science, University of Electro-Communications, 1-5-1 Chofugaoka, Chofu-shi, Tokyo 182-8585, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kawanaka, J., Advanced Photon Research Center, Japan Atom. Ener. Research Institute, 8-1 Umemidai, Kizu-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto 619-0215, Japan; Yamakawa, K., Advanced Photon Research Center, Japan Atom. Ener. Research Institute, 8-1 Umemidai, Kizu-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto 619-0215, Japan; Nishioka, H., Institute for Laser Science, University of Electro-Communications, 1-5-1 Chofugaoka, Chofu-shi, Tokyo 182-8585, Japan; Ueda, K.-I., Institute for Laser Science, University of Electro-Communications, 1-5-1 Chofugaoka, Chofu-shi, Tokyo 182-8585, Japan
Abstract: A diode-pumped Yb:LiYF4 chirped-pulse regenerative amplifier has been demonstrated. 24 ml output power was obtained with 10 Hz repetition rate before compression. 53 mJ was numerically estimated with an additional diode pump source. ©2000 Optical Society of America.

Authors: Isemann A., Fallnich C.
Title: Pushing thermal limitation in high-power colquiriite lasers pumped by broad-area laser diodes
Source title: OSA Trends in Optics and Photonics Series

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: El Paso Natural Gas has bought...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: El Paso Natural Gas has bought a gas storage company that plans to construct the Copper Eagle Gas Storage facility near Phoenix, AZ, from Pinnacle West Energy. The proposed storage project, which is scheduled to start commercial service in 2007, has three underground storage caverns, each with a withdrawal capacity of 320 million cu ft/day, an injection capacity of 160 million cu ft/day and a working gas storage capacity of 3.2 bcf.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: Latin America: Mexico: Shell has received...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: Shell has received an environmental permit for a proposed LNG regasification terminal in Baja California state. The $0.7 billion project will be developed in Costa Azul, 23 km north of Ensenada, and will have capacity for regasifying 7.5 million ton/yr. The unit will come on stream in 2007, and will supply power plants and industrial customers in the northwest with surplus gas exported to southern California. Meanwhile, the energy regulator, CRE, has given approval to Marathon Oil and its partners for a regasification and storage plant near Tijuana, also in Baja, CA. Marathon's project is the first to receive permission from the CRE. The capacity of the unit will be 0.75 bcf/day. Total investment will be more than $1.5 billion. Construction is planned to start in 2003 and the project will be on stream in 2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: FCE to install power plants at two universities
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: FuelCell Energy (FCE) has been contracted by Grand Valley State University, MI, to install and service a DFC300A fuel cell power plant for its Energy Institute's new 26,000 sq ft research center in Muskegon, MI. Funding for the Grand Valley State University project, including the building and the fuel cells, is being provided by a $3 million alternative energy grant from the Michigan Public Service Commission and bonding from the City of Muskegon. FCE's Direct FuelCell® power plant will provide electricity and a heat recovery system for heating and cooling applications in newly created research space, incubator facilities, a conference center, and classrooms. The project will include a solar photovoltaic installation that will provide hot water and warm air for heating and air-conditioning. This facility will be the world's first commercial project to integrate fuel cell technology, a heat recovery system for heating and air-conditioning, photovoltaics, and a NiMH battery storage system to store excess energy, creating a building that powers itself using "green" sources. Startup of the project, which will cost $1.25 million, exclusive of a 5-yr renewable service agreement, is expected in summer 2005.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Focus: Bahamas: Planning a place on the world energy map
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: To break into the energy industry, Bahamas is looking at the fast-growing LNG business. Three companies see the islands, with their closeness to Florida, as a good location for LNG regasification plants. Tractebel LNG, AES (the power producer), and El Paso (the gas trader) have all proposed LNG regasification terminals in the Bahamas. Gas would be piped to Florida, where it would enter the inter-state gas transmission system. Tractebel's Calypso Pipeline project, inherited from Enron, was the first for an offshore regasification terminal. However, AES proposal seems to be the most advanced, having already won US regulatory approval. The gas will travel through a 0.85 bcf/day, 90-mi pipeline to Fort Lauderdale. The terminal, storage tanks, and regasification plant would be sited on Ocean Cay, in the Bimini islands group. Both the Tractebel and El Paso facilities have been proposed for Grand Bahama, at Freeport and South Riding Point. The Calypso Pipeline would run 90 mi to Port Everglades, carrying 0.83 bcf/day, while El Paso would pipe ≤ 1 bcf/day, 127 mi to West Palm Beach. Analysts predict that only two of the three proposals will be approved.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: Latin America: Mexico: The country's energy regulator...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: Mexico's energy regulator, CRE, has awarded Shell permits for LNG regasification and storage operations at two planned LNG facilities in the country. Shell proposes to spend $1.1 billion to build LNG storage plants at Costa Azul, in Baja California state, and a LNG receiving terminal at Altamira, in Tamaulipas state, on the Gulf of Mexico. The storage tanks at Costa Azul would each have capacity of 170,000 cu m and capacity to supply 1 bcf/day of gas to North Baja and California. Total investment in that project is at $74 million. The tanks will start operations in 2007. In Altamira, Shell will spend $307 million to build two 150,000 cu m storage tanks with capacity to supply 425 million cu ft/day to combined-cycle power plants owned by CFE.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Project: Work begins on DEGT's Patriot extension
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Abstract: Duke Energy Gas Transmission's efforts to expand and extend its East Tennessee Natural Gas (ETNG) pipeline system are under way. Murphy Bros will expand the ETNG pipeline in Tennessee and Virginia and extend it through the Patriot Extension, a new 94-mi pipeline into southwest Virginia and North Carolina. Murphy Bros is the prime contractor on the project. The ETNG pipeline system has transported natural gas to industries and local distribution companies (LDC) in Tennessee and parts of Virginia for the past 50 yr. The 1129-mi pipeline system begins in central Tennessee, converges near Knoxville and extends to a point near Roanoke, VA. The system provides natural gas transportation and storage services to about 40 LDC and 17 industries.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: A unit of sempra...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: A unit of Sempra Energy has paid an undisclosed amount to acquire a proposal by Dynegy to develop a 1.5 billion cu ft/day LNG import terminal at Hackberry, LA. The plant is scheduled to open in 2007 at a cost of $0.7 billion. The facility will have 10 billion cu ft of storage capacity.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Solar/PEM fuel cell demo project for Proton, successful Hipress test
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Proton Energy Systems has won a $375,000 contract to develop a 1 kwe regenerative solar/PEM fuel cell demonstration system. The contract, with Jacobs Sverdrup Technology, will support testing a the Naval Air Weapons Station at China Lake, CA. Proton has announced successful high-pressure testing of its new Hipress™ PEM cell stack module for hydrogen generation. The solar/fuel cell demonstration system will integrate Proton's Unigen® Regenerative Fuel Cell System, which includes a Hogen® hydrogen generator, hydrogen storage tanks, a PEM fuel cell, and a Navy-supplied solar photovoltaic array. The hydrogen generator will incorporate Proton's renewable interface, which uses electricity generated by the solar array to produce hydrogen by electrolysis. The project will demonstrate grid-independent, constant power output using a renewable energy system capable of remote operation. The Hipress cell stacks passed the 1000 hr mark of system operation at 2000 psi, proving the technology's durability.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: In Brief: NREL investigates ultracapacitors for FCHVs
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Researchers at the DOE's National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) are studying the use of ultracapacitors in fuel cell hybrid vehicles (FCHV). Ultracapacitors are energy storage devices used in electric and hybrid electric vehicles, and can either replace or supplement conventional chemical batteries. Engineers from NREL's Center for Transportation Technologies & Systems used ADVISOR, a hybrid electric vehicle simulation model, to simulate a FCHV with ultracapacitor energy storage. They found that the ultracapacitor can capture a sizeable amount of regenerative braking energy that would otherwise be lost, improving FCHV fuel economy.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Newsreel: KM Energy partners moves forward on $30 million CMC project
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP's $30 million Cheyenne Market Center (CMC) service has started following FERC approval. The CMC project entails constructing and operating pipeline, compression and storage facilities that will allow for the receipt, storage, and subsequent redelivery of natural gas supplies at the Cheyenne Hub in Rockport, CO, and KMIGT's Huntsman facility in Cheyenne County, NE, as well as other strategic points nearby. The expansion and associated service is fully subscribed under long-term contracts. To accommodate the additional volumes, the company will add more than 10,000 hp of compression at the existing Rockport and Huntsman facilities, and will construct a new station in Kimball County, NE, that will provide ≈ 2300 horsepower of compression.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Military FCV contracts for Quantum, ECD
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: The US Army Tank-Automotive and Armaments Command (TACOM) National Automotive Center (NAC) has awarded Quantum Technologies a contract to develop and demonstrate a high-performance, hydrogen fuel cell powered light-duty, special operations vehicle. TACOM has also awarded the first phase of funding for NAC to partner with Energy Conversion Devices (ECD Ovonics) in a $500,000 contract for its joint venture Texaco Ovonic Hydrogen Systems to develop a transportable solid hydrogen storage and refueling system for hydrogen fuel cell powered off-road military vehicles. This new program will integrate a hydrogen fuel cell powered hybrid electric powertrain into a light-duty off-road vehicle, for performance that meets or exceeds the gasoline IC engine version. ECD Ovonics will perform the hydrogen storage and refueling system work under its service agreement with Texaco Ovonic Hydrogen Systems. Within the scope of the project, the Ovonic™ transportable hydrogen storage system will store at least 10 kg of hydrogen in safe, compact, low-pressure solid form.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: In brief: Manitoba encouraging hydrogen industry
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: The government of Manitoba, Canada, has released report outlining opportunities for hydrogen energy developments in the province, which has so far lagged behind British Columbia et al. in the push to develop a fuel cell and hydrogen industry. The new Canadian Fuel Cell Commercialization Roadmap makes no mention of Manitoba, whose only notable contribution to fuel cell development is that Winnipeg will host a hybrid fuel cell/ultracapacitor bus demonstration in 2005. This project will utilize fuel cell technology from Hydrogenics and a hydrogen storage system from Dynetek. The Preliminary Hydrogen Opportunities Report examines the future use of hydrogen, and outlines economic opportunities for the province. It also recommends priorities to spur the province's industry, e.g., the Winnipeg bus project and establishing a Hydorgen Research Centre of Excellence.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Top of the news: Senate approves ethanol mandate
Source title: National Petroleum News
Abstract: By a vote of 64-28, the Senate approved the fuels title of the Energy Bill on 6/5/2003. The approved version follows very closely the fuels provisions, which had been approved by the Environment and Public Works Committee just before the Memorial Day recess. Key provisions affecting marketers are repeal of the oxygenate mandate for reformulated gasoline (RFG); a phase-out of the use of MTBE in gasoline after 4 yr; and the imposition of a Renewable Fuels Standard, or ethanol mandate, eventually reaching 5 billion gal/yr. It also contains some modest provisions that move in the right direction in terms of underground storage tank program reform and a very limited provision allowing co-mingling at the retail outlet of ethanol-additized gasoline with other gasoline.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: Middle East: Kuwait: A new energy ministry has been formed...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: Kuwait's new energy ministry has been formed to oversee investment of ∼ $14 billion in the next few years. It will take responsibility for Project Kuwait, in which western firms have been asked to help double crude output from northern fields to 0.9 million bpd by 2006-07. The project will draw investment of ∼ $7 billion. Other projects include the proposed $ 2 billion Qatar-Kuwait gas pipeline. A sales contract, which will go some way to guaranteeing the line will soon be signed between Kuwait Petroleum, ExxonMobil, and Qatar Petroleum. The energy ministry will also oversee a $4 billion development in the power sector, including the installation of four new power plants to be fed with gas from the Qatar-Kuwait pipeline. Among other major proposed projects is the construction of 19 new oil storage tanks, with capacity of 11.4 million bbl, valued at ∼ $0.8 billion.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Bush pushes fuel cell support to $1.7bn in next 5 years
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: In the State of the Union address of President Bush at the end of January 2002, he announced his $1.2 billion FreedomFUEL Initiative to develop the technology needed for commercially viable hydrogen-powered fuel cells. The initiative will invest $720 million in new funding over the next 5 yr to develop the technologies and infrastructure needed to produce, store, and distribute hydrogen for use in fuel cell vehicles and electricity generation. Combined with the FreedomCAR (Cooperative Automotive Research) Initiative, the president is proposing a total of $1.7 billion over the next 5 yr to develop hydrogen-powered fuel cells. Hydrogen is perceived as the key to a clean energy future, and together the FreedomFUEL and FreedomCAR initiatives are intended to overcome key technical and cost barriers, through lowering the cost of hydrogen and creating effective hydrogen storage.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Project: Marathon, partners get first-ever LNG permit from Mexico
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Abstract: The Mexican government awarded its first-ever permit for the construction and operation of a LNG storage facility to Marathon Oil Corp and partners Grupo GSS SV de CV and Golar LNG Ltd. The facility will be located near Tijuana, Baja California, Mexico. The proposed Tijuana Regional Energy Center is an integrated complex that will consist of a LNG offloading terminal and a 750 million cu ft/day regasification plant, a 1200-Mw power generation plant to supply regional electricity needs, a 20-million gal/day seawater desalination plant to provide fresh water for the city of Tijuana, wastewater treatment facilities to augment existing processing capacity of the San Antonio de los Buenos treatment plant, and related natural gas pipeline infrastructure. The Tijuana Regional Energy Center will be a state-of-the-art complex designed to meet the region's expected population growth and stimulate economic development in the coming years.

Authors: Barkved O., Heavey P., Kjelstadli R., Kleppan T., Kristiansen T.G.
Title: Valhall field - Still on plateau after 20 years of production
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE Offshore Europe Oil and Gas Exhibition and Conference 2003, OE 2003
Affiliations: SPE; SPE, BP
Authors with affiliations: Barkved, O., SPE; Heavey, P., SPE; Kjelstadli, R., SPE; Kleppan, T., SPE, BP; Kristiansen, T.G., SPE, BP
Abstract: The estimated recoverable reserves from the Valhall field at start of production in 1982 were 250 MMSTB. Now, after twenty years on primary depletion, a total of 500 MMSTB has been produced and additional 500 MMSTB remains to be produced of the original 2.6 BSTB in place. This corresponds to a recovery factor of 40%. Possibilities to increase ultimate recovery have been defined. These will require further insights into the detailed architecture of the field and improved understanding of the reservoir energy and displacement efficiency. Approximately 50% of the drive to date has been from rock compaction. The field is a North Sea Chalk field producing from Tor and Lower Hod Formations, porosity is exceeding 50% in places, some fractured permeability is present, but matrix permeability is generally low, less than 10 mD. Application of new technology has been fundamental in bringing the field up to current performance. New completion techniques combined with dedicated draw down schedules has been established to reduce influx of the weak chalk formations and reduce well failures. Special well design for a compacting and subsiding environment has also been implemented. Drilling of the overburden has been a key challenge. This has been partly mitigated by detailed geological mapping of problem zones versus structure, lithology, overpressure and wellbore stability analysis, but has also resulted in replacing extended reach wells by the installation of new flank drilling and production facilities. The particular characteristics of the overburden and chalk also pose challenges for data acquisition. Coring technology & practices are very tightly controlled, as is selection of logging devices. A water flood scheme has been approved based on a successful water flood pilot, but issues related to sweep efficiency, presence of fault and fracture zones and large variation in thickness need to be understood to capture it’s full potential. The reservoir will also experience extra water induced compaction and increased subsidence. New logging technology has recently made it possible to define and characterize the fracture system, which combined with a range of surveillance techniques will be key in this work. Seismic imaging has generally been a challenge at Valhall due to the presence of gas in the overburden. Use of 4C seismic technology has improved this. In addition, the 4D seismic response appears to be very sensitive to production-induced depletion, compaction of the reservoir and subsidence of the overburden and seafloor. Seismic techniques will be critical in future development. For a more detailed review of the first 10 years of Valhall, reference is made to the paper by Ali and Alcock [1]. Copyright 2003, Society of Petroleum Engineers Inc.
Index Keywords: Boreholes; Data acquisition; Digital storage; Floods; Fracture; Infill drilling; Limestone; Lithology; Oil wells; Petroleum reservoir evaluation; Seismology; Subsidence; Current performance; Displacement efficiency; Fractured permeability; Matrix permeability; North Sea; Recoverable reserves; Recovery factors; Reservoir energy; Water flood; Well failure; Compaction

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government guidelines: Abraham Ratchets up natural gas concerns
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Abstract: With the summer well under way, the Bush administration seems to be taking short-term natural gas problems very seriously, yet continues to express opposition to some of the key incentives needed to get the long-term Alaskan natural gas pipeline off the ground. Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham pointed out that the US had 696 bcf in storage at the end of March 2003, the lowest level since 1976, when the EIA began keeping records. By the week of 4/11/2003, levels had dropped to 623 bcf. If the desired storage level of 3-3.5 tcf of natural gas is reached by the end of October, gas must be injected much more into storage than the usual weekly average of 60 bcf, however, at that time that the most recent numbers on injections showed they had increased to 72 bcf for the most recent week on record.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Sempra Energy Trading plans to...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: Sempra Energy Trading plans to build the Bluewater natural gas storage facility in St Clair, MI. The facility, which will go into commercial operation in April 2004, is projected to have a storage capacity of 27 bcf, with a sendout capacity of about 0.7 bcf/day.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Australia: Woodside begins Enfield development
Source title: Chemical Engineer
Abstract: Woodside Energy awarded the first major construction contact of the hull for a floating production, storage, and offloading vessel for its Enfield oil development off the North West Cape in Western Australia to Samsung Heavy Industries of South Korea. The 260-m long vessel will be self-propelled and can leave location in bad weather. The Enfield project is ∼ 40 km northwest of the North West Cape. The fields have an estimated combined proven oil reserves of 146.4 million bbl and combined probable oil reserves of 216.4 million bbl. The combined probable scope for recovery volumes are currently estimated at 103.1 million bbl. Production from the field is expected in the fourth quarter of 2006. Total Enfield development capital costs are estimated at ∼ $(Aust) 1.5 billion.
Index Keywords: ENFIELD OIL FIELD, AUSTRALIA

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Mini fuel cell manufacturing plant for Masterflex
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Masterflex AG has inaugurated its new fuel cell manufacturing facility, which will mass-produce 50 we miniature PEM fuel cells for notebook computers, printers, and other network-independent mobile office systems. The units offer ∼ 20 times the energy capacity of a conventional battery, allowing a notebook to be operated for 30-50 hr. The mini fuel cell is supplied with hydrogen from a metal hydride storage device. The Nordrhein-Wesfalen regional government is supporting the enterprise within the NRW Fuel Cell Competence Network (Kompetenz-Netzwerk Brennstoffzelle) to develop the region into an international fuel cell hub. Masterflex is very confident that it will start mass production and full marketing of its mini fuel cells in 2004. In March 2003, the firm demonstrated its first prototype for mobile office systems at the CeBIT exhibition in Hannover. The company anticipates quickly ramping up production from 30,000 to 50,000 mini fuel cells/yr.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Honda, Plug demonstrate home hydrogen station
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Honda R&D Co Ltd, in collaboration with Plug Power, have successfully demonstrated a prototype Home Energy Station (HES) that can generate hydrogen from natural gas for use in FCV while providing electricity and hot water to the home. The HES system can produce enough hydrogen to refill the tank of a Honda FCX car once a day, with the filling process taking just a few minutes. The system configuration consists of a reformer, a fuel cell to provide power for the overall system using some of the extracted hydrogen, hydrogen purification, a compressor, and a high-pressure storage tank. The tank has a capacity of 400 L at 420 bar, and the system can produce a maximum of 2 N cu m/hr of hydrogen at 99.99% or higher purity.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Proceedings of HotOS 2003 - 9th Workshop on Hot Topics in Operating Systems
Source title: Proceedings of HotOS 2003 - 9th Workshop on Hot Topics in Operating Systems
Abstract: The proceedings contain 31 papers. The topics discussed include: scheduling and simulation: how to upgrade distributed systems; development tools for distributed applications; magpie: online modeling and performance-aware systems; high availability, scalable storage, dynamic peer networks: pick two; crash-only software; certifying program execution with secure processors; using runtime paths for macroanalysis; sensing user intention and context for energy management; virtual appliances in the collective: a road to hassle-free computing; the phoenix recovery system: rebuilding from the ashes of an internet catastrophe; magpie: online modeling and performance-aware systems; and why can't I find my files? new methods for automating attribute assignment.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: ASHRAE Transactions 2003
Source title: ASHRAE Transactions
Abstract: The proceedings contains 75 papers. Topics discussed include HVAC control, energy codes and standards, heat storage, air conditioning, supermarket refrigeration, advances in room air distribution, water treatment topics for enhanced system safety and performance, optimum control strategies for variable flow pumping, absorption/sorption heat pumps and refrigeration systems, duct design, construction and airflow measurement, residential thermal distribution efficiency, air-to-carbon dioxide heat exchangers, energy simulation: building loads, improvements in fenestration analysis, international thermal storage developments and interoperable computer applications and recent advances in tube-side multiphase flow visualization, heat transfer and pressure drop correlation.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: ASHRAE Transactions 2003
Source title: ASHRAE Transactions
Abstract: This Volume 2 of the conference proceedings contains 86 papers. Topics discussed include natural convection, heat pumps, refrigeration systems, heating systems, ventilation and heat supply units, water cooled chillers, thermal comfort, thermal energy storage, solar thermal collectors, air exchange efficiency, waste heat driven dessicant systems, energy conservation, cleanroom design, whole building energy simulation, winter performance and thermal environment.

Authors: Dolce J., Colozza A., Wagner R.
Title: A regenerative electric power system for high altitude airships
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States; Analex Corporation, Cleveland, OH, United States; University of Toledo, Cleveland, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dolce, J., NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States; Colozza, A., Analex Corporation, Cleveland, OH, United States; Wagner, R., University of Toledo, Cleveland, OH, United States
Abstract: Interest exists for developing technologies that will allow for long term observation and scientific study of the upper atmosphere as well as a move to investigate "greener" aircraft propulsion systems through the use of "more electric power". This paper discusses recent work that was undertaken by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Glenn Research Center. A study was conducted to evaluate the use of regenerative systems on high altitude airships, which have the potential to meet many of these needs. The baseline airship configuration was derived from requirements set by the Department of Defense, in that it would fly at 70,000 feet (21 kilometers) for as long as a year. This would give it a 380 mile radius viewing capability which could provide radar coverage over most of the East Coast. The study commenced with various airship sizes to ascertain the capability of meeting long term missions throughout the year, especially given high winds during the winter. This would set the requirements for sizing the energy and power levels that would be used for stationkeeping as well as for an assumed payload. Operating scenarios versus technology breakthroughs will the trades necessary for continuous operation at altitude. These scenarios could include operating several airships sequentially, operating airships that are not fully regenerative (i.e., incorporating fuel storage to compensate for high-energy requirements) or operating alternative observation platforms such as Airborne Warning and Control Systems (AWACS) aircraft. Technology breakthroughs would be needed should the airship need to maintain continuous coverage throughout the year and at all locations. Primarily, these breakthroughs would require significant reductions in mass to minimize the lifting volume, which would minimize drag. The technologies that were incorporated in this study include: thin film photovoltaic cells, regenerative fuel cell energy storage systems, high voltage power management and distribution systems, lightweight, high speed motors and controls, low Reynolds number thermal management systems and mechanical integration. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.

Authors: Zhang Y., Yang J.
Title: Low Cost Instruction Cache Designs for Tag Comparison Elimination
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX 75083, United States; Comp. Sci./Engineering Department, Univ. of California at Riverside, Riverside, CA 92521, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Y., Computer Science Department, University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX 75083, United States; Yang, J., Comp. Sci./Engineering Department, Univ. of California at Riverside, Riverside, CA 92521, United States
Abstract: Tag comparison elimination (TCE) is an effective approach to reduce I-cache energy. Current research focuses on finding good tradeoffs between hardware cost and percentage of comparisons that can be removed. For this purpose, two low cost innovations are proposed in this paper. We design a small dedicated TCE table whose size is flexible both horizontally (entry size) and vertically (number of entries). The design also minimizes interactions with the I-cache. For a 64-way 16K cache, the new design reduces the tag comparisons to 4.0% with a fraction only 20% of the hardware cost of the way memoization technique [5]. The result is. 40% better compared to a recent proposed low cost design [2] of comparable hardware cost.
Author Keywords: Low-Power Instruction Cache; Tag Comparison Elimination

Abstract: LEO simulated life tests of 100Ah Lithium-Ion cells have been performed by ESA-ESTEC since May 1999. The test conditions are fixed 30% depth of discharge (DOD) cycling test and variable DOD cycling test. The tests reach to 17,000 cycles and 35,000 subcycles, respectively. The results of capacity and voltage trend are showing good agreement with the estimation. It has enough margin to achieve required in LEO mission for more than 7 years. © 2003 by JAPAN STORAGE BATTERY CO., LTD.

Authors: Lee H.G., Chang N.
Title: Energy-Aware Memory Allocation in Heterogeneous Non-Volatile Memory Systems
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Design
Affiliations: Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, H.G., Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea; Chang, N., Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea
Abstract: Memory systems consume a significant portion of power in hand-held embedded systems. So far, low-power memory techniques have addressed the power consumption when the system is turned on. In this paper, we consider data retention energy during the power-off period. For this purpose, we first characterize the data retention energy and cycle-accurate active mode energy of the non-volatile memory systems. Next, we present energy-aware memory allocation for a given task set taking into account arrival rate, execution time, code size, user data size and the number of memory transactions by the use of trace-driven simulation. Experiments demonstrate that our optimal configuration can save up to 26% of the memory system energy compared with traditional allocation schemes.

Authors: Liao W., Li F., He L.
Title: Microarchitecture Level Power and Thermal Simulation Considering Temperature Dependent Leakage Model
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, Univ. of California at Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liao, W., Electrical Engineering Department, Univ. of California at Los Angeles, United States; Li, F., Electrical Engineering Department, Univ. of California at Los Angeles, United States; He, L., Electrical Engineering Department, Univ. of California at Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we present power models with clock and temperature scaling, and develop the first of its type coupled thermal and power simulation with temperature-dependent leakage power model at micro-architecture level. We show that leakage energy and total energy can be different by up to 2.5X and 2X for temperatures between 90°C and 130°C, respectively. Given such big energy variations, no power model at microarchitecture level is accurate without considering temperature dependent leakage models.

Authors: Menon A., Nandy S.K., Mehendale M.
Title: Multivoltage Scheduling with Voltage-Partitioned Variable Storage
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design
Affiliations: Texas Instruments India, India; Indian Institute of Science, India
Authors with affiliations: Menon, A., Texas Instruments India, India; Nandy, S.K., Indian Institute of Science, India; Mehendale, M., Texas Instruments India, India
Abstract: Multivoltage scheduling (MVS) for datapaths offers the energy savings of voltage scaling on a per-operation basis with a voltage aware operator scheduling. This work investigates the effect of using multivoltage register file storage in operator graph scheduling for multivoltage datapaths, thus partitioning the variable storage space on the basis of operating voltages. Scheduling operations on multivoltage functional units lowers the energy-delay product by exploiting slack in the schedule. We find that using multivoltage partitioned register files do the same by exploiting the variable lifetimes in the schedule. In a resource constrained context, longer variable lifetimes provide the opportunity to store such variables in low voltage register files. A ZOLP formulation for the resource constrained MVS problem is presented along with energy-delay savings obtained from applying this formulation to image processing transform graphs.

Authors: Molina C., Aliagas C., García M., González A., Tubella J.
Title: Non Redundant Data Cache
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Design
Affiliations: Dept. Eng. Infomàtica, Universitat Rovira i Virgili, Tarragona, Spain; Dept. d'Arquitectura de Computadors, Univ. Politecnica de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain; Intel Barcelona Research Center, Intel Labs, Univ. Politécnica Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain

Politecnica de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain, Intel Barcelona Research Center, Intel Labs, Univ. Politécnica Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain; Tubella, J., Dept. d'Arquitectura de Computadors, Univ. Politecnica de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain
Abstract: Current microprocessors spend a huge percentage of the die area to implement the memory hierarchy. Moreover, cache memory is responsible for a significant percentage of the total energy consumption. This paper presents a novel data cache design to reduce its die area, power dissipation and latency. The new scheme, called Non Redundant Cache (NRC), exploits the immense amount of value replication observed in traditional data caches. The NRC cache significantly reduces the storage requirements by avoiding the replication of values. Results show that the NRC cache reduces the die area in a 32%, the power dissipation by 14% and the latency by 25%, while maintaining the miss ratio of a conventional cache.

Authors: Ponomarev D., Kucuk G., Ergin O., Ghose K.
Title: Power Efficient Comparators for Long Arguments in Superscalar Processors
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, State University of New York, Binghamton, NY 13902-6000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ponomarev, D., Department of Computer Science, State University of New York, Binghamton, NY 13902-6000, United States; Kucuk, G., Department of Computer Science, State University of New York, Binghamton, NY 13902-6000, United States; Ergin, O., Department of Computer Science, State University of New York, Binghamton, NY 13902-6000, United States; Ghose, K., Department of Computer Science, State University of New York, Binghamton, NY 13902-6000, United States
Abstract: Traditional pulldown comparators that are used to implement associative addressing logic in superscalar microprocessors dissipate energy on a mismatch in any bit position in the comparands. As mismatches occur much more frequently than matches in many situations, such circuits are extremely energy-inefficient. In recognition of this inefficiency, a series of dissipate-on-match comparator designs have been proposed to address the power considerations. These designs, however, are limited to at most 8-bit long arguments. In this paper, we examine the designs of energy-efficient comparators capable of comparing arguments as long as 32 bits in size. Such long comparands are routinely used in the load-store queues, caches, BTBs and TLBs. We use the actual layout data and the realistic bit patterns of the comparands (obtained from the simulated execution of SPEC 2000 benchmarks) to show the energy impact from the use of the new comparators. In general, a non-trivial combination of traditional and dissipate-on-match 8-bit comparator blocks represents the most energy-efficient and fastest solution. As an example of this general approach, we show how fast and energy-efficient comparators can be designed for comparing addresses within the load-store queue of a superscalar processor.
Author Keywords: Low-power comparators; Superscalar datapath
Index Keywords: Benchmarking; Bit error rate; Buffer storage; Computer simulation; Data reduction; Data storage equipment; Energy dissipation; Energy efficiency; Formal logic; Queueing networks; Low-power comparators; Superscalar datapath; Microprocessor chips

Authors: Nicolaescu D., Veidenbaum A., Nicolau A.
Title: Reducing Data Cache Energy Consumption via Cached Load/Store Queue
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design
Affiliations: Center for Embedded Computer Systems, University of California, Irvine, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nicolaescu, D., Center for Embedded Computer Systems, University of California, Irvine, United States; Veidenbaum, A., Center for Embedded Computer Systems, University of California, Irvine, United States; Nicolau, A., Center for Embedded Computer Systems, University of California, Irvine, United States
Abstract: High-performance processors use a large set-associative L1data cache with multiple ports. As clock speeds and size increase such a cache consumes a significant percentage of the total processor energy. This paper proposes a method of saving energy by reducing the number of data cache accesses. It does so by modifying the Load/Store Queue design to allow "caching" of previously accessed data values on both loads and stores after the corresponding memory access instruction has been committed. It is shown that a 32-entry modified LSQ design allows an average of 38.5% of the loads in the SpecINT95 benchmarks and 18.9% in the SpecFP95 benchmarks to get their data from the LSQ. The reduction in the number of LI cache accesses results in up to a 40% reduction in the LI data cache energy consumption and in an up to a 16% improvement in the energy-delay product while requiring almost no additional hardware or complex control logic.
Author Keywords: Cache; Load queue; Low energy; Low latency; Low power; LSQ; Memory; Store queue

Authors: Hu J.S., Nadgir A., Vijaykrishnan N., Irwin M.J., Kandemir M.
Title: Exploiting Program Hotspots and Code Sequentiality for Instruction Cache Leakage Management
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Design
Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hu, J.S., Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Nadgir, A., Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Vijaykrishnan, N., Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Irwin, M.J., Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Kandemir, M., Computer Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Abstract: Leakage energy optimization for caches has been the target of much recent effort. In this work, we focus on instruction caches and tailor two techniques that exploit the two major factors that shape the instruction access behavior, namely, hotspot execution and sequentiality. First, we adopt a hotspot detection mechanism by profiling the branch behavior at runtime and utilize this to implement a HotSpot based Leakage Management (HSLM) mechanism. Second, we exploit code sequentiality in implementing a Just-In-Time Activation (JITA) that transitions cache lines to active mode just before they are accessed. We utilize the recently proposed drowsy cache that dynamically scales voltages for leakage reduction and implement various schemes that use different combinations of HSLM and JITA. Our experimental evaluation using the SPEC2000 benchmark suite shows that instruction cache leakage energy consumption can be reduced by 63%, 49% and 29%, on the average, as compared to an unoptimized cache, a recently proposed hardware optimized cache, and a cache optimized using compiler, respectively. Further, we observe that these energy savings can be obtained without a significant impact on performance.
Author Keywords: Cache design; Leakage power
Index Keywords: Benchmarking; Buffer storage; Codes (standards); Design; Electric potential; Energy utilization; Microprocessor chips; Optimization; Program processors; Cache design; Leakage power; Leakage currents

Authors: Li M.-H., Kenny A., Beach R., Palazzolo A., Provenza A., Kascak A.
Title: Fault tolerant homopolar magnetic bearings
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: Texas A and M University, United States; NASA Glenn Research Center, United States
Authors with affiliations: Li, M.-H., Texas A and M University, United States; Kenny, A., Texas A and M University, United States; Beach, R., NASA Glenn Research Center, United States; Palazzolo, A., Texas A and M University, United States; Provenza, A., NASA Glenn Research Center, United States; Kascak, A., NASA Glenn Research Center, United States
Abstract: Magnetic suspensions (MS) satisfy the long life and low loss conditions demanded by satellite and ISS based flywheels used for Attitude Control and Energy Storage (ACES) service. This paper summarizes the development of a novel MS that improves reliability via fault tolerant operation. Specifically, flux coupling between poles of a homopolar magnetic bearing is shown to deliver desired forces even after termination of coil currents to a subset of "failed poles". Linear, coordinate decoupled force-voltage relations are also maintained before and after failure by bias linearization. Current distribution matrices (CDM) which adjust the currents and fluxes following a pole set failure are determined for many faulted pole combinations. The CDM's and the system responses are obtained utilizing 1D magnetic circuit models with fringe and leakage factors derived from detailed, 3D, finite element field models. Reliability results are presented vs. detection/correction delay time and individual power amplifier reliability for 4, 6, and 7 pole configurations. Reliability is shown for two "success" criteria, i.e. (a) no catcher bearing contact following pole failures and (b) re-levitation off of the catcher bearings following pole failures. An advantage of the method presented over other redundant operation approaches is a significantly reduced requirement for backup hardware such as additional actuators or power amplifiers. © 2003 by MING-HSIU LI.

Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC

Abstract: This paper introduces a heat pump system with a latent heat storage utilizing seawater installed in an aquarium. Heat from the seawater is collected and used as the heat source for the heat pump system. This maintains the indoor conditions at constant temperature and relative humidity. With regard to the heat pump system using low-temperature unutilized heat source, development is introduced on a heat source load responsive heat pump system, which combines a load variation responsive heat pump utilizing seawater with a latent heat (ice plus water slurry) storage system using nighttime electric power serving for electric power load leveling. The experimental COP (Coefficient of performance) of the proposed heat exchanger from seawater and latent heat storage cooling assisted heat pump system will be shown in detail. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.

Authors: Smart M.C., Ratnakumar B.V., Chin K.B., Whitcanack L.D., Surampudi S.
Title: Performance characteristics of lithium-ion technology under extreme environmental conditions
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smart, M.C., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Ratnakumar, B.V., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Chin, K.B., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Whitcanack, L.D., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Surampudi, S., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Abstract: Lithium-ion technology has been demonstrated to have high specific energy, high energy density, and relatively long life. In addition, lithium-ion technology is especially attractive, since it has the potential to operate over a very wide temperature range, which is particularly important for a number of applications. This potential derives from the fact that lithium-ion cells possess organic solvent-based electrolytes, in contrast to aqueous-based electrolytes, which can be tailored to provide high conductivity over a wide range of temperatures. Thus, in recent years, advances in electrolyte formulations have led to dramatic improvements in the capability of lithium-ion technology to operate at extreme temperatures, especially low temperatures. However, it still remains a challenge to demonstrate excellent low temperature capability throughout the life of a cell, especially after being subjected to high temperature cycling or exposure. In order to understand these performance limitations, a number of aerospace prototype cells, ranging in capacity from 1 to 45 AHr, have been tested over a wide range of temperatures (-70 to +75°C). In addition, many cells have been tested under conditions of alternating high and low temperatures to determine the impact that variable temperature cycling has upon cell health and performance. To further elaborate upon possible performance degradation mechanisms present, the results of a number of experimental three-electrode cells will be presented. These individual cells have provided a test vehicle in which electrochemical characterization of electrodes can be performed, as a function of cycling and storage. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Degradation; Electrochemical electrodes; Electrolytes; Energy conversion; Ions; Lithium; Lithium-ion batteries; Temperature; Electrochemical characterizations; Electrolyte formulation; Environmental conditions; High temperature cycling; Performance characteristics; Performance degradation; Performance limitations; Wide temperature ranges; Environmental technology

Authors: Kimble M.C.
Title: Fuel cell & electrolyzer energy storage system for telecommunication backup power
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: ElectroChem, Inc, 400 W. Cummings Park, Woburn, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kimble, M.C., ElectroChem, Inc, 400 W. Cummings Park, Woburn, MA, United States
Abstract: ElectroChem has been developing and demonstrating a regenerative fuel cell energy storage system for backup power applications including telecommunication towers and computer data processing centers. The increasing unreliability of electrical energy from the grid is financially hurting many organizations whose business revenue is dependent on the constant interchange of digital data information. Primary power to these organizations is provide by the electrical grid and backed up with lead acid batteries and diesel generators. Unfortunately, both the batteries and the diesel generators have many undesirable attributes including hazardous emissions, low reliability, and high cycle-life costs. ElectroChem's ECcell™ fuel cell based system has been designed to deliver reliable and high quality electrical energy for backup power applications with a low cycle-life cost. During a power outage, our system provides uninterrupted electrical power from a proton exchange membrane fuel cell stack using pressurized storage of hydrogen and oxygen gas. Water generated during the fuel cell reaction is collected and stored until the grid power or other primary power is restored. This water is then electrolyzed in our highpressure electrolyzer regenerating the hydrogen and oxygen gases in the gas tanks. One of the real advantages of our system approach is that the system is entirely a closed-loop system that is clean and quiet. Our design approach maximizes the system reliability by using a minimum of components that also lowers the system cost. © 2003 by ElectroChem, Inc.

Authors: Gemci T., Chigier N.
Title: Electrohydrodynamic atomization for mems combustion engines
Source title: 41st Aerospace Sciences Meeting and Exhibit
Affiliations: Spray Systems Technology Center, Mechanical Engineering Department, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gemci, T., Spray Systems Technology Center, Mechanical Engineering Department, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States; Chigier, N., Spray Systems Technology Center, Mechanical Engineering Department, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Abstract: This paper aims to demonstrate the feasibility of generating monosized droplets in the diameter range of 1-10 μm for the commercially available liquid hydrocarbons fuels (gasoline, kerosene, and diesel) using the electrospray technique through an 100 μm ID stainless steel capillary. The result will be used to develop a Micro ElectroMechanical Systems (MEMS) based electrospray system for liquid fuel injection in powerMEMS devices. The flow rate of the MEMS electrospray system must be sufficient for continuous micro-combustor operation. The main factors to be considered are: energy efficiency and small size for the atomization system, the mixing process and the combustion chamber. MEMS based propulsion devices have a great potential for providing high specific power. A growing trend of miniaturization in electro and mechanical engineering devices (micro transmitters, embedded micro sensors/actuators, small robots, wrist communicators, indestructible jet engines, micro-airborne sensors and communicators, micro thermal-chemical power systems etc.) has stimulated new concepts for thermal-fluid scientists in the field of micro-power generation in the watts range. The interest in chemical energy sources as alternatives to electrochemical batteries for MEMS applications lies in the potential to significantly increase energy storage densities because the specific energy of liquid hydrocarbon fuels is around 100 times larger than that of batteries. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Burke K.A.
Title: Unitized regenerative fuel cell system development
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burke, K.A., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: Unitized Regenerative Fuel Cells (URFC) have recently been developed by several fuel cell manufacturers. These manufacturers have concentrated their efforts on the development of the cell stack technology itself, and have not up to this point devoted much effort to the design and development of the balance of plant. A fuel cell technology program at the Glenn Research Center (GRC) that has as its goal the definition and feasibility testing of the URFC system balance of plant. Besides testing the feasibility, the program also intends to minimize the system weight, volume, and parasitic power as its goal. The design concept currently being developed uses no pumps to circulate coolant or reactants, and minimizes the ancillary components to only the oxygen and hydrogen gas storage tanks, a water storage tank, a loop heat pipe to control the temperature and two pressure control devices to control the cell stack pressures during operation. The information contained in this paper describes the design and operational concepts employed in this concept. The paper also describes the NASA Glenn research program to develop this concept and test its feasibility.

Authors: Price D., Goldman E., Nett D., Putnam S., Weidenheimer D., Bloemker C., White R., Wynn T.
Title: Dew technology at the Titan Corporation
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: Titan Pulse Sciences Division, San Leandro, CA, United States; Titan Electromagnetics and Electronics Division, Albuquerque, United States; Titan Pulse Sciences Division, San Diego, CA, United States; Titan Pulse Sciences Division, Watsonville, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Price, D., Titan Pulse Sciences Division, San Leandro, CA, United States; Goldman, E., Titan Pulse Sciences Division, San Leandro, CA, United States; Nett, D., Titan Pulse Sciences Division, San Leandro, CA, United States; Putnam, S., Titan Pulse Sciences Division, San Leandro, CA, United States; Weidenheimer, D., Titan Pulse Sciences Division, San Leandro, CA, United States; Bloemker, C., Titan Electromagnetics and Electronics Division, Albuquerque, United States; White, R., Titan Pulse Sciences Division, San Diego, CA, United States; Wynn, T., Titan Pulse Sciences Division, Watsonville, CA, United States
Abstract: The Titan Corporation has been developing directed energy technologies since the early 1980's. Over this time Titan has provided advanced power supplies for electromagnetic gun and laser research while making broader contributions in the field of high power microwaves (HPM). Titan's HPM work expanded from initial efforts fielding and operating the first gigawattlevel oscillators for susceptibility test applications, to research and development maximizing the peak and average output powers and overall efficiency realized from such systems. As interest in HPM technology has spread globally, Titan has leveraged this core competency and provided the HPM equipment for nearly all of the major European effects test facilities. Titan's current interests focus on compact, efficient and reliable directed energy weapon systems, and the advanced subsystems and components that enable the same. Specific subsystems of interest include pulse forming networks, intermediate energy storage and power conditioning elements. These subsystems are designed for reduced size and weight while still meeting severe service, platform integration, lifetime and thermal management constraints. Specific components under development at Titan include lasergated solid-state switches and both high peak and high average power, frequency-agile, HPM oscillators. Status and recent results from this research are presented. © 2003 by David Price.

Authors: Kammash T.
Title: Laser accelerated heavy-ion plasma propulsion system
Source title: 39th AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference and Exhibit
Affiliations: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kammash, T., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Abstract: The Ultrafast "Laser Accelerated Plasma Propulsion System" LAPPS makes use of lasers with very short pulse lengths to accelerate charged particles to relativistic speeds. Recent experimental data reveal that high intensity lasers are capable of producing collimated, charge-neutral proton beams containing more than 6 × 1014 particles at a mean energy of 5 MeV with a total beam energy of 500J. If used in propulsion, these systems are capable of generating specific impulses of more than one million seconds albeit at very modest thrusts, and require a nuclear power system to drive them. A major research effort at the University of Michigan is directed at finding ways to enhance the thrust of LAPPS. One approach is to irradiate larger focal spots in solid targets, and the other is to accelerate heavier ions by first removing the moisture from targets then coating them with materials of larger mass numbers such as carbon or fluorine. In this paper we address these issues in light of a recently developed acceleration model. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Heavy ions; High energy lasers; Nuclear fuels; Acceleration models; High intensity lasers; Laser accelerated plasma propulsion systems; Nuclear power system; Research efforts; Solid targets; Specific impulse; University of Michigan; Propulsion

Authors: Moshovos A.
Title: Checkpointing Alternatives for High Performance, Power-Aware Processors
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design
Affiliations: Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Moshovos, A., Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Toronto, Canada
Abstract: High performance processors use checkpointing to rapidly recover from branch mispredictions and possibly other exceptions. We demonstrate that conventional checkpointing becomes unattractive in terms of resource and power requirements for future generation processors. We propose out-of-order checkpoint release and checkpoint prediction, two alternatives that require significantly less resources and power while maintaining high-performance. We demonstrate their utility at the register alias table (RAT). Our methods reduce the number of RAT checkpoints to 1/3 (from 48 down to 16) for an aggressive, 8-way superscalar processor with a 256-entry instruction window. Using a 0.1 um process model we estimate that RAT power is reduced by 24%.
Author Keywords: Checkpointing; Out-of-order execution; Power density; Power-aware; Renaming
