Abstract: Advanced Power Reactor 1400(APR1400) is an evolutionary ALWR with the rated thermal power of 4,000 MW. APR1400 adopts improved safety systems to enhance plant safety and to satisfy licensing and utility requirements. In particular, the containment system is a mitigation part of the defense in depth philosophy to prevent large radioactive material release into the environment in the event of an accident. In addition, it is strengthened by additional margins in the design consideration of severe accidents with a realistic approach. In this paper, the design objectives applied to the APR1400 containment system are discussed first. The major design features to improve the performance and safety of the containment system are followed, where improved features affecting the safety function of the containment such as containment and reactor cavity configuration, heat removal, fission products control, hydrogen control, safety depressurization and vent, and in-containment refueling water storage tank, and so on are discussed in detail. Finally, the results of safety analysis for DBA and severe accident are presented.
Index Keywords: Fission products; Hydrogen storage; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Nuclear reactor accidents; Advanced power reactor 1400; Containment systems; Depressurizations; Design and analysis; Design considerations; Design objectives; Hydrogen control; In-containment refueling water storage tank; Product design

Authors: Vallier J., Fernández N., Tielas M.
Title: Management and automation of set point calculations in NPPS
Source title: 2003 International Congress on Advances in Nuclear Power Plants - Proceedings of ICAPP 2003
Affiliations: Empresarios Agrupados, Magallanes, 3, 28015 Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Vallier, J., Empresarios Agrupados, Magallanes, 3, 28015 Madrid, Spain; Fernández, N., Empresarios Agrupados, Magallanes, 3, 28015 Madrid, Spain; Tielas, M., Empresarios Agrupados, Magallanes, 3, 28015 Madrid, Spain
Abstract: The large number of Setpoints and associated allowable values that have to be determined in a nuclear power plant prompted EMPRESARIOS AGRUPADOS to develop the AVACO program to computerise and optimise the calculation process. This application has been developed based on Microsoft© ACCESS 97 database and Mathsoft© Mathcad 8 calculation program. The calculation methodology used by AVACO complies with the procedures and criteria established in Regulatory Guide 1.105, issue 3, dated December 1999, Setpoints for Safety-Related Instrumentation, and in standard ISA-S67.04.01-2000. The computerised calculation of nominal trip points and allowable values for trip functions saves time, prevents possible errors which are more likely to occur in manual calculation, and allows adequate control of input data and results. The database contains all input data and associated references required for calculation, as well as the calculation results. This integration enables the quick and efficient handling, storage and updating of large volumes of data required for calculation. Mathcad 8 performs the calculations using templates created for different measuring channel configurations. Said templates define in text form the formulae used. Following the manual introduction of input data into the database, these data are automatically transferred to the corresponding spreadsheet template; the calculation results are then automatically incorporated back into the database. EMPRESARIOS AGRUPADOS and TECNATOM are currently using this application in the Calculation of Setpoints for the Lungmen Nuclear Power Plant project.
Index Keywords: Nuclear power plants; Calculation process; MicroSoft; Setpoints; Nuclear energy

Authors: Solbrig C.W., Lineberry M.J., Benedict R.W.
Title: Repository storage strategy with central station processing
Source title: 2003 International Congress on Advances in Nuclear Power Plants - Proceedings of ICAPP 2003
Affiliations: Argonne National Laboratory, P.O. Box 2528, Idaho Falls, ID 83403-2528, United States
Authors with affiliations: Solbrig, C.W., Argonne National Laboratory, P.O. Box 2528, Idaho Falls, ID 83403-2528, United States; Lineberry, M.J., Argonne National Laboratory, P.O. Box 2528, Idaho Falls, ID 83403-2528, United States; Benedict, R.W., Argonne National Laboratory, P.O. Box 2528, Idaho Falls, ID 83403-2528, United States
Abstract: One of the technical limitations of the Yucca Mountain spent fuel repository capacity to store spent fuel from U.S. reactors for the next 50 years depends on the long-term power output in the spent nuclear fuel. Processing all of the commercial spent fuel existing in the U.S. would require a gargantuan effort, but processing some of the spent fuel is practical and could increase the effective storage capacity of Yucca Mountain. The purpose of this work is to determine potential scenarios for processing plant(s) needed to assure that the Yucca Mountain Repository technical capacity will be adequate at least until 2050 with increasing nuclear energy production. Processing reduces the geologic disposal requirements by separating the spent fuel into: 1) transuranics (TRU, i.e., plutonium plus minor actinides), 2) uranium, and 3) fission products. The transuranics are the primary long-term (> 250 years) heat source and the uranium is the major mass component of the spent nuclear fuel. These two products can be used to manufacture fast reactor fuel while the fission products, any process losses, and the non-processed fuel must be disposed in a geologic repository. If the TRU product is converted into fission products, which is assumed to be done in fast reactors in this study, and the TRU wastes are not placed in Yucca Mountain, the long-term heat sources are reduced. This reduction simplifies the heat management strategy and fission product storage. The equivalent metric tons of spent nuclear fuel, which legislatively sets the capacity of Yucca Mountain, can be increased five times as compared to unprocessed spent fuel. Fission product wastes also accrue from processing fast reactor spent fuel, at the same rate per GWY as thermal plants, and will also be stored in Yucca Mountain. A model to calculate the storage requirements for different power projections and processing plant sizes is described in this paper. As expected, results show storage saved is independent of the actual U.S. power in the future, but depends mainly on the processing plant size. The total storage required decreases strongly with processing rate. With any reasonable nuclear power projection, including one constant at the year 2000 level, the legislated capacity of Yucca Mountain will be reached by 2015. Early action taken to build a small plant (500 MTHM/yr) by 2014 would allow later larger plant(s) to be sized to fit the actual demand and still stay within the "technical capacity" of Yucca Mountain until at least mid-century. U.S. spent fuel plus the high level waste from a 500 MTHM/yr processing plant started in 2014, followed by an evolutionary 2000 MTHM/yr plant in 2025 with a nuclear growth of 2 percent per year starting in 2005 could be handled by Yucca Mountain until the year 2050. An alternative growth model staying static until 2010 and a 3% annual increase starting in 2011 could be handled by processing plants of 500 MTHM/yr in 2014, and a 1500 MTHM/y both in 2021 and 2028. In order to minimize the storage of transuranics, their consumption in fast reactors is important. The number of fast reactor plants is dependent on their design and their conversion ratio. For the 2% nuclear energy growth scenario, ninety plants would be required with a conversion ratio of 1., whereas only 47 plants with a conversion ratio of 0.5 are needed.
Index Keywords: Fast reactors; Fission products; Fuels; Geological repositories; Landforms; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive wastes; Spent fuels; Uranium; Energy productions; Geologic repository; Spent fuel repositories; Spent nuclear fuels; Storage requirements; Technical capacity; Technical limitations; Yucca mountain repository; Fuel storage

Authors: Bang Y.S., Ahn H.J., Kim I.-G., Kim B.H.
Title: Regulatory approach on pool temperature limit of in-containment refueling water storage tank under accident condition
Source title: 2003 International Congress on Advances in Nuclear Power Plants - Proceedings of ICAPP 2003
Affiliations: Korea Institute of Nuclear Safety, 19 Gusung-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Taejon, 305-338, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Bang, Y.S., Korea Institute of Nuclear Safety, 19 Gusung-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Taejon, 305-338, South Korea; Ahn, H.J., Korea Institute of Nuclear Safety, 19 Gusung-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Taejon, 305-338, South Korea; Kim, I.-G., Korea Institute of Nuclear Safety, 19 Gusung-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Taejon, 305-338, South Korea; Kim, B.H., Korea Institute of Nuclear Safety, 19 Gusung-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Taejon, 305-338, South Korea
Abstract: The In-containment Refueling Water Storage Tank (IRWST) is a newly adopted system in the design of the Advanced Pressurized Reactor (APR)-1400 in Korea. The key function of IRWST of interest is to condense the steam released from the pressurizer through Pilot Operated Safety Relief Valves (POSRV) through "sparger" to the water in the tank under the accident condition. The integrity of the piping system and the IRWST in which the spargers are submerged is strongly dependent on the hydrodynamic loads induced by the POSRV and IRWST operation. In the present study, a regulatory approach to determine the local pool temperature limit specific to the APR-1400 is discussed. The approach is based on the similarity in function and structure between the IRWST and BWR (Boiling Water Reactors) suppression pool while considering the difference in quencher configuration. The criteria on the local temperature limit in BWR suppression pool, the related event analysis scope, and the analysis assumptions are reviewed for providing a background of the criteria for the APR-1400 IRWST. The detailed design of APR-1400 IRWST is reviewed and the related accident analyses are investigated. The applicability of the BWR criteria, accident analysis scope, and assumption in analysis are also investigated. As a result, it is found that maximum local temperature, 366.5 K (200°F), is an applicable limit during the all accident conditions of APR-1400 IRWST. The scope of event analysis can be equivalently matched to those events in BWR, however, the assumptions in analysis of total loss of feedwater (TLOFW) needs further study due to its nature of beyond design basis accident. Local-to-bulk temperature difference also should be incorporated into the criteria such that the temperature difference should be determined by the current computational fluid dynamic (CFD) capability directly and the sufficient verification should be provided.
Index Keywords: Computational fluid dynamics; Design; Feedwater analysis; Lakes; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Nuclear reactor accidents; Safety valves; Tanks (containers); Temperature; Accident conditions; Beyond design basis accident; Hydrodynamic loads; In-containment refueling water storage tank; Pressurized reactors; Safety relief valve; Temperature differences; Temperature limits; Boiling water reactors

Authors: Lee J.H., No H.C.
Title: Scaling and parametric studies of condensation oscillation in an in-containment refueling water storage tank
Source title: 2003 International Congress on Advances in Nuclear Power Plants - Proceedings of ICAPP 2003
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Korea Power Engineering Company, 360-9 Mabuk-ri, Guseong-eup, Yongin-si, Gyeonggi-do 449-713, South Korea; Department of Nuclear and Quantum Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 373-1 Kusong-dong Yusong-gu, Taejon 305-701, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, J.H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Korea Power Engineering Company, 360-9 Mabuk-ri, Guseong-eup, Yongin-si, Gyeonggi-do 449-713, South Korea; No, H.C., Department of Nuclear and Quantum Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 373-1 Kusong-dong Yusong-gu, Taejon 305-701, South Korea
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to study the condensation oscillation phenomena by steam-jetting into subcooled water through a multi-hole sparger, implementing a scaling methodology and the similarity correlation between the test facility and model prototype. To corroborate the scaling methodology, various experimental tests were conducted. The thickness of the boundary layer that encloses the steam cavity was found to be equal to the maximum length of the steam cavity formed. Three key scaling parameters were identified and correlated with the maximum amplitude of pressure oscillation: flow restriction coefficient, area ratio of discharge hole to steam cavity, and density ratio of water to steam. Variations of the oscillation amplitude were small when steam-jetting directions were altered. The concept of a reduction factor was introduced for estimating the oscillation amplitude of the multi-hole sparger with test data from a single-hole sparger.
Index Keywords: Condensation; Digital storage; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Oscillating flow; Steam; Test facilities; Experimental test; In-containment refueling water storage tank; Maximum amplitude; Oscillation amplitude; Pressure oscillation; Reduction factor; Scaling methodology; Scaling parameter; Steam condensers

Authors: Koo J.M., Yim H.S., Hong H.P., Kim Y.B., Kim H.B.
Title: Development of coil current monitoring system for control element drive mechanism control system
Source title: 2003 International Congress on Advances in Nuclear Power Plants - Proceedings of ICAPP 2003
Affiliations: Korea Power Engineering Company, Inc. (KOPEC), 150 Duckjin-Dong Yusung-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Koo, J.M., Korea Power Engineering Company, Inc. (KOPEC), 150 Duckjin-Dong Yusung-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea; Yim, H.S., Korea Power Engineering Company, Inc. (KOPEC), 150 Duckjin-Dong Yusung-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea; Hong, H.P., Korea Power Engineering Company, Inc. (KOPEC), 150 Duckjin-Dong Yusung-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea; Kim, Y.B., Korea Power Engineering Company, Inc. (KOPEC), 150 Duckjin-Dong Yusung-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea; Kim, H.B., Korea Power Engineering Company, Inc. (KOPEC), 150 Duckjin-Dong Yusung-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea
Abstract: The development trends of the Instrumentation and Control (I&C) systems in the Nuclear Power Plants (NPPs) have been recently focused on the improvements of man-machine interface and self-diagnosis to improve the operability and maintainability. KOPEC has developed the on-line Coil Current Monitoring System (CCMS) for the effective and preventive maintenance support of the Control Element Drive Mechanism Control System (CEDMCS). This paper introduces the design of hardware, man-machine interface (MMI), algorithm and software for the CCMS which consists of signal conditioning module, data acquisition computer, and monitoring and analysis computer including related application programs. All coil data are stored and retrieved, and the user can easily operate the system. This system provides various functions such as zoom, scroll, alarm, data logging, instruction and guide for troubleshooting, the generation of the database for abnormal waveform, print, and etc. The Control Element Drive Mechanism (CEDM) coil data is automatically analyzed by checking CEDM timing sequence, coil current amplitude and pattern mismatch of waveform. In addition, it shows various analytical results on MMI displays and informs the diagnosis of abnormal conditions. For more precise analysis, the acquired coil current waveform is manually compared with reference or specific waveform, and database file for automatic fault detection is generated if necessary. This paper also presents the review of test results of CEDM and CEDMCS integrity test performed at plant site using the CCMS. After a successful site acceptance test, many control components of CEDMCS such as opto-isolator card, hall sensor, ACTM (Automatic CEDM Timing Module) card and Silicon Controlled Rectifier (SCR) have been calibrated or replaced after surveillance test using the developed system. The CCMS has been utilized in the Korean Standard Nuclear Power Plants (KSNPs) and has shown that it enhances the operability and reliability of the CEDMCS.
Index Keywords: Acceptance tests; Application programs; Computer hardware; Control systems; Digital storage; Fault detection; Hall effect transducers; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Preventive maintenance; Automatic fault detection; Design of hardwares; Instrumentation and control; Korean standard nuclear power plants; Man-machine interface; Monitoring and analysis; Signal conditioning module; Site acceptance test; Monitoring

Authors: Shimizu M., Kashiwakura J., Hayashi M.
Title: Development of transportation and storage dry metal cask
Source title: 2003 International Congress on Advances in Nuclear Power Plants - Proceedings of ICAPP 2003
Affiliations: Nuclear Systems Division, Hitachi, Ltd., 1-1, Saiwai-cho, 3-chome, Hitachi, Ibaraki, 317-8511, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shimizu, M., Nuclear Systems Division, Hitachi, Ltd., 1-1, Saiwai-cho, 3-chome, Hitachi, Ibaraki, 317-8511, Japan; Kashiwakura, J., Nuclear Systems Division, Hitachi, Ltd., 1-1, Saiwai-cho, 3-chome, Hitachi, Ibaraki, 317-8511, Japan; Hayashi, M., Nuclear Systems Division, Hitachi, Ltd., 1-1, Saiwai-cho, 3-chome, Hitachi, Ibaraki, 317-8511, Japan
Abstract: Spent fuels discharged from nuclear power plants in Japan are planed to be reprocessed at the nuclear fuel recycle plant under construction at Rokkasho-mura. Since the amount of the spent fuels exceeds that of recycled fuel, the spent fuels have to be properly stored and maintained as recycle fuel resource until the beginning of the reprocessing. For that sake, interim storage institutions are being constructed outside the nuclear power plants by 2010. The storage dry casks have been practically used as the intermediate storage in the nuclear power plants. From this reason, the storage system using the storage dry casks is promising as the intermediate storage institutions outside the nuclear power plants, which are under discussion. In the intermediate storage institutions, the storage using the dry cask of the storage metal cask with business showings, having the function of transportation is now under discussion. By employing transportation and storage dual-purpose cask, the repack equipments can be exhausted, and the reliability of the intermediate storage institution can be increased. Our Hitachi, Ltd. has been developing the high reliable and economical transportation and storage dry metal cask. In this report, the outline of our developing transportation and storage dry cask, the various fundamental experiments for developing the metal dry cask, and the results of drop test of a third scale model are described.
Index Keywords: Fuels; Metals; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Recycling; Societies and institutions; Spent fuels; Drop test; Fuel resources; Fundamental experiments; High reliable; Hitachi; Intermediate storage; Scale modeling; Storage systems; Nuclear fuel reprocessing

Authors: Chang C.-J., Lee C.-H., Hong W.-T., Wang L.L.C.
Title: Investigation of the performance of IIST passive core cooling system for Steam Generator Tube Rupture
Source title: 2003 International Congress on Advances in Nuclear Power Plants - Proceedings of ICAPP 2003
Affiliations: Nuclear Engineering Division, Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, P.O. Box 3-3, Lung-Tan, Taoyuan, 325, Taiwan; Gengood Engineering Corporation, 138, Sec. 1, Guangfu Rd., Sanchung City, Taipei, 241, Taiwan; Power Research Institute, Taiwan Power Company, 84, Ta An Road, Shulin, Taipei County, 238, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, C.-J., Nuclear Engineering Division, Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, P.O. Box 3-3, Lung-Tan, Taoyuan, 325, Taiwan; Lee, C.-H., Nuclear Engineering Division, Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, P.O. Box 3-3, Lung-Tan, Taoyuan, 325, Taiwan; Hong, W.-T., Gengood Engineering Corporation, 138, Sec. 1, Guangfu Rd., Sanchung City, Taipei, 241, Taiwan; Wang, L.L.C., Power Research Institute, Taiwan Power Company, 84, Ta An Road, Shulin, Taipei County, 238, Taiwan
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to conduct experiments at the Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER) Integral System Test (IIST) facility for evaluation of the performance of the Passive Core Cooling System (PCCS) during the postulated Steam Generator Tube Rupture (SGTR) event. The IIST is a reduced-height and reduced-pressure (RHRP) test facility that is capable of simulating the thermal-hydraulics of a Westinghouse three-loop PWR. The IIST PCCS includes three core makeup tanks (CMTs), a-four stage automatic depressurization system (ADS), a passive residual heat removal heat exchanger (PRHR HX) submerged into an in-containment refueling water storage tank (IRWST). Four experiments were performed with (1) passive safety injection for two tubes ruptured, and (2) manual actuation of ADS for one, two, and six tubes ruptured. The experimental results show that long term core cooling can be reached for the above SGTR cases. For two tubes ruptured with passive safety injection, effective core cooling can be maintained through the heat removal of PRHR HX and the CMT recirculation flow. For the cases of tube rupture with manual ADS operation, the transient responses of these tests were similar to the small break loss-of-coolant accident (SBLOCA) once ADS was actuated.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Cooling systems; Deceleration; Experiments; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Nuclear reactor accidents; Steam generators; Tanks (containers); Thermoelectric equipment; Automatic depressurization systems; Core makeup tanks; In-containment refueling water storage tank; Institute of nuclear energy researches; Passive core cooling systems; Re-circulation flow; Steam generator tube ruptures; Thermal hydraulics; Tubes (components)

Authors: Novikov V., Parker F.
Title: The global nuclear legacy and its implication on the sustainability of nuclear power
Source title: 2003 International Congress on Advances in Nuclear Power Plants - Proceedings of ICAPP 2003
Affiliations: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, Laxenburg, Austria; Russian Research Center-Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Vanderbilt University, Nashville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Novikov, V., International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, Laxenburg, Austria, Russian Research Center-Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Parker, F., International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, Laxenburg, Austria, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, United States
Abstract: Many studies aimed at evaluation of sustainability of energy development in the 21st century showed that nuclear option might be among the identified sustainable energy options. Nevertheless, attempts to create an international political consensus on the nuclear power's role in sustainable development failed. The question arises: What is behind these controversies? Why do technical views and public perception, that greatly influences the political debate, so diverge? The evaluation of the Global Nuclear Legacy that was performed within the IIASA "Radiation Safety of the Biosphere" (RAD) project definitely shows that the Global Nuclear Legacy has emerged as one of the most important environmental, social, and political problems today. The largest fraction of the radioactive waste is currently being stored at the sites where it was generated, in facilities that were not built for long-term storage. Recent terrorist attacks highlight the risk posed by radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel storage sites that may be targets or used for dirty bombs. Additional threats of environmental degradation are associated with decommissioning of aged nuclear facilities and with carrying out nuclear disarmament at the places where the lack of sufficient infrastructure made it extremely difficult. Thus, the actual and potential implications of the Global Nuclear Legacy will put a huge burden on the future generations and therefore contradict the definition of sustainability given in the Brundtland Report. It seems that the nuclear legacy of the 20th century will stigmatize attempts in the 21st century to utilize advanced techniques if they are characterized as "nuclear". We call this phenomenon "the Stigma of the Global Nuclear Legacy", meaning the inevitable association (conscious or unconscious) of the global nuclear legacy left by intensive development of the nuclear industry, civilian and military, during the second half of the 20th century with nuclear power in general. Is it possible to neutralize the stigma of the Global Nuclear Legacy, and thus enhance the likelihood of success of the nuclear energy option? The paper reviews some outcomes of the IIASA RAD project studies of the Global Nuclear Legacy and discusses the lessons learnt that could help hopefully to answer the above question. As a contribution to this need, the IIASA RAD-project formulated a concept of a five-step study aimed at a better understanding of how to neutralize the nuclear stigma and enhance the future of the nuclear option.
Index Keywords: Fuel storage; Nuclear energy; Nuclear industry; Nuclear power plants; Radioactive wastes; Radioactivity; Energy development; Future generations; Long-term storage; Nuclear disarmaments; Nuclear facilities; Political debates; Political problems; Sustainable energy; Sustainable development

Authors: Diril A.U., Dhillon Y.S., Choi K.-W., Chatterjee A.
Title: An O(N) supply voltage assignment algorithm for low-energy serially connected CMOS modules and a heuristic extension to acyclic data flow graphs
Source title: Proceedings of IEEE Computer Society Annual Symposium on VLSI, ISVLSI
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA  30332, United States
Authors with affiliations: Diril, A.U., School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA  30332, United States; Dhillon, Y.S., School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA  30332, United States; Choi, K.-W., School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA  30332, United States; Chatterjee, A., School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA  30332, United States
Abstract: In this paper, a novel algorithm is proposed for assigning supply voltages to serially executing functional units (FUs) in a digital system such that the overall dynamic energy consumption is minimized for a given timing constraint. Novel closed form expressions for optimum supply voltage values are presented. The computation time of the algorithm is O(N) for N FUs in series. An extension of the O(N) algorithm is proposed for optimizing the acyclic data flow graph associated with any given task. Given the number of FUs available for the task, the operations required for the task are scheduled on the FUs. Voltages are then assigned to the FUs on each path of the flow graph using the O(N) algorithm. Energy savings of 10-60% are achieved on DSP filter designs using the proposed high-level optimization methodology over single supply voltage designs. © 2003 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Data flow computing; Delay; Digital systems; Dynamic voltage scaling; Energy consumption; Flow graphs; Frequency; Iterative algorithms; Scheduling algorithm; Timing

Authors: Tomutsa L.
Title: Computed tomography applications for the oil and gas industry
Source title: 3rd World Congress on Industrial Process Tomography
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tomutsa, L., Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, United States
Abstract: Core flooding, monitored by CT scanning can include water, gas, surfactant, polymer, foam, microbial, steam and other floods as dictated by the recovery processes that are most suited for specific reservoirs. Processes such as wormhole formation, gravity segregation, channeling and fingering during oil production, formation damage and fluid invasion during drilling, and methane hydrate dissociation are also studied by CT imaging. Microfocal CT imaging, using high magnification provides pore network data needed for pore scale modeling and for the study of fluid-rock interactions which, together with the pore topology and geometry, control the flow and trapping of hydrocarbons.Equipment used for imaging porous rocks ranges from industrial CT scanners and modified medical scanners for large samples, to desktop micro-scanners and synchrotron sources for micron resolution of small samples. While traditional CT equipment was stationary, located in laboratories remote from drilling sites, recent development of a portable, cabinet sized, high-speed whole-core scanner, has permitted field measurements of rock properties and geological interpretation prior to any core degradation that can occur due to its preservation, transport, and storage (Freifeld, 2003). The continued trend towards higher resolution and less expensive system components is greatly enhancing the capability of specialized CT systems used in the oil and gas industry.X-ray computed tomography (CT) has been used extensively in the oil and gas industry for imaging, quantifying properties, and determining the distribution of fluids in porous rocks (Wellington, 1987). Samples imaged range in size from tens of centimeters to a few millimeters, with respective voxel sizes varying from hundreds of microns down to a few microns. Whole cores, retrieved during drilling operations, are scanned for geological characterization and for selection of locations where representative plugs will be taken for laboratory petrophysical measurements. Core plugs are scanned to evaluate heterogeneities, such as laminations, fractures, and vugs (large open voids), that influence fluid flow. During laboratory fluid flow tests performed on core plugs (core floods), CT scanning is used to measure the three-dimensional time-varying fluid saturations. Microplugs are scanned to image the pore structure and determine distributions of fluids within the pore space.Porosity and permeability are important rock properties that determine the economic value of a petroleum reservoir. Porosity is the fraction of the bulk volume of the material occupied by voids. It characterizes the volume available in porous rock to store fluids in. Permeability is a measure of the ease with which a fluid can be made to flow through the porous rock by an applied pressure gradient. Relative permeability characterizes the flow when multiple phases and fluids coexist within the same porous rock. Relative permeability is the ratio of permeability of a particular phase to the intrinsic rock permeability and it is a function of phase saturation.To determine the porosity of a core sample, CT scans are performed with the sample saturated successively by two fluids that exhibit strongly contrasting x-ray attenuations, such as air and brine. Knowing the attenuations of the two fluids, the difference between these two sets of images provides the porosity distribution. If two fluids occupy pore space in unknown proportions, CT can be used to determine the saturation of each fluid providing that the fluids have adequate attenuation contrasts. Otherwise, their contrast can be increased by contrast agents, such as iodine or bromine based compounds. Single energy scans are performed for two-fluid saturation measurements. If saturations of three phases (oil, brine and gas) need to be determined, scans are performed at two energies. Dual energy scanning is also used to measure the bulk density and the effective atomic number of the core material. To perform these measurements, the sample needs to be within a coreholder that keeps the ample both immobile, within the x-ray scanner, and provides a means to flow fluid through the core. © 2003 International Society for Industrial Process Tomography.
Index Keywords: Air; Atoms; Bromine compounds; Core samples; Coremaking; Digital storage; Drilling equipment; Floods; Flow of fluids; Gas hydrates; Gas industry; Gases; Geology; Iodine compounds; Medical imaging; Methane; Oil shale; Oil well drilling; Petroleum reservoir engineering; Petroleum reservoirs; Porosity; Reservoirs (water); Rock drilling; Rocks; Scanning; Tomography; Well drilling; Effective atomic number; Fluid-rock interaction; Geological interpretation; Methane hydrate dissociation; Petrophysical Measurements; Porosity distributions; Tomography applications; X-ray computed tomography; Computerized tomography

Authors: Nunes R.C., Da Silva M.M., Davies R.
Title: A comparison of database systems for storing XML documents
Source title: ICEIS 2003 - Proceedings of the 5th International Conference on Enterprise Information Systems
Affiliations: INETI, Departamento de Optoelectrónica, Estrada Lumiar, Lisboa, 1649-038, Portugal; Instituto Superior Técnico, Av. Rovisco Pais, Lisboa, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Nunes, R.C., INETI, Departamento de Optoelectrónica, Estrada Lumiar, Lisboa, 1649-038, Portugal; Da Silva, M.M., Instituto Superior Técnico, Av. Rovisco Pais, Lisboa, Portugal; Davies, R., INETI, Departamento de Optoelectrónica, Estrada Lumiar, Lisboa, 1649-038, Portugal
Abstract: As the need to store large quantities of increasingly complex XML documents augments, the requirements for database products that claim to support XML also increases. For example, it is no longer acceptable to store XML documents without using indices for efficient retrieval of large collections. In this paper we analyse the current versions of products representing the three main approaches to XML storage: native XML databases, XML support by relational databases, and object-oriented databases with XML support. Several products are analysed and compared, including performance tests. Performance aside, one of our main conclusions is that the market urgently needs a standard query language and API, analogous to SQL and ODBC, which were probably the main drivers for the success of relational databases.
Author Keywords: Databases; Integration; Storage; XML

Authors: Hodgett R.A.
Title: Data management: The challenge of the future
Source title: ICEIS 2003 - Proceedings of the 5th International Conference on Enterprise Information Systems
Affiliations: University of South Australia, GPO Box 2471, Adelaide, SA  5001, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Hodgett, R.A., University of South Australia, GPO Box 2471, Adelaide, SA  5001, Australia
Abstract: There has been an explosion in the generation of data in organizations. Much of this data is both unstructured and decentralized. This raises a number of issues for data management in organizations. This paper reports on an investigation that was undertaken in Australia to study the way in which organizations were dealing with the growth and proliferation of data and are planning for the future. The results show a high level of consciousness of the issues but indicate a prevalent optimism that technology will continue to provide solutions to present and future problems facing organizations. It appears that much magnetically recorded data will inevitably be lost over the next few decades unless positive actions are taken now to preserve the data.

Authors: Ho P.-M., Wong T.-T., Choy K.-H., Leung C.S.
Title: PCA-based compression for image-based relighting
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Multimedia and Expo
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shatin, Hong Kong; Dept. of Electronic Engineering, City University of Hong Kong, Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Ho, P.-M., Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shatin, Hong Kong; Wong, T.-T., Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shatin, Hong Kong; Choy, K.-H., Dept. of Electronic Engineering, City University of Hong Kong, Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong; Leung, C.S., Dept. of Electronic Engineering, City University of Hong Kong, Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong
Abstract: The ability to change illumination is a crucial factor in image-based modeling and rendering. Image-based relighting offers such capability. However, the trade-off is the enormous increase of storage requirement. In this paper, we propose a compression scheme that effectively reduces the data volume while maintaining the real-time relighting capability. The proposed method is based on principal component analysis (PCA). A block-wise PCA is used to practically process the huge input data. The output of PCA is a set of eigenimages and the corresponding relighting coefficients. By dropping those low-energy eigenimages, the data size is drastically reduced. To further compress the data, eigenimages left are compressed using transform coding and quantization while the relighting coefficients are compressed using uniform quantization. We also suggest the suitable target bit rate for each phase of the compression method in order to preserve the visual quality. Finally, we propose real-time engine that relights images from the compressed data. © 2003 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Data compression; Image-based relighting; Principal component analysis

Authors: Laughton M.A., Barak M., Inman D.
Title: Batteries
Source title: Electrical Engineer's Reference Book: Sixteenth Edition
Affiliations: Department of Materials, Imperial College, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Laughton, M.A.; Barak, M.; Inman, D., Department of Materials, Imperial College, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Electrochemical science is an interdisciplinary subject, which is unique both in its concepts (the chemical interactions between matter and electrons particularly across interfaces) and general in its applications. Electrochemical reactors use electrical energy to isolate elements from their compounds, as in the electro winning of metals (copper, silver, aluminium) or chlorine, or the production of hydrogen or oxygen by the electrolysis of water. On the other hand, electrochemical power sources-batteries and fuel cells store chemical energy, which can be instantly converted into d.c. electrical energy. The term "battery" refers to an assembly of voltaic primary or secondary cells. Batteries of secondary cells are known also as storage batteries or accumulators. In both primary and secondary batteries, the individual cells consist of a positive and negative electrode immersed in an ion-conducting medium called the electrolyte and generally separated by a porous non-conducting diaphragm, called the separator. © 2003 Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Chlorine compounds; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electrolytes; Secondary batteries; Chemical interactions; Electrochemical power sources; Electrochemical reactor; Electrochemical science; Electrolysis of waters; Ion-conducting medium; Negative electrode; Production of hydrogen; Electric batteries

Authors: Davenport J.S., Howard M.G., Busby R.H., Preston S.B., Chandler M.J.H.
Title: Road Transport
Source title: Electrical Engineer's Reference Book: Sixteenth Edition
Affiliations: Lucas Automotive Ltd, United Kingdom; Kennedy and Donkin Transportation Ltd, United Kingdom; Silent Power Ltd, United Kingdom; GEC Traffic Automation Ltd, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Davenport, J.S., Lucas Automotive Ltd, United Kingdom; Howard, M.G., Kennedy and Donkin Transportation Ltd, United Kingdom; Busby, R.H., Kennedy and Donkin Transportation Ltd, United Kingdom; Preston, S.B., Silent Power Ltd, United Kingdom; Chandler, M.J.H., GEC Traffic Automation Ltd, United Kingdom
Abstract: This chapter discusses road transport or automobiles on the road. Within the framework of the modern automobile, there is an elaborate mechanism to enable energy to be changed readily from one form to another. Although the electrical equipment is only a small proportion of the whole, its satisfactory operation is essential for the normal running of the automobile. The chemical energy in the fuel is changed within the engine to provide the propulsion of the automobile. A small portion of the transformed energy is taken to operate the electrical equipment. In turn, the electrical apparatus may have to convert this energy into heat (demister), light (legal requirements), and sound (horn), or back to mechanical energy (starter motor). In addition, the electrical equipment may be called upon to supply energy when the automobile engine is at rest; so an energy storage system is necessary. An accumulator or storage battery is used to store this energy. © 2003 Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Automobiles; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Engines; Equipment; Roads and streets; Transportation; Chemical energy; Electrical apparatus; Electrical equipment; Energy storage systems; Legal requirements; Mechanical energies; Road transports; Storage battery; Motor transportation

Authors: Higuchi S., Matsuda T.
Title: A high earthquake-proof spread foundation system for energy storage tanks
Source title: WIT Transactions on the Built Environment
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Technical Research Institute of Obayashi Co, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Higuchi, S., Department of Civil Engineering, Technical Research Institute of Obayashi Co, Japan; Matsuda, T., Department of Civil Engineering, Technical Research Institute of Obayashi Co, Japan
Abstract: A high earthquake proof spread foundation for the tank structures named "Seismic action control foundation" was developed. "Seismic action control foundation" consists of a concrete slab and the improved ground under the slab utilizing the deep mixing method. "Seismic action control" effect is theoretically basing on the dynamic soil-structure interaction. In this study, performances of the "Seismic action control foundation" were investigated with numerical analyses. Followings were found fiom the results. (1) Up to 30 % reduction of the base shear of the tank structure is turned out on the "Seismic action control foundation" compared with those of the piled foundation by numerical analyses. (2) It is able to reduce the area of "Seismic action control foundation" up to 50% without decreasing the effect of the seismic input reduction. © 2003 WIT Press.

Authors: Hagart-Alexander C.
Title: Temperature measurement
Source title: Instrumentation Reference Book: Third Edition
Authors with affiliations: Hagart-Alexander, C.
Abstract: This chapter provides an overview of temperature measurement. Temperature is one of the most frequently used process measurements. Almost all chemical processes and reactions are temperature-dependent. Not infrequently in chemical plants, temperature is the only indication of the progress of the process. Where the temperature is critical to the reaction, a considerable loss of the product may result from incorrect temperatures. In some cases, loss of control of temperature can result in catastrophic plant failure with the attendant damage and possible loss of life. Another area where accurate temperature measurement is essential is in the metallurgical industries. There are many other areas of industry where temperature measurement is essential. Such applications include steam raising and electricity generation, plastics manufacture and molding, milk and dairy products, and many other areas of the food industries. Furthermore, temperature is a measure of stored or potential energy in a mass of matter. It is the state of agitation, both lateral and rotational oscillation, of the molecules of the medium. © 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Chemical plants; Metallurgy; Plastics applications; Plastics molding; Potential energy; Temperature measurement; Chemical process; Electricity generation; Food industries; Loss of control; Loss of life; Metallurgical industry; Process measurements; Temperature dependent; Food storage

Authors: Miyamoto H., Tokunaga T.
Title: Prospects of engineering applications of submarine-groundwater-discharge research in Japan
Source title: Land and Marine Hydrogeology
Affiliations: Department of Geosystem Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-Ku, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyamoto, H., Department of Geosystem Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-Ku, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan; Tokunaga, T., Department of Geosystem Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-Ku, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan
Abstract: This chapter discusses the prospects of engineering applications of submarine groundwater discharge (SGD) research in Japan. SGD and chemical fluxes through SGD are subjects of active study in the fields of marine science and hydrology. Although only a few measurements of SGD are made in Japan, the importance of SGD in coastal hydrological activities is well recognized in the country. Slight differences in hydrological conditions affecting SGD might sometimes cause serious problems for large-scale constructions, such as undersea tunnels and energy storage facilities. Understanding of SGD fluxes and their impact on hydrological environments is important for coastal zone management. The chapter reviews recent studies on SGD and its role in hydrological environments. It also reviews some problems and interesting topics of SGD research in Japan from an engineering point of view. © 2003 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Klopstock T., Dimauro S.
Title: Metabolic Myopathies
Source title: Neurological Disorders: Course and Treatment: Second Edition
Affiliations: Department of Neurology, Ludwig-Maximilians University, 81377 Munich, Germany; Department of Neurology, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York 10032, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klopstock, T., Department of Neurology, Ludwig-Maximilians University, 81377 Munich, Germany; Dimauro, S., Department of Neurology, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York 10032, United States
Abstract: This chapter discusses metabolic myopathies. Metabolic myopathies "sensu stricto" are those with defined blocks of metabolic pathways caused by deficient or nonfunctional enzymes. Mitochondrial encephalomyopathies are multisystemic disorders that usually include a metabolic myopathy. Muscle contraction depends on the provision of energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). Carbohydrates are the most important source of energy for brief, intense exercise in anaerobic conditions. The glycogenoses are hereditary disorders caused by enzyme deficiencies in glycogen metabolism or glycolysis. They have been assigned Roman numerals in the order of their discovery but are now also specified by the underlying enzyme defect. Muscle damage results from glycogen storage on the one hand and from energy failure on the other. The clinical manifestation of glycogen storage is fixed, progressive, mostly proximal muscle weakness. Many metabolic myopathies discussed in this chapter and several other conditions, especially exposure to therapeutic or recreational drugs, may lead to rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria. Even otherwise healthy individuals may have myoglobinuria when they subject themselves to unusually strenuous physical exertion for which they have not been adequately trained. Other causes of myoglobinuria include toxic, ischemic, mechanical, or thermal damage to muscle. © 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Endo M., Ahm Kim Y.
Title: Applications of Advanced Carbon Materials to the Lithium Ion Secondary Battery
Source title: Carbon Alloys: Novel Concepts to Develop Carbon Science and Technology
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Shinshu University, 4-17-1 Wakasato, Nagano-shi 380-8553, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Endo, M., Faculty of Engineering, Shinshu University, 4-17-1 Wakasato, Nagano-shi 380-8553, Japan; Ahm Kim, Y., Faculty of Engineering, Shinshu University, 4-17-1 Wakasato, Nagano-shi 380-8553, Japan
Abstract: This chapter describes the correlations between the microstructural parameters and the electrochemical properties of the conventional and novel types of carbon materials for Lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries. The market demand and the trends in the lithium-ion secondary batteries are also discussed. The Li-ion secondary batteries are the best portable energy storage device for the consumer electronics market. Recent developments of the Li-ion secondary batteries have been achieved by the use of selected carbon and graphite materials as anodes. The anode carbons include the graphitizable carbons such as-the milled mesophase pitch-based carbon fibers, and the non-graphitizable carbon such as-the polyparaphenylene-based carbon that are heat-treated at low temperatures. The carbon and graphite materials have a wide variety of microstructure, texture, crystallinity and morphology, depending on their preparation processes and precursor materials, as well as various forms such as powders, fibers and spherules. The performance of the lithium ion secondary batteries depends significantly on the microstructure of the anode materials made from carbon and graphite. © 2003 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Kim C.-J., Jang J.-Y., Kim Y.-H., Kim Y.-T.
Title: Active boost converter a study on the characteristics of power factor correction circuits with input active boost converter
Source title: ICEMS 2003 - Proceedings of the 6th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Halla University, San 66, Heungup, Wonju, Kangwondo, South Korea; Tae-Ha Mechatronics Co., Ltd., 205-3(#23), AnYang7-dong, ManAn-Ku, AnYang, Kyonggi-do, South Korea; Department of Electrical Engineering, Wonju National College, San 2-1, Heungup, Wonju, Kangwondo, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, C.-J., Department of Electrical Engineering, Halla University, San 66, Heungup, Wonju, Kangwondo, South Korea; Jang, J.-Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Halla University, San 66, Heungup, Wonju, Kangwondo, South Korea; Kim, Y.-H., Tae-Ha Mechatronics Co., Ltd., 205-3(#23), AnYang7-dong, ManAn-Ku, AnYang, Kyonggi-do, South Korea; Kim, Y.-T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Wonju National College, San 2-1, Heungup, Wonju, Kangwondo, South Korea
Abstract: Switching power supply is widely used in many industrial fields. Power factor correction (PFC) circuits have tendency to be applied in new power supply designs. The input active power factor correction (APFC) circuits can be implemented using either the two-stage approach or the single-stage approach. The single-stage PFC circuit has advantage to reduce the number of components. However, unlike in the two-stage approach, the dc voltage on the energy storage capacitor in a single-stage PFC circuit is not well regulated. As a result, in universal line application (90 - 265 Vac), the storage capacitor voltage varies with the load and line variation. In this paper, the performances of output voltage regulation and transient response are clarified. The validity of designed boost PFC circuit is confirmed by MATLAB simulation and experimental results. © 2003 International Academic Publishers/World Publishing Corporation.

Title: A comparative Examination of performance for air Force/Nasa Nckel hydrogen packs in LEO cycling
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane IN 47522, United States; Aerospace Corporation, Los Angeles CA 900009, United States; Nasa Glenn, Cleveland OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, H.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane IN 47522, United States; Baer, J.M., Aerospace Corporation, Los Angeles CA 900009, United States; Manzo, M.A., Nasa Glenn, Cleveland OH 44135, United States
Abstract: Since 1987, a total of twenty-nine nickel hydrogen packs of several ampere-hour ratings from four manufacturers have been in LEO cycling at NAVSEA Crane. The manufacturers are Eagle-Picher, Gates, Hughes, and Yardney. The packs are in IPV, CPV, and SPV configurations. The largest number of packs has come from Eagle-Picher, eleven in number. Currently, fourteen packs remain on test. We take this opportunity to attempt to draw some general conclusions regarding pack performance as a function of several variables in LEO cycling, storage prior to cycling, and pack construction.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Manufacture; Naval vessels; Air force; Several variables; Hydrogen

Authors: Bents D.J., Scullin V.J., Chang B.-j., Johnson D.W., Garcia C.P., Jakupca I.J.
Title: Test of hydrogen-oxygen PEM fuel cell stack at NASA Glenn Research Center
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; QSS Group, Inc, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Analex Corporation, Brook Park OHs 44142, United States; Thermo-Mechanical Systems Branch, United States; Scientific Applications Development Branch, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bents, D.J., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States, Thermo-Mechanical Systems Branch, United States; Scullin, V.J., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States, Scientific Applications Development Branch, United States; Chang, B.-j., QSS Group, Inc, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Johnson, D.W., QSS Group, Inc, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Garcia, C.P., QSS Group, Inc, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Jakupca, I.J., Analex Corporation, Brook Park OHs 44142, United States
Abstract: This paper describes performance characterization tests of a 64-cell hydrogen oxygen PEM fuel cell stack at NASA Glenn Research Center in February 2003. The tests were part of NASA's ongoing effort to develop a regenerative fuel cell for aerospace energy storage applications. Purpose of the tests was to verify capability of this stack to operate within a regenerative fuel cell, and to compare performance with earlier test results recorded by the stack developer. Test results obtained include polarization performance of the stack at 50 and 100 psig system pressure, and a steady state endurance run at 100 psig. A maximum power output of 4.8 kWe was observed during polarization runs, and the stack sustained a steady power output of 4.0 kWe during the endurance run. The performance data obtained from these tests compare reasonably close to the stack developer's results although some additional spread between best to worst performing cell voltages was observed. Throughout the tests the stack demonstrated the consistent performance and repeatable behavior required for regenerative fuel cell operation.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Hydrogen; NASA; Oxygen; Polarization; Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC); Regenerative fuel cells; Aerospace energy storage; Consistent performance; Maximum power output; PEM fuel cell stack; Performance characterization; Performance data; Power out put; System pressure; Testing

Authors: Harris J.D., Hepp A.F., Raffaelle R.P., Gennett T., Vander Wal R., Landi B.J., Luo Y., Scherson D.A.
Title: Growth and characterization of multi-walled carbon nanotubes at NASA Glenn Research Center
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: Dept. of Chemistry, Cleveland State University, Cleveland, OH 44115, United States; Thin-Film Technology Group, NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Dept. of Physics, Rochester Institute of Technology, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Dept. of Chemistry, Rochester Institute of Technology, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; National Center for Microgravity Research, NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; NanoPower Research Laboratory, Rochester Institute of Technology, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Dept. of Chemistry, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harris, J.D., Dept. of Chemistry, Cleveland State University, Cleveland, OH 44115, United States, Thin-Film Technology Group, NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Hepp, A.F., Thin-Film Technology Group, NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Raffaelle, R.P., Dept. of Physics, Rochester Institute of Technology, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Gennett, T., Dept. of Chemistry, Rochester Institute of Technology, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Vander Wal, R., National Center for Microgravity Research, NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Landi, B.J., NanoPower Research Laboratory, Rochester Institute of Technology, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Luo, Y., Dept. of Chemistry, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106, United States; Scherson, D.A., Dept. of Chemistry, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106, United States
Abstract: Aligned multi-walled carbon nanotubes were prepared by the injection chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method using an iron-based organometallic compound as the catalyst source and toluene as the solvent. The concentration of the catalyst precursor was found to influence both the growth habit of the nanotubes, as well as the amount of iron in the deposited material. As deposited, the multi-walled carbon nanotubes contained as little as 2.8% iron by weight. The material was characterized by scanning electron microscopy, tunneling electron microscopy, Raman spectroscopy and thermogravimetric analysis. Using a second synthetic method, multi-walled carbon nanotubes were grown directly onto Co-coated stainless steel (SS) metal supports. Coulometric analysis of the cyclic voltammograms obtained for the carbon nanotube coated electrodes yielded lithium ion storage capacities as high as those observed for more conventional carbon materials, providing evidence that all the multi-walled carbon nanotubes within the entire ensemble are electrochemically active.
Index Keywords: Catalysts; Chemical vapor deposition; Coated wire electrodes; Energy conversion; Iron; NASA; Organic solvents; Organometallics; Scanning electron microscopy; Thermogravimetric analysis; Catalyst precursors; Coulometric analysis; Cyclic voltammograms; Deposited materials; Injection chemical vapor deposition; Lithium ion storages; Organometallic compounds; Tunneling electron microscopy; Iron compounds

Authors: He B., Rydstrand M., Martin V., Setterwall F.
Title: Designing paraffin waxes phase change material (PCM) cool storage system for peak shaving in district cooling system
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Energy Processes, Royal Institute of Technology, SE-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: He, B., Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Energy Processes, Royal Institute of Technology, SE-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Rydstrand, M., Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Energy Processes, Royal Institute of Technology, SE-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Martin, V., Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Energy Processes, Royal Institute of Technology, SE-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Setterwall, F., Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Energy Processes, Royal Institute of Technology, SE-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: Improvements of energy efficiency and a reduction of environmental pollution, particularly by CO2, can be achieved in many ways. District cooling contributes to an overall improvement in the efficiency of energy use, as well as to minimize the use and corresponding leakage of ozone-depleting refrigerants. In an absorption district cooling system, combining a PCM storage for peak shaving provides economic advantages. In the present paper, a computer model has been developed to study phase equilibrium and design paraffin waxes cool storage. Based on the previously presented phase equilibrium diagram of the binary system of tetradecane and hexadecane, two polynomial equations of temperature and liquid/solid phase equilibrium composition, and one polynomial equation of the heat of fusion and liquid composition have been derived through curve-fit. The polynomial equations provide a convenient way to obtain the phase change temperature range and storage density, and both are very important thermal characteristics for PCMs storage design and application. One simple system layout for integrating a PCM storage with an absorption chiller, requiring no additional control for charging/discharging the storage is analysed. It is demonstrated that a design storage density corresponds to the paraffin waxes phase change temperature range. This needs to be accounted for in cool storage system design or else cooling capacity loss and unnecessary cost will result. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cooling storage; Phase change materials (PCMs); Phase diagram; Phase equilibrium; Polynomial equation
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Cooling systems; Design; Energy conversion; Energy efficiency; Phase diagrams; Phase equilibria; Polynomials; Design and application; District cooling system; Environmental pollutions; Equilibrium compositions; Phase change temperature; Phase equilibrium diagrams; Polynomial equation; Thermal characteristics; Phase change materials

Authors: Hanamura K., Kumano T., Iida Y.
Title: Electric power generation by super-adiabatic combustion in thermoelectric porous element
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: Research Center for Carbon Recycling and Energy, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152-8552, Japan; Dept. of Environmental and Renewable Energy Systems, Gifu University, 1-1 Yanagido, Gifu 501-1193, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hanamura, K., Research Center for Carbon Recycling and Energy, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152-8552, Japan; Kumano, T., Research Center for Carbon Recycling and Energy, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152-8552, Japan; Iida, Y., Dept. of Environmental and Renewable Energy Systems, Gifu University, 1-1 Yanagido, Gifu 501-1193, Japan
Abstract: A new energy conversion method from combustion heat to electric power has been proposed on the basis of super-adiabatic combustion in a pair of thermoelectric porous elements. A mixture of about 1% methane in air is introduced into the elements; where the flow direction changes regularly. By energy recirculation through the heat storage of the porous elements, the combustion temperature becomes higher than the theoretical flame temperature by a factor of about two. A sharp temperature gradient is automatically established in the elements. The electric power is generated with a total thermal efficiency of 0.2%. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Energy conversion; Heat storage; Methane; Combustion heat; Combustion temperatures; Electric power; Flow direction; Porous elements; Recirculations; Theoretical flame temperature; Thermal efficiency; Combustion

Authors: Zimmerman A.H.
Title: Self-discharge losses in lithium-ion cells
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: Electronics and Photonics Laboratory, The Aerospace Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zimmerman, A.H., Electronics and Photonics Laboratory, The Aerospace Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States
Abstract: The self-discharge losses in several lithium-ion cell designs have been measured by three different methods. The losses are separated into time-dependent and state- of-charge dependent contributions. For most cycling conditions the time-dependent self-discharge losses are dominant, however, after several months of stand on open circuit or float charge the state of charge dependent losses become significant. The self-discharge rate has been found to not increase monotonically with state-of-charge, but to drop somewhat at intermediate states of charge. The implications of these measurements for maintaining balanced cell capacities in batteries and establishing optimum storage voltage levels for batteries are discussed. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Cycling conditions; Dependent contributions; Intermediate state; Lithium-ion cells; Open circuits; Self-discharges; State of charge; Voltage levels; Lithium batteries

Authors: Hirano S., Saitoh T.S.
Title: Performance of supercooled thermal energy storage unit
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba 305-8569, Japan; Graduate School of Environmental Studies, Tohoku Univ, Sendai 980-8579, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hirano, S., National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba 305-8569, Japan; Saitoh, T.S., Graduate School of Environmental Studies, Tohoku Univ, Sendai 980-8579, Japan
Abstract: Performance of the latent heat thermal energy storage unit which uses supercooling was experimentally investigated. Compared with conventional thermal energy storage, supercooled thermal energy storage (Super-TES) stores thermal energy at a lower temperature than the melting point of phase change material (PCM), so that Super-TES reduces heat loss from storage systems. The PCM used in this work is disodium hydrogenphosphate dodecahydrate. The melting point of the PCM is 35.5 °C. The volume of the storage tank is 14 L and the tank has 152 capsules of PCM. The tank is partitioned into two rooms by thermal insulation. The PCM capsule exists in both sides of the partition. After the storage period, the lower room is cooled for initiating crystallization. The result of the experiments shows that the storage unit can control the nucleation of the supercooled PCM. After two-month-period storage, about 60 % of the input energy remained and 10% of the energy was lost during the cooling operation for nucleation. Consequently, the energy efficiency was about 50%. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Energy efficiency; Melting point; Nucleation; Phase change materials; Supercooling; Tanks (containers); Hydrogen phosphates; Input energy; Latent heat thermal energy storage; Lower temperatures; Storage periods; Storage systems; Storage tank; Storage units; Heat storage

Authors: Burke K.A.
Title: Fuel cells for space science applications
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burke, K.A., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: Fuel cell technology has been receiving more attention recently as a possible alternative to the internal combustion engine for our automobile. Improvements in fuel cell designs as well as improvements in lightweight high-pressure gas storage tank technology make fuel cell technology worth a look to see if fuel cells can play a more expanded role in space missions. This study looks at the specific weight density and specific volume density of potential fuel cell systems as an alternative to primary and secondary batteries that have traditionally been used for space missions. This preliminary study indicates that fuel cell systems have the potential for energy densities of >500 W-hr/kg, >500W/kg and >400 W-hr/liter, >200 W/liter. This level of performance makes fuel cells attractive as high-power density, high-energy density sources for space science probes, planetary rovers and other payloads. The power requirements for these space missions are, in general, much lower than the power levels where fuel cells have been used in the past. Adaptation of fuel cells for space science missions will require "down-sizing" the fuel cell stack and making the fuel cell operate without significant amounts of ancillary equipment.
Index Keywords: Astronomy; Energy conversion; Fuel systems; Gas fuel purification; Internal combustion engines; Ancillary equipment; Fuel cell designs; Fuel cell technologies; High power density; High pressure gas; High-energy densities; Power requirement; Space science missions; Fuel cells

Authors: Ming Chen H., Walter T., Chapman P., Lee N.
Title: Recent development of magnetic bearings for flywheel energy storage
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: Foster-Miller Technologies, 431 New Karner Road, Albany, NY 12205-3868, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ming Chen, H., Foster-Miller Technologies, 431 New Karner Road, Albany, NY 12205-3868, United States; Walter, T., Foster-Miller Technologies, 431 New Karner Road, Albany, NY 12205-3868, United States; Chapman, P., Foster-Miller Technologies, 431 New Karner Road, Albany, NY 12205-3868, United States; Lee, N., Foster-Miller Technologies, 431 New Karner Road, Albany, NY 12205-3868, United States
Abstract: Two applications of magnetic bearings to flywheels are presented. In the first, conical active magnetic bearings were developed to replace ball bearings for a terrestrial application. Each conical bearing has three pairs of slanted electromagnetic poles. To control these poles, a distributed feedback control method was designed to take five displacements, four radial and one axial, as input, and command six power amplifiers to generate the pole-magnetizing currents as output. Experimental results indicated a robust control system as analytically predicted. In the second application, a suspension system using repulsivetype radial passive bearings with axially stacked permanent-magnet (PM) ring pairs is being developed for a space-based flywheel system. This system also includes an active zero-power magnetic thrust bearing and a small active radial damper to supplement radial damping. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Flywheels; Poles; Power amplifiers; Thrust bearings; Wheels; Active Magnetic Bearing; Distributed feedback; Electromagnetic poles; Flywheel energy storage; Flywheel systems; Magnetic thrust bearing; Suspension system; Terrestrial application; Magnetic bearings

Authors: Lee E.
Title: Integrated HTS systems for energy conversion in space
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Korea, Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 373-1 Guseong-dong, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 305-701, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, E., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Korea, Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 373-1 Guseong-dong, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 305-701, South Korea
Abstract: We have constructed a superconductor-magnet momentum wheel for micro satellites and propose a micro energy storage and attitude control system for nano/pico satellites using a high-temperature superconductor - magnet bearing system. The HTS systems can perform the dual function of a power/attitude control system using flywheel elements for both power storage and attitude control. The momentum wheel for micro satellites has mass of1.1 kg with an angular momentum capacity of 3.5 J sec. It occupies a volume of 12.7 cm in diameter and 5 cm in height. It operates within the restricted power budget of a micro satellite with a total power supply of 10 watts only. It consumes less than 1 watt for sustenance.The micro HTS flywheel for nano/pico satellites has an angular momentum capacity of 0.083 J·s and stores 2.32 kJat 530 krpm. Its energy storage capacity is approximately45 Wh/kg with an energy density of around 370 kJ/L. The system is ideally suited for low earth orbit energy storage, power generation and attitude control of spacecraft such as nano satellites. © 2003 by Eunjeong Lee. Published by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.

Authors: Sobczyk T.J., Weinreb K., Wegiel T., Sułowicz M., Warzecha A.
Title: Modeling saturation of main magnetic circuit of cage induction motors in presence of eccentricity
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Diagnostics for Electric Machines, Power Electronics and Drives, SDEMPED 2003 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Cracow University of Technology, ul. Warszawska 24, Cracow, 31-155, Poland; Electrotechnical Institute, ul. Pozaryskiego 28, Warsaw, 04-708, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Sobczyk, T.J., Electrotechnical Institute, ul. Pozaryskiego 28, Warsaw, 04-708, Poland; Weinreb, K., Cracow University of Technology, ul. Warszawska 24, Cracow, 31-155, Poland; Wegiel, T., Cracow University of Technology, ul. Warszawska 24, Cracow, 31-155, Poland; Sułowicz, M., Electrotechnical Institute, ul. Pozaryskiego 28, Warsaw, 04-708, Poland; Warzecha, A., Cracow University of Technology, ul. Warszawska 24, Cracow, 31-155, Poland
Abstract: Nowadays, diagnostics and monitoring of rotor eccentricity in induction cage motors is based on Fourier spectrum of stator currents. To predict precisely the current spectrum an adequate mathematical model should be used. In this paper the authors presented an improved model of induction cage motor accounting for saturation of the magnetic circuit due to the main MMF harmonic in presence of eccentricity. The crucial point of this improvement is to determine nonlinear inductances of motor windings under such conditions. In this paper it is done by introducing an equivalent magnetizing current, which determines a state of machine magnetic circuit. It allows to predict qualitatively (by physical considerations) the co-energy function and finally, to create machine equations by Lagrange formalism. In order to find data for a such model, magnetic field distribution has to be round from field model of a machine. In this paper the authors created a model for a real induction motor being tested in the field by authors. Field distribution in magnetic circuit of this machine is found by FEM and basing on it the co-energy is calculated as a function of the equivalent magnetic current and parameters determining eccentricity. Resulting equations with all necessary nonlinear functions for this real motor are presented. © 2003 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Induction motors; Lagrangian functions; Magnetic circuits; Magnetic fields; Mathematical model; Monitoring; Nonlinear equations; Rotors; Saturation magnetization; Stators

Authors: Kanchubotla S.A., Diong B.M.
Title: Analysis, simulation and testing of a novel 4-element current-source resonant inverter
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Southeastern Symposium on System Theory
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX  79968, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kanchubotla, S.A., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX  79968, United States; Diong, B.M., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX  79968, United States
Abstract: High-frequency resonant power converters are an attractive choice for high power density applications. Only resonant converters with 2 energy-storage elements have been studied and used for applications. However, some of the drawbacks of this class of converters (including poor load regulation, discontinuous mode operation and poor transient response) can be overcome by the judicious augmentation of the resonant circuit. This paper presents the results of a study performed on a novel 4-element current-source resonant inverter circuit. These include analytical results on its steady-state characteristics (including input impedance, resonant frequency, input-output transfer function, individual component voltage and current stresses, and efficiency). In addition, samples of analytically derived design charts, simulation results and experimental results are shown. They indicate that this resonant inverter has certain advantages over present ones. © 2003 IEEE.

Abstract: This paper focuses on the influence of memory size limitation on the dynamic translation of Java methods into native code. Specifically, we address the issue of managing a "code cache", a small memory space allocated for storing the dynamically generated native code. We show that by adopting a smart bypassing strategy we can enhance the effectiveness of a code cache based system significantly. © 2003 IEEE.

Abstract: Based on the research of photovoltaic array output feature and lead-acid storage battery input feature, the paper presents an optimal control theory combining photovoltaic array maximum power point tracking (MPPT) technique and lead-acid storage battery optimal charging method. Title: Starch world markets and isolation of starch

Abstract: Starch is deposited in different storage organs of numerous plants in the green environment and functions as an essential energy reservoir. Thus, starch, together with other storage compounds, enables plants to start a new cycle in plant reproduction. Several cereal grains as well as some tubers and roots are cultivated for being utilized as substrates for starch production. © 2003 by Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Abstract: The paper deals with the problem of the development of a pulse generator on the basis of impact-excited generator with the inductive energy storage to supply powerful electrophysical installations. A new charging circuit of the inductive energy storage with thyristor keys allowed removing a fast-acting electromechanical commutator which disconnects the circuit of the energy storage in the moment of the energy-load transfer. The research conducted on the model of the impact-excited generator done in asynchronous engine MTF-211 dimensions showed that in XH/XyDeh cyrillic = 2 parameters the stored energy is increased 1.5 times. © 2003 7th Korea-Russia Intl Sym on Science.
